column1: Better Buy: Intel Corporation vs. NVIDIA;3/16/2017;"Intel(NASDAQ: INTC) andNVIDIA(NASDAQ: NVDA) are titans of the same semiconductor industry
column2: born a generation apart. As in all human endeavors
column3: the only   constant in business is change
column4: and Intel and NVIDIA find   themselves today at different stages of their corporate life   cycles.Thanks to coming adoption of technologies such as self-driving   cars and artificial-intelligence (AI) software
column5: NVIDIA has seen   demand for its graphics chips move from a niche into the   mainstream. On the other hand
column6: Intel roared to global dominance   during the rise of PCs and mainframe servers
column7: but it has   struggled to tap into more recent growth markets such as mobile   computing
column8: deep learning
column9: and the like.So which is the better stock for you to buy today: Intel or   NVIDIA? Let's examine three different aspects for NVIDIA and   Intel to determine which companies' shares appear more attractive   today.makeArticleAd();Financial fortitudeThose same life-cycle differences reveal themselves in   assessing the financial strength of NVIDIA and Intel. Look at   these four important metrics of liquidity and solvency for both   companies.CompanyCash and InvestmentsDebtCash From OperationsCurrent RatioNVIDIA$6.8 billion$2.8 billion$1.7 billion4.7Intel$14.9 billion$25.2 billion$21.8 billion1.7Data sources: NVIDA and Intel investor relations; Yahoo!   Finance.NVIDIA easily beats Intel in terms of near-term liquidity --   as evidenced by its current ratio -- and in terms of net debt
column10: which is just a fancy accounting term for cash and equivalents   minus debt. That being said
column11: Intel's cash flow-generation   capabilities are staggering. Though $18.4 billion of its debt   will mature in 2022 or later
column12: Intel could easily erase the   majority of its leverage in a single year
column13: even after subtracting   the $9.6 billion it spent on capital expenditures in 2016.Intel is also an example of a company that uses debt
column14: or a   leveraged capital structure
column15: as a source of competitive   advantage. It's one of the few semiconductor companies that also   owns its chip fabrication plants; NVIDIA outsources its fab to a   consortium of partners includingTaiwan Semiconductor
column16: Samsung
column17: and more. Operating large fixed assets such as   semiconductor manufacturing plants requires plenty of capital
column18: which explains Intel's use of ample leverage. Either way
column19: both   companies are in fine financial shape
column20: given their respective   strategies
column21: so let's call this one a tie and move on.Winner: Tie.Image source: Getty Images.Durable competitive advantagesNVIDIA and Intel each enjoy meaningful competitive advantages   in their respective areas of the global semiconductor market.Sources estimate Intel controls 87% of the PC CPU market and   95% the server CPU market
column22: although the exact numbers aren't as   important as knowing that Intel dominates the global PC and data   center microprocessor markets
column23: and for a predictable reason:   Intel's longtime performance advantage over the competition --   namely
column24: Advanced Micro Devices(NASDAQ: AMD)  -- has allowed the company to charge higher   prices per unit for its chips.Intel plows an aggressive portion of its profits back into its   research and development
column25: which has
column26: in turn
column27: allowed it to   maintain the performance advantages of its chips. Barring   execution risks
column28: which have been a concern fromtime to time
column29: this long-standing trend has served as a virtuous cycle that   has allowed Intel to dominate its core markets and consistently   produce above-average profits for its shareholders.The dollar values involved help flesh this dynamic out a bit   more. In the past three years
column30: AMD's revenue has totaled $4.2   billion in 2016
column31: $3.9 billion in 2015
column32: and $5.5 billion in   2014. In contrast
column33: Intel's research-and-development budgetalonehas totaled $12.7 billion
column34: $12.1 billion
column35: and $11.5 billion over   the same period. This kind of structural advantage is   incredibly difficult to overcome.NVIDIA's competitive advantages are more technological than   structural at the moment. Because of its long-standing place as   the creator graphics computing
column36: on which it still focuses
column37: NVIDIA's chips have generally been the best of breed in each of   the graphics processing applications its products serve. The   company pressed that advantage with last year's debut of its   Pascal architecture
column38: around which it launched a number of new   chips.Better still
column39: NVIDIA has used its advantage to help   consolidate early leads in core growth markets such as AI   computing platforms and driverless cars. In recent years
column40: NVIDIA   has become the GPU supplier to the AI efforts atMicrosoft
column41: Facebook
column42: Amazon.com
column43: Alphabet
column44: andApple
column45: to name a few. Much has also been made of NVIDIA's potential in   self-driving cars
column46: where it supplies the graphics chips that   power the autonomous-vehicle efforts ofFord
column47: Tesla
column48: Volkswagen
column49: Honda
column50: and many more. Both of these industries figure to offer   substantial growth opportunities over the coming decade
column51: and   NVIDIA's place as the go-to supplier to support these emerging   technologies speaks to their compelling value proposition.Winner: NVIDIA.ValuationThe way the market is pricing Intel and NVIDIA shares should   come as little surprise
column52: given what we just learned about the   outlook for their businesses. Here's a snapshot of three of the   most commonly used valuation metrics for Intel and NVIDIA.CompanyP/EForward P/EEV/EBITDANVIDIA38.329.523.6Intel16.912.37.8Data source: Yahoo! Finance.Both companies also pay dividends: Intel shares currently   yield 2.9%; NVIDIA
column53: a mere 0.5%.As for which stock appears the more attractively valued
column54: I   think both companies appear reasonably valued
column55: given their   respective growth outlooks. The multiple trends fueling NVIDIA's   growth should support its earnings growth for arguably a decade   or more
column56: so its sky-high valuation shouldn't be a deterrent for   investors with a similarly long time horizon.As more of a mature company
column57: Intel will have its investment   outlook driven by its ability to grow its EPS and return excess   capital to shareholders. Its fantastic economics should allow it   to do so
column58: but it's hard to get excited about a company that   analysts see growing sales just 0.9% this year and 2% in   2018. So in terms of which company is more appropriately   valued
column59: I think both companies trade near prices that seem   fair.Winner: Tie.And the winner is... NVIDIA by a noseBoth companies present interesting value propositions to   investors today. Intel offers a mix of profitability and income   at a fairly discounted price
column60: which could prove compelling to   more conservative investors. However
column61: many of NVIDIA's growth   markets are in their early stages
column62: which makes it the more   attractive stock to own over the long term.10 stocks we like better than IntelWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column64: the newsletter they have run for   over a decade

column1: Adobe Systems Incorporated (ADBE) Stock Soars on Earnings Beat;3/16/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsI argued coming intoAdobe Systems Incorporated(NASDAQ:ADBE) earnings that there wasno reason to bet against Adobe stock. Adobe earnings had come in ahead of consensus for four straight quarters. Adobe stock had quadrupled in less than five years. As the old saw goes
column3: ""The trend is your friend."" Clearly
column4: that trend was in favor of ADBE.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockFor a fifth straight quarter
column5: Adobe earnings came in ahead of analyst estimates. Non-GAAP earnings of 94 cents per share beat the Street by seven cents. Nearly 22% revenue growth was two points ahead of consensus.ADBE stock is up roughly 4% in after-hours trading
column6: after yet another quarter that seems to support the long-term bull case for Adobe stock.Adobe Earnings: The Fifth Straight BeatAdobe's fiscal first-quarter earnings were even more impressive than past beats. On average
column7: Adobe earnings had come in about 4% above consensus the past few quarters; in Q1 FY17
column8: Adobe beat by a solid 8%.7 Dividend Stocks With Yields That Grow Like WeedsBeyond the numbers
column9: the news was good - and broad-based. Digital Media Annualized Recurring Revenue (ARR)
column10: a key measure of the company's success in ""cloud
column11: hit $4.25 billion
column12: up nearly 7% simply in the first three months. Marketing Cloud revenue of $477 million was up over 26% year-over-year
column13: actually accelerating from prior-year growth of 21%. Non-GAAP operating income increased 42%
column14: and non-GAAP net income rose 40%.As CFO Mark Garrett pointed out in the Q1 release
column15: ""Adobe achieved record revenue
column16: profit and cash flow"" in the quarter.All told
column17: the Adobe earnings report was a blowout by any measure.What Earnings Mean for Adobe StockHeading into the quarter
column18: it seemed likely that ARR
column19: in particular
column20: would be a focus of investors. That figure is moving to a larger and larger share of overall revenue: now about 70% on a trailing twelve-month basis. The ability to continue torrid growth even on a base that size - and without simply taking revenue away from legacy product sales
column21: likeMicrosoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT) does with Office - seems likely to support Adobe stock in trading on Friday.The second area of focus is in the Marketing Cloud business. Adobe obviously has little competition for Acrobat or Photoshop. In marketing
column22: however
column23: the competitive landscape is very different. Adobe is going up against giants such assalesforce.com
column24: inc.(NYSE:CRM)
column25: Oracle Corporation(NYSE:ORCL) andInternational Business Machines Corp.(NYSE:IBM).Clearly
column26: Adobe is winning. The nearly 27% revenue growth in that business seems likely to be a major facet of the narrative coming out of Adobe earnings. The marketing business is the one segment where Adobe has true upside: in most of the Creative Media business
column27: for instance
column28: the company's dominance is such that eventually its growth rate will slow to that of the market as a whole.Marketing
column29: however
column30: presents a multi-billion-dollar opportunity with literally worldwide potential. And the fact that Adobe is not only surviving
column31: but thriving while fighting some of the largest tech companies in the world has to boost the case for Adobe stock.Bottom Line on ADBE StockAll told
column32: the Adobe earnings surprise should be no surprise. This is a company firing on all cylinders
column33: with substantial market opportunities in front of it. I'd be surprised to see the market shrug off the Q1 beat as something already incorporated into Adobe's stock price. The size of the earnings beat
column34: the strength in cloud
column35: and the performance in the Marketing Cloud segment all point to a stock that should rise in trading on Friday.And Q1 supports the bull case here. Adobe stock isn't cheap - but it's hardly expensive. FY18 analyst estimates likely will be boosted moderately after the strong Q1 FY17 performance.Why Snap Inc (SNAP) Stock Could Soon RallyAs they near $5
column36: ADBE stock trades at about 23 times FY18 earnings plus cash. In a market where many lesser companies are receiving similar multiples
column37: that hardly seems excessive. And it seems to leave more room for Adobe stock to run.Again
column38: ""the trend is your friend."" And Adobe earnings in Q1 show that the trend should stay positive for some time to come.As of this writing
column39: Vince Martin did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace7 IPOs That Were Done the Right Way6 Tech Stocks to Buy for the VR BoomThe postAdobe Systems Incorporated (ADBE) Stock Soars on Earnings Beatappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column2: beating both the Zacks Consensus earnings and revenues estimates.  (To learn more about Oracle's Q3 Earnings

column4: which is dominated by Amazon.comAMZN
column5: while International Business MachinesIBM
column6: MicrosoftMSFTand GoogleGOOGLare becoming notable competitors.Oracle on Wednesday reported cloud software revenues of $1.1 billion
column7: up 85% compared to the same period a year ago and total revenues were $9.3 billion
column8: up 3%. In dollars
column9: the cloud business grew by almost $500 million year-over-year while the total revenues grew $260 million.The software company's new cloud-computing service has been offsetting the revenue decline in the company's long-time software-licensing operations. Revenues from new software licenses saw a $266 million decline
column10: a 16% fall from a year earlier.""Both our SaaS and PaaS business are doing great
column11: I'm even more excited about our second generation IaaS business
column12: said Oracle co-founder and Chief Technology Officer
column13: Larry Ellison. ""Our new Gen2 IaaS is both faster and lower cost than Amazon Web Services.""There is no doubt that Oracle has been investing money to ensure their products and services are in the best shape to compete against powerhouses like Amazon. The operating expenses in cloud software as a service and platform as a service went up by 25% while $4.5 billion were put into research and development for the reported quarter.Despite the impressive growth in its cloud software sector
column14: Oracle is still nowhere near Amazon
column15: who dominates the cloud spaceowning 40% of the cloud market share. However
column16: in February
column17: Oracle altered the terms of its licensing policy to double the cost of running its software in Amazon's cloud environment
column18: reported byMarket Realist.With this move
column19: Oracle took away one of Amazon's cloud service's main selling points
column20: which is the cheaper route to the cloud and presented its own cloud platform as the cheaper option.Oracle reported earnings of $0.63 per share and revenues of $9.27 billion. The company's Board of Directors declared a quarterly cash dividend of $0.19 per share of outstanding common stock
column21: up 27% from the current quarterly dividend of $0.15.Oracle expects the fourth quarter of 2017 to be another strong quarter. The cloud software revenue
column22: including SaaS/PaaS and IaaS
column23: with software license and software support is expected to grow 1-3%.Oracle is currently a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold) with a Style Score ""A"" in Momentum.More Stock News: 8 Companies Verge on Apple-Like   RunDid you miss Apple's 9X stock explosion after they launched their iPhone in 2007? column1: Is ORCL A Top Tech Stock?;3/16/2017;"makeZacksArticleAd();Oracle(ORCL) is in the news today following some strong earnings.  The stock is making fresh 52 week highs and is up around 7%.  Let's take a look at the report
column2: what analysts are saying and if this stock should get some consideration in your own portfolio.The ReportORCL reports revenue in three segments
column3: Software and Cloud
column4: Hardware and finally Services.  Of the three groups
column5: only Software and Cloud came in ahead of expectations but that was enough to drive total revenue to $9.27B when the Street was looking for $9.26B.The company reported EPS of $0.63 when the Zacks Consensus was calling for $0.57.  That translates into a positive earnings surprise of 10.5% with a beat of $0.06.Follow Brian Bolan on Twitter: @BBolan1DividendThe company noted that they are raising their dividend to $0.19 from $0.15.  That is a 27% increase and not something you want to see from a growth company.  In fact
column6: the stock has an ""F"" for its Growth Style Score.  Value
column7: on the other hand
column8: is not terrible.  The stock is trading at 18x forward earnings which are right around the market's historical multiple.Oracle Corporation Dividend Yield (TTM)Oracle Corporation Dividend Yield (TTM)|Oracle Corporation QuoteGuidanceThe company guided Wall Street to $0.78-$0.82 for next quarter when the expectation was for $0.78.  Revenue is expected to increase 1%-2% on a constant currency basis.  Currency is expected to be a significant headwind that could account for revenues to be impacted by 2% and EPS to be adjusted by around $0.02.AnalystsJMP Securities liked the quarter and moved the stock to market perform from market underperform.  JP Morgan increased their price target to $51 from $42.  Cowen raised their target to $48 from $46 and noted that there is good visibility.Zacks RankRight now
column9: ORCL is a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold)
column10: but that could change as the estimate changes roll into our system.  The Zacks Rank looks at all the earnings estimate revisions and looks for the strongest moves.  Check back in a day or two to see if ORCL can move up on Zacks Rank thanks to this quarter.ORCL In A Tech Portfolio?The quarter was a good one and we are seeing higher price targets and at least one upgrade.  That said
column11: the dividend increase makes me think that this stock wants to be more of a value play that what most investors think of when they search for 'top tech stocks' or something similar.  Yes
column12: ORCL has a spot in tech as a benchmark name
column13: but I want something more from the tech stocks that I put in my portfolio.This would be a name you would put cash into as a placeholder instead of just having cash.  Over the last year
column14: this stock has traded in a range between $39 and $42.  With a breakout over $46 we could be setting up for a solid drift higher into the next report
column15: but I would be surprised to see it reach $50 anytime soon.Oracle Corporation Price

column1: Is Qualcomm
column2: Inc. (QCOM) Stock Stuck In a Bear Trap?;3/16/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsQualcomm
column4: Inc.(NASDAQ:QCOM) is really a victim of its own amazing success. Since the mid-1980s
column5: the company has been able to develop cutting-edge mobile technologies that have defined the industry. The result is that the profits have been standout. Yet this has caught the ire of customers and even governments. The claim: QCOM is really a monopolist that is willing to leverage its unfair power.makeArticleAd();Source:Karlis Dambrans via FlickrThis has happened to other tech titans through history
column6: of course.Just some of the examples includeMicrosoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT)
column7: AT&T Inc.(NYSE:T) andInternational Business Machines Corp.(NYSE:IBM). The problem is that - even when they resolved their legal disputes and antitrust actions - the companies suffered a prolonged period of stagnation and sub-par investor returns.Unfortunately
column8: I think the same could be the case with Qualcomm stock. Already the returns have been lackluster. For the last five years
column9: QCOM stock has posted a miserable 11% loss.QCOM Stock's WoesThen again
column10: the company must deal with a host of massive legal actions. While one was settled
column11: which included a $975 million payment to the Chinese antitrust authorities
column12: there are currently active suits in the U.S.
column13: Europe and Korea
column14: which recently filed a claim for $873 million. Then of course
column15: there is the $1 billion suit fromApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL).And yes
column16: the core legal claim is that the practices of QCOM are inherently anti-competitive and unfair. After all
column17: when the company charges a royalty
column18: it is not a fixed amount per unit
column19: but instead a percentage of the price of the device.7 Blue-Chip Stocks Holding You BackAccording toAAPL CEO Tim Cook:""They were insisting on charging royalties for technologies that they had nothing to do with. And so we were in a situation where the more we innovated with unique features like touch ID or advanced displays or cameras
column20: just to name a few
column21: the more money Qualcomm would collect for no reason
column22: and the more expensive it would be for us to innovate. So
column23: it's somewhat like buying a sofa and you charge somebody a different price depending upon the price of the house that it goes into
column24: just from our point of view
column25: this doesn't make sense and we don't believe it will pass muster in the courts.""Interestingly enough
column26: the potential monetary damages are almost trivial. QCOM has a cash hoard of $10.8 billion and a market cap of $86 billion.The real issue then? Well
column27: for Qualcomm stock
column28: it's the threat to the business model. According to the mostrecent 10-K
column29: the licensing business generated a juicy $6.5 billion in pre-tax earnings last year
column30: compared to $2.2 billion for the rest of the other operations.In other words
column31: if the licensing arrangements are deemed to be unfair and anti-competitive
column32: then the ramifications could be far-reaching. It would strike a dagger straight into the cash machine. So given this
column33: is it any wonder that QCOM stock has been such a terrible investment?Of course not.Now it's true that there are still some bullish factors at work with Qualcomm stock. The company has made some key strategic investments with its chip technologies
column34: which should open up profitable opportunities with desktops and data centers. To make this happen
column35: QCOM has a major partnership with MSFT to use Snapdragon 835 processors for the Windows 10 platform.There are also some other compelling growth opportunities
column36: such as with market for autos and the Internet of Things. In fact
column37: the company has made a huge wager on this opportunity with the proposed $47 billion acquisition ofNXP Semiconductors NV(NASDAQ:NXPI)
column38: which is the world's fifth-largest non-memory semiconductor supplier and it has a large chunk of key markets for in-vehicle systems
column39: secure identification
column40: near field communication technology and digital networking.Does the Snap Inc (SNAP) Debacle Signal Doom for These Unicorns?Oh
column41: and Qualcomm stock is trading a very reasonable valuation. Note that the forward price-to-earnings ratio is only 12X.Bottom Line on Qualcomm StockBut this may not matter much. A large-cap tech company can languish for quite a while
column42: especially when there remains uncertainty. And again
column43: with QCOM stock
column44: the problem is that its business model is under relentless attack. In the meantime
column45: the growth rate for smartphones has decelerated over years as markets have become saturated.So in light of all this
column46: Qualcomm stock really looks more like a bear trap
column47: not an interesting value opportunity.Tom Taulli runs the InvestorPlace blogIPO Playbookand is the author of various books
column48: includingTaxes 2017: Saving A Bundle.Follow him on Twitter at@ttaulli. As of this writing
column49: he did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace10 Safe Dividend Stocks to Own During the Next Market Crash7 Dividend Stocks With Yields That Grow Like WeedsThe postIs Qualcomm
column50: Inc. (QCOM) Stock Stuck In a Bear Trap?appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Service Provider Router Revenues Thrive Worldwide in 2016;3/15/2017;"According to a recent report by Dell'Oro
column2: the service provider router and carrier Ethernet switch industry has witnessed a successful 2016 primarily attributed to strong demand from cloud service providers. This happened despite the fact that the traditional telecom operators trimmed network spending at least for the near-term.Routers are telecom infrastructure devices used to deliver data packets from one network to another. These are located at gateways
column3: the places where two or more networks connect. In 2016
column4: the aggregate market size of service provider router and carrier Ethernet switch was more than $13 billion.Phenomenal demand for 100 Gbps Ethernet ports was the main driving force for this record breaking revenue achievement. China played a major roll as cloud service providers of this country were busy installing backbone and data center interconnect networks. Several industry analysts have estimated that the global router market will reach around $72 -- $73 billion by 2022.Massive growth in the usage of mobile devices has heightened transportation of data traffic substantially. In order to manage this burgeoning demand for photo
column5: video and online data services
column6: telecom operators are required to install more routers to ensure smooth transfer of data packets.In the U.S.
column7: majority of demand for service provider router and carrier Ethernet switch are from large cloud service operators like Amazon Web Services of Amazon.com Inc.AMZN
column8: Microsoft Azure of Microsoft Corp.MSFTand Alphabet Inc.GOOGL. All three stocks currently carry a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold). You can seethe complete list of today's Zacks #1 Rank (Strong Buy)   stocks hereLeading manufacturers of service provider router and carrier Ethernet switch are Juniper Networks Inc.JNPR

column4: HPE and More;3/15/2017;"Alphabet'sGOOGLCloud Next announcements were huge

column6: or Hewlett Packard EnterpriseHPEbuying NimbleNMBLor the CIA's alleged hacking.Here are the top stories from last week:Google Cloud NextAt its Cloud Next conference in California last week
column7: Google demonstrated that it finally has a big growth engine that isn't driven by the search services it is identified with. The cloud strategy has been unfolding over the past few years for both Microsoft and Google. But the companies have taken different approaches based on their existing strengths and weaknesses. In Google's case

column1: Why Adobe Systems Incorporated (ADBE) Stock Will Keep on Truckin’;3/15/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsIt was only a few years ago that investors were wondering whetherAdobe Systems Incorporated(NASDAQ:ADBE) was in a long-term decline. Photoshop and Flash seemed likely to be victims of the shift away from desktop usage. Adobe earnings plunged in FY2013 and declined again in fiscal 2014. ADBE stock looked like dead money.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockAdobe stock looks very different now
column3: however. ADBE has almost quadrupled in the last five years.Photoshop and the company's Document segment overall have flattened out
column4: as predicted. But success in Adobe's Marketing Cloud and Digital Media has led Adobe earnings and ADBE stock steadily higher.There's no reason to expect a change in ADBE stock coming out of the first quarter release
column5: due Thursday. Expectations are high
column6: to be sure. But Adobe earnings have beaten those expectations for four straight quarters. Q1 results seem likely to drive a fifth straight beat.Adobe Earnings: Expect GrowthAgain
column7: expectations are high coming into Adobe earnings for the first quarter. Wall Street consensus suggests a 19% increase in revenue and further expansion in margins. Earnings-per-share are expected to rise 30%
column8: to $0.87 from $0.66.The 7 Best IPOs to Buy for the Rest of 2017But if that seems like a tall order
column9: bear in mind that both are relatively in line with ADBE earnings and sales guidance after Q4. (Analysts are expecting a bit higher revenue growth
column10: with guidance suggesting an ~18% increase.) And of late
column11: Adobe has had no problem beating its guidance - and Street estimates.Both FY15 earnings above $2 and FY16 earnings above $3 (both non-GAAP) exceeded the company's long-term targets laid out after fiscal 2013. In FY16
column12: Adobe earnings beat consensus - handily - in each of the last four quarters
column13: helping drive further gains in ADBE stock.While the absolute growth rates sound high
column14: estimates actually suggest a deceleration from fiscal 2016 results. Revenue increased 22% last year
column15: with EPS rising nearly 50%. With continued cloud adoption boosting both sales and margins
column16: there's little reason to see much of a slowdown in fiscal 2017. That should lead to Q1 numbers looking solid - and likely further gains for Adobe stock.Potential Catalysts for ADBE StockHeadline numbers aside
column17: the Adobe earnings release will have more information on the company's cloud transition. What has been impressive about Adobe is that cloud adoption has driven higher overall sales.Unlike
column18: say
column19: Microsoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT)
column20: where cloud versions of Office arejust cannibalizing product sales
column21: ADBE's overall top line is growing. The company's ARR (annualized recurring revenue)
column22: a direct measure of strength in cloud services
column23: will be a closely watched metric in Q1.One point of concern on that front might be questions about whether ARR is going to hit a ceiling soon. That figure already represented nearly two-thirds of Adobe revenue in fiscal 2016. If investors worry about potential diminishing returns in that initiative
column24: ADBE stock could struggle coming out of earnings.In addition
column25: Marketing Cloud results will be closely watched
column26: as that's the one area where Adobe isn't a dominant leader. Its Photoshop and Acrobat businesses have little in the way of competition
column27: but cloud-based marketing is a tougher field.Adobe is going against major competition:Salesforce.com
column28: Inc.(NYSE:CRM)
column29: Oracle Corporation(NYSE:ORCL) andInternational Business Machines Corp.(NYSE:IBM)
column30: among others. If Adobe shows that it's taking further market share in that business
column31: there's really nothing to stop further growth - and further gains for ADBE stock.Finally
column32: operating expenses may be closely watched as well. While margins and earnings have improved steadily
column33: some bears on Adobe stock have pointed to rising spend as a possible problem once revenue growth slows down. For now
column34: those investments in sales and G&A are bearing fruit. But Adobe will need to show disciplined growth.How to Play Adobe Stock Into EarningsI'm not sure ADBE represents an ideal earnings trade. Expectations are high: Cowen & Co. upgraded Adobe stock to a Buy
column35: with a $140 price target just this past Friday. The market might shrug off a modest earnings beat
column36: given the performance over the last two years
column37: in particular.Target Corporation (TGT) Stock Will Keep Sinking Without This ChangeThere's no reason to bet against ADBE stock
column38: however. The nature of the cloud model makes earnings relatively predictable (as a large portion of revenue is under contract). That would seem to leave little room for an earnings miss.From a longer-term perspective
column39: Adobe stock still has more room to run. Valuation isn't that high
column40: with the stock trading around 31x FY17 guidance plus its nearly $4 per share in cash. Against ~25% EPS growth
column41: that valuation is far from ridiculous. A dividend probably is on the way soon (Adobe already is buying back stock).The Marketing Cloud business
column42: in particular
column43: can cement the bull case. A business with 30%+ operating margins and three dominant franchises is always going to get a bid from investors. And Q1 earnings seem likely to only strengthen that case.As of this writing
column44: Vince Martin did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace10 Monthly Dividend Stocks to Buy to Pay the Bills10 Dangerous Dividend Stocks to Dump NowThe postWhy Adobe Systems Incorporated (ADBE) Stock Will Keep on Truckin'appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Better Buy: Shopify Inc. (U.S.) vs. Veeva Systems Inc.;3/15/2017;"One of the most important terms for forward-looking investors to understand is SaaS. This four-letter term stands for Software-as-a-Service. And companies that have mastered SaaS are becomingverylucrative investments.Perhaps the easiest way to envision this is to remember what it was like -- and still is for some -- to installMicrosoft'sOffice Suite onto their computer. And really
column2: 15 years ago
column3: who could afford to go without the bare minimum of Microsoft Word on their computer?makeArticleAd();The installation process -- using a CD -- was time consuming
column4: and only applied to one device at a time. But now
column5: Microsoft Office 365 allows paying members to access the software via the cloud from any connected device. Another way of thinking of it is on-demand software that you subscribe for.Image source: Getty Images.But there are lots of other examples of such technology
column6: and they are gaining popularity at a breakneck pace.Veeva Systems(NYSE: VEEV) provides cloud solutions that help drug companies do everything from manage their sales force to keep track of FDA clinical tests for the drug approval process.Shopify(NYSE: SHOP)
column7: on the other hand
column8: is an SaaS company that provides a one-stop shop for any entrepreneur or medium-sized business to establish an e-commerce presence.Both stocks have been very successful as of late
column9: but which is the better buy today? That's impossible to answer with 100% certainty
column10: but there are different lenses through which we can examine the question. Here are three of the most relevant and how Shopify and Veeva compare.Sustainable competitive advantagesI wish I could go back in time and explain to my beginning-investor self just how important sustainable competitive advantages are. Often referred to as a ""moat"" by professional investors
column11: this represents the special something that keeps customers coming back month after month
column12: while keeping competitors at bay for decades.The moat for Shopify and Veeva can be described in three short words: high switching costs.Let's put ourselves in the shoes of a typical Veeva customer for a second. You're a medium-sized biotechnology firm. You use Veeva CRM to manage your sales force -- which includes everything from a customer database
column13: to secured email communications.You also use Veeva Vault to capture electronic data that's crucial for your FDA approval
column14: and to make sure that you're abiding by all of the relevant government regulations. It took you weeks to train all of your employees to use and communicate on Veeva's platform. But now that they are familiar with the platform
column15: your company's efficiency has skyrocketed.How much of a headache would it be -- both from an operational and financial standpoint -- to switch to another provider for all of these mission-critical functions? As long as Veeva doesn't start jacking up prices to the point where they are prohibitively expensive
column16: you'd much rather focus your time and energy on your core business mission.The same can be said for Shopify. The company has three different tiers of subscriptions to help you start and maintain your e-commerce presence. Once you reach the highest level
column17: Shopify can help you not only manage your website
column18: but it also offers payment processing and shipping services.Those are big deals
column19: and if your company grew up with Shopify as the platform of choice
column20: you would be equally loathe to switch to a different provider after years of familiarity
column21: data
column22: and training using its products.Both of these companies have very strong moats
column23: but in the end
column24: this is a draw.Winner = TieFinancial fortitudeOne important thing to note is that financial fortitude is especially important for young SaaS companies. It takes enormous up-front investments to set up the infrastructure necessary to become successful in the field. If a company doesn't have a reliable cash stash to act as a safety net
column25: the smallest bit of chaos could wipe the balance sheet clean.Here's how these two companies stack up in terms of financial fortitude.CompanyCashDebtNet IncomeFree Cash FlowShopify$392 million$0($35 million)($10 million)Veeva$346 million$0$54 million$59 millionData source: Yahoo! FinanceI cannot stress enough how important it is that neither Shopify nor Veeva has any long-term debt to speak of. That makes them infinitely healthy.It's worth mentioning that because these companies operate using a subscription-model
column26: there's often a lag between large contracts being signed
column27: and revenue actually being collected.It's also important to point out that while Shopify has yet to be profitable
column28: it should have no problem running its business. With a loss of only $10 million in cash flow over the past year
column29: there's more than enough cash on hand for the business to aggressively reinvest in growth opportunities.But if we're forced to choose a winner here
column30: Veeva has the edge by a nose. Being able to produce free cash flow is a definite bonus
column31: and one that we shouldn't ignore.Winner = VeevaValuationFinally
column32: we have valuation. While this isn't an exact science
column33: there are some straightforward metrics we can consult to give us an idea of how expensive each stock is.CompanyP/EP/FCFP/SShopifyN/AN/A15Veeva6410912Data source: Yahoo! Finance
column34: E*Trade. P/E represents figures from non-GAAP earnings.Because of the aforementioned cash flow and income situation at Shopify
column35: this is a relatively easy category to pick a winner in. Even on the one metric where we do have some apples-to-apples comparison
column36: Shopify appears to be trading at a 25% premium.Though Veeva isn't cheap by any stretch of the imagination
column37: it's profitable -- and thus
column38: easier to measure its relative value.Winner = VeevaThe winner is...So there you have it: Veeva would appear to be the better bet today. The company's profitability gives it a slight edge over Shopify. But to be honest
column39: I think these are two of the most exciting mid-cap stocks to invest in today.Right now
column40: Shopify is purposely spending alittlemore than it brings in via sales -- so analysts just have to accept that it won't be profitable for a while. But in the process
column41: it is capturing massive market share. Combine that market share with high switching costs and all the company would have to do to be profitable is turn off its spending spigot a little bit and income would boom.That's why I ownbothof these stocks in my personal portfolio
column42: and they combine to make up over 5% of my real-life holdings. I think you'd do your future self a huge favor to take a look at both for your own retirement portfolio.10 stocks we like better than Veeva SystemsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column43: it can pay to listen. After all
column44: the newsletter they have run for over a decade
column45: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column46: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Veeva Systems wasn't one of them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

column1: Oracle (ORCL) Earnings: Will Cloud Momentum Finally Move the Stock?;3/15/2017;"How much of Oracle’s (ORCL) total revenue will be made up by its Cloud business? column1: Battle of Dividends: Apple
column2: Inc. vs Microsoft;3/14/2017;"Even tech stocks can sometimes be soliddividend   stocksfor income investors. And two of thebest dividend   stocksin the tech sector are undoubtedlyApple(NASDAQ: AAPL) andMicrosoft(NASDAQ: MSFT) . But which of these two dividend-paying tech   juggernauts is the better bet for investors looking for   income?Comparing these two dividend stocks is particularly timely
column3: given thatApple stockhas soared about 21% in the past three months while Microsoft has   lagged with a 2.4% gain during the same period. After Apple's   recent rise in its stock price
column4: is Microsoft looking more   attractive?makeArticleAd();MSFTdata byYChartsMicrosoftCompanyDividend YieldPayout Ratio3-Year Compound Average Dividend Growth             RateEPS Growth in Most Recent QuarterMicrosoft2.4%69.5%11.7%6.6%Data source: Reuters. Table by author.Microsoft is a well-rounded dividend stock. With a dividend   yield of 2.4%
column5: the software giant easily beats Apple's 1.6%   dividend yield. Going further
column6: the yield is meaningfully higher   than the 2% average dividend yield of stocks in the S&P   500.However
column7: to achieve this dividend yield
column8: Microsoft needs to   pay out a higher portion of its earnings than Apple does. In the   trailing 12 months
column9: Microsoft has paid out 69.5% of its earnings   in dividends. Notably
column10: however
column11: Microsoft's dividend payments as   a percentage of its free cash flow are just 42%. Paying out only   42% of its annual free cash flow in dividends
column12: Microsoft's   dividend is easily sustainable.Another area where Microsoft shines as a dividend stock is in   the company's underlying earnings growth. Microsoft has recently   witnessed a strong return to earnings growth
column13: with EPS up 6.6% in   the company's most recent quarter. This earnings growth should   help Microsoft maintain its 11.7% average annual dividend   increase of the past three years.AppleCompanyDividend YieldPayout Ratio3-Year Compound Average Dividend Growth             RateEPS Growth in Most Recent QuarterApple1.6%27%9%2.3%Data source: Reuters. Table by author.Apple's weaknesses as a dividend stock compared with Microsoft   are immediately apparent. Its 1.6% dividend yield is well below   Microsoft's and even below the average 2% dividend yield of   stocks in the S&P 500. Further
column14: Apple's earnings growth   recently is paltry. In the company's most recent quarter
column15: EPS   rose just 2.3% year over year.But Apple stands out when it comes to its payout ratio. With a   payout ratio of just 27%
column16: Apple has substantial room for further   dividend increases in the future. And Apple's dividend payments   as a percentage of its free cash flow are even lower
column17: at just   23%.Image source: Getty Images.So while Apple's three-year average annualized dividend growth   of 9% is lower than Microsoft's 11.7% average annualized growth   during the same period
column18: Apple's dividend looks as if it will   probably grow faster in the coming years.Overall
column19: it seems that Apple's rising stock price recently has   suppressed the company's dividend yield to a low enough level to   make Microsoft look like the better dividend stock today -- a   different conclusion from in myNovember 2015 comparison
column20: when Apple's dividend yield was higher and its payout ratio was   even lower. However
column21: while Microsoft may be the better dividend   stock today
column22: Apple still looks like an attractive bet for income   investors thanks to the growth potential evident from the   company's very low payout ratio.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column23: it can pay to listen. After all
column24: the newsletter they have run for   over a decade
column25: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column26: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Apple wasn't one of them!   That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better   buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6
column27: 2017Teresa Kersten is an employee of LinkedIn and is a member     of The Motley Fool's board of directors. LinkedIn is owned by     Microsoft.Daniel Sparksowns shares of Apple. The Motley Fool owns shares of and     recommends Apple. The Motley Fool has the following options:     long January 2018 $90 calls on Apple and short January 2018 $95     calls on Apple. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: 6 Tech Stocks to Buy for the VR Boom;3/14/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsBuzzwords are one of those ""things"" that excite technology enthusiasts. So trends like ""virtual reality"" and ""augmented reality"" may entice investors to pay any price multiple.makeArticleAd();Source:Maurizio Pesce via Flickr (Modified)AR
column3: or augmented reality
column4: superimposes computer-generated input on top of the real world.Alphabet Inc's(NASDAQ:GOOGL
column5: NASDAQ:GOOG) ill-fated Google Glass is a good example. VR
column6: or virtual reality
column7: is an artificial environment where the user's actions partly determine what happens in that environment.3 Pharmacy Stocks at Risk Due to Skyrocketing Drug CostsThe reality is clearly more muted for this sector. The promises for this market are high
column8: but the rate of adoption for the technology will not happen as fast as everyone thinks. With that warning

column31: through the PlayStation console

column1: QQQ Is Once Again A Top Growth ETF;3/14/2017;"The world of exchange-traded funds is filled with heavy weight indexes geared towards a variety of stock selection criteria.  The venerableSPDR S&P 500 ETF(SPY) is the largest and most heavily traded of the top ten funds by asset size.  SPY is known for its meaningful diversification
column2: tremendous liquidity
column3: and low costs.  It’s the benchmark by which nearly every stock-focused strategy is ultimately compared against.Having a benchmark is important because it allows investors the opportunity to compare similar investment styles to determine if a fund is meeting their expectations.  It can easily identify consistent trends that are worthy of greater interest or evasion.One such outlier among the largest U.S. stock ETFs is the pattern of outperformance demonstrated by thePowerShares QQQ(QQQ) over the last decade.  Per Yahoo Finance data
column4: this ETF has outperformed SPY in 8 of the last 10 years.  The only two negative divergences being 2008 and 2016.makeArticleAd();What Is QQQ?One of the primary reasons for this consistent strength is the unique nature of the QQQ portfolio.  This ETF is constructed using a market-capitalization weighted asset allocation.  This method gives the largest share of assets to the biggest stocks within the index.Its security selection criteria includes the 100 largest non-financial domestic and international stocks trading on the Nasdaq Stock Market.  The index is rebalanced quarterly and constituents are re-evaluated annually to ensure they make the cut.Nasdaq is widely regarded as a landing spot for technology stocks
column5: which is why QQQ has nearly 58% of its exposure in this single sector.  Consumer discretionary and health care stocks round out the top three groups
column7: respectively.It’s worth noting that Apple Inc (AAPL)
column8: Microsoft Corp (MSFT)
column9: and Amazon Inc (AMZN) represent over one quarter of the total exposure within QQQ.  That means these three mega-cap stocks are going to have an outsized impact on the fund’s total return and have been top performers over their tenure.At present QQQ has $46.5 billion in assets under management
column10: making it the seventh largest ETF listed on U.S. exchanges.  It also charges a relatively modest expense ratio of 0.20% annually for investors to access this strategy.Historical Performance And RisksQQQ has recorded an impressive 10-year annualized gain of +12.60% versus +7.51% in SPY through 2/28/17
column11: per fund company data.  Despite its relative weakness in 2016
column12: this fund is off to an impressive start in the first quarter of 2017 as well.  The technology-heavy index fund carries a 5% lead over the broader benchmark and continues to demonstrate momentum divergence signals at each new all-time high.This strength has become second-nature to the those who prefer the more aggressive
column13: growth-oriented style that QQQ conjures.  However
column14: there are always risks to consider after a prolonged period of robust returns as well.The dominance of the QQQ portfolio has been its concentration in high-flying technology and consumer discretionary stocks
column15: while eschewing value sectors like finance.  There may ultimately come a time when those stocks falter (like the 2000 tech crash) and QQQ falls by the wayside relative to the broader market and more defensive ETF alternatives.Furthermore
column16: future outperformance in QQQ will need to be driven by either earnings growth of the underlying holdings or continued expansion of valuation statistics.  The latter leaves open the possibility of sharper corrections as fundamentals become stretched.The Bottom LineLike many passive ETFs that shine bright in the spotlight
column17: QQQ’s strengths during the current bull market may ultimately be a weakness during the next cycle.  That is why it is critically important to evaluate the underlying holdings and their weighting within any ETF you are considering for your portfolio.  Security selection and position sizing are the two most important factors in long-term returns."

column1: Intel Buys Mobileye to Boost Presence in Autonomous Cars;3/14/2017;"Intel CorporationINTCrecently announced that it is buying Israel-based Mobileye
column2: an autonomous vehicle technology provider
column3: for a whopping $15.3 billion in an all cash deal.Notably
column4: Intel is paying $63.54 for each Mobileye share. This represents a 33% premium to the Mobileye's closing price of $47.00 as of Mar 10.In response to the announcement
column5: shares of Mobileye appreciated 28.24% on the bourses. However
column6: the news failed to excite Intel shareholders and the stock was down 2.09% at the close.We note that shares of Intel have underperformed the ZacksSemiconductor - Generalindustry over the last one year. While the industry gained 39.5%
column7: shares of the technology major returned a modest 11.7% during the same time period.The underperformance can be due to growing competition in the semiconductor market.Intel's dominance in the chip market has come under threat due to increasing usage of ARM-based chips by the likes of MicrosoftMSFTin recent times. Moreover
column8: sluggish PC demand continues to hurt its top line.However
column9: we believe that the latest deal will strengthen Intel's competitive position in the autonomous car technology market
column10: currently dominated by the likes of NVIDIANVDAand QualcommQCOM. This will help the stock rebound in the rest of 2017.What Does this Mean for Intel?Per a Business Insider report
column11: an estimated 10 million self-driving cars will hit the pitch by 2020. An IDC report states that the burgeoning Internet of Things (IoT) space is projected to be worth $1.7 trillion by 2020 with 30 billion connected ""things"". Notably
column12: Intel is fast gaining traction in the self-driving systems space through the acquisition of startups in the segment. With the buyout
column13: Intel will now have access to Mobileye's  technologies related to cameras
column14: in-car networking
column15: sensor-chips
column16: roadway mapping
column17: cloud software
column18: machine learning and data management.We also note that Mobileye isthecompany that Tesla Motors has worked with before to fulfill its autonomous vehicle dream. However
column19: Tesla parted ways after the death of a driver trying to operate one of its Tesla Model S using Mobileye's autonomous driving technology.Hopefully
column20: Mobileye has learnt its lessons after the crash as Intel is banking upon it to turn its fortunes around.However
column21: competition is intensifying in the space. Some notable collaborations include Ford and Baidu's partnership to invest $150 million in Veldyne Lidar
column22: a maker of light sensor technology. Alphabet has also partnered with Fiat Chrysler per which Google will incorporate its self-driving technology into 100 Chrysler Pacifica minivans to be used as test vehicles.Separately
column23: Google and Ford Motor have partnered to lead a coalition of companies that will push for federal approval of autonomous cars in the near future. Uber
column24: Lyft and Volvo are other members of this coalition.Intel Corporation Revenue (TTM)Intel Corporation Revenue (TTM)|Intel Corporation QuoteZacks RankAt present
column25: Intel has a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold). You can seethe complete list of today's Zacks #1 (Strong Buy) Rank stocks here.Zacks' 2017 IPO Watch ListBefore looking into the stocks mentioned above

column1: CenturyLink Has Its Head in the Clouds;3/14/2017;"If there's one thing that's certain in the world of   technology
column2: it's change. And so it goes for telecommunications   giantCenturyLink(NYSE: CTL)
column3: which continues to foster its strategic revenue   streams to offset declines in its legacy businesses.Of course
column4: CenturyLink also has its hands full ensuring itsimpending acquisitionofLevel 3 Communications(NYSE: LVLT) closes as planned later this year. But in the   meantime
column5: one intriguing strategic growth opportunity for   CenturyLink lies with its budding status as an IT services and   enterprise cloud solutions provider.To that end
column6: CenturyLink recently launched its new Cloud   Application Manager
column7: a ""cloud-agnostic management platform""   designed to simplify enterprise customers' deployment of   workloads
column8: managed services
column9: and third-party cloud resources   across hybrid hosting environments.makeArticleAd();CenturyLink's Cloud Application manager helps automate and     manage multiple clouds from a single interface. Image source:     CenturyLinkOne cloud platform to rule them all...According to David Shacochis
column10: CenturyLink VP of Hybrid IT   product management:Many of our customers and partners struggle with the     business challenge of determining the best execution venue for     their business applications. We designed Cloud Application     Manager to give our customers a wide variety of infrastructure     options across diverse public and private cloud environments.     Cloud Application Manager helps companies avoid vendor lock-in
column11: automate application deployments
column12: scale workloads across     disparate hosting environments
column13: and optimize their costs over     time.Better yet
column14: CenturyLink is offering customers the   flexibility to use Cloud Application Manager through either a   self-service model with their own IT staff
column15: or as one actively   managed by CenturyLink's team. Cloud Application Manager also   comes in either a cloud-based software-as-a-service (SaaS)   version
column16: or in a ""data center version"" with a virtual appliance   that runs on-premises in the customer's data center.If all of this sounds familiar
column17: it's likely because Cloud   Application Manager leveraged CenturyLink's $20 millionacquisition of multi-cloud platform   specialistElasticBox this past June. At the time
column18: CenturyLink CTO   Aamir Hussain noted their acquiree's compelling platform   supported over a dozen different cloud providers
column19: includingAmazonWeb Services
column20: IBM's SoftLayer
column21: MicrosoftAzure
column22: andVMware
column23: as well as Google Compute Engine
column24: OpenStack
column25: and of course   CenturyLink Cloud.As Hussain further elaborated
column26: ElasticBox's platform freed   ""businesses to focus on issues that are central to their   organization rather than spending time and resources managing   multiple clouds.""Better days ahead?So what does this mean for CenturyLink's business? For   perspective
column27: during CenturyLink's quarterly conference call last   month
column28: management explained that lower-than-expected managed   hosting and IT services revenue was one culprit for the company   arriving near the low end of its fourth-quarter 2016   guidance.To be fair
column29: the bulk of the blame still sat with slower growth   in both CenturyLink's consumer broadband and consumer video   revenue. But those obviously troublesome segments come with their   own challenges. And any relative success CenturyLink can garner   through current and forthcoming products like Cloud Application   Manager could serve to not only drive incremental revenue   themselves
column30: but also afford the company a perfect segue into   CenturyLink's other complementary IT consulting and managed   services solutions.Prior to Cloud Application Manager's formal launch
column31: for   example
column32: CenturyLink had already launched other new and expanded   solutions in recent months spanning managed security services
column33: Managed SAP and HANA
column34: enterprise cloud and managed big data
column35: and   Big Data-as-a-Service products. CenturyLink CEO Glen Post   insisted they ""have all been very well received by industry   analysts and are beginning to show good traction with our   customers.""In the end
column36: then
column37: I think investors would do well to keep a   close eye on any similar signs of early traction for   CenturyLink's Cloud Application Manager when the company next   reports quarterly results in early May. If it proves successful
column38: it could mean better days ahead for patient CenturyLink   shareholders.10 stocks we like better than CenturyLinkWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Intel Corp. and Qualcomm
column2: Inc.: On a Collision Course;3/14/2017;"For years
column3: there has been very little intersection betweenIntel's(NASDAQ: INTC) core businesses andQualcomm's(NASDAQ: QCOM) . Intel's revenue today comes primarily from   sales of personal-computer processors
column4: processors for enterprise   and cloud servers
column5: and networking applications.Qualcomm
column6: on the other hand
column7: makes most of its profit from   licensing wireless technologies and patents
column8: and generates most   of its revenue by selling chips that go into smartphones and
column9: to   a lesser extent
column10: other mobile devices like tablets.Image source: Qualcomm.makeArticleAd();For years
column11: it has been widely known that Qualcomm was working   on processors designed to attack Intel's data-center dominance;   first commercial shipments are expected to begin in the second   half of 2017. And for years
column12: Intel has been going on about trying   to attack Qualcomm's wireless-chip business -- achieving its   first real success last year when it captured cellular-modem   share from Qualcomm inApple's(NASDAQ: AAPL) iPhone 7-series smartphones.In other words
column13: these two chip giants are on a collision   course. Let's look at what each side could lose
column14: what each side   stands to gain
column15: and what this coming battle might mean for   investors in either company.Intel deals its major -- but potentially only -- blowIn the past
column16: Intel had told investors that it expected to   compete broadly across the mobile-processor market. Indeed
column17: the   company said it was developing a whole stack of chips
column18: designed   to span everything from low-end smartphones to what the company   referred to as ""hero devices.""In addition to those chips
column19: Intel had been pursuing   stand-alone cellular-modem efforts for quite some time
column20: though   with little success until recently.Investors might be aware that Intel canceled its pipeline of   mobile-processor products and substantially reduced its   investment levels there. (Intel said at its most recent investor   meeting that from 2015 to 2017
column21: its spending in mobile will go   down about 55%.)So
column22: Intel is
column23: by and large
column24: neutralized as a threat to   Qualcomm's mobile-processor business.However
column25: the company won a large portion of the cellular-modem   spots inside Apple's iPhone 7 series of smartphones
column26: which led to   a reasonable bump in revenue for Intel and a corresponding   decrement to Qualcomm's revenues.Qualcomm sharpening its knivesThough Intel's mobile efforts ultimately translated into   Qualcomm losing some business at Apple
column27: Qualcomm's ambitions are   much more significant.Qualcomm announced that it will be working with software giantMicrosoft(NASDAQ: MSFT) to bring personal computers running Windows 10 on   Qualcomm's Snapdragon 835 processors to market during the second   half of 2017 -- directly attacking Intel's largest business.To make matters worse for Intel (and perhaps sweeten the deal   for Qualcomm)
column28: Qualcomm seems committed to developing data-center   processors for now. Significant share gains on Qualcomm's part   (and corresponding share losses on Intel's part) -- should they   occur -- aren't likely to happen overnight.However
column29: Qualcomm's upcoming Centriq 2400 chips havealready gotten Microsoft's blessingfor its internal use
column30: which lends credibility to the notion that   major data-center customers may be willing -- and
column31: frankly
column32: eager   -- to work with alternative suppliers rather than Intel.The upside and downside for each companyFor Intel
column33: the only upside I see in this contest is its   potential to gain some additional cellular-modem share from   Qualcomm at Apple. The opportunity likely isn't that big from the   standpoint of annual revenue
column34: and that revenue would likely come   at a much lower margin than Intel's corporate average. Right now
column35: Intel's ability to hurt Qualcomm in its core wireless-chip   business seems limited.The upside for Qualcomm
column36: on the other hand
column37: seems greater. It   can take share from Intel in the latter company's core business   of personal-computer chips
column38: as well as its data-center business
column39: starting from essentially zero share.Intel certainly has significant resources with which to defend   itself
column40: so it's probably not prudent for investors in either   company to model in substantial market-share shifts to Qualcomm   anytime soon. But
column41: in terms of which company has more to gain and   which has more to lose: The answers come up Qualcomm and Intel
column42: respectively.10 stocks we like better than QualcommWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column43: it can pay to listen. After all
column44: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column46: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Qualcomm wasn't one of     them! column1: How Intel Corporation's Execution Issues Have Helped Qualcomm
column2: Inc.;3/13/2017;"It's no secret that wireless chip giantQualcomm(NASDAQ: QCOM) is making all sorts of noise about its efforts to   become a major player in the market for data center processors.   Not only has the company made public its plans to push into this   market
column3: but the chipmaker recently announced that it is working   closely with software giantMicrosoft(NASDAQ: MSFT) to ""accelerate next generation cloud services on   its 10 nanometer Qualcomm Centriq 2400 platform"" and that ""this   collaboration will span multiple future generations of hardware
column4: software and system.""You'll notice that Qualcomm loves to highlight the fact that   its Centriq 2400 is manufactured on a 10-nanometer technology.   This is intentional
column5: as the market leader that Qualcomm is trying   to compete with --Intel(NASDAQ: INTC) -- won't be shipping server processors based on   its own 10-nanometer technology anytime soon.Image source: Intel.makeArticleAd();Now
column6: Intel will argue that its 14-nanometer technology is   roughly equivalent in terms of apples-to-apples chip area to the   10-nanometer chip manufacturing technology that Qualcomm is using   for its chips (though Intel admits that the foundry 10-nanometer   technologies are ahead of its own 14-nanometer technologies in   this respect).That's a reasonable argument
column7: but here's the uncomfortable   implication that comes from that: Qualcomm's upcoming Centriq   2400 processors will still be built on a denser manufacturing   technology than Intel's upcoming Skylake-based server processors   will.It's clear that Intel's execution problems with respect to   both product development as well as manufacturing technology have   helped Qualcomm. Let me explain why.Intel's fighting with the wrong chipsHad Intel's manufacturing and product development roadmap not   gotten off track
column8: it would have launched the Skylake server parts   in the fall of 2016 and would possibly be preparing its first   10-nanometer server processors for launch in the second half of   2017.In that case -- if Intel's claims that its 10-nanometer   technology is significantly denser than competing 10-nanometer   technologies are accurate -- Intel would have been time-to-market   with Qualcomm's Centriq 2400 server processor with its own   10-nanometer server processor family.This would have meant that Intel would have a   higher-performing
column9: more power efficient family of products with   which to fend off the potential threat that Qualcomm poses to its   lucrative data center business.No 10-nanometer for a while for IntelIt is unlikely that Intel will bring to market server   processors based on its 10-nanometer technology in 2018
column10: at least   based on a leaked road map from Dell that's beencirculating around the Web.So
column11: if we assume that the first 10-nanometer Intel server   processors arrive in the first half of 2019
column12: then it's very   likely that Qualcomm will have moved past the 10-nanometer   Centriq 2400 and will compete with such a part using foundry   7-nanometer technology.Since the foundry 7-nanometer technologies are likely to be   like Intel's 10-nanometer technology in terms of transistor   density
column13: it's unlikely that Intel will be able to claim a   substantial manufacturing technology density lead when it comes   to data center chips.Conversely
column14: Qualcomm will be able to market having the   ""world's first"" 7-nanometer server chips.The first step is admitting you've got a     problemIt's bad enough that Intel's execution problems have allowed a   relative newcomer to the data center chip market to start   bringing to market chips using denser technologies than Intel's   use. What makes it worse
column15: though
column16: is that Intel management simply   refuses to publicly acknowledge that theremightbe a problem with its execution that needs to be addressed.Indeed
column17: the companystilltells investors that it has athree year leadin terms of the density of the manufacturing technologies that it   brings to market!As long as Intel remains convinced that it has a ""three year   lead"" in terms of chip area over its competitors
column18: despite the   serious execution problems
column19: schedule slips
column20: and trail of   cancelled products left by virtually all of its business units
column21: then it's unlikely that the company is going to take the actions   necessary to correct whatever organizational flaws that led to   this situation in the first place.The first step is admitting you have a problem
column22: and when it   comes to manufacturing technology
column23: Intel simply isn't ready to do   that yet.10 stocks we like better than IntelWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column24: it can pay to listen. After all
column25: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column27: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Intel wasn't one of them!     That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better     buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

column1: One Put
column2: One Call Option To Know About for Microsoft;3/13/2017;"Consistently
column3: one of the more popular stocks people enter into theirstock options watchlistat Stock Options Channel is Microsoft Corporation (Symbol: MSFT). So this week we highlight one interesting put contract
column4: and one interesting call contract
column5: from the April expiration for MSFT. The put contract our YieldBoost algorithm identified as particularly interesting
column6: is at the $62 strike
column7: which has a bid at the time of this writing of 70 cents. Collecting that bid as the premium represents a 1.1% return against the $62 commitment
column8: or a 9% annualized rate of return (at Stock Options Channel we call this theYieldBoost).Selling a put does not give an investor access to MSFT's upside potential the way owning shares would
column9: because the put seller only ends up owning shares in the scenario where the contract is exercised. So unless Microsoft Corporation sees its shares decline 4.3% and the contract is exercised (resulting in a cost basis of $61.30 per share before broker commissions
column10: subtracting the 70 cents from $62)
column11: the only upside to the put seller is from collecting that premium for the 9% annualized rate of return.makeArticleAd();Interestingly
column12: that annualized 9% figure actually exceeds the 2.4% annualized dividend paid by Microsoft Corporation by 6.6%
column13: based on the current share price of $64.76. And yet
column14: if an investor was to buy the stock at the going market price in order to collect the dividend
column15: there is greater downside because the stock would have to lose 4.28% to reach the $62 strike price.Always important when discussing dividends is the fact that
column16: in general
column17: dividend amounts are not always predictable and tend to follow the ups and downs of profitability at each company. In the case of Microsoft Corporation
column18: looking at the dividend history chart for MSFT below can help in judging whether the most recent dividend is likely to continue
column19: and in turn whether it is a reasonable expectation to expect a 2.4% annualized dividend yield.Turning to the other side of the option chain
column20: we highlight one call contract of particular interest for the April expiration
column21: for shareholders of Microsoft Corporation (Symbol: MSFT) looking to boost their income beyond the stock's 2.4% annualized dividend yield. Selling the covered call at the $65.50 strike and collecting the premium based on the $1.35 bid
column22: annualizes to an additional 16.5% rate of return against the current stock price (this is what we at Stock Options Channel refer to as theYieldBoost)
column23: for a total of 18.9% annualized rate in the scenario where the stock is not called away. Any upside above $65.50 would be lost if the stock rises there and is called away
column24: but MSFT shares would have to climb 1.1% from current levels for that to occur
column25: meaning that in the scenario where the stock is called
column26: the shareholder has earned a 3.2% return from this trading level
column27: in addition to any dividends collected before the stock was called.The chart below shows the trailing twelve month trading history for Microsoft Corporation
column28: highlighting in green where the $62 strike is located relative to that history
column29: and highlighting the $65.50 strike in red:The chart above
column30: and the stock's historical volatility
column31: can be a helpful guide in combination with fundamental analysis to judge whether selling the April put or call options highlighted in this article deliver a rate of return that represents good reward for the risks. We calculate the trailing twelve month volatility for Microsoft Corporation (considering the last 251 trading dayMSFT historical stock pricesusing closing values
column32: as well as today's price of $64.76) to be 19%.In mid-afternoon trading on Monday
column33: the put volume among S&P 500 components was 685
column34: 332 contracts
column35: with call volume at 685
column37: for a put:call ratio of 0.73 so far for the day
column38: which is above normal compared to the long-term median put:call ratio of .65. In other words
column39: if we look at the number of call buyers and then use the long-term median to project the number of put buyers we'd expect to see
column40: we're actually seeing more put buyers than expected out there inoptions tradingso far today.Find out which 15 call and put options traders are talking about today.Top YieldBoost MSFT Calls »"

column22: but instead of ''shares'' investors are actually buying and selling ''units''. These ''units'' can be traded back and forth just like stocks
column23: but can also be created or destroyed to accommodate investor demand. Each week we monitor the week-over-week change in shares outstanding data
column24: to keep a lookout for those ETFs experiencing notable inflows (many new units created) or outflows (many old units destroyed). Creation of new units will mean the underlying holdings of the ETF need to be purchased
column25: while destruction of units involves selling underlying holdings
column26: so large flows can also impact the individual components held within ETFs.Click here to find out which 9 other ETFs had notable inflows »"

column1: Can NVIDIA Regain Its Mojo?;3/13/2017;"It seems somewhat disingenuous referring to a stock that has rallied roughly 530% over the last five years as having ""lost its mojo.""However
column2: the fact remains that shares of graphics chip leaderNVIDIA(NASDAQ: NVDA) have indeed fallen roughly 18% from their 52-week high in early February.makeArticleAd();NVDAdata byYCharts.So
column3: how should investors think about this newfound bearishness in NVIDIA shares? Does the sell-off in its stock represent a paradigm shift in investor sentiment toward the company
column4: or does it create an attractive potential entry point? Let's explore this topic in greater detail.NVIDIA stock: What goes up must come down?The only major news to break since NVIDIA's stock peaked -- which occurred on February 7th -- was the company's release of its full-year and fourth-quarter results for its fiscal year 2017
column5: which took place on February 9th. As a quick point of clarification
column6: NVIDIA runs its fiscal year one full year ahead of the calendar year
column7: for some odd reason.At any rate
column8: NVIDIA actually released earnings that exceeded analyst estimates in terms of sales and profits.If anything
column9: it seems safe to say that some investors have been simply taking profits on their NVIDIA investments
column10: a strategy that seems sensible for short-term investors concerned about NVDIIA's admittedly rich valuation. Moreover
column11: while it enjoys many well-defined positives
column12: there is one potential storm forming on the horizon that could sap some of the wind from NVIDIA's sails.Long-time graphics laggardAdvanced Micro Devices(NASDAQ: AMD) plans to launch its Vega chip series later this year
column13: a move that some analysts believe could allow AMD to steal significant market GPU market share from NVIDIA. Though we don't know any of the specifics regarding AMD's Vega chips yet
column14: the hope is that they will serve as a cheaper alternative to NVIDIA's GTX chip series
column15: while not sacrificing much in the way of performance. If that proves to be the case
column16: NVIDIA could be forced to lower the prices of corresponding chipsets. Of course
column17: worrying about this is putting the cart before the horse to a certain extent
column18: but it bears noting as something that could inhibit NVIDIA's growth. And given NVIDIA'ssky-high valuation
column19: that could be enough to compel investors sitting on large paper gains to sell.Image source: NVIDIA.NVIDIA long-term business outlook remains favorableIn as much as NVIDIA has indeed ""lost its mojo
column20: it's important to remember that NVIDIA's multiyear investment thesis appearsas strong as ever. As we saw in its earnings release
column21: the main drivers underpinning NVIDIA's growth today are high-end gaming
column22: artificial intelligence (AI) software
column23: and self-driving cars.eSports still don't receive a lot of coverage from the mainstream media
column24: but the craze's momentum is undeniable. eSport's global audience was estimated to reach 256 million viewers in 2016
column25: according to one industry researcher. Large events regularly enjoy sponsorship from blue-chip brands likeCoca-Cola
column26: Nissan
column27: and more
column28: which has led to a dramatic increase in purse sizes for some of the genre's most popular events. This
column29: in turn
column30: has helped increase the awareness of the pastime to many casual fans
column31: particularly in Asia
column32: where the sport is most popular. The same researcher believes total revenue related to eSports will reach $1.1 billion by 2019
column33: up from $463 million in 2016. The rush of money and interest into the sport should help continue to create demand for NVIDIA's best-of-breed graphics processing chips
column34: which rose 44% last year.Better still
column35: major trends like AI software and driverless cars remain in their early stages. Last year
column36: NVIDIA saw an unprecedented surge in demand for its GPUs to power an impressive host of applications. NVIDIA's GPUs are the chip of choice to power the various AI projects at tech giants such asMicrosoft
column37: Alphabet
column38: Facebook
column39: the National Cancer Institute
column40: the U.S. Department of Energy
column41: and many others. Turning to self-driving cars
column42: NVIDIA has also partnered with an impressive array of major automakers
column43: though this technology figures to more meaningfully contribute to its growth early next decade.Not to belabor the point
column44: but hopefully it's clear now that NVIDIA has far from lost its mojo. True
column45: the company's stock prices has fallen from its recent all-time highs
column46: but it easily remains in positive territory over the last 12 months
column47: and for good reason. NVIDIA is one of the best-positioned companies to profit from several of the largest continuing trends in technology.10 stocks we like better than NvidiaWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column48: it can pay to listen. After all
column49: the newsletter they have run for over a decade
column50: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column51: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now...and Nvidia wasn't one of them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6
column52: 2017.Suzanne Frey
column53: an executive at Alphabet
column54: is a member of The Motley Fool's board of directors. Teresa Kersten is an employee of LinkedIn and is a member of The Motley Fool's board of directors. LinkedIn is owned by Microsoft.Andrew Tonnerhas no position in any stocks mentioned. The Motley Fool owns shares of and recommends Alphabet (A and C shares)
