column56: and Nvidia. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: Heres How I Invest My Own Retirement Cash;3/13/2017;"By Brett OwensIt's a question I get a lot
column2: both from members of myContrarian Income Reportservice and folks who drop by ourContrarianOutlookwebsite:How do you invest your own nest egg?I'll answer it in just a moment.makeAd('4'
column4: 'mktsnews'
column5: 'vanguard'
column7: '');I was reminded of this question again last week
column8: when I was   looking at the returns of theVanguard Dividend Appreciation ETF (VIG)--and thinking about how dead simple it would be to beat the   fund's return over the long haul.All it would take is the slightest bit of research.Big on Hype
column9: Short on PerformanceVIG is one of the best cases I've seen of an investment taking   an inherent advantage and getting nothing out of it.The fund tracks the NASDAQ US Dividend Achievers Select Index
column10: which includes 184 companies that have raised their payouts   annually for at least 10 years. For that reason
column11: it gets a lot of   airtime from the pundits
column12: who regularly peg it as a proxy for   dividend growers in general.And if you've read my columns
column13: you know I'm a big fan ofdividend-growth stocks.The reason: they consistently rack up some of the market's   biggest gains.What I consider the leading study on the subject
column14: by research   firm Ned Davis & Associates
column15: proves it. After sifting through   43 years' worth of data
column16: from January 1972 through December 2014
column17: Davis's researchers found that dividend growers topped all other   types of stocks.It wasn't even close: with a 10.1% average annual return
column18: they   blew away steady payers (7.1%) and non-payers (2.6%).So VIG should easily beat the S&P 500
column19: then
column20: right?Wrong.Stretch it over any timeframe: one year
column21: three years
column22: five   years
column23: 10 years and since VIG's inception in 2006
column24: and at best   your return would havejust barelysqueaked past the market's.Dividend-Growth Edge Goes AWOLThat's disappointing
column25: given VIG's built-in edge.Now let's go one step further and pick the five fastest   dividend growers among VIG's top 10 current holdings (without   even getting into P/E ratios
column26: earnings history
column27: revenue growth   and the like) over the past decade.Those five stocks areCVS Health (CVS)
column28: Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA)
column29: Microsoft (MSFT)
column30: PepsiCo (PEP)andMedtronic (MDT).A quick backtest shows that all but one (Medtronic) have   outperformed VIG:Active Investing Wins AgainHolding these five would have handed you a 152.3% total   return
column31: compared to 110.9% for VIG
column32: as their relentless dividend   growth (ranging from 150.8% for PepsiCo to a massive 733.3% for   CVS) squeezed their share prices higher.And that's just the result of a fairly ""dumb"" dividend-growth   strategy. Now let's see what happens when we add just a little   more refinement.Which brings me to...Where My Retirement Cash Is Going NowRight now
column33: I'm putting 100% of my 401(k) contributions into   VIG's cousin
column34: theVanguard Dividend Growth Fund (VDIGX).That's because I have to choose from a set list of funds
column35: but at   least one of them is VDIGX
column36: which is a proven winner.According to the prospectus
column37: VDIGX focuses on ""high-quality   companies that have prospects for long-term total returns as a   result of their ability to grow earnings and their willingness to   increase dividends over time.""Manager Donald J. Kilbride also considers factors like   valuation and future dividend-growth potential. That's a much   more focused approach than VIG's.Kilbride's stewardship comes at a cost
column38: however: the fund's   expense ratio is 0.33%
column39: more than three times higher than VIG's   0.09%. But he's earning his keep
column40: delivering a total return   that's crushed VIG and the market since VDIGX's inception in   February 2006 (net of fees
column41: of course):The Power of a Focused Dividend-Growth     StrategyBut if you're thinking of buying VDIGX now
column42: you're out of   luck. Vanguard closed the fund to new investors in July 2016.Even so
column43: as with VIG
column44: we can do an end run around that and   pick the five fastest dividend growers (again over the past 10   years) from among VDIGX's top 10 holdings
column45: which combined make up   29.8% of the portfolio.Here
column46: we're getting both fast dividend growthandpiggybacking on Kilbride's eye for value and dividend-growth   potential.These stocks are:Microsoft (MSFT)
column47: Costco Wholesale (COST)
column48: Chubb (CB)
column49: Medtronic (MDT)andUnion Pacific (UNP).(For this back test
column50: I've left outCanadian National Railway (CNI)
column51: whose dividend growth would have qualified it in Canadian-dollar   terms but falls short when converted to US funds.)Again
column52: we see the same result: four of these five beat VDIGX
column53: with the sole exception
column54: again
column55: being Medtronic:Active Investing: 2
column56: Passive: 0What's more
column57: these five dividend growers generated a combined   total return of 244.5%. That'sfarmore than the 152.3% we squeezed out of our five VIG   selections.It also neatly captures the power of combining dividend growth   with bargain valuations
column58: a strong earnings history and other   signs of payout strength.The bottom line? Investing in a ""dumb"" dividend-growth ETF is   okay. A ""smart"" one is better
column59: and picking your own dividend   growers (which
column60: by the way
column61: is how I invest my personal   retirement stash) is hands-down the best way to go.The Sweet Spot: 8% YieldsWithDividend GrowthDividend growth is great
column62: but none of the stocks above yield   more than 2.8% today. What if you need big dividend incomenowso you can retire comfortably?After all
column63: 2.8% just won't cut it unless you're rich already!But you can retire on as little as $500
column64: 000 today by focusing   on stealth income plays such as closed-end funds (CEFs)
column65: preferred shares and real estate investment trusts (REITs). In   many cases
column66: these issues pay secure yields of 8% or better--with   dividend growth to boot!This meansyou're assuring yourself of 10%+ annual returns
column67: with   most of that coming as cash dividends!These vehicles are safe
column68: but they aren't as well known as your   typical (and usually expensive) blue chip. And that'sgoodfor us
column69: because we can lock up secure income streams of 8% or   more while enjoying payout growth and price upside
column70: too.The 6 bargain buys I want to show you today are perfect for   2017. Because no matter what happens in Washington or with the   Fed
column71: these 8% payers are going to become increasingly popular   with retirees as they're discovered. Make sure you buy them now
column72: before their prices get bid up (and their yields get squeezed).Click here for full details on my favorite 8%     plays in funds
column73: preferreds and REITs--and I'll share the names
column74: tickers and buy prices with you
column75: too."

column1: Voice: The Next Computing Empire;3/11/2017;"This article is the first in a two-part series aimed at     exploring the rapidly developing state of voice computing from     the investor's perspective. In Part I
column2: I discuss why it's now     increasingly clear that the human voice will become society's     next major computing interface
column3: and why it will continue     proliferating through our homes and businesses. In Part II
column4: I'll dive deeper into the new and emerging business models. In     Part II
column5: I'll discuss the various players involved in the race     to commercialize the technology -- those best-positioned to     profit today
column6: those positioning themselves to thrive tomorrow
column7: and those dropping the ball entirely. I'll also dive deeper     into the fascinating business models voice computing will soon     enable
column8: and how those models will evolve as the technology     continues to improve.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();For nearly 40 years
column9: we've seen the computer evolve into an   indispensable accessory of Western society driven by three   powerful technologies that defined their eras and played a   monumental role for investors along the way.The personal computer gave many of us our first glimpse at the   digital world
column10: normalizing the idea that such machines have a   place in our homes and everyday lives. The internet tapped us   into that world
column11: offering us endless floods of information
column12: entertainment
column13: and commerce around which we willingly began   shaping our civilization. And then the smartphone encouraged us   to take that digital world everywhere we go
column14: leaving nothing but   a few taps on a touchscreen between us
column15: our computers
column16: and   constant immersion.Now
column17: a fourth technology -- voice computing--is removing that last barrier.Reimagining the roles computers playImagine driving down the highway
column18: coming home from work
column19: and     without taking your hands off the wheel or hitting any buttons
column20: asking your car to turn up the heat in your house
column21: preheat the     oven for dinner
column22: and play your favorite album
column23: all in the same     breath. Picture negotiating with a street vendor in Beijing
column24: having your phone translate the entire conversation between     Mandarin and English out loud
column25: so you can haggle in real time.     Or how about a stuffed animal that can tell your daughter     interactive stories every night before bed
column26: reshaping the     adventure at every twist and turn based on her responses and     reactions.These aren't hypothetical scenarios -- they're happening     right now.The human voice is well on its way to becoming the next     major medium we use to interact with computers
column27: and as we'll     explore in this two-part series
column28: voicecomputingis the burgeoning field of technology making it possible.     Already spanning multiple consumer and enterprise ventures     (think call center routing
column29: digital dictation
column30: or the virtual     assistants on smartphones)
column31: the industry's ultimate aim is     enabling people to carry on hands-free
column32: conversational-style     interactions with computers.It's an ambitious prospect capable of significantly     expanding the roles computers play in our everyday lives
column33: but     it's also one that appears inevitable when considering the     trajectory computers have taken
column34: without fail
column35: since their     introduction
column36: evolving in shape and form around contemporary     technology to solve unmet needs.Image Source: Getty ImagesAnd yet voice computing's evolution is different. Unlike any     form of computing to come before it
column37: the technology bypasses     the physical realm
column38: allowing users to query the internet
column39: manage their surroundings
column40: and connect to third-party services     without ever having to touch a physical device -- all in the     time it takes to form a sentence.If that sounds unnecessary
column41: then consider just how limitless     the applications could be. From the surgeon who needs to     rapidly adjust the conditions of her operating room     mid-procedure
column42: to the disabled veteran who simply hopes to     access the appliances in his home. The sheer number of everyday     applications for such a technology has prompted Grand View     Research to project the global market for voice recognition     technology will reach $128 billion annually by 2024
column43: an     estimate that may undershoot the overall economic opportunity     at play considering the potential verticals include healthcare
column44: defense
column45: entertainment
column46: consumer goods
column47: and more (I'll discuss     these in more detail in Part II).There is one thing we can be certain of
column48: however. Voice     computing is extremely likely to transform the way we interact     with technology in society
column49: but before that can happen
column50: a     large-scale societal shift toward adopting the interface must     occur
column51: a shift thatcannotoccur until several key hurdles are overcome.Understanding the challenges aheadTo analyze those obstacles
column52: let's turn to the most       promising application of voice-driven technology today:       virtual digital assistants.Data Sources: Socratic Technologies
column53: Vantiv
column54: Statista.         Chart by AuthorThanks to the success of the iPhone andApple's(NASDAQ: AAPL) other devices
column55: Siri is currently the most       wildly used virtual assistant in the United States
column56: but until       recently
column57: it's also perfectly exemplified what's holding       voice computing back. To put it simply
column58: speaking with Siri       can often feel more like a novelty than a time-saver
column59: a       sentiment shared not just among Apple users
column60: but most       smartphone owners with access to similar voice computing       technology.It's a problem we can break down into three fundamental       hurdles.The first is that users must often resort to awkward       combinations of hyper-specific phrasing and hurried       robo-speak to have their speech accurately recognized. Andrew       Ng
column61: chief scientist atBaidu(NASDAQ: BIDU) and one the most respected names in the field
column62: perhaps put it best in 2015 when he noted
column63: ""Speech       recognition
column64: depending on the circumstances
column65: is say 95 per       cent accurate. So maybe it gets one word in 20 wrong. That's       really annoying if it gets one in 20 wrong and you probably       don't want to use it very often. That's probably where speech       recognition is today.""The second hurdle is that even when our speech iscorrectlyrecognized
column66: there still remains a strong chance it will bemisinterpretedwhile undergoing natural language understanding
column67: a process in       which the assistant attempts to comprehend what we want using       the sequence of words (and eventually
column68: the tone
column69: pace
column70: and       inflection) we give. And even if that speech is correctly       understood
column71: an assistant may still simply be unable to solve       for the request due to technical constraints. Examples of       both cases can be seen in the screenshot below
column72: along with a       sense of how frustrating the encounter can be.Image Source: Author's iPhoneEncounters like these make us feel as though we're wasting       our time trusting our phones to do what we could have done       ourselves with only a little more effort upfront. Over time
column73: they build up
column74: eventually discouraging us from even tryingto       use our assistants for anything complex
column75: instead relying on       them only for the most trivial of tasks
column76: like setting alarms       or creating reminders.Thankfully
column77: these first two hurdles are solvable with data
column78: third-party partnerships
column79: and time
column80: each of which the major   players in this space have been actively accruing for years.   Returning to our example
column81: since Siri was introduced to the world   in 2011
column82: virtual assistants have grown far more capable of   correctly interpreting requests thanks to advances in deep   learning
column83: a thriving field of AI being utilized byAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL)
column84: Amazon(NASDAQ: AMZN)
column85: Baidu
column86: and others to improve speech recognition
column87: natural language understanding
column88: and other components of voice   computing at astounding rates. (Click herefor an outstanding story byThe New York Timeson Google's significant role in making this happen).Equally as important
column89: decisions by Apple and its competitors   to open their platforms up to third-party services have made   today's voice-based assistants feel far more capable than in   years past. These decisions allow Siri
column90: for example
column91: to call you   a ride using your Uber account
column92: or order a pizza through your   storedDomino'sinformation -- not unlike anactualsecretary would do.As the potential behind voice computing becomes increasingly   obvious in the coming months and years
column93: we should expect more and   more third parties to hop on board
column94: eventually expanding the   scope of what a partnership could entail (instead of ordering an   Uber
column95: imagine ordering a plane ticket). One look at the rate of   growth for third-party commands available on Amazon's voice-based   assistant
column96: Alexa
column97: can tell us a lot.Data Source: Voicebot. Chart by AuthorWith time
column98: these technical achievements and partnerships will   continue compounding
column99: eventually making for a highly practical   voice computing experience. Even marginal improvements in the   technology will convince users to begin using voice as an   interface more frequently. In the same talk regarding the current   state of the voice industry
column100: Ng went on to say
column101: ""I think that as   speech recognition accuracy goes from say 95 per cent to 98
column103: all of us in the room will go from barely using it   today
column104: to using it all the time."" He added
column105: ""Most people   underestimate the difference between 95 and 99 per cent ... 99   per cent is a game changer.""Although we're not yet able to predict when the technology   will reach that point
column106: if the recent pace of progress is any   indication -- since Ng's speech
column107: Baidu has built a program   capable of dictating English three times faster
column108: and with 20%   less errors
column109: than human beings -- it won't be much longer.In the meantime
column110: an arguably far more important hurdle stands   in the way. It's a problem shared by every other major computing   medium in use today
column111: only voice is actually solving for it.An instantaneous computing experienceNo matter the medium
column112: we've always interacted with computers   by issuing commands. In the 1950s
column113: we meticulously punched those   commands into cards before feeding them into hulking machines.   Now
column114: technology allows us to simply type
column118: speak them and expect a result.Yet despite these advancements
column119: today's mediums still subject   users to a unique set of delays
column120: a sort of friction that   inherently slows down the process betweenthinkinga command and actually being able tocommunicatethat command to your devices. A decade ago
column121: that friction most   likely entailed tracking down a PC with internet
column122: using the mouse   to open a browser
column123: using the keyboard to run a search
column124: and then   sorting for the result. But today
column126: it simply   means reaching into our pockets for our phone
column128: and tapping away.It's a process so effortless
column129: the average American now checks   their phone an estimated 46 times per day. It's even become   fashionable to argue there's no longerenoughfriction separating society from our devices; that we'retooplugged in to the digital world.So when you consider that voice computing's primary advantage   iseliminatingfriction
column130: it becomes tempting to dismiss the technology as a   solution to a trivial problem. What that argument critically   fails to consider
column132: is that friction is about more than   simple convenience
column133: and that any amount of friction
column135: fundamentally limits the dynamic between a user and   their computing medium in two ways.Let's take the smartphone for example.Image Source: PixabayThe seemingly trivial motions we make when reaching for our   phone still require us to be in immediate proximity of the   device. We have to walk over to kitchen counter if we left our   phone there; we have to remember it's on the counter even before   we can do that. Then
column137: we're   required to physically handle it
column138: a process that generally   requires we have one hand free and able.That may not sound like much
column139: but these limitations force our   computing experience to revolve around the location of our   device
column140: as opposed to it revolving around us.They can create roadblocks for those with disabilities affecting   their vision or hands (or really
column141: even those who just have sticky   hands
column144: those far away from their   device
column146: those with an immediate computing   need.There's a reason speech is our most instinctual form of   communication.If we have a question
column147: and if we know those around us can   answer that question
column148: we don't pull out our phone and run a   search
column149: we open our mouths and ask. We do that because it's   instantaneous. Now contrast that with having to locate your   phone
column150: having to type in your password
column151: having to navigate to an   app
column154: or speak your command. These behaviors   are not instinctual
column155: but we put up with them because the people around us usually   don't have the answers
column156: and because smartphones are our best   alternative.But they don't have to be.The rise of voiceIt's not obvious quite yet
column157: but today's physically bound   mediums have left a large hole to fill and voice computing is   starting to fill it.Over the past two years
column158: the technology has begun manifesting   itself in the form of always-on
column159: always-listening devices able to   virtually bypass the friction inherent in today's major computing   mediums. Currently
column160: these devices are best exemplified by   Amazon's line of Echo smart speakers
column161: which employ far-field   voice recognition technology allowing users to command Alexa from   across multiple rooms and through various background noises at   any time simply by calling for it out loud.Image Source: Amazon.com.Put another way
column163: Amazon's Echo is giving   consumers their first glimpse at a frictionless computing   experience. Following its initial setup
column165: no looking around for the device
column166: and no navigating   through screens to issue a command. When it works correctly (like   Siri
column167: Alexa is still very much in its infancy and subject to   misinterpreting commands) it really does allow users to convert   their thoughts to a command in the time it takes to form a   sentence
column168: capturing the essential promise of voice as a   medium.And if the early estimated adoption rate for the device is any   indication -- Amazon hasn't officially released sales   figures
column170: Consumer Intelligence Research   Partners (CIRP) estimates a staggering 8.2 million Echos have   already been sold in the U.S. (a number that pales in comparison   to Morgan Stanley's estimates of over 11 million)
column171: suggesting the   device has achieved well over 5% household penetration -- early   demand for a seamless computing experience is strong
column172: and will   likely grow stronger as capable competitors race to introduce   their own offerings (see Google's Home
column177: and third-party   support continue improving at rapid pace.Data Sources: VoiceLabs
column180: InfoScout. *2017     figures are VoiceLab projections. Chart by AuthorTo be clear
column181: these devices will never replace today's existing   computing mediums
column182: but will rather augment them. While   screens will remain the preferred medium for our more detailed   and visual computing needs
column183: voice will begin its ascent by taking   on an increasing share of our more ""conversational"" demands
column184: common requests we want addressed with the immediacy we expect   from dialogue (""Cancel my doctor's appointment."" ""Pause that   music!"" ""What's a good non-fiction book to read on the beach? ...   Great
column185: order that one."")As the technology grows capable of handling increasingly   nuanced and complex requests
column186: and as voice-enabled devices   proliferate and evolve
column187: we can expect more users to grow   comfortable engaging with the technology around the home
column189: and gradually more pervasive aspects of society.Andthat'swhere the real opportunities begin.The opportunity at handSome of the biggest tech empires in modern history have been   built around the personal computer
column192: each of which has provided the infrastructure for technology to   penetrate deeper and more reflexively into everyday life
column193: allowing creative companies to reach consumers in entirely new   ways.In just 10 years
column194: the iPhone helped Apple grow to become the   largest corporation in the world
column195: but it also popularized   smartphone technology in the U.S.
column196: helping to create the   infrastructure that in turn enabledFacebook(NASDAQ: FB)
column203: and countless others to create businesses that   reach deeper into our lives than any before.Image Source: Author's iPhoneAnd yet voice technology is going deeper.It's becoming an invisible
column205: weaving itself more seamlessly into the fabric of   our lives than any before it. It's called on using our most   instinctual
column207: and it's accessible   in the time it takes to form words. It's a technology that   provides tomorrow's innovators a far more intimate and pervasive   way to help us satisfy our digital wants.It's a startling but increasingly inevitable reality for both   investors and society.In Part II: The Playing Field
column208: I'll discuss various players   involved in the race to commercialize voice computing. To be the   first to know when Part II is released

column1: Here's Why the Best Is Yet to Come for Microsoft Corporation;3/11/2017;"Microsoft(NASDAQ: MSFT) shares rallied 24% over the past 12 months
column2: hitting a historic high and outperforming the S&P 500's 18%   gain. However
column3: that rally also boosted Microsoft's trailing P/E   to 30
column4: which is slightly higher than the industry average of 29   for business software companies.Some investors may believe that premium puts a near-term   ceiling over Microsoft's stock price. While that may be true
column5: Microsoft can still probably climb higher over the long term   thanks to three major catalysts.Image source: Pixabay.makeArticleAd();1. Its growing cloud ecosystemBack in 2015
column6: Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella declared that    Microsoft would generate $20 billion in annual cloud   revenues by the end of fiscal 2018. At the time
column7: its commercial   cloud businesses had an annual run rate of $6.3 billion. That   figure  topped $14 billion last quarter -- indicating that   it could hit Nadella's target and account for nearly a fifth of   the company's estimated revenues in  2018.Most of Microsoft's cloud revenues come from its main cloud   services
column8: Office 365
column9: Outlook
column10: and the Dynamics CRM (customer   relationship management) platform. A smaller portion comes from   its cloud platform Azure
column11: which lends out storage
column12: computing   power
column13: analytics
column14: and development tools to enterprise customers.   Microsoft doesn't disclose Azure's exact sales figures
column15: but it   claimed that its revenue rose 93% annually and its computing   usage more than doubled last quarter. All that growth could   offset Microsoft's biggest weakness -- its slowing sales of   Windows licenses.2. Its disruptive moves into new marketsMicrosoft's biggest mistake over the past decade was missing   the technological shift toward mobile devices
column16: which left it   chained to the aging PC platform as iOS and Android devices   flooded the market. But under Nadella
column17: Microsoft is pushing back   with disruptive moves of its own.Its acquisition of LinkedIn enhances Dynamics with  more   enterprise data
column18: which can help it challenge CRM market leaderSalesforce(NYSE: CRM) . Tighter connections between LinkedIn
column19: Office 365
column20: and Outlook can also widen the moat of its enterprise tools   against challengers like Google's G Suite. Microsoft's recent   introduction of Teams
column21: which merges Skype for Business
column22: Office   365
column23: OneNote
column24: and other features on a cloud-based collaboration   platform
column25: counters similar platforms like Slack andCisco's Spark.Microsoft's HoloLens. Image source: Microsoft.Microsoft also made bold moves on the hardware front. It   recently announced that it had alreadysold ""thousands""of  HoloLens AR headset development kits
column26: and the    upcoming Windows 10 Creators update will add 3D image   capture and editing tools to let artists and developers create 3D   objects which can be viewed in the headset. Microsoft also   announced that  its hardware partners will launch high-end   VR headsetsstarting at $300-- about half the price of an Oculus Rift. Those moves could all   put Microsoft ahead of the tech curve again.3. Embracing ARM-based devices
column27: Android
column28: and     iOSMicrosoft once had a misplaced devotion to x86 processors and   its own operating system. By sticking withIntel's(NASDAQ: INTC) x86 chips instead of supporting ARM chips
column29: Microsoft locked itself out of the smartphone and tablet markets
column30: which overwhelmingly used ARM's more power-efficient processors.   The company eventually pivoted toward ARM chips with Windows RT   and Windows Phone
column31: but apps for those devices were initially   incompatible with older x86-based machines.To move past that awkward phase
column32: Microsoft launched new   versions of Windows 10 which were  fully compatible with   both Intel's x86 chips andQualcomm's(NASDAQ: QCOM) ARM-based Snapdragon chips. It also recently   announced that it will run its Azure cloud platform on    Qualcomm's ARM-based Centriq 2400 server solutions. These   moves could hurt Intel's dominance of the PC and data center   markets.As for mobile devices
column33: it's clear that Windows Phone and   Windows 10 Mobile -- which runs on less than  1% of   smartphones worldwide -- were failures. But instead of pushing   out more expensive hardware
column34: Microsoft downsized its mobile   business and focused on launching more apps for Android and iOS.   This meant that PC users could still access Microsoft's Office   365
column35: Outlook
column36: OneDrive
column37: and other services on the go even if they   didn't own a Windows Phone -- which keeps Microsoft relevant in    the ""mobile-first
column38: cloud-first world"" which Nadella   discussed at the beginning of his tenure.The key takeawaysUnder former CEO Steve Ballmer
column39: Microsoft complacently milked   its Windows and Office cash cows. That complacency caused it to   miss the shift toward cloud services and mobile devices
column40: but   Satya Nadella seems to know how to get the company back on   track.Under Nadella
column41: Microsoft is focusing on the businesses that   work
column42: like the cloud
column43: and reducing its exposure to costly mobile   hardware. Microsoft is also investing in the future by expanding   its enterprise ecosystem and developing new AR and VR hardware.   To me
column44: all these moves indicate that Microsoft's best days are   still ahead.10 stocks we like better than MicrosoftWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Is This NVIDIA's Next Big Opportunity?;3/11/2017;"Image source: NVIDIA.Gaming isNVIDIA's(NASDAQ: NVDA) biggest revenue source while the automotive   business is said to be its nextbig play. However
column2: the company's data center business -- which hasAmazon(NASDAQ: AMZN) andMicrosoft(NASDAQ: MSFT) as clients -- is putting both gaming and   automotive to shame in terms of growth.makeArticleAd();Data from NVIDIA. Chart by author.The 205% year-over-year growth in NVIDIA's data center revenue   during the fourth quarter eclipsed both gaming and automotive
column3: which reported ""moderate"" growth of 66% and 37%
column4: respectively   over the same time period. Data center is the company's   second-largest business
column5: with over 13% of revenue
column6: and it could   continue to grow for two reasons: the deployment of more data   centers and upgrades to the existing ones.Data centers will need more GPUsNowadays
column7: the type and volume of information that data centers   process has become more complex than ever. The growing usage of   3D applications in virtualized workspace environments is creating   the need for high-performance computing that is enabled by GPUs.   Instead of deploying a 3D-graphics-enabled application on an   individual workstation
column8: enterprises are now using the data center   to install the 3D apps so they can be accessed by users   remotely.Apart from the complexity
column9: the volume of data processed in   data centers is also rising thanks to concepts such as the   Internet of Things.TheInternet of Thingsgenerates two categories of data. The first is the large data   type that consists of images and videos generated by different   electronic devices. The second is the passive or small data type   that is generated by different sensors and low-energy devices   powering the Internet of Things. As data centers handle both   these data types
column10: they will need upgraded GPUs to enhance   computing speeds and control costs simultaneously.As it turns out
column11: NVIDIA's Tesla GPUs for the data center   deliver on both counts -- faster speed and lower costs. These are   capable of enhancing computing speeds by five times and reduce   costs by 60%
column12: according to Shanker Trivedi
column13: the company's VP of   Enterprise Business. The advantages delivered by these GPUs have   allowed the company to rack up an impressive clientele in   datacenters
column14: especially in high-performance computing.NVIDIA's GPUs are powering major cloud service providers such   as Amazon Web Services
column15: GoogleCloud
column16: Microsoft Azure
column17: and Softlayer. The company's client list   in datacenters will continue expanding as global mobile data   traffic is expected to grow eightfold from 2015 to 2020
column18: driven   by Internet of Things applications.The increasing data traffic will spawn the need for more   datacenters
column19: with TechNavio forecasting that the global data   center market will grow 11% annually between 2016 and 2020. But
column20: apart from the construction of new datacenters
column21: NVIDIA will also   benefit from the upgrades to the existing ones.Upgrades will drive GPU demandCloud service providers have started upgrading their existing   data centers to meet the rise in data volumes and tackle   complexity. Amazon
column22: for example
column23: upgraded its services using   NVIDIA's Tesla GPU accelerators late last year. Amazon Web   Services used eight Tesla accelerators
column24: with each of them being   powered by a pair of GPUs.The NVIDIA GPUs were used to add a new virtual server
column25: known   as P2
column26: to Amazon's data center. The new server carries seven   times the computational capacity of Amazon's previous platform
column27: known as G2
column28: which was running a legacy GPU.Similarly
column29: Microsoft has also started offering a preview of   NVIDIA's accelerated data center solutions on the Azure platform   to give customers a taste of supercomputer-class performance.   Azure clients can now deploy professional grade graphics   solutions to remote workstations and accelerate their computing   speeds over the cloud. In this way
column30: Microsoft is providing   infrastructure-as-a-service (IaaS) to its clients by upgrading   its existing data centers.The IaaS market will be worth $43 billion in 2020 as compared   to $22 billion last year
column31: according to IDC. This will increase   the demand for NVIDIA's GPUs as they will be used to accelerate   computing power and capacity in data centers to enable IaaS   growth.The Foolish takeawayThe data center market is going to get bigger in the long run   and NVIDIA counts the biggest cloud service providers as its   clients. This will allow it to get more of its GPUs into data   centers to enable high-performance computing needs and eventually   boost its business.10 stocks we like better than NvidiaWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: Why General Electric Company (GE) Stock Is STILL a Powerhouse;3/10/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsInvestors should consider holding diversified companies as part of their investing strategy. These conglomerates operate in multinational jurisdictions
column3: don't rely on a single sector for revenue and in some cases
column4: pay out a regular dividend.makeArticleAd();Source:Mike Mozart via Flickr (Modified)General Electric Company(NYSE:GE)
column5: whose shares are valued at just 15.7 times forward earnings
column6: has a dividend yielding 3.2%.Its long-term debt (of 1.39x equity) is more than manageable. If GE stock dips more
column7: this is the stock to consider. In the third quarter
column8: General Electric was third only toMicrosoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT) andApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) in buying back shares.In Q3
column9: the company bought back $3.7 billion. Apple repurchased $6 billion
column10: while Microsoft bought back $4.4 billion. GE returned $30.5 billion to shareholders last year. This included a share buyback of $22 billion.The company is not a favorite pick among the analysts
column11: despite the respectable General Electric dividend. JPMorgan added GE stock as a top stock to avoid
column12: citing sub-par core operating performance.8 Dividend Growth Stocks Raising The BarInvestors need not pay any attention to analysts there. General Electric has strong leadership under CEO Jeffrey Immelt. It is embracing technology by focusing on the Internet of Things with its ""smart machines"" development.Growth Potential of GE StockGeneral Electric's move to merge its oil and gas services business withBaker Hughes Incorporated(NYSE:BHI) is a net positive.The energy sector is uncertain and it faces slow growth. Despite the challenging oil and gas market ahead
column13: GE stock still kept up with its pace of dividends and share buybacks. On its fourth-quarter conference call
column14: General Electric saidthe sector is stabilizing:""In oil and gas
column15: the environment continues to be challenging and activity levels remain muted
column16: external market indicators appear to be stabilizing with expected more balanced supply and demand fundamentals
column17: partly influenced by the recent OPEC production agreement. U.S. onshore rig count grew 33% versus the third quarter
column18: but was essentially flat versus the beginning of the year.""Although orders fell 27% year-over-year
column19: GE forecast no change in E&P spending. If the oil and gas market bottomed late last year
column20: the company will start seeing orders growing at its Alstom unit.The offshore drilling and sub-sea will still be a drag this year. General Electric hopes business picks up in North America onshore. It also needs the Middle East and Europe to stabilize. If that does not happen
column21: this segment will not meet the company's expectation of a smaller revenue decline in the second half of the year.General Electric's Earnings OutlookThe 2017 earnings-per-share forecast of $1.60 to $1.70 a share may prove too low an estimate for GE stock. In the meantime
column22: management is continuing with its plans on returning between $19 billion to $21 billion to shareholders this year.General Electric reported respectable growth in many of its units. For example
column23: revenue at HCS (health and life science) grew by 2 %. Immelt expects Aviation to grow again this year. GE is also improving its operating efficiency. A new IT structure that runs horizontally will save the company around $450 million.Investors shouldn't only consider General Electric the bellwether of the U.S. economy's health

column1: Advanced Micro Devices
column2: Inc. (AMD) Stock Is MUCH More Than Ryzen;3/10/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsThe past couple of weeks have been … well
column4: interesting ones forAdvanced Micro Devices
column5: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMD) shareholders. AMD stock
column6: after more than quintupling over the course of the prior 12  months
column7: fell 16% in just four days a week ago and has struggled to pick itself up off the mat in the meantime.makeArticleAd();Source:Matthew Rutledge via FlickrThe prod for the pullback? Reports that its new (and well-hyped) computer processor wasn't performing quite as well as expected once put to the test in real-world applications.As Ars Technica reviewer Mark Walton put it:""The [Ryzen] 1800X lags behind its Intel counterparts in gaming
column8: regardless of whether it's running at the same clock speed or higher.""It was a real blow to optimistic investors
column9: who had bid AMD stock up in a big way on hopes that the new CPU would be the centerpiece of a turnaround story. Now that story is in question.Thing is
column10: the Ryzen may not be as central to the company's rebound as it's been made it to be. Indeed
column11: Advanced Micro Devices has a lot more going for it besides the new CPU that investors aren't giving it credit for. Three specific items come to mind. Note than a handful of AMD's competitors are now becoming partners.3 Things AMD Still Has Going For ItWhile investors had high expectations for Ryzen
column12: the future for Advanced Micro Devices isn't dependent on it. In fact
column13: there are three other areas that may end up meaning even more for its top and bottom lines.9 Stocks to Buy That Are Growing Faster Than AmazonIn no particular order …Penetrating the Cloud Market:While AMD has always had a presence in most key tech markets
column14: cloud computing was never a key one for the company. That's changing now though… a ball that got rolling just in the past few weeks. In November
column15: Alphabet Inc's(NASDAQ:GOOGL) Google division tapped AMD
column16: looking to add its graphical processor units to Google's machine learning architecture.It's a curious development
column17: as GPU chips weren't designed to do anything more than handle a computer's display screen. As it turns out
column18: though
column19: its GPUs are very capable of parallel computing
column20: which is a critical aspect of this new cloud-based function.In the meantime
column21: Microsoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT) selected AMD processors to power its next-generation open course cloud platform.At stake is a piece of the cloud infrastructure market worth an estimated $300 billion per year.More Licensing Revenue:It's only an unconfirmed rumor thus far
column22: but a reasonably credible one. That is
column23: Intel Corporation(NASDAQ:INTC) is reportedly interested in using AMDs Radeon graphics technology to power Intel's integrated GPUs in future computers … displacingNvidia Corporation(NASDAQ:NVDA). The agreement between Nvidia and Intel ends at the end of March.At the very least
column24: the prospect of such an IP licensing deal could mean a couple hundred million dollars in annual high-margin revenue. If Intel really wants to step up its game
column25: though
column26: it could help fund improvements in the way its CPUs handle graphics.New GPUs Will Enhance New CPU Revenue:While the reviews for the new Ryzen processor have been mixed
column27: AMD stock holders should bear in mind that they're only half the next generation of hardware for Advanced Micro Devices.The other half of the one-two punch combination for AMD this year is the new Vega GPU
column28: which should be unveiled around the middle of this year.As was noted back on Feb. 7:""Vega
column29: is a second-generation high bandwidth memory (or HBM2) design found on a stacked-memory architecture that performs significantly better than the more common GDDR5 (double data rate type-five) utilized by most graphics processing units today. An essentially-infinite amount of memory can be dedicated to handling the display - the maximum virtualization is capped at a ridiculous 512 terabytes. This platform is about twice as powerful as most current alternatives
column30: and will make Advanced Micro Devices competitive with the newest generation of GPU architecture from Nvidia
column31: called Pascal.""More important
column32: Vega was largely built with the Ryzen processor in mend
column33: with each getting the most performance out of one another.Snap Inc (SNAP) Stock Is the Perfect Buy at This PriceIn the meantime
column34: it's not like the Ryzen CPU is a lost cause.As the company's CEO Lisa Su recently explained
column35: ""We hear people on wanting to see improved 1080p performance and we fully expect that Ryzen performance in 1080p will only get better as developers get more time with 'Zen.' We have over 300+ developers now working with 'Zen' and several of the developers for Ashes of Singularity and Total [War:] Warhammer are actively optimizing now.""Bottom Line for AMD StockAs encouraging as the future may be for the company whether or not Ryzen ends up performing well
column36: there's still no denying that AMD stock is overbought and ripe for some profit-taking; that 16% dip is nothing compared to 2016's huge rally.But don't confuse any future weakness from AMD as evidence of what's in store

column1: Can You Beat the S&P 500 with an Index Fund?;3/10/2017;"For Immediate ReleaseChicago
column2: IL - Investors focus in on the S&P 500 as a benchmark
column3: and for good reason. The index is one of the most popular
column4: liquid
column5: and diversified benchmarks out there. But is there an easy way to beat its performance with a slight strategy tilt? We explore this idea in the latest edition of the Dutram Report and get to the bottom of the 'equal weight' strategy. To listen to the podcast
column6: click here: (https://www.zacks.com/stock/news/252308/Can-You-Beat-the-SampP-500-at-Its-Own-Game).The S&P 500 isthebenchmark for most investors.The important stock index consists of 500 of the largest companies that are listed on the NYSE or the Nasdaq
column7: and securities are weighted in the benchmark by market capitalization levels. Currently
column8: top stocks in the benchmark include AppleAAPLat about 3.6% of the total
column9: MicrosoftMSFTat 2.5% of the total
column10: and Exxon MobilXOMat 1.65%.But while this approach is a great barometer for market health
column11: is it the best way for investors to put their money to work? Investors have numerous options in this department
column12: including products likeSPY
column13: VOO
column14: orIVV
column15: as these simply follow the benchmark exactly as laid-out by the index creators. But is there a potentially better way?Enter Equal WeightIn this edition ofthe Dutram Report
column16: I look for an alternate approach in a talk to Michael Willis
column17: the lead portfolio manager ofINDEX Funds. His key product
column18: the Index Funds S&P 500 Equal WeightINDEXtakes the same S&P 500 stocks
column19: but invests in them equally.This means that instead of Apple accounting for nearly 4% of the total
column20: or Microsoft making up 2.5% of the fund
column21: each account for roughly 0.2% of the total
column22: at least at rebalancing dates. And not just the mega caps
column23: but each and every stock comes with this same weight
column24: giving the fund an equal interest in giants like Exxon
column25: and the smallest S&P 500 components alike.While this might sound like a small difference
column26: we go over in the podcast how this actually ends up being something very important to overall returns. Michael discusses how nearly half of the S&P 500 (market cap weighted) is tied up in about 50 companies
column27: and that the remaining 450 have to fight over the remainder. He argues that the equal weight is a much more balanced way to achieve exposure
column28: while thefund's fact sheetshows that this approach has outperformed the market over long time periods.We also talk about the pros and cons of this approach
column29: such as its potentially heavier weighting in mid-cap securities and what this means for investors
column30: as well as some important fund specifics. This includes information regarding the cost and minimum investment
column31: and also the reason for selecting a fund structure. We then go over the ways that INDEX differs from the ETF counterpart out there
column32: the Guggenheim S&P 500 Equal Weight ETFRSP
column33: looking beyond the lower cost of INDEX when compared to the Guggenheim fund.Bottom LineEqual weight investing is an overlooked strategy for targeting stocks
column34: but it is clearly one that can lead to outperformance over long time periods. If you are curious about this approach
column35: check out this podcast for everything you need to know about how it works
column36: and if this can help improve returns for long-term investors.So

column1: Stocks to Buy: 3 Tech Stocks Paying Nice Dividends;3/9/2017;"Many of the bestdividend   stocksare found in sectors where the rate of change and disruption is   slow -- sectors like consumer staples
column2: utilities
column3: and banks. But   there are some excellent dividend stocks in the tech sector
column4: too.Apple(NASDAQ: AAPL)
column5: IBM(NYSE: IBM)
column6: andMicrosoft(NASDAQ: MSFT)
column7: for instance
column8: all pay solid
column9: growing   dividends.Here's a look at why each of these tech giants represents a   good bet for investors looking for income.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();Apple: dividend upsideApple offers the smallest dividend yield -- 1.6% -- of these   three stocks. But investors shouldn't overlook its   attractiveness. Apple's dividend easily makes up what it lacks in   yield with growth potential.Currently
column10: Apple is paying out just 27% of its earnings
column11: leaving significant upside for dividend increases in the future.   Further
column12: management has demonstrated how it's prioritizing   dividend growth since the company initiated its dividend in 2012.   Adjusted for a 7-to-1 stock split in 2014
column13: Apple's dividend has   increased 50% since 2012.Apple's annual dividend increases have steadily remained at   about 10% -- a rate the company looks like it could sustain for   years to come.IBM: an above-average yieldWith a dividend yield of about 3.1%
column14: IBM has the fattest   per-share payout of these three stocks. Even more
column15: while IBM's   44% payout ratio -- the percentage of annual earnings it is   paying out in dividends -- is well above Apple's 27% payout   ratio
column16: it's still low enough for investors to expect meaningful   dividend growth for years to come.Indeed
column17: IBM's dividend has grown at a very healthy average   annualized rate of about 14% during the past five years. However
column18: the company's most recent dividend increase wasn't as substantial   as in past years. In 2016
column19: IBM's dividend increased 7.7%
column20: down   from an 18.2% hike in 2015
column21: as the company'songoing transformationhas put pressure on net income.Despite the slowdown in IBM's dividend increases
column22: the   company's 21 consecutive years of dividend increases
column23: along with   its low payout ratio
column24: set a solid precedent for ongoing dividend   increases over the long haul.Microsoft: enduring cash flow from a profitable business   modelMicrosoft's ability to generate heady levels of cash flow from   its profitable business model is undeniable. For the past 10   years
column25: Microsoft's gross profit margin
column26: or gross profit as a   percentage of revenue
column27: has been between about 61% and 81%. Sure
column28: the software giant's gross profit margin is on the low end of   this range today -- at 61%. But the inherent profitability of   Microsoft's software-focused business
column29: combined with the   stickiness of its Office suite and its enterprise applications   and services
column30: means it can count on enduring cash flow for years   to come
column31: to continue feeding investors solid dividends.Image source: Getty Images.With a 2.4% dividend yield
column32: Microsoft offers investors a   better dividend yield than Apple
column33: but it's still well behind   IBM's 3.1% dividend yield. While Microsoft's payout ratio of   69.5% is higher than IBM's
column34: Microsoft's dividend as a percentage   of free cash flow -- at 42% -- better captures the software   giant's room for dividend increases. Recent one-time charges   against earnings and restructuring charges have suppressed net   income and pushed the company's payout ratio higher. By   comparison
column35: Apple and IBM are paying out 23% and 41% of their   free cash flow in dividends.Microsoft's most recent annual increase was 8% -- and the   company's financials look set to support similar increases over   time.In general
column36: income investors may not find many great dividend   stocks in tech. But these three stocks are just as worthy of a   spot in an income portfolio as go-to Dividend Aristocrats in   consumer staples
column37: utilities
column38: and banking.10 stocks we like better than AppleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column40: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column1: 9 Blue-Chip Stocks This Top Money Manager Likes;3/9/2017;"Many investors began to drool over the energy and financial   sectors after the November elections. The prospect of lower   corporate tax rates and less restrictive regulatory yokes was a   big reason. But Larry Puglia

column7: who also owns the Washington Post
column8: over the   newspaper's campaign coverage.But Puglia feels the benefit to corporations - including many   tech companies - of repatriation of bank accounts stuffed   with cash has been overlooked somewhat. And Puglia thinks the   likelihood of antagonism between the tech sector and the White   House is overblown. ""We do not think that would happen to a great   degree

column1: Cavium Inc.'s Thunder X2 Aims for Microsoft Corporation's Cloud;3/9/2017;"Data center chipmakerCavium(NASDAQ: CAVM) announced on March 8 that it is ""collaborating   withMicrosoft(NASDAQ: MSFT) on evaluating and enabling a variety of cloud   workloads running on [its] flagship Thunder X2 ARMv8-A Data   Center processor for the Microsoft Azure cloud platform.""The announcement goes on to say that Cavium and Microsoft are   ""demonstrating web services on a version of Windows Server   developed for Microsoft's internal use running cloud services   workloads on Thunder X2.""Image source: Intel.makeArticleAd();This announcement is similar to one that fellow ARM-based   server processor makerQualcomm(NASDAQ: QCOM)made at the same time.Let's take a closer look at what this announcement means for   Cavium in the near term and potentially over the long term.Near term? Probably not muchThe wording of Cavium's press release appears carefully   constructed to avoid giving the impression that Microsoft is   planning to buy and deploy a bunch of Cavium's Thunder X2 chips   in its data centers anytime soon.Indeed
column2: the phrases ""evaluating and enabling"" as well as the   word ""demonstrating"" seem aways away from ""planning to deploy in   significant quantities.""So
column3: in the near term
column4: I don't expect the joint work that   Microsoft and Cavium are doing to lead to significant revenue for   Cavium anytime soon. The work that these two companies are doing   is much more likely to lay the groundwork for Microsoft to be   able to deploy potential successors to the Thunder X2 -- should   those products meet Microsoft's needs for certain workloads.Taking a longer-term viewAt this point
column5: it's starting to look as though Cavium and   Qualcomm are the only two merchant ARM-based server processor   vendors left in in the game (there are companies building chips   for their own internal use like Huawei
column6: for example).Cavium's edge appears to be its heritage is as a data   center/networking processor vendor (Qualcomm hails from a mobile   processor background)
column7: but Qualcomm has significantly greater   financial resources to try to slug it out with market incumbentIntel(NASDAQ: INTC) .It's likely not going to be easy for either company to wrest   away significant market share from Intel to begin with (which   invests more in data center-specific technologies and marketing   than either Qualcomm or Cavium -- probably more than both   combined)
column8: and that difficulty is compounded by the fact that   Cavium and Qualcomm must compete against each other
column9: too.Success for ARM server chip vendors like Qualcomm and Cavium   is
column10: in general
column11: not something that's guaranteed to come at all
column12: and if it does come
column13: it'll be hard won over multiple years after   substantial investments in research and development
column14: software/ecosystem enablement
column15: and marketing efforts.It's worth noting that on Cavium's most recent earnings call
column16: CEO Syed Ali said that the company ""expect[s] to release [its]   next generation products"" in 2017. Given that the company had   previously said that it would begin sampling Thunder X2 in the   beginning of 2017
column17: I'd expect shipments for revenue to occur late   in the year.What investors need to keep an eye on
column18: then
column19: is what kind of   revenue ramp Cavium ultimately begins to experience with Thunder   X2 and the impact it starts having on the company's financials
column20: independent of this announcement from Microsoft.10 stocks we like better than Cavium NetworksWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column21: it can pay to listen. After all
column22: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column23: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column24: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Cavium Networks wasn't     one of them! column1: Apple Inc. Should Thank WikiLeaks for Its CIA Reveal;3/9/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsOn Tuesday
column3: WikiLeaks released ""Vault 7
column4: a huge collection of documents that reveal hacking tools used by the CIA. While the dump paints the CIA in an unflattering light
column5: the fallout may well be worse for some of the world's largest tech companies
column6: includingApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL).makeArticleAd();Source: AppleSpecifically
column7: the CIA has a long list of iOS exploits it has used to gain access to iPhones. Despite being named along with numerous other giants of tech
column8: the latest WikiLeaks dump actually highlights a key advantage for Apple in particular.And while its aura of security may emerge tarnished
column9: the iPhone may actually come out ahead over the long term thanks to WikiLeaks.What Was in WikiLeaks Vault 7?The latestWikiLeaks dump involves 8
column10: 761 documentsoutlining a wide range of CIA hacking tools
column11: including viruses
column12: malware
column13: zero-day exploits
column14: trojans and remote control systems.In addition there are 14 iOS exploits listed
column15: several dozen Android vulnerabilities and methods for accessing encrypted chats (essentially reading the contentsbeforethey are encrypted by gaining access to the host device).9 Stocks to Buy That Are Growing Faster Than AmazonIt's not all smartphones
column16: either. The CIA has developedmalware to infect computersrunning macOS
column17: Windows and Linux. It's even capable of turning Samsung Smart TVs on their owners
column18: using them as listening devices to record conversations.This Doesn't Look Good for AppleApple has long positioned itself as a privacy advocate. It has always played up the security of the iPhone and evenrefused an FBI request to unlock the iPhoneused by a shooter in 2015's San Bernardino terrorist attack.Apple CEO Tim Cook released a written statement at the time
column19: saying:""… the U.S. government has asked us for something we simply do not have
column20: and something we consider too dangerous to create. They have asked us to build a backdoor to the iPhone.""The WikiLeaks Vault 7 release made it clear that iOS wasn't as secure as Apple had thought.How Apple Could Come Out AheadWikiLeaks is bad news for Apple in the short term. But the reveal of CIA hacking of mobile devices and consumer electronics could actually be good news for the company in the long run. Apple quickly went on record as saying many of the vulnerabilities identified in the WikiLeaks Vault 7 documentswere already addressed with iOS 10. And it is working to identify and patch any new issues.Apple and Google chose very different strategies when it comes to smartphones. Apple controls every aspect of iOS - its mobile operating system - as well as the hardware. It pushes out new major new iOS versions yearly and update releases (the kind that fix bugs or security issues) on demand. As a result
column21: nearly 80% of all iPhones are currently running iOS 10.Google also releases new versions of Android yearly
column22: but largely relies on smartphone manufacturers and wireless carriers to approve and push updates. They have little incentive to do so
column23: since lacking the latest Android features could be a reason to buy a new smartphone.With such a wildly varying assortment of smartphones
column24: updates can often be problematic
column25: leading to support issues. As a result
column26: the latest version of Android is on just 2% of all Android smartphones
column27: while themajority are running software released in 2014 or earlier.In other words
column28: even if Googlehadaddressed most of the issues in Android Nougat as claimed
column29: right now

column6: I began that report with a more important and sobering premise: why tens of millions of jobs globally were about to be eliminated in the next decade.This assertion came from research published in January of 2016 by Citi and the Oxford Martin School exploring the varying impact that automation would have on jobs and economies in major countries around the world.Here's what I wrote last June...Technology at Work v2.0: The Future Is Not What It Used to Be builds on 2013 research by Carl Benedikt Frey and Michael Osborne which found that 47 per cent of US jobs were at risk of automation over the next two decades.The 156-page report provides in-depth analysis of the vulnerabilities of countries and cities to job automation
column7: explores what automation will mean for traditional models of economic growth
column8: and considers how governments can prepare for the potentially disruptive impacts of job automation on society.Key areas of analysis in the new report include this startling projection right at the outset:Risks of job automation in emerging economies such as China and India are as high as 77% and 69% over the next two decades.That's a lot of emerging markets workers put out of work in a fairly short time.And it challenges what I had long believed: that China and India would make steady progress in their efforts to bring over 1 billion people collectively into the ranks of the global middle class.That assumption was based on the efficient ability and desire of corporations to move manufacturing and service jobs to those countries and thereby balance the global market for goods and labor with the most cost-efficient choices available.But the reality is that automation trends -- broadly defined as those involving cloud computing
column9: business intelligence (Big Data analytics)
column10: artificial intelligence
column11: and robotics -- will create far more disruption for capital and labor sources than most are imagining.It's not just about the select company going out of business because a new technology or software solution -- like 3-D ""printed"" parts -- just replaced what their 50 employees did for far less money. It's about entire industries getting turned inside-out. In short
column12: the industrial revolutions of China and India could be over sooner than many would like.Here's how the Citi-Oxford report summed it up...""While manufacturing productivity has traditionally enabled developing countries to close the gap with richer countries
column13: automation is likely to impact negatively on their ability to do this
column14: and new growth models will be required.""The impact of automation may be more disruptive for developing countries

column1: Stocks to Buy: 3 Tech Stocks Paying Nice Dividends;3/9/2017;"Many of the bestdividend   stocksare found in sectors where the rate of change and disruption is   slow -- sectors like consumer staples

But investors shouldn't overlook its   attractiveness. Apple's dividend easily makes up what it lacks in   yield with growth potential.Currently
column10: Apple is paying out just 27% of its earnings
column11: leaving significant upside for dividend increases in the future.   Further
column12: management has demonstrated how it's prioritizing   dividend growth since the company initiated its dividend in 2012.   Adjusted for a 7-to-1 stock split in 2014

column14: IBM has the fattest   per-share payout of these three stocks. Even more
column15: while IBM's   44% payout ratio -- the percentage of annual earnings it is   paying out in dividends -- is well above Apple's 27% payout   ratio
column16: it's still low enough for investors to expect meaningful   dividend growth for years to come.Indeed
column17: IBM's dividend has grown at a very healthy average   annualized rate of about 14% during the past five years. However

column20: down   from an 18.2% hike in 2015
column21: as the company'songoing transformationhas put pressure on net income.Despite the slowdown in IBM's dividend increases

column23: along with   its low payout ratio

column26: or gross profit as a   percentage of revenue
column27: has been between about 61% and 81%. Sure

column29: combined with the   stickiness of its Office suite and its enterprise applications   and services

column31: to continue feeding investors solid dividends.Image source: Getty Images.With a 2.4% dividend yield

column34: Microsoft's dividend as a percentage   of free cash flow -- at 42% -- better captures the software   giant's room for dividend increases. Recent one-time charges   against earnings and restructuring charges have suppressed net   income and pushed the company's payout ratio higher. By   comparison

column1: Cavium Inc.'s Thunder X2 Aims for Microsoft Corporation's Cloud;3/9/2017;"Data center chipmakerCavium(NASDAQ: CAVM) announced on March 8 that it is ""collaborating   withMicrosoft(NASDAQ: MSFT) on evaluating and enabling a variety of cloud   workloads running on [its] flagship Thunder X2 ARMv8-A Data   Center processor for the Microsoft Azure cloud platform.""The announcement goes on to say that Cavium and Microsoft are   ""demonstrating web services on a version of Windows Server   developed for Microsoft's internal use running cloud services   workloads on Thunder X2.""Image source: Intel.makeArticleAd();This announcement is similar to one that fellow ARM-based   server processor makerQualcomm(NASDAQ: QCOM)made at the same time.Let's take a closer look at what this announcement means for   Cavium in the near term and potentially over the long term.Near term? Probably not muchThe wording of Cavium's press release appears carefully   constructed to avoid giving the impression that Microsoft is   planning to buy and deploy a bunch of Cavium's Thunder X2 chips   in its data centers anytime soon.Indeed
column2: the phrases ""evaluating and enabling"" as well as the   word ""demonstrating"" seem aways away from ""planning to deploy in   significant quantities.""So
column3: in the near term
column4: I don't expect the joint work that   Microsoft and Cavium are doing to lead to significant revenue for   Cavium anytime soon. The work that these two companies are doing   is much more likely to lay the groundwork for Microsoft to be   able to deploy potential successors to the Thunder X2 -- should   those products meet Microsoft's needs for certain workloads.Taking a longer-term viewAt this point
column5: it's starting to look as though Cavium and   Qualcomm are the only two merchant ARM-based server processor   vendors left in in the game (there are companies building chips   for their own internal use like Huawei
column6: for example).Cavium's edge appears to be its heritage is as a data   center/networking processor vendor (Qualcomm hails from a mobile   processor background)
column7: but Qualcomm has significantly greater   financial resources to try to slug it out with market incumbentIntel(NASDAQ: INTC) .It's likely not going to be easy for either company to wrest   away significant market share from Intel to begin with (which   invests more in data center-specific technologies and marketing   than either Qualcomm or Cavium -- probably more than both   combined)
column8: and that difficulty is compounded by the fact that   Cavium and Qualcomm must compete against each other
column9: too.Success for ARM server chip vendors like Qualcomm and Cavium   is
column10: in general
column11: not something that's guaranteed to come at all
column12: and if it does come
column13: it'll be hard won over multiple years after   substantial investments in research and development
column14: software/ecosystem enablement
column15: and marketing efforts.It's worth noting that on Cavium's most recent earnings call
column16: CEO Syed Ali said that the company ""expect[s] to release [its]   next generation products"" in 2017. Given that the company had   previously said that it would begin sampling Thunder X2 in the   beginning of 2017
column17: I'd expect shipments for revenue to occur late   in the year.What investors need to keep an eye on
column18: then
column19: is what kind of   revenue ramp Cavium ultimately begins to experience with Thunder   X2 and the impact it starts having on the company's financials
column20: independent of this announcement from Microsoft.10 stocks we like better than Cavium NetworksWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column21: it can pay to listen. After all
column22: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column23: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column24: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Cavium Networks wasn't     one of them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are     even better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

column1: Can You Beat the S&P 500 at Its Own Game?;3/9/2017;"The S&P 500 isthebenchmark for most investors.The important stock index consists of 500 of the largest companies that are listed on the NYSE or the Nasdaq
column2: and securities are weighted in the benchmark by market capitalization levels. Currently
column3: top stocks in the benchmark include Apple (AAPL) at about 3.6% of the total
column4: Microsoft (MSFT) at 2.5% of the total
column5: and Exxon Mobil (XOM) at 1.65%.But while this approach is a great barometer for market health
column6: is it the best way for investors to put their money to work? Investors have numerous options in this department
column7: including products likeSPY
column8: VOO
column9: orIVV
column10: as these simply follow the benchmark exactly as laid-out by the index creators. But is there a potentially better way?Enter Equal WeightIn this edition ofthe Dutram Report
column11: I look for an alternate approach in a talk with Michael Willis
column12: the lead portfolio manager of INDEX Funds. His key product
column13: the Index Funds S&P 500 Equal Weight (INDEX)
column14: takes the same S&P 500 stocks
column15: but invests in them equally.This means that instead of Apple accounting for nearly 4% of the total
column16: or Microsoft making up 2.5% of the fund
column17: each account for roughly 0.2% of the total
column18: at least at rebalancing dates. And not just the mega caps
column19: but each and every stock comes with this same weight
column20: giving the fund an equal interest in giants like Exxon
column21: and the smallest S&P 500 components alike.While this might sound like a small difference
column22: we go over in the podcast how this actually ends up being something very important to overall returns. Michael discusses how nearly half of the S&P 500 (market cap weighted) is tied up in about 50 companies
column23: and that the remaining 450 have to fight over the remainder. He argues that the equal weight is a much more balanced way to achieve exposure
column24: while thefund's fact sheetshows that this approach has outperformed the market over long time periods.We also talk about the pros and cons of this approach
column25: such as its potentially heavier weighting in mid-cap securities and what this means for investors
column26: as well as some important fund specifics. This includes information regarding the cost and minimum investment
column27: and also the reason for selecting a fund structure. We then go over the ways that INDEX differs from the ETF counterpart out there
column28: the Guggenheim S&P 500 Equal Weight ETF (RSP)
column29: looking beyond the lower cost of INDEX when compared to the Guggenheim fund.Bottom LineEqual weight investing is an overlooked strategy for targeting stocks
column30: but it is clearly one that can lead to outperformance over long time periods. If you are curious about this approach
column31: check out this podcast for everything you need to know about how it works
column32: and if this can help improve returns for long-term investors.So
column33: make sure to listen to this edition ofthe Dutram Reportfor a closer look at equal weight investing
column34: and what the pros and cons of this approach are for those seeking a different way to play the S&P 500. And if you have any thoughts or comments
