column1: Apple Inc. Should Thank WikiLeaks for Its CIA Reveal;3/9/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsOn Tuesday
column3: WikiLeaks released ""Vault 7
column4: a huge collection of documents that reveal hacking tools used by the CIA. While the dump paints the CIA in an unflattering light
column5: the fallout may well be worse for some of the world's largest tech companies
column6: includingApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL).makeArticleAd();Source: AppleSpecifically
column7: the CIA has a long list of iOS exploits it has used to gain access to iPhones. Despite being named along with numerous other giants of tech
column8: the latest WikiLeaks dump actually highlights a key advantage for Apple in particular.And while its aura of security may emerge tarnished
column9: the iPhone may actually come out ahead over the long term thanks to WikiLeaks.What Was in WikiLeaks Vault 7?The latestWikiLeaks dump involves 8
column10: 761 documentsoutlining a wide range of CIA hacking tools
column11: including viruses
column12: malware
column13: zero-day exploits
column14: trojans and remote control systems.In addition there are 14 iOS exploits listed
column15: several dozen Android vulnerabilities and methods for accessing encrypted chats (essentially reading the contentsbeforethey are encrypted by gaining access to the host device).9 Stocks to Buy That Are Growing Faster Than AmazonIt's not all smartphones
column16: either. The CIA has developedmalware to infect computersrunning macOS
column17: Windows and Linux. It's even capable of turning Samsung Smart TVs on their owners
column18: using them as listening devices to record conversations.This Doesn't Look Good for AppleApple has long positioned itself as a privacy advocate. It has always played up the security of the iPhone and evenrefused an FBI request to unlock the iPhoneused by a shooter in 2015's San Bernardino terrorist attack.Apple CEO Tim Cook released a written statement at the time
column19: saying:""… the U.S. government has asked us for something we simply do not have
column20: and something we consider too dangerous to create. They have asked us to build a backdoor to the iPhone.""The WikiLeaks Vault 7 release made it clear that iOS wasn't as secure as Apple had thought.How Apple Could Come Out AheadWikiLeaks is bad news for Apple in the short term. But the reveal of CIA hacking of mobile devices and consumer electronics could actually be good news for the company in the long run. Apple quickly went on record as saying many of the vulnerabilities identified in the WikiLeaks Vault 7 documentswere already addressed with iOS 10. And it is working to identify and patch any new issues.Apple and Google chose very different strategies when it comes to smartphones. Apple controls every aspect of iOS - its mobile operating system - as well as the hardware. It pushes out new major new iOS versions yearly and update releases (the kind that fix bugs or security issues) on demand. As a result
column21: nearly 80% of all iPhones are currently running iOS 10.Google also releases new versions of Android yearly
column22: but largely relies on smartphone manufacturers and wireless carriers to approve and push updates. They have little incentive to do so
column23: since lacking the latest Android features could be a reason to buy a new smartphone.With such a wildly varying assortment of smartphones
column24: updates can often be problematic
column25: leading to support issues. As a result
column26: the latest version of Android is on just 2% of all Android smartphones
column27: while themajority are running software released in 2014 or earlier.In other words
column28: even if Googlehadaddressed most of the issues in Android Nougat as claimed
column29: right now
column30: there arehundreds of millions of Android devices that could still be affectedbecause they're running old software. Most iPhone users
column31: however
column32: should be okay
column33: and the rest can be assured that Apple's consistent program of releases will address any outstanding issues.Apple has a similar approach with macOS. It updates its Mac computer operating system regularly and pushes out security updates as issues are discovered. With the smart home
column34: Apple takes extreme security measures
column35: including costly custom chips
column36: factory inspections and end-to-end encryption between connected devices. This approach has meant slower adoption for its HomeKit platform
column37: but with the benefit of being far more secure than the competition.As for smart TVs eavesdropping on you
column38: that's just another reason to buy a relatively inexpensive streaming box - like an Apple TV - instead.The Age of Privacy Is OverMany people had been living with a probably naive expectation that everything they did with their smartphone was private and secure
column39: especially when using encrypted apps. The latest WikiLeaks dump should end that notion and leave people watching their TV
column40: PC and even smart thermostat with suspicion.Snap Inc. (SNAP) Aims to Win Where Disney (DIS) FailedBut by the time this plays out
column41: it's also likely to make it clearer than ever before that some products are more secure than others
column42: and some companies are in a better position to fix any vulnerabilities.Apple may have been named as one of the victims of CIA hacking
column43: but it was quick to respond and quick to make it clear many of the WikiLeaks exploits have already been addressed. Perhaps more importantly
column44: Apple's product strategy puts it in the position to be a leader in offering the most secure devices possible going forward.As of this writing
column45: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceApple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Is a Jekyll-and-Hyde Trade Right NowApple Inc. iPhone Grabs Even More Market ShareThe postApple Inc. Should Thank WikiLeaks for Its CIA Revealappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column3: CRM;3/9/2017;"makeZacksArticleAd();Last June I wrote a special report forZacks Confidentialcalled ""Big Economic Disruption: Big Data
column4: AI
column5: and Robotics.""While researching and talking about science-fiction technologies like machine learning and artificial intelligence is always fun
column6: I began that report with a more important and sobering premise: why tens of millions of jobs globally were about to be eliminated in the next decade.This assertion came from research published in January of 2016 by Citi and the Oxford Martin School exploring the varying impact that automation would have on jobs and economies in major countries around the world.Here's what I wrote last June...Technology at Work v2.0: The Future Is Not What It Used to Be builds on 2013 research by Carl Benedikt Frey and Michael Osborne which found that 47 per cent of US jobs were at risk of automation over the next two decades.The 156-page report provides in-depth analysis of the vulnerabilities of countries and cities to job automation
column7: explores what automation will mean for traditional models of economic growth
column8: and considers how governments can prepare for the potentially disruptive impacts of job automation on society.Key areas of analysis in the new report include this startling projection right at the outset:Risks of job automation in emerging economies such as China and India are as high as 77% and 69% over the next two decades.That's a lot of emerging markets workers put out of work in a fairly short time.And it challenges what I had long believed: that China and India would make steady progress in their efforts to bring over 1 billion people collectively into the ranks of the global middle class.That assumption was based on the efficient ability and desire of corporations to move manufacturing and service jobs to those countries and thereby balance the global market for goods and labor with the most cost-efficient choices available.But the reality is that automation trends -- broadly defined as those involving cloud computing
column9: business intelligence (Big Data analytics)
column10: artificial intelligence
column11: and robotics -- will create far more disruption for capital and labor sources than most are imagining.It's not just about the select company going out of business because a new technology or software solution -- like 3-D ""printed"" parts -- just replaced what their 50 employees did for far less money. It's about entire industries getting turned inside-out. In short
column12: the industrial revolutions of China and India could be over sooner than many would like.Here's how the Citi-Oxford report summed it up...""While manufacturing productivity has traditionally enabled developing countries to close the gap with richer countries
column13: automation is likely to impact negatively on their ability to do this
column14: and new growth models will be required.""The impact of automation may be more disruptive for developing countries
column15: due to lower levels of consumer demand and limited social safety nets. With automation and developments in 3D printing likely to drive companies to move manufacturing closer to home
column16: developing countries risk 'premature de-industrialisation'.""Digital industries have not created many new jobs. Since 2000

column18: most of which are directly associated with digital technologies.""This amount of disruption should not be taken lightly. column1: 4 High-Yield Dividend Stocks You Don't Have to Babysit;3/9/2017;"For long-term dividend investors
column2: the best type of stock is   one that can be bought and largely forgotten about
column3: with the   occasional checkup to make sure those dividend checks aren't in   danger. A few of the Fool's contributors have identified four   high-yielddividend   stocksthat fit this description. Here's whyMicrosoft(NASDAQ: MSFT)
column4: Vanguard High Dividend Yield ETF(NYSEMKT: VYM)
column5: ONEOK(NYSE: OKE)
column6: andEnterprise Products Partners(NYSE: EPD) are great buy-and-hold dividend stocks.A solid tech dividendTim Green(Microsoft):Being a technology company
column7: Microsoft is more susceptible to   disruption than other dividend-paying stalwarts. But it's not a   company that investors need to worry too much about. Under the   leadership of CEO Satya Nadella
column8: Microsoft has shed its image as   a tech dinosaur and aggressively embraced cloud computing.   Microsoft's stranglehold on the productivity software market   remains intact
column9: its cloud-computing platform is a strong No. 2   player
column10: and innovations like the HoloLens augmented reality   headset could put Microsoft right at the center of the next   computing revolution.Image source: Microsoft.makeAd('4'
column12: 'mktsnews'
column13: 'vanguard'
column15: '');Microsoft's dividend
column16: currently yielding about 2.4%
column17: isn't all   that high. But it's superior to that of the average yield of   stocks in theS&P 500
column18: which yields less than 2%. Microsoft produces an   incredible amount of free cash flow -- nearly $25 billion in   fiscal 2016. This fueled not only $11 billion in dividend   payments
column19: putting the payout ratio at about 44%
column20: but also $16   billion of share buybacks. There's still plenty of room to grow   the dividend going forward
column21: even without much earnings   growth.Microsoft's cash-rich balance sheet is another reason the   stock is attractive to dividend investors aiming to buy and hold   for many years. Microsoft had net cash of $37.8 billion at the   end of the latest quarter
column22: providing a massive cushion that can   sustain the dividend even in the roughest economic conditions.   While there are higher-yielding stocks available
column23: Microsoft is a   good option for long-term investors.Taking a basket approach to high yieldsBrian Feroldi(Vanguard High Dividend Yield ETF): It is natural for income-focused investors to want to own   stocks that offer up higher yields than the market in general.   However
column24: picking the right high-yield stocks can be tricky
column25: since   a massive payout can sometimes actually be a warning sign.One alternative that is available to all investors is to   instead invest in an exchange-traded fund (ETF) that is focused   on dividend stocks with above-average yields. If that sounds like   a smart way to go
column26: then I'd suggest that you give the Vanguard   High Dividend Yield ETF a closer look.This passively managed ETF owns more than 400 stocks that have   higher yields than the market in general. Its biggest holdings   are all names that investors are familiar with -- think   Microsoft
column27: ExxonMobil
column28: Johnson & Johnson-- which also provides investors with an extra layer of   stability.The VYM currently offers a dividend yield of 3%
column29: which is more   than 50% higher than that of the S&P 500 average yield.   Better yet
column30: this fund's 10-year total return -- which accounts   for the reinvestment of dividends -- is neck and neck with   the S&P 500.VYM Total Return Pricedata byYCharts.Despite all of its benefits
column31: Vanguard only charges a minuscule   0.08% expense ratio to access this ETF. Thus
column32: if you are after a   high yield but don't want to pick individual stocks
column33: the Vanguard   High Dividend Yield ETF could be an excellent choice for   you.This energy play is a naturalDan Caplinger(ONEOK):The plunge in energy prices in 2015 hurt companies throughout the   industry
column34: and even midstream infrastructure plays like ONEOK took   big hits in their share prices. Yet after losing 70% of its share   price
column35: ONEOK has surged in the past year
column36: nearly tripling as   investors have figured out that not all companies have the same   exposure to crudeoil   pricesas others.ONEOK has an impressive slate of infrastructure assets
column37: helping in the gathering process of natural gas from the Permian   Basin
column38: Rocky Mountain
column39: and Mid-Continent regions of the U.S. and   then processing
column40: storing
column41: and transporting it to key market   centers in the energy industry. That business relies more on   production volume than on price
column42: and although the producers that   ONEOK works with transport more natural gas when prices are   favorable
column43: the energy transportation giant has still been able to   produce solid results as oil andnatural   gas priceshave rebounded.ONEOK currently has a yield of 4.5%
column44: but that figure should go   up when the company completes its planned acquisition of itsONEOK Partners(NYSE: OKS) master limited partnership. Once the MLP deal is   complete
column45: ONEOK expects to boost dividends by a fifth
column46: which   should help the yield even further. As long as energy prices   remain strong enough to induce its clients to send natural gas   through its infrastructure network
column47: ONEOK will be in position to   keep delivering income to its investors.A model of consistencyMatt DiLallo(Enterprise Products Partners): Pipeline giant Enterprise Products Partners has an excellent   track record of paying investors an above-average dividend. In   fact
column48: since going public in 1998
column49: the company has raised its   payout 59 times
column50: including in each of the past 50 quarters. These   haven't been token increases
column51: either
column52: with its last payout   representing a 5.1% raise over the prior year. All these   increases have added up over the years
column53: with the company   currently yielding a very generous 5.8%.That payout is about as safe as they come. First of all
column54: more   than 85% of Enterprise's cash flow comes from fee-based service   contracts
column55: which provides it with very stable cash flow.   Furthermore
column56: the company pays out less than 80% of its cash flow
column57: which is well below the near-100% payout ratios of the average   MLP. Finally
column58: the company has a top-notch balance sheet
column59: evidenced by the fact it has one of the highest credit ratings   among MLPs. Add it up
column60: and Enterprise has the financial strength   to maintain its distribution rather easily.That said
column61: the company is more likely to maintain its   distribution growth streak than simply keep things status quo.   Fueling that growth potential is the fact that it has $6.7   billion of growth projects under construction and several   additional projects under development. These new assets should   enable the company to continue growing its cash flow
column62: giving it   more money to return to investors. Needless to say
column63: this is one   dividend stock that will not cause investors any worry.10 stocks we like better than MicrosoftWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column64: it can pay to listen. After all
column65: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column67: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Microsoft wasn't one of     them! column1: Qualcomm
column2: Inc. Data-Center Chips Get Microsoft Corporation’s Blessing;3/8/2017;"Qualcomm(NASDAQ: QCOM) is well known for its cellular modems and mobile   applications processors. Sales of such products make up the   overwhelming majority of its semiconductor revenues. Although   these businesses have been good to the chipmaker
column3: the company is   looking to bring its chip-design expertise into new markets.The company has been known to be working on data-center   processor designs for quite some time
column4: though it only formally   unveiled its intent to compete in this market in late 2015.Qualcomm's Centriq 2400 server processor. Image source:     Qualcomm.makeArticleAd();Qualcomm kicked off its efforts here when it began sampling   its first server chip -- a 24-core processor built using a   foundry 14/16-nanometer technology -- in late 2015. The company   began sampling a follow-on product -- a 48-core product built   using a foundry 10-nanometer technology -- in late 2016
column5: with   commercial shipments expected to begin in the second half of   2017.Qualcomm's server-chip efforts seemingly got server-software   giantMicrosoft's(NASDAQ: MSFT) blessing in a March 8 announcement. Let's take a   closer look.Bringing Windows to Qualcomm's ARM-based server     chipsOne of the hurdles to the adoption of processors built using   the ARM architecture in the server market has been the lack of   software infrastructure. Most data-center software today is   written for chips that implementIntel(NASDAQ: INTC) Architecture. This is unsurprising
column6: as Intel   has an overwhelmingly dominant market-share position in the   server-processor market.In a press release
column7: Qualcomm announced that it's working with   Microsoft to enable ""a variety of cloud [server] workloads to run   on the Microsoft Azure cloud platform powered by Qualcomm Centriq   2400 server solutions."" Qualcomm also says that its   data-center-focused division
column8: QDT (Qualcomm Datacenter   Technologies)
column9: ""has been working with Microsoft for several years   on ARM-based server enablement and has onsite engineering at   Microsoft to collaboratively optimize a version of Windows   Server
column10: for Microsoft's internal use in its data centers
column11: on   Qualcomm Centriq 2400-based systems.""From this press release
column12: it doesn't look as though Microsoft   is planning to sell the Qualcomm/ARM compatible Windows Server to   other server makers quite yet. The release explicitly highlights   that this version of Windows is ""for Microsoft's internal use in   its data centers.""That said
column13: perBloomberg
column14: Microsoft's Azure cloud service is ""No. 2 in cloud   infrastructure behindAmazon
column15: and it's one of the biggest server buyers
column16: so the opportunity   here for Qualcomm seems reasonably large and could get larger   should Microsoft make Windows Server on ARM -- and thus on   Qualcomm chips -- more widely available down the line.Success
column17: if it comes
column18: takes timeQualcomm seems to be doing a lot of software ecosystem work to   allow its chips to be a viable alternative in the server market.   That's the good news for Qualcomm. However
column19: investors should   be careful in setting their expectations around the company's   server-chip business.Intel
column20: the incumbent player
column21: still has the advantage of   incumbency
column22: the ability to offer many platform components as a   ""one stop shop"" (i.e. 3D XPoint memory
column23: Ethernet   controllers/switches
column24: FPGAs
column25: Xeon Phi accelerators
column26: and so on).   It also invests heavily in influencing major server buyers and   software vendors to optimize their codes to take advantage of the   features and capabilities of Intel's chips.Intel's 3D XPoint memory. Image source: Intel.Any significant share gains for Qualcomm
column27: should they   ultimately happen
column28: aren't likely to happen overnight. They'll   take time
column29: so it's probably unwise for investors to model in   significant revenue/unit share gains in the near term.Further
column30: if Qualcomm can't ultimately generate enough revenue   from server chip/platform sales to generate a reasonable return   on what is surely a significant investment -- product development   and marketing are not cheap -- then there's a risk that the   company will
column31: at some point down the line
column32: simply shutter the   efforts.But for now
column33: it will be interesting to see how Qualcomm's   product offerings and go-to-market strategy evolves
column34: and how much   commercial success it can ultimately achieve.10 stocks we like better than QualcommWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column35: it can pay to listen. After all
column36: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column37: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column38: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Qualcomm wasn't one of     them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

column1: Why Alphabet and Microsoft Should Start Disclosing Cloud Revenue;3/8/2017;"Alphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) is currently hosting its Google   Cloud Next '17 developer conference
column2: which kicked off earlier   today in San Francisco and runs through March 10. Speaking at the   event
column3: Google CEO Sundar Pichai made it clear that he sees Google   Cloud as an incredibly important part of the search giant's   future
column4: and not just one of the company's many side bets. ""To me
column5: Google Cloud is a natural extension of our mission to make the   world's information accessible and usable
column6: Pichai said.The distinction is that while search helps regular users   access information
column7: cloud computing infrastructure and the   related value-added services like analytics help the enterprise   organize and access their information. The cloud infrastructure   market is booming
column8: growing 49% last year to $38.1 billion
column9: according to market researcher Canalys. It's expected to jump   another 46% this year to $55.8 billion. As the market grows
column10: so
column11: too
column12: does the impact on the financials of the major players:   Google Cloud
column13: Microsoft(NASDAQ: MSFT) Azure
column14: andAmazon.com(NASDAQ: AMZN) AWS.Google data center in Council Bluffs
column15: Iowa. Image source:     Google.makeArticleAd();As such
column16: the former two should start disclosing exactly how   much cloud revenue they're bringing in.Follow Amazon's leadI never thought I'd see the day when Amazon was leading the   way in investor transparency
column17: given the e-commerce giant's   long-standing refusal to share various operating metrics that are   pertinent to investors. Yet
column18: when it comes to AWS and cloud   revenue
column19: Amazon is doing just that; Amazon started sharing AWS   financials in 2015. AWS revenue was $12.2 billion last year
column20: translating into $3.1 billion in operating income.Microsoft only discloses growth rates for Azure (up 93% last   quarter)
column21: but lacking a base number
column22: that data point is less   meaningful. We do know that total revenue in Microsoft's   intelligent cloud segment
column23: which includes Azure among other   offerings
column24: was $6.9 billion last quarter
column25: resulting in $2.4   billion in operating income. Lacking an official figure
column26: JPMorgan   analysts estimate Azure revenue for all of 2016 was $2.7 billion
column27: which would make AWS nearly five times bigger.Google includes Google Cloud revenue within its Google other   revenues segment
column28: which generated a hair over $10 billion in   sales in 2016. That also includes revenue from Google Play as   well as the company's growing hardware portfolio. One   particularly prominent Google Cloud customer that just went   public likely spent between $400 million to $450 million last   year
column29: and is committed to $400 million per year for thenext five years
column30: so there's that.Sharing is caringYou could reasonably argue that AWS is far more important to   Amazon than its peers' respective cloud businesses
column31: though
column32: specifically since AWS is by far the market leaderandit's such a major contributor to profitability due to razor-thin   margins in the core e-commerce business. In contrast
column33: Google and   Microsoft enjoy much higher gross margin
column34: as they each specialize   in software and services.Still
column35: the cloud infrastructure market is only going to become   increasingly important in the years ahead
column36: and investors will   want to see the results from the three largest players to assess   each company's competitiveness. Google and Microsoft should start   sharing more
column37: especially if it's as important as Pichai says it   is.10 stocks we like better than AlphabetWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column38: it can pay to listen. After all
column39: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column40: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column41: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Alphabet (C shares)     wasn't one of them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks     are even better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

column44: is a member of The     Motley Fool's board of directors. Teresa Kersten is an employee     of LinkedIn and is a member of The Motley Fool's board of     directors. LinkedIn is owned by Microsoft.Evan Niu

column1: Microsoft Corporation (MSFT) Stock Looks Overbought. It Isn’t.;3/8/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsFew names in the markets have almost universal appeal.Microsoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT) is one of them. Sure
column3: Apple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) products have more appeal
column4: Alphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOG
column5: NASDAQ:GOOGL) is more popular andAmazon.com
column6: Inc(NASDAQ:AMZN) is more engaging
column7: but let's give credit where credit is due. Most of us have grown up with Microsoft programs
column8: and we continue to use them frequently to this day.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockOf course
column9: emotional sentiment only goes so far. To prove its relevance in a changing world
column10: Microsoft must deliver the goods. For most of this decade
column11: the results for Microsoft stock have been fantastic.We're talking five out of seven years in the black
column12: with an average annual profit of nearly 14%. In addition
column13: MSFT stock has enjoyed four consecutive years of double-digit growth.I don't care how many caveats you can mention about the proverbial old dog … that's a trick that's tough to master at any age. Seemingly
column14: the change at the top of the Microsoft war room
column15: from Steve Ballmer to Satya Nadella
column16: is working wonders. Most importantly
column17: the willingness to aggressively push into new territory is encouraging for potential Microsoft shareholders.9 Stocks to Buy That Are Growing Faster Than AmazonInvestorPlace contributor Will Ashworth took this confidence further by declaring that MSFT stock willhit $80 this year. Is this wishful thinking
column18: or is there more to this than mere bravado?Challenges Facing MSFT stockFirst things first - I admire the guts Ashworth displayed. That's putting yourself out there and giving clarity to your point of view. It's something I wish I could see in Washington
column19: but that's a whole different ballgame.With MSFT stock specifically
column20: the bullish argument is an easy one
column21: but so is the cautious approach. Shares have soared despite the wave of competition in the consumer tech sector. InvestorPlace contributor Vince Martin speaks for a lot of people whenhe wrote
column22: ""I continue to be surprised at the strength shown by Microsoft stock. MSFT stock has risen roughly 150% in just four years - despite little movement in profits.""The lack of fundamental growth is even more perplexing when you consider Microsoft's position within the fierce environment. The company is either lagging
column23: or is getting challenged by rising up-and-comers. Martin writes:""For Office 365
column24: Tableau Software Inc(NYSE:DATA) is challenging Excel - and 27% revenue growth in 2016 suggests DATA is taking share from MSFT. Behemoths likeOracle Corporation(NYSE:ORCL) and many others are in the cloud space. Microsoft's Dynamics CRM product is a distant second tosalesforce.com
column25: inc. (NYSE:CRM).""A huge concern for those trading MSFT stock is the market capitalization. I'm not a fan of focusing on any one metric. Still
column26: with its equity valued at half a trillion dollars
column27: you have to take a step back. Is Microsoft stock really worth that much?Click to EnlargeKeep in mind that despite four consecutive years of double-digit growth
column28: the magnitude has also declined. The first strike was 39.5% in 2013
column29: followed by performances of 28.4%
column30: 21.9% and 16.5%.Microsoft Stock Is a Proven WinnerAdmittedly
column31: that's not the direction the trend should go. Nevertheless
column32: I think Ashworth is going to be a happy camper. Like other tech names
column33: Microsoft stock starts off the year fairly slowly. For example
column34: its first quarter returns are a relatively pedestrian 8%.But at year's end
column35: the average return jumps up to 30.7%
column36: nearly four times higher. That also means that those who are concerned about this year's slow start for MSFT stock shouldn't be.The other attribute that is remarkable about Microsoft is its resiliency. Between 2000 and 2011
column37: MSFT stock suffered a negative Q1 performance ten times. But in four of those instances
column38: shares managed to claw back positive returns for the year. That provides a lot of security for those making strongly optimistic calls for Microsoft stock.While investors have reason to look at MSFT cautiously
column39: I think Wall Street is giving Nadella and company a fair shake. They want to see what it can do with its long-term strategy
column40: and the signs are encouraging. A prime example is Microsoft'shigh-profile acquisitionofLinkedIn. By integrating its intellectual capital with Microsoft's vast networks
column41: it can do serious damage in the social media sphere.Snap Inc (SNAP) Stock: Stay Away at All Costs!Overall
column42: $80 for Microsoft stock is very reasonable. Although not dominant
column43: it's competing well in some of the most exciting and high-growth sectors. Both the company and the markets are loving the change in leadership and culture. Finally
column44: Microsoft continues to find ways to do well
column45: even in the most trying of circumstances. The only question is
column46: can I be the first to call $100 in 2018?As of this writing
column47: Josh Enomoto did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace3 Drug Stocks Hit by Trump's Call for Lower Prices4 Food Stocks at Risk Thanks to Record HeatThe postMicrosoft Corporation (MSFT) Stock Looks Overbought. It Isn't.appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Why FireEye Inc (FEYE) Stock Is a Terribly Good Speculation Pick;3/8/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsThere's a reason why many analysts are loathe to cover technology firms - they're just too damn volatile. Magnify that by three or four times for companies in burgeoning industries like cybersecurity.FireEye Inc(NASDAQ:FEYE) is a prime example of sound logic convincing you to go long
column3: only to wish you hadn't. Unless you're the Wall Street equivalent of Tom Brady
column4: you can't take the kind of hits FEYE stock has absorbed and simply get away with it.makeArticleAd();Source:David via Flickr (Modified)I mean
column5: who doesn't love cybersecurity? Whether you're talking about PC viruses or possibly altering the presidential election
column6: cybersecurity is a hot-button issue.Companies like FEYE are on the forefront of this ever-expanding and dynamic sector.Because of this distinct dynamism
column7: you'd figure that there's plenty of room for competitors. I doubt that cyber-criminals are always going to use the same tricks. Thus
column8: coming to market first may not necessarily be the absolute advantage that it is for other industries.To confirm this point
column9: FireEye stock started off with great fanfare. Investors were initially enthused by its robust momentum. But quickly
column10: FEYE stock began to lose favor. Indeed
column11: when you look at the organization topically
column12: it has never returned a profit for the year. And no
column13: I'm not going to include their extremely shortened 2013 debut.When you look at analyst coverage overall
column14: you'd be hard-pressed to find anybody sticking their neck out for FireEye stock. Jeff Reeves
column15: executive editor of InvestorPlace
column16: summed it up unambiguously when hewrote
column17: ""FEYE Stock Has Crashed for Good."" This was written in early August of 2016. Since then
column18: FEYE has lost nearly 25% in the markets.Cybersecurity Is Big Enough for FEYE StockSo is there any hope for this long-embattled company? At first
column19: the fundamentals don't look so hot for FEYE stock. As InvestorPlace writer and IPO Playbook editor Tom Taulli notes
column20: FEYE's most recentearnings reportwas terrible. More ominously
column21: their guidance for the first quarter is pedestrian
column22: to say the least
column23: and FireEye stock subsequently got pounded.8 Dividend Growth Stocks Raising The BarCompetitively
column24: FEYE has to go up against two tailwinds. Primarily
column25: they were late to the game in terms of cloud integration
column26: so they have some catch-up to do. On the broader front
column27: the company faces serious pressure from industry leadersPalo Alto Networks Inc(NYSE:PANW) andFortinet Inc(NASDAQ:FTNT).However
column28: FEYE stock also has to watch out for old guard firms likeMicrosoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT). They've got the resources to exercise their ""mid-life crisis"" of breaking into new sectors.At the same time
column29: we have to appreciate the scale of the cybersecurity landscape. According toSymantec Corporation(NASDAQ:SYMC) CEO Greg Clack
column30: 39% of North American residents have beenimpacted by cybercrimein 2016. In his words
column31: ""I think that's a very big crisis."" Naturally
column32: Mr. Clack is thinking specifically of his organization's solutions. But the reality is that FEYE has a solid chance of making up for lost ground.Furthermore
column33: con artists are constantly getting creative with theirnefarious activities. Many of these are exposed by government watchdogs
column34: but by that point
column35: the con is long gone. You can only imagine the possibilities with cybercrime. So yes
column36: FEYE stock looks absolutely terrible now
column37: I'll concede. But due to the evolving nature of cybercrime
column38: it's risky to assume that FireEye stock will forever be a dud.The Worst for FireEye Stock Is Behind ItBased on the actions of investors
column39: I think the company is in the early stages of a turnaround. Long-term
column40: the magnitude of volatility in FEYE stock is slowing significantly.Click to EnlargeFor example
column42: the average closing price for FireEye stock was $15.19. That's nearly a 60% loss from the prior year average of $37.64. But so far this year
column43: FEYE stock averages $12.22
column44: which is a more modest loss from last year of 19.6%.Another interesting point is that shares could have fallen much further than it did. Everyone agrees that 2016 was a choppy period for FEYE
column45: yet the lowest closing price last year was $11.01.Why Boeing Co (BA) Stock Will Hit Turbulence in 2017Presently
column46: the average close is 11% higher than this figure. Also
column47: its present market value is only a few cents shy of 2016's closing low. That's not a great statistic
column48: I know. But it leaves the impression that the worst of the volatility may be over.My final contrarian argument is that we're not dealing with a fly-by-night operation. FEYE CEO Kevin Mandia was a former U.S. Air Force intelligence officer
column49: and is widely considered a cybersecurity expert. This is not someone that is going to jeopardize his reputation on a whim. I'd also give FireEye stock a higher chance of success based on this much-needed
column50: highly demanded industry.Ultimately
column51: I understand the hesitation of FEYE stock. It has simply lost too much value to be termed a stable investment. But for those with some risk capital to play with
column52: FireEye stock is a compelling bet. The market losses are being pared
column53: and you have substantial intellectual firepower on the executive team.As of this writing
column54: Josh Enomoto did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace10 Dangerous Dividend Stocks to Dump Now7 Stocks to Buy That Are ALMOST in Buffett Buying RangeThe postWhy FireEye Inc (FEYE) Stock Is a Terribly Good Speculation Pickappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column2: Maximize Your Income From Dividends;3/8/2017;"Dividend investing is supposed to be a bit like watching grass grow: steady progress
column3: few surprises. But lately
column4: investors holding dividend-paying stocks have suffered some jarring setbacks.SEE ALSO:8 Great Dividend Stocks for RetireesHigher-yielding sectors such as utilities and real estate investment trusts saw valuations soar through much of 2016
column5: then suffered sharp pullbacks later in the year. Analysts see more pain ahead for high-dividend-yielding stocks as interest rates start to rise
column6: diverting income-focused investors from stocks into bonds. A stretch of stagnant earnings growth
column7: meanwhile
column8: put the brakes on the double-digit dividend growth that investors have grown accustomed to since the financial crisis. Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dividends climbed just 5% in 2016.""It's realistic to start thinking that the best might be over in terms of dividend growth
column9: says Christine Benz
column10: director of personal finance at investment-research firmMorningstar.makeAd('4'
column12: 'mktsnews'
column13: 'vanguard'
column15: '');Does this mean older investors should scale back dividend holdings? Hardly. The idea of getting income from stocks still ""makes a lot of sense
column16: particularly in this low-rate world
column17: says Tony DeSpirito
column18: co-manager ofBlackRock Equity Dividend fund. At roughly 2.5%
column19: the yield on theRussell 1000 Value Indexis about the same as the yield on the 10-year Treasury
column20: he notes. But while the Treasury bond offers a fixed coupon
column21: stocks offer potential dividend growth and share-price appreciation.The challenge is to pick the rightdividend stocksor funds. Rounding up the usual suspects--high dividend-yielding utilities
column22: REITs
column23: consumer staples and telecom stocks--may not be the best approach. One reason: You'd be ignoring some of the biggest dividend-paying sectors
column24: including technology and financials.The higher-yielding stocks also look expensive
column25: even after their late-2016 sell-off
column26: money managers say. Investors have used them as bond substitutes in a low-rate era
column27: and as rates rise
column28: these bond proxies will suffer more than lower dividend-yielders.Stocks that can deliver steady dividend growth
column29: rather than the richest yields
column30: offer the most fertile ground for dividend investors. These holdings look cheaper than the high-yielders
column31: they can hold up well in a rising-rate environment
column32: and they can offer a buffer against market volatility.You can maximize the income you get from these holdings by minimizing fees and taxes. In a dividend-focused mutual fund
column33: a lofty expense ratio can chew through most of your yield. And although the 15% tax rate paid by most investors on qualified dividends seems relatively benign
column34: many holdings favored by dividend investors and dividend funds don't get this treatment. Most REIT payouts
column35: for example
column36: are taxed as ordinary income.Follow these tips to build a dividend portfolio that can deliver reliable income despite rising rates and slowing dividend growth--so you can get back to watching the grass grow.Go for GrowthReliable dividend growers have proved resilient during the roughest times in the market. In a recent study
column37: S&P Dow Jones Indices compared the performance of dividend ""aristocrats""--S&P Composite 1500 stocks that have raised their dividends every year for at least 20 years--against high-yielding stocks in the S&P 500. During the 15 worst months for the broader stock market from the end of 1999 through September 2016
column38: the aristocrats lost 5.9%
column39: on average
column40: versus an 8.6% loss for the high-yielders and an 8.9% average decline for the S&P 1500.Thearistocrats tend to be more resilientduring the worst market downturns in part because raising dividends year after year reflects a certain level of financial health and discipline
column41: S&P notes.So where can you find dependable dividend growers at a decent price? For old-school dividend investors raised on Ma Bell and Coca-Cola
column42: the answers may be a bit surprising.One sector that's highly favored by value-minded dividend fund managers these days: technology. In 2016
column43: the sector surpassed financials to become the biggest contributor to S&P 500 dividends
column44: accounting for 15.5% of payouts.SEE ALSO:25 Dividend Stocks You Can Buy and Hold ForeverMature tech companies
column45: such as Microsoft (symbolMSFT; recent price
column47: Cisco Systems (CSCO
column48: $32) and Qualcomm (QCOM
column50: generate loads of free cash flow and are finding fewer opportunities to re-invest in their businesses
column51: says Mike Liss
column52: co-manager of theAmerican Century Value fund. That leaves them with an ""ability to increase their dividends at a rate better than the average stock
column53: Liss says.Microsoft
column54: which yields 2.3%
column55: has nearly doubled its quarterly dividend in the past five years
column56: to 39 cents a share. Money managers see more healthy dividend growth ahead as the company's leadership in cloud computing improves its earnings-growth prospects.Cisco
column57: which yields 3.3%
column58: is known for making the switches and routers that move data around computer networks. But Cisco is also expanding into faster-growing areas such as collaboration and security. The company has boosted its dividend every year since initiating its payout in 2011.Patient investors should also take a look at Qualcomm
column59: which yields 3.8%
column60: says John Buckingham
column61: chief investment officer atAFAM Capitaland manager of theAl Frank fund. The stock has been crushed this year
column62: in part because Apple is suing Qualcomm over its business practices
column63: and it now trades at just 11 times analysts' estimate of earnings in the coming year. Buckingham believes the litigation will ultimately be settled and ""the magnitude of the decline has created opportunity for those who can take a long-term view.""Look for Healthy PayoutsHealth care stocks have looked rather sickly lately. Concerns about repeal of the Affordable Care Act
column64: as well as talk from Washington about negotiating lower drug prices
column65: have weighed on the sector.But the political noise has created an opportunity for long-term dividend investors
column66: particularly in drug stocks. ""If you continue to create drugs that are innovative and meet unmet needs
column67: you're going to get premium pricing for those products
column68: Liss says.Holdings in Liss's fund include drug giants Pfizer (PFE
column69: $32) and Merck (MRK
column70: $64). Pfizer yields 3.8% and trades at just 13 times analysts' estimate of its full-year earnings. While the loss of patent protection on several drugs is a headwind
column71: the company maintains an impressive portfolio of patent-protected drugs and is launching several potential best-sellers in cancer
column72: immunology and other areas.Like Pfizer
column73: Merck has a strong pipeline of new drugs to balance out upcoming patent losses. Cancer drug Keytruda has been a notable success as the company sharpens its focus on unmet medical needs. Merck yields 2.9% and has raised its dividend six years in a row.Swiss drug giants Roche Holding (RHHBY
column74: $30) and Novartis (NVS
column75: $75) also look like good values
column76: says Matt Burdett
column77: associate portfolio manager atThornburg Investment Management. Pricey biologics
column78: which tend to have less generic competition
column79: account for a large portion of Roche's drug sales
column80: and Roche also has a strong diagnostics business. The stock yields 3.4%.Novartis
column81: which yields 3.6%
column82: is well diversified with pharmaceuticals
column83: eye care and other businesses. The company is launching several drugs in key areas such as cancer and heart failure.Guard Against Rising RatesRising rates generally aren't disastrous for dividend stocks. Looking at the two-
column84: three- and five-year periods following the initiation of Federal Reserve rate-hiking cycles dating back to 1954
column85: dividend payers have outperformed non-dividend payers
column86: according to AFAM Capital.But when interest rates rise
column87: some dividend payers do suffer. In recent research
column88: Morningstar looked at rising-rate periods from May 1953 through the end of 2016. The 30% of stocks with the highest yields lost about 1.5%
column89: on average
column90: while the 30% with the lowest yields gained 3.2%.SEE ALSO:8 Dow Dividend Stocks You Can Buy and Hold ForeverMany dividend-focused fund managers are favoring a sector that stands to benefit from rising rates: financials. As rates rise
column91: banks may see an improvement in their net interest margins--a measure of lending profitability. What's more
column92: banks are likely to see looser capital requirements and other deregulation under the new administration
column93: says Sandy Pomeroy
column94: co-manager of theNeuberger Berman Equity Income fund. With capital freed up
column95: banks may have more flexibility to boost their dividends.Many big bank stocks saw sharp run-ups after the election. One that still looks attractively valued is Bank of America (BAC
column97: says Matt Quinlan
column98: co-manager of theFranklin Income fund. At 1.1%
column99: it doesn't have the richest yield
column100: but it trades for less than book value. The bank has slowly recovered from its ill-advised 2008 acquisition of mortgage lender Countrywide Financial and has sharply cut costs in recent years.Rising rates are also ""a positive for insurance companies who have substantial dollars in fixed income
column101: Buckingham says. He likes MetLife (MET
column103: which yields 3% and trades at just 10 times analysts' estimate of its full-year earnings. The company is spinning off a U.S. retail unit
column104: a move that analysts see as helping MetLife generate more stable cash flow.Focus on FundsIf you're shopping for a dividend-focused mutual fund
column105: keep a close eye on fees. A mutual fund's expense ratio eats into its yield. So ""the relationship between expense ratio and income is quite direct
column106: Benz says.One high-quality
column107: low-cost fund is Vanguard Dividend Appreciation (VIG)
column108: an exchange-traded fund that yields 2.1% and charges just 0.09% annually. It tracks the Nasdaq U.S. Dividend Achievers Select Index
column109: which includes companies that have boosted dividends for at least 10 consecutive years.Another low-cost option: Schwab U.S. Dividend Equity ETF (SCHD). The fund tracks the Dow Jones U.S. Dividend 100 Index
column110: which includes companies that not only have paid dividends for 10 years in a row but also have strong cash-flow-to-debt ratios
column112: dividend yield and dividend growth. The fund yields 2.9% and charges just 0.07% annually.Investors looking to avoid the highest yielders might also consider iShares Core Dividend Growth ETF (DGRO). It tracks the Morningstar U.S. Dividend Growth Index
column113: which excludes stocks with yields in the top 10% of the broader stock universe. The fund charges 0.08% annually and yields 2.3%.Whether you're choosing a dividend-focused fund or picking your own stocks
column114: pay attention to the potential tax hit. Qualified dividends
column115: which include most U.S. stock dividends
column116: get favorable tax treatment. Taxpayers in the 25% to 35% tax brackets pay 15% on qualified dividends. Taxpayers in the 10% and 15% brackets pay zero; those above the 35% bracket pay 20%. If your adjusted gross income is more than $200
column119: you'll owe an additional 3.8% on your net investment income
column120: including qualified dividends.But many holdings favored by dividend investors don't pay qualified dividends. Payouts from REITs
column121: some foreign stocks and convertibles can be taxed as ordinary income. With master limited partnerships
column122: a large chunk of distributions is typically tax-deferred
column123: but investors may pay a combination of capital-gains and ordinary-income tax rates when they sell their units.""It's worth looking under the hood"" of dividend-focused funds because many of these funds hold non-qualified dividend payers
column124: Benz says. She points toAmerican Century Equity Income
column125: which is a high-quality fund but tends to hold some non-qualified dividend payers such as convertibles. The fund's 10-year tax-cost ratio is 1.8
column127: meaning that investors have lost an average annual 1.8% of assets to taxes. Investors inVanguard Dividend Appreciation Index fund
column129: have sacrificed far less to taxes
column130: losing an average annual 0.73% over the period.Another taxing question for dividend investors is whether to hold foreign dividend-paying stocks--or funds that invest in those stocks--in an IRA. Many countries withhold taxes from dividends that their companies pay to overseas investors. U.S. investors are taxed a second time on those dividends
column131: either when they report dividend income for their taxable accounts or withdraw money from their IRA. You can claim a foreign tax credit on your federal return for the taxes withheld by the foreign country--but only if you hold the stocks in a taxable account. If you hold the investments in an IRA
column132: there's no way to recoup the foreign taxes paid.""If you have an IRA and a taxable account
column133: put the foreign stocks or foreign stock funds into the taxable account
column135: a financial adviser atBurke Financial Strategies
column137: N.J. But there's a caveat: Companies in countries that don't have a tax treaty with the U.S. may pay non-qualified dividends
column138: making them a poor fit for a taxable account. Most countries have a tax treaty with the U.S.
column139: but there are significant exceptions such as Brazil
column140: Chile and Singapore.TAKE OUR QUIZ:Test Your Investing IQ"

column1: Microsoft's Slack Rival Is Almost Ready for Prime Time;3/7/2017;"Watch out
column2: Slack.Microsoft(NASDAQ: MSFT) is coming after you.The software giant launched a Slack rival called Microsoft   Teams inNovember
column3: leveraging the stronger Microsoft brand instead of calling it   Skype Teams
column4: which Microsoft had been rumored to be considering.   At the time
column5: it was a limited launch with only a handful of   customers being able to preview the offering. Microsoft is now   ready to roll out Microsoft Teams with general availability
column6: making good on its prior target of the first quarter of 2017 for   general availability.A week from today
column7: Microsoft will host an online event to   launch Microsoft Teams more broadly.makeArticleAd();Microsoft Teams looks an awful lot like Slack. Image source:     Microsoft.Bundled pricing undercuts SlackMicrosoft Teams has a lot of potential
column8: mostly thanks to   Microsoft's already-strong position within enterprise   productivity software. By including Microsoft Teams in certain   bundles of Office 365 and promising deeper integrations with   Office
column9: the company can make a compelling pitch to enterprise   customers. Combined with the fact that the interface is nearly   identical
column10: the switching costs for users would be fairly   manageable as well since Microsoft Teams will feel familiar for   Slack users.In terms of pricing
column11: here are the Office 365 plans that   include Teams. The more expensive plans include many other   features beyond Teams.PlanCost (Annual Commitment)Cost (Monthly Commitment)Office 365 Business Essentials$5 per user per month$6 per user per monthOffice 365 Business Premium$12.50 per user per month$15 per user per monthOffice 365 Enterprise E1$8 per user per monthN/AOffice 365 Enterprise E3$20 per user per monthN/AOffice 365 Enterprise E5$35 per user per monthN/AData source: Microsoft.Compare those prices with Slack's offerings (not including   Slack's free tier).PlanCost (Annual Commitment)Cost (Monthly Commitment)Slack Standard$6.67 per user per month$8 per user per monthSlack Plus$12.50 per user per month$15 per user per monthData source: Slack.Considering how much more is included in the various Office   365 plans
column12: Microsoft has the potential to deliver quite a bit of   value compared to Slack
column13: since Slack's prices only include its   chat offering. To be clear
column14: Slack is a great chat and   collaboration tool
column15: but Microsoft can appeal better to a limited   IT budget while replicating many of the things that make Slack so   good (which is also why investors should berelieved that Microsoft didn't spend $8 billion   to acquire Slack). That's a key benefit of Microsoft's scale
column16: since it has plenty   of development resources and can compete aggressively
column17: bundling   Teams with a slew of other offerings.Slack announced Slack Enterprise Grid in January
column18: which is   better equipped to handle the needs of larger organizations.   Pricing information is not publicly listed
column19: and prospective   enterprise customers need to get in touch with Slack to negotiate   rates.It's also worth pointing out that Microsoftisn't the only tech giantthat wants a piece of Slack's market share
column20: so this market is   only going to get more competitive.10 stocks we like better than MicrosoftWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column7: Russian regulator Roskomnadzor said the agency rejected the LinkedIn bid after it refused to move storage sites holding personal data of Russian users to that country
column8: ""confirming its lack of interest in working on the Russian market"".A LinkedIn spokesman responding by email Reuters told the news company it was unable to negotiate a compromise acceptable to both sides.""While we believe we comply with all applicable laws
column9: and despite conversations with Roskomnadzor - including meeting with them in Moscow in December 2016 - we have been unable to reach an understanding that would see them lift the block on LinkedIn in the Russian Federation

column1: Will Salesforce.com
column2: Inc. (CRM) Sell Out to International Business Machines Corp. (IBM)?;3/7/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsSalesforce.com
column4: Inc.(NYSE:CRM)
column5: whose rapid growth makes up for a compelling shortage of earnings
column6: warned shareholders that its first quarter may not be what they hope for. Investors have yet to show their feelings by fleeing CRM stock
column7: however.makeArticleAd();Source:TopoI6 Via FlickrInstead
column8: analysts listened to the soothing tones of its earnings call
column9: where the company bragged about its past and predicted $10 billion in revenue for the coming year.Few seem to have noticed the fine print.Profits for the first quarterare going to be down. That $10 billion in revenue is not going to represent much growth over the fourth quarter's $2.3 billion sale rate.Slower growth could hammer the stock
column10: whose market cap of $57 billion means a price to sales ratio of 5.7
column11: assuming the company meets its estimates. That's a ratio comparable to that ofAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOGL)
column12: only without the profits of Google.For CRM stock
column13: the future is now. But perhaps
column14: by forging an alliance withInternational Business Machines Corp.(NYSE:IBM)
column15: its future now might be in its past.Looking Beyond the CloudSalesforce has more than doubled its revenues since 2012 based on cloud applications. The company's ticker symbol
column16: CRM
column17: stands for Customer Relationship Management
column18: the first major enterprise database application to move from corporate data centers into less-expensive clouds. But since then the company has built a full suite of such applications
column19: and all have been successful.7 Stocks That Will Hit All-Time Lows in 2017The enterprise cloud has been very
column20: very good for Salesforce.com
column21: and competitors have done more than take notice. Cloud is now the default home of major database applications. Competitors likeMicrosoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT)
column22: Oracle Corporation(NYSE:ORCL) and IBM all now brag about the size of their clouds
column23: and the sophistication of enterprise applications built on them.The S-shaped ""sales curve
column24: of slow growth in a new market
column25: rocket-like growth as mass markets adopt something and slower growth once that is achieved
column26: is approaching the end of the line for cloud. CRM stock bulls insist that things like the internet of thingswill keep growth going
column27: but each new niche now brings big-time competitors with it
column28: such asGeneral Electric Company(NYSE:GE)
column29: which calls its industrial IoT cloud Predix.Alliance TimeAs markets mature
column30: they consolidate. Competitors pair up
column31: starting with alliances
column32: then moving naturally toward mergers. Having fewer competitors means they can maintain pricing
column33: and margins
column34: even as growth slows.This is why some analysts are pushinga merger-of-equals that won't happenbetween Salesforce andAdobe Systems Inc.(NASDAQ:ADBE)
column35: whose ""Creative Cloud"" applications would seem a natural fit.Salesforce's strategy has been to pick-off smaller application spaces as they appear
column36: as with its 2016 buy ofDemandware
column37: which serves online merchants
column38: acquired for $2.8 billion. The company made10 acquisitions during 2016
column39: and in January it continued this withSequence
column40: which designs user interfaces
column41: a business now dubbed UX for User Experience.As a software house
column42: rather than a hardware company
column43: Salesforce has always had to manage its hosting carefully. Its original code came from Oracle
column44: and the companies have had a fraught existence. So over the years
column45: Salesforce has added Microsoft andAmazon.com Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) toits partner list
column46: although these relationships are
column47: like love
column48: subject to change on the first suspicion of betrayal.Snap Inc (SNAP) Stock: Stay Away at All Costs!You canadd IBM to the list. Salesforce will now mix its data with IBM's Watson - a quick route into artificial intelligence and
column49: perhaps
column50: into IBM itself.Where the Ride Ends for CRM StockI believe the end of the ride for Salesforce is in sight and IBM would make a compelling destination. IBM now sells at half its sales
column51: its revenues have been declining for years
column52: and Salesforce could halt that slide. With CEO Virginia Rometty approaching 60
column53: often a retirement age at Big Blue
column54: Benioff might make a natural successor at age 52.Benioff would also give IBM a more entrepreneurial face
column55: and IBM would give him a much bigger playing field on which to perform cloud magic. He has been telling all who would listen that a ""roaring"" market meansSalesforce is not interested in acquisitions.How about a sale?Dana Blankenhornis a financial and technology journalist. His latest novel isBridget O'Flynn vs. Something Big & Ugly.Write him atdanablankenhorn@gmail.comor follow him on Twitter at@danablankenhorn. As of this writing
column56: he was long AMZN
column57: GOOGL and MSFT.The postWill Salesforce.com
column58: Inc. (CRM) Sell Out to International Business Machines Corp. (IBM)?appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd (BABA) Stock Can Still Win BIG in Cloud;3/7/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAlibaba Group Holding Ltd(NYSE:BABA) founder and Executive Chairman Jack Ma has a lot of irons in the fire; nowhere is that truer than in his fight to take onAmazon.com
column3: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) in the global race for enterprise cloud computing dominance. Right now
column4: it's not even close - Amazon is leading by a country mile
column5: but BABA is quickly closing the gap between the two and that's a good thing if you own Alibaba stock.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockAmazonenteredthe cloud computing business in 2006. Amazon Web Services (AWS) now generates more than $3.1 billion in operating income (fiscal 2016) from $12.2 billion in revenue
column6: a juicy operating margin of 25.4%.This was considerably higher than the $1.1 billion it generated from $123.8 billion (0.90% operating margin) in revenue from its e-commerce and Amazon Prime membership fees.It's easy to understand why BABA wants in on Amazon's action - there's lots of money to be made from the cloud.What's Going on With Alibaba Stock and the Cloud?In Q3 2016
column7: Alibaba went over the $1 billion annual run rate in cloud computing revenue generating $254 million from 765
column8: 000 paying customers
column9: up 115% and 100% year-over-year respectively. Most importantly
column10: its cloud computing business had an operating loss of just $49 million
column11: 18.3% less than its Q2 2016 operating loss of$60 million.That's great news for Alibaba stock because at this rate
column12: it should be in the black by sometime in fiscal 2017 and that will add to the already significant operating profits it generates from its core e-commerce business -$4 billionin the third quarter alone
column13: a mouth-watering operating margin of 59.7%.7 Stocks That Will Hit All-Time Lows in 2017Put another way
column14: BABA's cloud computing segment along with its other money-losing businesses lost $976 million in the third quarter on revenue of $961 million; essentially
column15: it lost a dollar for every dollar of revenue.That's insane.Alibaba generated$5.5 billionin operating profit through the first nine months of fiscal 2016 despite losses in other areas totaling $2.8 billion. Amazon generated $4.2 billion in operating income from more than 10 times the revenue.There are many reasons why you might want to own Amazon's stock (Jeff Bezosis a big one) but consider how valuable BABA stock would be were its cloud computing business generating operating profit margins similar to AWS.Alibaba's cloud computing business would go from an annual loss of $225 million ($169 million operating loss in Q3 2016 on an annualized basis) on $1 billion in revenue to an operating profit of $250 million on the same revenue
column16: a $475 million difference.""Our goal is to overtake Amazon in four years
column17: whether that's in customers
column18: technology
column19: or worldwide scale
column20: Simon Hu
column21: the head of Alibaba's cloud businesstoldReutersin 2015. ""Amazon
column22: Microsoft and others have already laid the groundwork for us by educating the markets about cloud in the U.S. and Europe
column23: so we have an even better opportunity to join in the competition.""Estimates put the global cloud computing business at $20 billion. However
column24: given Amazon's AWS revenue in 2016 was $12.2 billion
column25: Microsoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT) is coming on in this area and thought to be in thesecondspot behind AMZN and Alibaba's annual run rate is over $1 billion
column26: the number is likely much higher.Why Facebook Inc (FB) Stock Could Have More Problems Than You ThinkAccording to TechCrunch
column27: Synergy Research Group analyst John Dinsdale revealed that ""For cloud infrastructure services (IaaS
column28: PaaS
column29: Hosted Private Cloud services) Alibaba is now ranked sixth
column30: based on worldwide revenues in Q4. For China specifically
column31: while AWS and Microsoft are in the top five ranking in China
column32: the market is led by Alibaba (a long way out in front) followed by China Telecom. Alibaba market share is running at 40 percent [in China] and has been increasing with time.""Bottom Line on BABA StockInterestingly
column33: the fact that BABA stock was late to the cloud computing party
column34: might actually work in its favor because large companies are far more open to working in the cloud these days than they were a decade ago when Amazon got in the business.Therefore
column35: you could argue that the company's investment in the cloud
column36: albeit several billion dollars
column37: is still far less risky than Amazon's initial moves back in 2006.While there are many tentacles to the Alibaba stock
column38: cloud computing is one that will continue to reap dividends for BABA stock in the years to come.As of this writing
column39: Will Ashworth did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace7 Telecom Stocks That Are High-Yield Money Traps5 Blue-Chip Stocks to Buy in MarchThe postAlibaba Group Holding Ltd (BABA) Stock Can Still Win BIG in Cloudappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: 6 Things You Didn't Know About Baidu
column2: Inc.;3/6/2017;"Many tech investors are probably familiar with the basic facts   aboutBaidu(NASDAQ: BIDU) -- it's the biggest search engine in China
column3: it has   a growing ecosystem of cloud-based services likeAlphabet's(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) Google
column4: and it benefited greatly   from Google's exit from the mainland Chinese market in 2010.Those are the bullet points in the growth story that boosted   Baidu stock by nearly 1
column5: 500% over the past decade. But today
column6: we'll take a look at six lesser-known facts about the ""Chinese   Google"" which many investors might have overlooked.Image source: Author's screenshot.makeArticleAd();1. CEO Robin Li cut his teeth in the U.S. tech     industryAfter earning a master's degree in Computer Science from the   University of Buffalo
column7: Baidu co-founder and CEO Robin Li worked   at Dow Jones & Co.'s IDD Information Services and search   company Infoseek in the  1990s.At IDD
column8: Li developed the software for the online version ofThe Wall Street Journaland invented his patented Rankdex site-scoring algorithm for    SEO rankings -- which currently powers Baidu's search   engine. At Infoseek
column9: Li created the image search function
column10: which   was subsequently used inDisney's Go.com network. After spending over five years at those two   companies
column11: Li returned to China and co-founded Baidu with   investor Eric Xu in early 2000.2. Baidu is developing driverless carsLike Google
column12: Baidu believes that autonomous electric cars   would be a natural extension of its data mining ecosystem. The   company started testing out driverless cars on public roads in   late 2015
column13: and formed a driverless tech research center in   Silicon Valley last April.Image source: Getty Images.Baidu is powering these vehicles with a combination ofNVIDIA's automotive chips
column14: HERE Maps
column15: and its own AI algorithms. It's   currently outsourcing production of these vehicles to Chinese   automakers
column16: and has declared that it will launch an autonomous   shuttle bus  by 2018.3. It's beefing up its AI effortsFor search engines like Baidu and Google
column17: AI plays a key role   in recognizing images
column18: analyzing search patterns
column19: and deciding   what types of targeted ads will appeal to users. That's why Baidu   hired a lot of top talent in AI -- its chief scientist Andrew Ng   previously helmed the Google Brain AI project
column20: and its new   augmented reality chief Qi Lu was previously an AI specialist atMicrosoft.Baidu hasn't been shy about challenging Google in the AI arms   race. In January

column1: These Catalysts Will Give the Fintech Industry Its Next Leg Up;3/6/2017;"The financial technologies industry has been one of the few breakout markets over the last 10 years. column3: there is a huge debate regarding the penetration of mobile payments amongst consumers as some still question the security of their personal information. Even revolutionary mobile wallets such asApple(AAPL) Pay are yet to gain traction as previously predicted
column4: despite employing the use of fingerprint technology to execute transactions.As such
column5: it appears the initial hype about the industry being revolutionary in the financial payments market has recently stalled.makeArticleAd();Nonetheless
column6: this industry could yet be set for the next leg up thanks to an array of catalysts that seem to be building up behind the scenes. The fintech industry is now more than just about payments. It is stretching its wings to credit
column7: the stock market and traditional banking institutions. These could hold the key to its growth and development over the next few years.Credit and insuranceThis area of the fintech industry is still at the early stages of development with just a few players embracing the paradigm shift in the market. Right now
column8: you can easily get asset finance loans
column9: insurance premium financing and payday loans from various online platforms
column10: including mobile devices and web portals.For instance
column11: Rob Sinclair Equipment is an Australia-based revolutionary asset finance platform that specializes in financing the purchase of equipment in the transport industry. According to the company
column12: the segmentation of the fintech industry could be the key to boosting growth at the consumer level. Rob Sinclair notes more customers are showing the willingness to embrace various aspects of the industry when the companies they deal with specialize in a few segments rather than offering generalized products.In addition
column13: the introduction of mobile applications has opened the doors for financial services companies to bring their products closer to their customers. While mobile wallets are the most popular in that respect
column14: credit and insurance providers are beginning to join in on the action. Most companies are coming in to act as a link between mainstream banking institutions and consumers. With the help of mobile applications
column15: customers can now apply for loans while on the move and get approval within minutes.Blockchain and algorithmic tradingThe stock market is pretty much the leading option when it comes to investing. A few things
column16: however
column17: have changed over the last decade or so. Investors are adapting to new methods of participating in the market and even some of the top hedge funds have started to embrace the change.Algorithmic trading is slowly becoming a norm amongst investors
column18: but a few tweaks still need to be made in order to make it a widely accepted method of trading. Some countries have stiff regulations when it comes to high-frequency trading while security threats still hover for online traders.With many countries now realizing the changes that have been taking place in the stock market over the last few years
column19: however
column20: a more accommodative regulatory framework could be in the making. Additionally
column21: with network technologies such as blockchain already proving reliable
column22: the security threat posed to online traders could be trimmed to the bare minimum.Blockchain is a network infrastructure that has been growing in popularity over the last few years due to the success of various applications such as bitcoin
column23: which run on the network. In fact

column25: which could signal a show of reliability and boost adoption.ConclusionIn summary

column27: there are a few under the radar business segments in this industry that could trigger the next leg up.The main challenge has been to get customers to feel at ease about linking personal data to some of these technologies

column29: as noted

column1: Better Buy: Amazon.com
column2: Inc. vs. Microsoft;3/6/2017;"They're two of the five largest publicly traded companies in   the world. column3: their recent histories

column5: to determine which   tech stalwart represents the better stock to buy today.Financial fortitudeThough both companies are financial behemoths

column7: Yahoo! Finance.Microsoft and Amazon are in fine financial shape. However

column9: it earns a   win in this category by beating the world's largest e-commerce   provider in three categories. Plus

column13: likeApple

column16: but its annual 10-K filing   showed that it kept approximately 96% overseas. But since it   generates plenty of operating cash flow to fund its domestic and   international operations
column17: this is really a non-issue for   investors.Winner: Microsoft.Durable competitive advantagesMicrosoft and Amazon.com each enjoy competitive advantages
column18: albeit of different sorts. Amazon's primary moats are its scale   and risk-taking culture. At this point

column20: accounting for 91% of revenue in   2016. As the world's largest e-commerce site by revenue
column21: Amazon has an incredible scale that allows it to consistently   offer low prices. More impressive still

column23: Fulfillment by Amazon
column24: third-party ads on Amazon.com
column25: and so on -- allows it to charge   the lowest prices possible on its e-commerce site

column27: which is at the core of Amazon's strategy and touches on its   unique culture.Image Source: Amazon.comTo create a culture that could invent profit centers to buoy   its low- or even negative-margin e-commerce sales
column28: Amazon CEO   Jeff Bezos and his team needed to create a culture where   risk-taking and unconventional thinking were the norm. Bezos   summarized risk-taking's foundational place in Amazon's culture   in the 2015 annual letter:A word about corporate cultures: For better or for worse
column29: they are enduring
column30: stable

column33: Amazon never would have   had the audaciousness and vision to launch many of its most   important initiatives

column58: TAXES
column59: DEPRECIATION
column60: AND AMORTIZATION. Data source: Yahoo!   Finance.Here we get a great comparison of two investing styles --   growth versus value. Neither comes out ahead here. More   conservative investors who prefer to own stocks with something of   a margin of safety will probably be drawn to Microsoft
