column1: What Investors Missed in the Market This Week;3/4/2017;"More evidence that the economy continued to chug along came   this week when the Institute for Supply Management said its   non-manufacturing index jumped 110 basis points from January to   February
column2: and reached 57.6%. For context
column3: any rating above 50%   means more businesses are expanding. The 57.6% rating was the   highest since October 2015
column4: and the expansion of 16 of the 18   sectors was the highest number since the middle of 2014.In broader news
column5: the S&P 500 finished with its   sixth-consecutive weekly gain
column6: and the Dow tallied its   fourth-consecutive weekly gain. All that aside
column7: there were some   major headlines and moves in the markets this week. Let's hit   some highlights.A successful IPOImage source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();If you're an investor
column8: or just casually follow the markets
column9: chances are you heard aboutSnap Inc.'s(NYSE: SNAP) successful IPO on Thursday. The company announced   a day prior to the IPO that it would sell 200 million shares for   $17 per share
column10: which was the largest U.S. IPO since 2014.   Although the company has never turned a profit
column11: investors jumped   on board the IPO wagon
column12: sending its shares up 44%
column14: when shares hit the market on Thursday.The IPO made a lot of people rich
column15: including Snap CEO Evan   Spiegel
column16: who sold at least $272 million worth of shares and still   owns roughly $3.6 billion
column17: according to MarketWatch. Snap's IPO   raised almost $2.5 billion for the parent company and another $1   billion for the founders and early investors.But now the real work begins
column18: because Snap just as easily   could go the way of Twitter
column19: which declined consistently after   its IPO
column20: rather than Facebook
column21: which became a tech juggernaut in   the years following its IPO. Snap has roughly 158 million users   -- mostly between the ages of 18 and 24 -- and is growing.Now
column22: it's just a matter of if and when Snap can better   monetize its growing user base consistently. This is a task much   easier said than done -- just ask Twitter.Bad opticsEvery kiss begins with Kay
column23: but that brand image might not be   what consumers and investors think of first forSignet Jewelers Ltd(NYSE: SIG)
column24: the owner of Kay Jeweler and Jared
column25: among others.   TheWashington Postreported that hundreds of former employees claimed the company's   CEO and other management members allowed a corporate culture of   sexual harassment and discrimination.The attorneys were only granted permission to release the   statements publicly Sunday
column26: and the headlines sent shares of   Signet Jewelers stock down roughly 13% during intra-day trading   on Tuesday. No matter how you slice the issue
column27: it's bad for   the jewelry company
column28: especially in today's easily offended and   social-media-intensive world.Going forward
column29: a class-action hearing is scheduled for early   next year
column30: when witnesses will be called to testify before an   arbitration judge for the first time. Currently
column31: Signet Jewelers   trades at a forward price-to-earnings ratio of eight
column32: per   Morningstar.com estimates
column33: which could tempt value investors. If   you find yourself in that camp
column34: buyer beware -- this will be   something to watch over the next couple of years.An aging dinosaurShares of video game retailerGameStop(NYSE: GME) received yet another reminder that its business is   going to be an uphill battle as more consumers opt to purchase   video games online. On Tuesday
column35: Microsoft(NASDAQ: MSFT) announced a subscription service for Xbox One that   will give full access to over 100 older video games.The service
column36: named Xbox Game Pass
column37: gives consumers another way   to pass the GameStop brick-and-mortar stores
column38: and could easily   create a headwind for the game company's sales of both new and   used video games. Investors were quick to react to Microsoft's   announcement and sent GameStop shares quickly down 10% during   intra-day trading.In my opinion
column39: GameStop is an aging dinosaur that looks to be   heading the way of Blockbuster in an increasingly digital world.   The company's top and bottom lines have been stagnant since 2010.   Without a growth story
column40: in addition to an increasingly digital   world
column41: there doesn't seem to be much value left in owning shares.   So it's no surprise that the company trades at a paltry 6.7 times   forward earnings
column42: per Morningstar.com estimates.10 stocks we like better than Snap Inc.When investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column43: it can pay to listen. After all
column44: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column45: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column46: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Snap Inc. wasn't one of     them! column1: Inside Snapchat: The Biggest Tech IPO Since Facebook;3/3/2017;"Snap Inc.SNAP
column2: parent company of Snapchat
column3: recently made its historic market debut. It was the second-largest U.S.-based technology IPO ever
column4: behind only FacebookFB
column5: one of its key industry competitors no less.Snapchat is one of the most popular messaging and social media apps on the market today. It humbly began as a class project by former Stanford University students Evan Spiegel (now CEO)
column6: Reggie Brown
column7: and Bobby Murphy. (For an inside look at Mr. Spiegel
column8: check out this Zacks article:Can Snapchat's Evan Spiegel Be the Next Mark Zuckerberg?)Launched officially in 2012
column9: Snapchat allows users to take photos
column10: record videos
column11: add text and drawings
column12: and send them to a controlled list of recipients. These photos and videos disappear within 1-10 seconds-the amount is up to the sender-after the recipient views them.What Makes Snapchat So Popular?You know you're doing something right when huge tech corporations begincopyingall of your ideas. Giants like Facebook and MicrosoftMSFThave spent the better part of four years trying to emulate Snapchat
column13: debuting new tools and features that are shamelessly similar to what the startup is known for.What makes the app so compelling?Ever since its debut
column14: Snapchat has steadily climbed the social media ranks
column15: having gained the top spot among teenagers over TwitterTWTR
column16: Facebook
column17: and even Instagram (though the photo-sharing app is swiftly closing ranks). According toMashable
column18: who cited a Piper Jaffray study
column20: 500 U.S. teens were polled ""to see what they felt was the most important social network
column21: and Snapchat took 28% of votes. Instagram came in close-second with 27%
column22: followed by Twitter and Facebook.""Over the last year or so
column23: Snapchat has been launching new unique feature after new unique feature
column24: introducing things like Snapchat Discover
column25: expanding its video and picture filter library
column26: and partnering with events like the Oscars
column27: where the app let its users watch live behind-the-scenes footage of the red carpet and the actual show.Teenagers love Snapchat
column28: and teenagers are a coveted demographic for any tech company. The study both demonstrates Snapchat's incredible ability in capturing this fickle group of people
column29: as well as why teenagers prefer this kind of digital platform.Ephemeral EngagementSnapchat is a social
column30: ephemeral experience that favors photos and videos over text-based media
column31: and the company has made these qualities a priority in its development and business model. Engagement is not new for social media applications. In fact
column32: it is very important to all social media companies
column33: as engagement is the driving revenue factor
column34: besides advertising. Snapchat
column35: though
column36: is approaching it in a completely different way.Harvard Business School (HBS) Professors Marco Iansiti and Karim Lakhanioffer an interesting perspectiveon this idea. In an introduction to the elective course ""Digital Innovation and Transformation"" presented in HBS's Digital Initiative
column37: Iansiti and Lakhani argue that Snapchat is ""not just a messaging system
column38: but also a social network
column39: community
column40: and an ad platform.""Most importantly
column41: Snapchat is anephemeralsocial network
column42: community
column43: and ad platform. Their unique
column44: yet increasingly popular application method is a major contributing factor to their success.Iansiti and Lakhani continue
column45: arguing that ""Snapchat provides a window into this challenging question: what drives value creation and capture in today's digital economy?"" In other words
column46: Snapchat offers a business model perfect for our current digitized economy
column47: monetizing ephemerality in an innovative way.Advertising & VideoNot only is Snap monetizing ideas
column48: but it is also attempting to make money off its intensely high user base-the company has roughly 100 million daily active users-by introducing transient advertisements that disappear after a set amount of time.This is a basic
column49: yet clever
column50: business move for the company. The combination of a large user base and high daily activity is a goldmine for advertisers. Snap recognizes this
column51: and smartly charges an astounding $750
column52: 000 minimum for a day of advertising. By charging per day instead of the usual per click
column53: the company is letting go of the typical internet advertising model.The price may be staggering for some
column54: but because of Snapchat's huge
column55: engaged audience
column56: their early ad products have attracted big-name buyers like McDonald'sMCD
column57: SamsungSSNLF
column58: Macy'sM
column59: and ComcastCMCSA-owned Universal Studios.Video is another medium that Snapchat is capitalizing off of. According to a recentBloombergreport
column60: Snapchat is now getting around 10 billion video views a day
column61: with more than a third from its ""Stories"" feature. This figure is impressive because Snapchat is mobile-only. In comparison
column62: Facebook's last reported video count was 8 billion daily views
column63: which includes both mobile and desktop traffic.The issue of what counts as a video
column64: however
column65: may be a potential problem for the app going forward. Snapchat's videos are only a few seconds long
column66: and most of the videos disappear once they are viewed. The company will need to clarify what they see as a video view in order to accurately paint a convincing picture.Problems to ConsiderDespite all of the company's positive aspects
column67: Snapchat does not come without controversy. Because of its ephemeral platform
column68: Snapchat has been associated with sexting
column69: a news topic that garners wide public attention whenever reported on. To some
column70: the app is a perfect tool for sexting
column71: as any inappropriate content quickly disappears.The company has also been caught in racial controversies. On last April 20
column72: the unofficial marijuana holiday
column73: Snapchat released a new face filter meant to make users look like late reggae legend Bob Marley. The filter adds a Marley-style hat
column74: dreadlocks
column75: and darkens users' skin town
column76: which had some people dubbing the filter as a form of digital blackface.And also last year
column77: Snapchat released a filter lens that caused users' faces to look like caricatures of Asian people
column78: with shut eyes and rosy cheeks. Snapchat toleThe Vergethat ""the lens was inspired by anime
column79: and was meant to be playful."" It was eventually taken down
column80: and will not be put back into circulation.Snap also lost a number of executives after brief stays during its time as a startup. In 2014
column81: the company lost Peter Magnusson
column82: who was the VP of Engineering
column83: after six months. And in 2015
column84: revenue boss Mike Randall leaving after a short
column85: seven-month stint
column86: with COO Emily White and HR chief Sara Sperling departing that year as well. Shannon Petranoff
column87: a former Paramount VP who joined Snapchat in March of 2015
column88: returned back to Paramount that September
column89: while Jill Hazelbaker
column90: VP of communications and policy
column91: left for Uber after a year at Snap.An IPO for the Ages?The hype surrounding Snap's IPO was
column92: to put it bluntly
column93: insane. The company originally priced its initial public offering at $17 per share
column94: which came in above the expected range of $14 to $16 per share and valued Snap at $24 billion. However
column95: because of such high demand
column96: SNAP stock started trading on the NYSE at $24 a share
column97: rising as high as $26.05 at one point during the day.More than 200 million shares
column98: which was the entire size of the offering
column99: changed hands over the course of the day and accounted for roughly 10% of the total volume of trading on the NYSE; Snap's IPO ended up being 12 times oversubscribed
column100: meaning there were 12 times more orders than there were shares offered. Shares of Snap closed their first day of trading up 44% to $24.48 per share
column101: boosting its market cap to roughly $33 billion.CEO Evan Spiegel has always recognized the importance of an IPO
column102: andtoldRe/codeat its annual conference back in 2015 that ""[Snap] needs to IPO. We have a plan to do that."" He did not give details back then but stressed that ""an IPO is really important."" Now that the company has made that giant step
column103: its eager investors are wondering what's next for the company.Since its launch
column104: Snap has molded itself as a company for the digital age and technology-grounded economy
column105: and huge corporations wanted in from the get-go. Back in 2013
column106: the company caught the attention of both Facebook and Alphabet Inc.'sGOOGLGoogle division. They offered to acquire Snapchat for $3 billion and $4 billion
column107: respectively. In a bold
column108: but smart move
column109: Snapchat turned down both offers
column110: with attention from investors rising exponentially as a result from the decision.Snap's primary demographic
column112: and ephemeral business model made the company quite the IPO catch. Despite having made no money yet-Snap lost $514.6 million in 2016
column113: and warns that it ""may never achieve or maintain profitability
column114: according to its IPO prospectus-these things
column117: marking an IPO for the ages.Interested in the other top stories of the week? Listen to Zacks Friday Finish Line to catch up on the week's financial and investment news.Everything You Need to Know About Snapchat's IPO   NowYou may be curious about the buzz surrounding Snap Inc.'s IPO
column118: but should you snap up this tech stock? In the2017 IPO Watch List
column119: you'll get an inside look at Snap's exciting prospects and potential challenges.You'll also learn about 4 other exciting tech companies with jaw-dropping growth. Each could go public in the coming months. Imagine being in the first wave of investors to jump on a company with almost unlimited growth potential? column1: Nokia Corp (ADR) (NOK) Hopes Old Phone Revival Can Help NOK Stock;3/3/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsThe high-tech world is still buzzing afterNokia Corp (ADR)(NYSE:NOK) andBlackBerry Ltd(NASDAQ:BBRY) showed off new handsets at last weekend's Mobile World Conference. However
column3: I'm not sure nostalgia for candy bar phones and keyboard PDAs draws the right kind of attention to either company.makeArticleAd();Source:Open Grid Scheduler / Grid Engine via Flickr (Modified)For one
column4: NOK never really left the ""dumb"" end of the phone market behind
column5: so the company's grand ""return"" with a new version of its near-indestructible 3310 handset - popular in 2001 at a price around $120 - is only a shock to people who stopped paying attention
column6: which they did for a reason.Granted
column7: the feature phones that NOK recently pulled back out ofMicrosoft Corporation's(NASDAQ:MSFT) orbit accounted for 9% of the category last year
column8: but that No. 2 share behindSamsung Electronic(OTCMKTS:SSNLF) only added up to 35 million handsets
column9: or at best 2% of the global phone market.A Lesson in Scale for NOK StockSure
column10: it's remotely possible that the return of the 3310 at $50 will somehow dramatically reverse 16 years of technology progress
column11: and be enough to convince a new generation of back-to-basics consumers to trade in their smartphones
column12: I find it unlikely.7 Stocks That Will Hit All-Time Highs in 2017I just don't see that happening here in numbers that even double NOK's market share
column13: and even if it does
column14: an extra 35 million $50 handsets sold close to cost really isn't going to move the needle for NOK stock. Even if the company manages to book half the retail price on each phone as revenue
column15: it's going to take 120 million of them to add 10% to the top line.That's the real lesson of scale here. NOK never went away; it's still a big company
column16: built on the chassis of the old Alcatel and Lucent networking businesses. Now that it has its phones back from MSFT
column17: management needs to deploy them to embrace the future and expand on the role the company wants to play in the Internet of Things (IoT).To me
column18: that means developing phones that don't compete withApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) or Samsung for consumer pocket space
column19: but ones that instead let smart devices communicate with each other. Consider that
column20: in a world of billions of $50 machine-to-machine data relays
column21: the market becomes very interesting for NOK stock investors.It's a similar story for BBRY
column22: which was evolving nicely into an IoT proposition
column23: until now. We may feel nostalgic for the days of a ubiquitous business BlackBerry
column24: but that era was over more than a decade ago. We've since learned to type on virtual keyboards.7 Stocks to Buy That Are ALMOST in Buffett Buying RangeThe question I have about the next generation of BBRY devices revolves around what great things they can do to win consumers away from the iPhones and Androids that already dominate the market. They need to trigger a revolution and not just recapitulate the past.The bottom line is
column25: as interesting as it was to get a blast from the past from these two companies
column26: I just don't see this strategy being a boon for either stock right now.Hilary Kramer is the editor ofGameChangers

column17: but instead of ''shares'' investors are actually buying and selling ''units''. These ''units'' can be traded back and forth just like stocks
column18: but can also be created or destroyed to accommodate investor demand. Each week we monitor the week-over-week change in shares outstanding data

column20: while destruction of units involves selling underlying holdings

column13: apps and smart devices across the country
column14: shows the Seattle-based e-commerce giant isn't infallible
column15: after all. But
column16: don't hold your breath thinking this glitch will put a damper on AMZN stock.According to the company's statement
column17: the outage impacting the S3 cloud services was due to human error. An issue in the S3 billing process was being debugged by members of the Amazon Simple Storage Service team. In an attempt to rectify the issue
column18: which involved taking down a small number of servers
column19: one of the engineers entered an incorrect keystroke.""An authorized S3 team member using an established playbook executed a command which was intended to remove a small number of servers for one of the S3 subsystems that is used by the S3 billing process
column20: Amazon saidin a statement on its website. ""Unfortunately
column21: one of the inputs to the command was entered incorrectly and a larger set of servers was removed than intended.""The servers that were mistakenly taken down supported two other S3 subsystems
column22: which triggered a widespread outage impacting government services
column23: news sites
column24: the Securities and Exchange Commission
column25: Business Insider
column26: Quora and Slack and a host of other institutions considered significant to the internet infrastructure.7 Stocks That Will Hit All-Time Highs in 2017It remains to be seen whether this issue will cause Amazon to lose any customers to competing cloud platforms such as those offered byMicrosoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT) orAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOGL). To its credit
column27: however
column28: Amazon didn't try to hide behind its mistake
column29: saying Thursday it was making several changes to avoid the potential of similar problems in the future.""We want to apologize for the impact this event caused for our customers. While we are proud of our long track record of availability with Amazon S3
column30: we know how critical this service is to our customers
column31: their applications and end users
column32: and their businesses."" Amazon said in its statement. ""We will do everything we can to learn from this event and use it to improve our availability even further.""Bottom Line for AMZN StockThough Amazon might lose some support in terms of AWS being touted as best-of-breed cloud

column1: Advanced Micro Devices
column2: Inc. (AMD) Stock Became a Market Stunner — Can it Last?;3/3/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsIf I'm being painfully transparent
column4: I almost want to callAdvanced Micro Devices
column5: Inc. (NYSE:AMD) ""fake news."" A little more than two years ago
column6: AMD stock was trading for under two bucks. Now
column7: it has been toying with $15 with little sign of slowing down. And I don't consider a near 5% loss on the day to be a sign of anything. This is especially true considering Advanced Micro Devices is up 22.6% for the year so far.makeArticleAd();Source:Matthew Rutledge via FlickrI understand the point that rallies can be extremely pronounced from the depths of market volatility. We've seen similar patterns in the number one rival for AMD stock:Intel Corporation(NASDAQ:INTC). Those that bought the dips inNvidia Corporation(NASDAQ:NVDA) and held on for the big surge were handsomely rewarded.But these are companies that are recognized leaders in their field of specialty. AMD
column8: in contrast
column9: historically has been the discount leader
column10: playing catch-up with the big boys.Still
column11: AMD stock registered an amazing 295% run last year. Even more astounding
column12: speculators that caught AMD in mid-February of 2016 saw their investment rise by around 600%! Go in hard with a couple performances like that and you'll be out of the rat race in no time.But is there any growth remaining in Advanced Micro Devices?A Game Changer (Literally!) for AMD StockInvestorPlace contributor Joseph Hargett certainly thinks so. His bullishness isn't based just on the momentum begetting momentum thesis. Rather
column13: Hargett sees the company's latestRyzen CPUas a game changer
column14: something that will put the hurting on Intel. From the initial reports
column15: it's hard to disagree.3 Ignored Tech ETFs That Are Too Good to Pass UpRyzen will go head-to-head with Intel's flagship i7 processor
column16: which isn't a surprising move in and of itself. Advanced Micro Devices and Intel have always warred for consumer attention like bitter siblings. Naturally
column17: Intel has had the upper hand
column18: whereas AMD was considered the ""poor man's Intel."" That same dynamic can be found in the markets
column19: with AMD stock gyrating from euphoria to despair and back again.Although it's a commonly expressed sentiment with mixed results
column20: this time could be different for Advanced Micro Devices. The Ryzen is armed with more features than the i7
column21: including attributes that are vital to its core video-gamer base.Most importantly
column22: it clocks in at half the price of its rival's offering
column23: which will inevitably draw much excitement. AMD has previously supplied chips toMicrosoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT) andSony Corp (ADR)(NYSE:SNE) for their video game systems.On the technical front
column24: Hargett notes that there's significantshorting activityin AMD stock. All it would take are a few good reviews
column25: and that will send shares moving higher. Those who are short Advanced Micro Devices will have to cover their position to stay in it. But the overwhelming upside pressure could be too much
column26: forcing them to close their transaction. In order to do that
column27: borrowed shares of AMD stock that initiated the short would have to be bought back.After those market gymnastics
column28: demand for AMD shoots even higher.Advanced Micro Devices Still Has to Face the MusicOf course
column29: the obvious risk is whether or not the computing industry bites. Maybe after intensive reviews
column30: the Ryzen isn't what it seemed to be. After all
column31: we are talking about semiconductors. This sector has a bloody history of punishing missteps - and not everyone makes it out alive. Considering that AMD stock is still very much a speculative investment
column32: the obvious risk is not one to take lightly.I think we can all appreciate the moxy that Advanced Micro Devices has shown. Other companies could have simply folded under the trials
column33: but not AMD - good for them. But we also can't ignore the reality of the situation. AsInvestorPlacecontributor Ryan Furhmann notes
column34: ""Intel is expected to report sales of around $59 billion this year. AMD stock will log just over $4 billion in sales
column35: making it about7% the sizeof Intel.""Due to the easing of the supply glut in computer chip products
column36: some might think we're entering into a semiconductor renaissance. I look at it more as the changing of the tide. However
column37: the ocean is still the ocean. AMD stock and others can enjoy the favorable tailwind
column38: but eventually
column39: there will be another challenge.The question is
column40: will AMD be strong enough to weather it?It's a Super-Risky PropositionIf you look at the technical momentum
column41: you have to like the chances for AMD stock. Shares are moving firmly in a bullish trend channel. Aside from some overheating readings
column42: the standard technical barometers are signaling green. As Wall Street likes to say
column43: the trend is your friend.Click to EnlargeOrdinarily
column44: I'd agree. But darn it
column45: the fundamental picture for AMD stock is ugly. It's so ugly that I would reference a part of the human anatomy as a prefix if I could. But I'm going to keep it clean.Here's the deal - based on the Altman Z-score
column46: the only thing that Advanced Micro Devices has been doing is moving from one state of distress to another. We're not arguing whether the company is on stable ground: it's not. We're just analyzing magnitude of troubles.Snap Inc. (SNAP): Snapchat IPO ALMOST Beats the OddsFor a contrarian
column47: buying when others are selling is an art form. But what happens when everybody else is buying the same troubled stock? Furthermore
column48: shouldn't an embattled company make substantive strides of improvement?Strictly from the data
column49: AMD moved from intractably distressed to ""normal"" distressed. That is an improvement
column50: I'll concede. But at some point
column51: the dial has got to move to at least a grey zone. Sadly
column52: AMD stock is well far away from that. So even though it has been an incredible ride
column53: I think investors need to be cautious here.As of this writing
column54: Josh Enomoto was long SNE stock.More From InvestorPlace7 Stocks That Will Hit All-Time Highs in 201710 Dangerous Dividend Stocks to Dump NowThe postAdvanced Micro Devices
column55: Inc. (AMD) Stock Became a Market Stunner - Can it Last?appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: IBM Watson Introduces Cognitive Imaging to Boost Healthcare;3/3/2017;"International Business Machines CorporationIBMrecently launched IBM Watson Imaging Clinical Review
column2: a cognitive imaging offering
column3: which happens to be the first of its kind from the Watson Health stable
column4: at the Health IT Conference for 2017.Additionally
column5: the company announced that the Watson Health medical imaging collaborative has been expanded to 24 organizations globally to address eye
column6: heart
column7: brain
column8: breast and related conditions further.IBM's cognitive imaging offering will initially address cardiovascular diseases such as aortic stenosis which currently affects nearly 1.5 million people in the U.S. IBM intends to expand the coverage to nine additional cardiovascular conditions such as valve disorders
column9: deep vein thrombosis
column10: cardiomyopathy (a heart muscle disease) and myocardial infractions (heart attacks) in the long run.International Business Machines Corporation Price and   ConsensusInternational Business Machines Corporation Price   and Consensus|International Business Machines Corporation QuoteHow Cognitive Imaging Works?The Watson Health Imaging Clinical Review was designed by the members of the Watson Health medical imaging collaborative that comprises of academic medical centers
column11: private radiology practices
column12: leading health systems
column13: imaging technology companies and ambulatory radiology providers.The objective of the cognitive imaging offering is to utilize medical imaging techniques to identify as well as predict the chances of getting affected with diseases such as cancer
column14: eye diseases
column15: diabetes and other diseases related to the heart
column16: brain and other related conditions.It utilizes cognitive text analytics to verify whether the doctor's remarks regarding a particular patient were entered into the electronic health record (EMR)
column17: the diagnosis list and the billing records.IBM's cognitive imaging offering is a targeted artificial intelligence tool that has the potential to help the healthcare providers standardize their healthcare services and build a database of patient data which could be utilized to enhance their healthcare offerings.Moreover

column10: Instagram
column11: the popular photo-sharing app

column36: and the app sat around for about a year afterwards before being officially removed.Other Snapchat rip-off ventures of Facebook include disappearing posts

column52: King of the TeensIf all of these influential tech and internet companies have spent the better part of four years trying to emulate Snapchat

column73: or just copied Snapchat's ideas. Snapchat is fresh
column74: and it has created a world inhabited mostly by teenagers and young adults and their favorite brands and celebrities. No parents allowed.It's no wonder
column75: then

column78: Snapchat is cool. Where Facebook appeals to older generations and Instagram to ""capturing the perfect moment
column79: Snapchat is for everything in between.Snapchat is for the ""real

column1: Alphabet Could Be Berkshire's Next Tech Buy;3/2/2017;"After loading up onApple(AAPL) shares
column2: couldBerkshire Hathaway(NYSE:BRK.A) (NYSE:BRK.B) buyAlphabet Inc.(GOOG) (GOOGL) shares next? Alphabet has been bought aggressively by multiple famous gurus. Buffett and Munger have commented favorably on the company's competitive position several times. The latest Berkshire shareholder letter indicates Buffett is very knowledgeable about the technology space.The fact that so many value investors are buying Alphabet at current multiples indicate it is a great business at a fair price. It is not immediately obvious how popular the stock is because Alphabet trades an A and a C share class
column3: which are treated as seperate companies by lists put together through automation. They are economically equivalent
column4: however
column5: and if you add them up
column6: Alphabet is one of the highest-owned stocks among the great investors tracked by GuruFocus.Back in 2009
column7: Warren Buffett(Trades
column8: Portfolio) talked aboutIBM(IBM)
column9: Apple and Google:makeArticleAd();""The chances of being way wrong in IBM are probably less
column10: at least for us
column11: than the chances of being way wrong in Google or Apple. I just don't know how to value them.I would not be at all surprised to see them be worth a lot more money 10 years from now but I would not buy either one of them. I sure as hell wouldn't short them either.""In addition
column12: Charlie Munger(Trades
column13: Portfolio) said:""Google has a huge new moat. In fact
column14: I've probably never seen such a wide moat.""Munger added it was also filled with sharks. It is impossible to assess a moat without understanding competitors and their chances to successfully assault a company's market share. In this case
column15: Munger might have seen the potential early while Buffett remained unconvinced. Buffett has alluded to his biggest mistakes as acts of omission.Bill Gates
column16: formerMicrosoft(MSFT) chairman and a good friend of Buffett
column17: stepped down in 2014. Microsoft runs the only real competition to Google search. Gates stepping down may have freed Buffett to learn about that competitive landscape from him.In additon
column18: Google founders Larry Page and Sergey Brin and Chairman Eric Schmidt traveled to Omaha to talk to Buffett when setting up the new Alphabet structure
column19: which is molded after Berkshire.Shortly before the trip
column20: they brought in CFO Ruth Porat
column21: who understands the tech founders' goals for the company.Buffett included the following paragraphs in the 2017 shareholder letter
column22: putting my spider senses on red alert:""In 2002
column23: entrepreneur Mitch Kapor asserted that 'By 2029 no computer - or 'machine intelligence' - will have passed the Turing Test
column24: ' which deals with whether a computer can successfully impersonate a human being. Inventor Ray Kurzweil took the opposing view. Each backed up his opinion with $10
column25: 000. I don't know who will win this bet
column26: but I will confidently wager that no computer will ever replicate Charlie.That same year
column27: Craig Mundie of Microsoft asserted that pilotless planes would routinely fly passengers by 2030
column28: while Eric Schmidt of Google argued otherwise. The stakes were $1
column29: 000 each. To ease any heartburn Eric might be experiencing from his outsized exposure
column30: I recently offered to take a piece of his action. He promptly laid off $500 with me. (I like his assumption that I'll be around in 2030 to contribute my payment
column31: should we lose.)""This paragraph shows Buffett has been studying the tech world very hard and is open to the possibility the Turing test will be cracked by 2029. He also must have looked into the dynamics of driverless or pilotless technology
column32: note the recent investment into airlines
column33: to take on a $500 bet. I do not think betting against Buffett is generally a profitable endeavour. What jumped out at me is
column34: apparently
column35: Alphabet's chairman and Buffett recently spoke again. They must have spoken for quite some time for the subject of this casual bet to come up.All these factors have led me to speculate on the potential of an Alphabet investment.The pieces are falling into place.Buffett has been studying tech intensely.Berkshire has made a 180 as far as tech investments go.Buffett and Munger view Alphabet as having an incredibly strong moat.Alphabet's valuation is at an attractive level given the interest from the value investing greats. Porat is a great addition to the executive suite
column36: covering up pre-existing weaknesses in the team.Google executives have met with Buffett on multiple occasions and Schmidt talked to him recently.The one thing I could see keeping Buffett from making an investment is his distaste for stock-based compensation. Alphabet continues to dole it out like it is candy on Halloween.I would go as far as to say it would greatly surprise me if we do not see Berkshire buying a stake in Alphabet in the next five years.Disclosure: Author owns none of these stocks.Start afree 7-day trial of Premium Membershipto GuruFocus.Premium MembersThis article first appeared onGuruFocus."

column1: How to Trade Caterpillar Inc. (CAT) After Federal Raid;3/2/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsToday is a dayCaterpillar Inc.(NYSE:CAT) shareholders will wish they stayed in bed. CAT stock finished more than 4% lower in response to the sight of federal agents raiding the heavy equipment juggernaut's offices.makeArticleAd();Source:Anthony via FlickrI'm betting the Feds aren't looking to buy farm equipment. And so are the denizens of the Street. In true shoot-first-and-ask-questions-later fashion
column3: traders are liquidating Caterpillar shares from their portfolios with prejudice.Despite the damage
column4: CAT stock remained above all significant support levels. So it remains to be seen if today's decline will morph into a trend-killing breakdown.Trading volume ran hot all day
column5: with 23 million shares changing hands by day's end.Click to EnlargeNot surprisingly
column6: there was a mad dash into the options pit for protection. Option premiums for downside puts are exploding today as investors scoop up insurance just in case today's raid is the tip of the iceberg. Implied volatility ripped higher throughout the trading session
column7: ending near a 52-week high.5 Blue-Chip Stocks to Sell in MarchThe action in CAT today presents some attractive trading opportunities for bulls and bears alike. While the fallout to today's surprising news is impossible to predict
column8: the marketplace is paying you to take risk right now.Let's explore two trade ideas: one bull and one bear.A CAT Stock Trade for Everyone!Bear:To capitalize on additional selling
column9: consider buying a put spread. By purchasing a near-the-money put and selling a far out-of-the-money put option
column10: we can create a position that exploits the relative expensiveness of downside puts.Buy the Apr $90/$85 put spread for $1.05 or better.Consider it a cheap bet that Caterpillar shares remain heavy for the month ahead. The risk is limited to the initial $1.05 debit and will be lost if CAT stock sits above $90 at expiration.The reward is limited to the distance between strikes minus the net debit
column12: and will be captured if the stock falls below $85 by expiration. With such a large potential reward in the offing
column13: there's no reason to get greedy here. I suggest taking profits if the put spread rises to $2.10
column14: giving you a 100% return.Bull:If you think today's swoon is overblown
column15: then there are numerous ways to exploit the fear.3 Reasons to Sell Advanced Micro Devices
column16: Inc. (AMD) Stock NOWConsider selling the Apr $85 put options for $1.15.As long as CAT stock sits above $85 at expiration
column17: the put will expire worthless
column18: allowing you to pocket the $1.15 credit. The puts reside about 10% out-of-the-money
column19: so we'd have to see strong follow-through to today's drop without any recovery for you to lose money at expiration.And
column20: if you're a willing buyer of CAT shares in the $85 region
column21: you could allow assignment if the put sits in-the-money at expiration. You will have to buy 100 shares of stock for each put sold.As of this writing
column22: Tyler Craig did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace10 Dangerous Dividend Stocks to Dump NowSell the Bounce In Fitbit Inc (FIT) StockMicrosoft Corporation (MSFT) Stock Is Worth About $100 Billion Too MuchThe postHow to Trade Caterpillar Inc. (CAT) After Federal Raidappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: What Does Warren Buffett See in Apple?;3/2/2017;"SinceWarren Buffett(Trades
column2: Portfolio)'s annual letter came out and he followed up with a lengthy interview on CNBC where he talked about how much moreApple(AAPL) stock Berkshire now owned - and how he was the one who bought most of it - I have gotten a lot of email questions asking about his purchase.This is not the first time I have received a slew of emails questioning the logic of one of Buffett's investments. Since I have been writing articles about investing
column3: he has made four investments that really got a reaction from value investors who doubted the logic of what he was doing. These include: Buffett's initial purchase of railroad stocks and his subsequent purchase of all of Burlington Northern
column4: his investment inIBM(IBM) despite him having said he does not invest in tech stocks
column5: his investment in the four major U.S. airlines despite the fact he has said the airline industry is a terrible one for investors and now his investment in Apple.Berkshire Hathaway's (NYSE:BRK.A)(NYSE:BRK.B) investment in Apple is far from the most controversial of these cases. A bunch of other value investors like the stock. It is a reasonably priced stock on an enterprise value basis - Apple has a lot of net cash
column6: so its market cap exaggerates the valuation being put on the company. But
column7: each of these investments by Buffett is an example of him moving into an area he had not previously touched. I am not sure Buffett ever invested in a railroad stock despite the fact that when he started his career - in the early 1950s - railroad stocks were a much bigger part of the investment landscape than they are today. Buffett may not have bought tech stocks before IBM - but it is
column8: in most every other respect
column9: the kind of stock Buffett would normally buy.makeArticleAd();Also
column10: Buffett previously said the reason he never ownedMicrosoft(MSFT) was because no matter whether it was true or not - people would assume the purchase was the result of inside information from his friend
column11: Bill Gates(Trades
column12: Portfolio). He also said
column13: however
column14: that at one pointMicrosoft stockgot to a price - presumably
column15: this is sometime after the 2008 financial crisis - that seemed low to him. Buffett rarely talks about whether the price of a stock seems low
column16: high
column17: etc. unless he understands something about that business and that industry. So
column18: it is not unreasonable to think Buffett believes he understands some things about Microsoft. And those things might allow him to - within a very wide value range - know whether even a tech stock like Microsoft is cheap or not.Now
column19: let's look at Apple. What does Buffett see in that stock? The number one thing that appeals to Buffett about Apple is something that should not matter at all to you. Buffett is attracted to Apple's size. It is a huge stock. Buffett said on that same CNBC interview I mentioned that Berkshire was unlikely to take a bigger than 10% stake in a company because of the problems that presents. Berkshire has ended up with more than 10% of a company's stock
column20: but that has often been helped along by share repurchases on the part of the company itself.Right now
column21: Ted Weschler and Todd Combs are each running $10 billion portfolios at Berkshire. Those are the small portfolios. Buffett is investing at a whole order of magnitude more in size. But
column22: let's start with just the kind of ideas Weschler and Combs need to come up with.Assume you are running a $10 billion portfolio that is fully invested in common stocks. Further assume you want to avoid buying more than 10% of a company's stock. Now
column23: assume you are a concentrated type investor the way Buffett is. As I write
column24: my own portfolio is 65% invested in just two stocks:Frost(CFR) andBWX Technologies(BWXT). It is 85% invested in just three stocks. The third stock
column25: however
column26: is a micro-cap. Managers investing billions of dollars cannot even look at a micro-cap. The very smallest stocks they can possibly buy are things like Frost and BWX Technologies. So
column27: how much of their portfolio could they put in those two stocks? Remember
column28: I have 65% of my portfolio in those stocks.Well
column29: if you are managing $10 billion
column30: and you are buying stock in a company with a market cap of about $6 billion (which is about the size of Frost and BWX)
column31: you can put just under $600 million into the company without crossing the 10% ownership threshold. So
column32: say you have two good ideas that are each $6 billion companies - put them both together and you get just 12% of your portfolio in those stocks. Now
column33: for me personally
column34: I do not want to spend time worrying about a stock that is much less than 20% of my portfolio. Here
column35: we are talking about stocks that are 6% of your portfolio if you buy absolutely as much of them as possible. You see the problem. And I have understated it.Buffett is running about 10 times what Weschler and Combs are running individually. And neither Frost nor BWX Technologies is a small company. Within its niche of Texan banks
column36: Frost is the biggest. And within its niche of nuclear work for governments rather than civilians
column37: BWX Technologies is the biggest. So
column38: Buffett cannot be looking for companies that have market caps of $6 billion. He wants companies with market caps of $60 billion or even $600 billion. Apple has a market cap of even more than $600 billion. So
column39: here we have a company where instead of putting just 5% of your portfolio into the stock at the very most
column40: you might get the chance to put 10%
column41: 20% or even 50% of your portfolio into the stock. When Buffett was running his partnership
column42: he liked to put 25% into his best idea. In the case ofAmerican Express(AXP)
column43: he even went beyond that. If we do a little math with the amount of money Buffett manages at Berkshire
column44: we can see that ideas in the $100 billion to $700 billion market cap range are really
column45: really useful to him because he can potentially deploy $10 billion to $70 billion (10% of the value of these kinds of companies) into such gigantic public companies.Think about what kinds of companies you have in the $100 billion to $700 billion range. It is pretty limited. Buffett likes focused companies. He likes brands. A great idea for Buffett is something likeCoca-Cola(KO)
column46: American Express
column47: Wells Fargo(WFC)
column48: Moody's(MCO)
column49: or Gillette. Those were great ideas because they were not just big companies. They did very few things in a very big way. Buffett's stake in Gillette got swapped intoProcter & Gamble(PG) stock. He eventually did a deal to get out of P&G by taking control of Duracell. Duracell is a big brand like Gillette. P&G is an even bigger company
column50: but only a few of its brands are huge in a way that is useful to Buffett. P&G as a whole is more diversified into things that are not really as good as Gillette is on a standalone basis.Not only is Apple a huge company
column51: it is a hugely focused company
column52: which is attractive to Buffett. Apple's fortunes are now tied to one brand (as they really always have been) and largely to one product (the iPhone). When you listen to what Buffett said about Apple
column53: you realize how important this is. Buffett said he likes Apple. He said he sees how integral the iPhone is to the lives of people - especially young people - who now have it. And he says that he sees - at places like the Nebraska Furniture Mart stores he owns - that people upgrade from one iPhone to another instead of considering competing brands. So
column54: the investment thesis is surprisingly focused for a giant company. It really has to do with one brand and one product
column55: the iPhone. That is it. Buffett can evaluate the stickiness of one consumer product and one brand. That makes Apple easier to understand than Procter & Gamble orDisney(DIS) or other giant consumer-oriented businesses that are actually much more diversified. Apple is not diversified. That is the potential attraction.Moving on
column56: Buffett thinks Apple
column57: like IBM
column58: is not going to do a lot of big acquisitions. He thinks the company is going to buy back a lot of its own stock. This is a very common theme in a lot of his investments. One of the surest signs you can find for a ""catalyst"" that might change his thinking about a company is that company turning inward and focusing on the things it does best while dedicating its free cash flow toward reducing its share count year after year instead of expanding into other areas.Buffett is not an activist investor
column59: but if you look at those areas where he has been most vocal - either while on a board
column60: in the way he abstained from a vote or what he said to the press - it is almost always a capital allocation decision. It is usually related to the issuance of company stock. Sometimes it is related to overpaying. Nonetheless
column61: he is constantly urging the management of the companies he invests in to focus on widening their moat
column62: doing what they do best and investing in themselves at a reasonable price (by buying back their own stock) rather than investing in somebody else by overpaying.The only times I can think of Buffett having any complaints about Coca-Cola had to do with an acquisition the company wanted to do (at too high a price) or with giving stock to top executives. The stock grants to executives incident at Coke was reported in the press as Buffett complaining about executives being overpaid. I think the reason he abstained on that vote had more to do with the fact the company would be permitted to cause a lot of dilution if it used the program to the full extent it was asking shareholder approval for. So
column63: it was probably more about Buffett wanting Coca-Cola to shrink its share count rather than grow it.When Buffett was asked on CNBC about the growth prospects of both IBM and Apple
column64: he answered by talking about share buybacks. Before Buffett bought it
column65: IBM had one of the longest and most aggressive histories of buying back its own stock you can find at any public company. A lot of Berkshire's investments have this feature. Look at how much American Express has shrunk its share count since Buffett bought that position. Or look at how much Coca-Cola has bought back of its own stock. In both cases
column66: I'm pretty sure Berkshire's investments are worth at least 33% more than they otherwise would be because these companies have shrunk their share count by more than 25% while Berkshire owned them. Buffett mentioned in the CNBC interview that Apple had bought back almost 5% of its stock in a year. That is unlikely to be a one-time thing. Apple will have problems with where its cash is located - it will end up with a lot of cash that would be taxed if brought back to the U.S. - but it does not need cash to grow
column67: it cannot grow that fast anymore organically and it does not do big acquisitions.For a tech company its size
column68: Apple has historically been especially averse to acquisitions. A company as profitable as Apple that does not use money on high-priced
column69: transformative acquisitions is eventually going to have to use that cash to buy back its own stock. There just are not any other realistic options. It could pay dividends; and because of Berkshire's own tax status
column70: Buffett would benefit at least as much from dividends as from (fairly or overpriced) buybacks. He does not mind dividends
column71: and he certainly does not mind buybacks at stocks he chose in the first place.What about Apple's lack of future growth? I think this actually attracts Buffett. That sounds counterintuitive. But
column72: let me explain. Apple is a tech stock and a consumer product company. The most dangerous time to invest in tech stocks and consumer product stocks is when they sell a high-priced product to a small pool of customers. The reason for this is that it allows market entry at the low end. If you are selling $1
column73: 000 watches or $10
column74: 000 computers
column75: someone can come in selling a cheaper and more basic version of the product to a large group of people who have never owned the product. All sorts of market leaders run into this problem. They have the biggest dollar share of the industry
column76: but economies of scale - and certainly gains in experience - are driven in large by the unit volume you do. The leader is in an awkward position because trying to expand the market cuts into their profitability on a per-customer basis.If you are selling computers to corporate customers - you are not dreaming of the day when every living room in America can have a cheap
column77: basic desktop. That future is potentially bad for you in several ways. One
column78: it teaches whoever you are competing with a lot about many of the things you do. Two
column79: it cheapens the image of what you are selling. Three
column80: it changes the way you will have to sell what you are selling. Almost all technology
column81: especially any sort of consumer tech
column82: follows this pattern. It can be very tough for investors because it leads to a two-stage adoption of the technology.In phase one
column83: one leader establishes their dominance in the ""pro"" market and the stock looks great. But
column84: in phase two
column85: another - and usually different - leader establishes their dominance in the ""consumer"" market. Then that stock looks great at the expense of the first leader. We could be talking about computers or cell phones here. But if you go back further in history
column86: TVs and radios followed the same pattern too. These things are always invented long
column87: long before you remember them being invented
column88: but were not adopted quickly. People tend to remember when they started seeing cell phones everywhere
column89: when they started using the internet in their own home and so on. Those years have nothing to do with when these products were first invented
column90: commercialized and so forth. Often
column91: there was a company you have completely forgotten about that made and lost a fortune before the time period you even think of the new consumer tech as being suddenly important to society.What does this have to do with Apple? It is part of a broader question. Just how ""moaty"" are consumer technology companies? At least on one side of the economic value equation
column92: companies like Apple
column93: Facebook(FB) andAlphabet's Google (GOOG)(GOOGL) depend entirely on the mass appeal of their product. We call them technology companies. Internally
column94: I am sure they seem very technical to those inside the organization. But how much does technology drive the economic returns at these companies? And
column95: at this point
column96: how easy is it to attack any of these business models on some technical difference between your product and theirs? How much of what makes the iPhone successful is the Apple brand
column97: the fact a customer already owns an iPhone and is used to using it
column98: the fact a customer's friends
column99: family and peers already own an iPhone and
column100: as a consequence
column101: the fact other entrepreneurs and organizations have invested time money and effort in trying to reach people by designing products to be used on an iPhone?In other words
column102: has the iPhone become the default choice for customers because the Apple brand is good enough
column103: the status quo is good enough
column104: people are not all going to jump on another bandwagon together and the suppliers are going to be where the demand is? Is the iPhone always going to be the easiest choice? This is exactly the same question for Facebook and Google. A very long time ago
column105: I wrote that while I did not ownGoogle stockand did not know how the organization would develop over time as a company
column106: I did know that understanding anything technical about a search engine no longer mattered. Google does not need to be the world's best search engine to be the world's most popular search engine. The advantages it has are too entrenched and the differences between one set of search results and another are so small - Google does not really have to compete on quality anymore. Google is enough of a brand and search is enough of a commodity that it does not matter.The things that got Apple to the position it is now in are not necessarily the things that will keep it there. A lot of readers emailed me asking about Apple's brand and whether it would last. The answer to that is yes and no. It will be a recognizable brand that is seen as good enough in a decade or two. I would be very surprised if that changed. On the other hand
column107: I would be surprised if the Apple brand was seen as being particularly innovative or standing for very specific design choices or anything like that in a decade or two. Coca-Cola is a great brand
column108: but it is not a very specific brand. It cannot be anymore. When people think cola they think Coca-Cola. And when people think phone - they think Apple. But
column109: Apple will not need to convince anyone to try a smartphone for the first time anymore. They do not really even have to convince anyone to try an Apple product for the first time anymore.Apple has very high returns on the money it actually ties up in its business. The numbers look lower because they have excess cash. Likewise
column110: the stock looks more expensive than it is because it has a lot of excess cash. If Apple's sales grow somewhere between nominal GDP and the rate of inflation in the countries where it operates in and the company dedicates every cent it makes - or more
column111: since Apple already has net cash - to buying back its own shares
column112: it will still be a ""growth"" stock on an EPS basis. For an example of this
column113: see BWX Technologies. It is not really a growth company at all in terms of what it does. It does not gain new customers (outside of the U.S. Navy). It does not win totally new projects (outside of the carriers and subs it has long provided reactors for). And it does not even get many more orders for a higher build rate for the number of those ships now than it did in the recent past. Despite all that
column114: the company just put out a press release saying it expected a ""low double-digit"" EPS growth rate for the next three to five years. That is a growth stock
column115: but it is one because it is doing something very
column116: very profitable on a return on capital basis. It is retaining all the business it already has and growing the business it retains a tiny but consistent bit
column117: and then it is taking all the money it makes and buying back its own stock. When a super high-quality business buys back its own stock
column118: it is not impossible to turn an underlying 5% type growth rate in how much more your customers actually want into more like a 10% growth rate in the earnings you report per share.IBM is another good example of that. In the 10 years before Buffett bought the stock
column119: it was not very good at company-wide revenue growth. Over the last decade
column120: IBM had close to 9% annual EPS growth at the same time it had close to zero percent revenue growth. A lot of that is accomplished simply by not growing the assets you tie up in the business at all (IBM's net tangible assets actually shrank over the last decade) and then taking all your free cash flow and - instead of growing assets like most companies do - use it to reduce your share count.What Warren Buffett (Trades
column121: Portfolio) sees in Apple is probably a slow growth
column122: wide moat consumer brand that can use all its free cash flow to buy back its own stock and thereby be a high-growth stock in terms of EPS
column123: even while it is slow growth in terms of additional units sold. Apple may not be a growth company anymore
column124: but that does not mean it cannot be a growth stock. All Buffett cares about is the growth in earnings per share. So
column125: he is not necessarily betting Apple can sell a lot more iPhones over the next five to 10 years. What Buffett's betting on is Apple's ability to report a lot more in earnings per share over the next five to 10 years.Disclosures: Long CFR

column1: Microsoft Corporation (MSFT) Stock Is Worth About $100 Billion Too Much;3/2/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsMicrosoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT) stock continues to trade just off all-time highs
column3: with its market capitalization now at $500 billion. I continue to be surprised at the strength shown by Microsoft stock. MSFT stock has risen roughly 150% in just four years - despite little movement in profits. Adjusted earnings per share were $2.78 in fiscal 2012 and only a penny more
column5: in fiscal 2016.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockAdmittedly
column6: there are some reasons for the increase in the Microsoft stock price. Both investors and customers are high on the Azure cloud platform. The Surface product line shows significant promise. And CEO Satya Nadella has received top marks from analysts and shareholders.There's a real case that the ""new"" Microsoft is different from the ""old"" Microsoft
column7: which has been to the benefit of MSFT stock. Earnings growth should return: Wall Street consensus estimates forecast a 7% increase in FY17 per-share earnings and 9% the following fiscal year.But even that doesn't seem enough to keep Microsoft stock above $60. MSFT is valued at almost 22 times FY17 earnings
column8: a multiple that implies consistent growth. Meanwhile
column9: Windows and legacy Office products are declining and most of the new initiatives cannibalize existing sales
column10: in at least some manner.7 Stocks That Will Hit All-Time Highs in 2017Microsoft obviously isn't going to collapse
column11: and long-awaited earnings growth may just be at hand. But more modest growth expectations seem to support a share price closer to $50 than to $60.Growth Drivers Simply Aren't That BigAll the bullish talk surrounding Microsoft stock seems to focus on the Azure cloud offering and the Surface line. But those two categories aren't major drivers here: combined
column12: they drive less than 10% of total sales (Azure is estimated to bring in around$2.5 billion.)To be sure
column13: cloud as a whole is a bigger part of MSFT revenue. The company is looking for a $20 billion run rate in commercial cloud in FY18
column14: which would imply more than 20% of total sales coming from the cloud. Surface is a great product and a Surface Phone could - finally - get Microsoft a consistent presence in the smartphone space.8 of the Most Overrated Stocks on Wall Street Right NowAll told
column15: I can see the reason for some optimism regarding the two growth drivers. But not too much
column16: considering that growth in both categories has some drawbacks.Taking Revenue From ElsewhereThe other issue with counting on Azure and Surface
column17: beyond their relatively small contribution
column18: is that growth in both categories is coming from the existing revenue base. The $20 billion commercial cloud figure sounds great - but that growth is coming largely from Office 365 and Azure. Revenue from those products isn't new to Microsoft; much of it is coming from legacy
column19: disk-based Office customers and/or existing SQL buyers.Even Surface isn't necessarily a pure growth driver. Taking a sale from a rival likeHP Inc(NYSE:HPQ) is a win
column20: but an HP sale still drives Windows 10-related revenue for MSFT. That software revenue drops to the bottom line at much higher margin than sales of a Surface product.Basically
column21: growth isn't 100% organic for Microsoft. It doesn't portend some sort of top-line acceleration for the company as a whole
column22: nor does it make MSFT stock a growth play.A Winner In Declining BusinessesAdding to those concerns is that Microsoft isn't quite as well-positioned in the newer areas. Azure is second toAmazon.com
column23: Inc.'s(NASDAQ:AMZN) Amazon Web Services (AWS). Microsoft wants to grow in China
column24: but so doesAlibaba Group Holding Ltd(NYSE:BABA)
column25: which is rolling out its own AWS-type solution.For Office 365
column26: Tableau Software Inc(NYSE:DATA) is challenging Excel - and 27% revenue growth in 2016 suggests DATA is taking share from MSFT. Behemoths likeOracle Corporation(NYSE:ORCL) and many others are in the cloud space. Microsoft's Dynamics CRM product is a distant second tosalesforce.com
column27: inc.(NYSE:CRM).There are still a lot of obstacles and a number of tough competitors in the way of Microsoft's growth. In fact
column28: in most of the key areas
column29: Microsoft is second place
column30: at best.Bottom Line for Microsoft StockOverall
column31: the idea that Microsoft stock is pricing in accelerated growth strikes me as far too optimistic. There are drivers - but I'm skeptical that all will come through - and in the meantime
column32: Windows and disk-based Office revenues will continue to decline.The 150%-plus gain in MSFT stock has come in large part from the idea that Microsoft is in a different position than it was in 2012 or 2013. Then
column33: investors were concerned about declining PC sales
column34: and the lack of any real ability for MSFT to grow otherwise.Microsoft is in a better position now
column35: but it's hardly perfect. PC concerns still remain; phones
column36: cloud and notebooks are tough spaces and overall growth continue to be rather muted. There's enough here to expect some sort of EPS growth
column37: which likely implies a high double-digit multiple. But that
column38: in turn
column39: implies a share price in the $50-$55 price range.That values Microsoft somewhere around $100 billion less than where it trades at the moment. If that sounds like a lot of money
column40: bear in mind that Microsoft stock has added $300 billion in value over the past four years and essentially zero in net income.As of this writing
column41: Vince Martin did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace7 Blue-Chip Stocks That Are Flush With CashThe 7 Best ETFs for Retirement Investors7 Best Stocks to Buy for a Donald Trump Green LightThe postMicrosoft Corporation (MSFT) Stock Is Worth About $100 Billion Too Muchappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Google Submits Updated Designs for Charleston East Campus;3/2/2017;"Alphabet Inc.'sGOOGLGoogle has submitted updated plans for its iconic office complex in Silicon Valley.The 18.6 acre Google Charleston East office space is the search giant's first ground-up project. Initially announced in 2015
column2: the project has gone through several revisions after facing problems with the city planning board.Over the last six months
column3: the stock has outperformed the ZacksInternet-Servicesindustry. It returned 7.5% compared to the industry's gain of 3.3%.Impressive and FuturisticThe new campus will resemble a circus tent supported by slanted tent poles. The 2-story office building will be spread across a 595
column4: 000 square feet area with the capacity to house around 3000 employees.The ground floor will be publicly accessible and include walking trails
column5: public parks
column6: retail space
column7: food stalls and lots of greenery. The campus is expected to be completed within 30 months.The centerpiece of the office space that Google describes as ""photovoltaic integrated canopy skin"" will generate renewable energy through solar power and have indoor climate
column8: sound and air quality control mechanisms.To further decrease consumption of electricity
column9: smile-shaped clerestories spanning two sides of each 102-foot bay will bring natural light in to the building.Google's expansion plan in north Mountain View is a reminder that Silicon Valley based tech giants are striving to build more impressive and futuristic office spaces.In 2015
column10: FacebookFBmoved to a 430
column11: 000 square foot extensive campus. Also

column16: Google is trying to build a highly flexible workplace
column17: capable of adapting to changing business needs on the one hand and serving the local communities on the other.The company swapped lands with Microsoft'sMSFTLinkedin last year in a deal that helped both companies make uninterrupted progress with their respective construction plans.Currently Alphabet carries a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold). column1: Pure Storage (PSTG) Posts Narrower-than-Expected Q4 Loss;3/2/2017;"Pure Storage Inc.PSTGreported non-GAAP loss (including stock-based compensation) of 21 cents per share in the fourth-quarter of fiscal 2017
column2: which was narrower than the Zacks Consensus Estimate by 3 cents.Excluding stock-based compensation
column3: non-GAAP loss was a couple of cents narrower than loss of 12 cents reported in the year-ago quarter.Following the results
column4: shares of the company were down 6.9% in after-hours trading. Also
column5: we note that the shares of the company have underperformed the ZacksComputer- Storage Devicesindustry over the last one year. While the industry gained 44.7%
column6: the stock declined 34.1%.The underperformance of the stock could be primarily attributed to an intensifying competitive landscape with the presence of major players such as Amazon'sAMZNAWS Microsoft'sMSFTAzure in the cloud storage and NetApp.Quarter DetailsPure Storage has two reportable segments namely
column7: ProductandSupport.In the fourth quarter
column8: Product revenues of $186.8 million surged 46.7% on a year-over-year basis
column9: primarily driven by a record 450 customer additions and renewed business from existing customers.Support revenues of $41.0 million increased a whopping 79.4% on a year-over-year basis as a result of revenue recognition on ongoing support contracts.Total revenue was $227.9 million
column10: which was up a significant 51.7% year over year and ahead of the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $224 million. Notably
column11: 77% of the revenues came from the U.S. while the remaining 23% was contributed by other international markets taken together.During the quarter
column12: Pure Storage added 450 new customers
column13: bringing the total additions for the year to 1
column14: 400. We note that this takes the total count of Pure Storage's existing customer base to over 3
column16: which includes over 100 of the Fortune 500 companies.Some notable companies that adopted Pure Storage's technology during the quarter were Hulu (streaming video service provider)
column17: Subway (restaurant chain)
column18: Royal Philips
column19: Konami
column20: Phreesia
column21: National Hockey League
column22: Keker Van Nest & Peters (law firm) and Ion (a geosciences company).Notably
column23: the storage market is currently going through a rapid transition with more and more customers opting for cloud-capable storage for data integrity and predictive analytics. Hence
column24: Pure Storage continues to focus on the All-Flash Array and cloud segments
column25: which are in great demand and augur well for the company in the long run.Moreover
column26: the company's end-to-end platforms such as FlashBlade and FlashArray as well as FlashStack which was developed in association with Cisco have been made cloud capable and are witnessing growing adoption rates.  Additionally
column27: the company's NVNe Flash is capable of improving the performance and efficiency of organizations
column28: which are likely to help improve Pure Storage's top line in the coming years.We also note that during the last quarter
column29: the company replaced the traditional storage devices
column30: which required 20 racks of spinning discs
column31: for two of its customers with a single 4U FlashBlade
column32: which is more compact and only the size of a microwave oven.With the passage of time
column33: as technology becomes more and more developed
column34: the space required to store data will shrink. Hence
column35: Pure Storage's compact storage technology is likely to gain further traction in the future.Reported R&D expenses as a percentage of revenues decreased 390 basis points (bps) while reported sales and marketing expenses as a percentage of revenues decreased 290 bps. On the other hand
column36: general and administrative expenses as a percentage of revenues decreased 320 bps.Non-GAAP gross margin was 66.1%
column37: which expanded 10 basis points (bps) on a year-over-year basis.Non-GAAP operating loss was $4.4 million compared with a loss of $22.1 million in the year-ago quarter.Non-GAAP net loss came was $4.8 million that narrowed down from the year-ago loss of $22.3 million.Pure Storage

column1: 3 Top Dividend Stocks to Buy Now;2/28/2017;"Despite the stock market's big run-up
column2: shares inMicrosoft(NASDAQ: MSFT)
column3: UnitedHealth Group(NYSE: UNH)
column4: andJohnson & Johnson(NYSE: JNJ) could still be heading higher. If so
column5: investors savvy   enough to have added these three topdividend   stocksto their income portfolios could make out handsomely
column6: because all   three companies have an opportunity to overdeliver on cash flow   and profit.A technology titan turning the cornerIt wasn't too many years ago that investors were shunningMicrosoft shares
column7: fearful that a dying PC market would be the end to this   company's long winning streak. However
column8: a portfolio of cloud   software products that are perfectly suited to today's   decentralized workplace has caught fire with companies of all   sizes
column9: and that's rekindled interest in this technology   powerhouse.IMAGE SOURCE: GETTY IMAGES.makeArticleAd();To be clear
column10: the company's still got more work to do. The PC   business is still slowing
column11: but next-generation solutions are   growing quickly
column12: and because of their high margins
column13: they're   providing profit-friendly tailwinds. Last quarter
column14: the company's   personal computing segment revenue fell 5% from a year ago
column15: but   that decline was offset by a 10% jump in productivity and   business processes sales to $7.4 billion and a 8% jump in   intelligent cloud segment sales. Productivity and business   processes growth was driven by 47% increase in Office   365 commercial revenue and 22% growth in Office consumer   products and cloud services revenue. Meanwhile
column16: intelligent cloud   sales were driven by a 12% increase in server products and a   93% surge in revenue for Azure
column17: its app development and   management business.Overall
column18: growth in Microsoft's higher-margin businesses helped   the company deliver non GAAP net income of $6.5 billion and   non-GAAP earnings per share of $0.83
column19: up 6% and 9% from a   year ago
column20: respectively. That profit growth bodes well for   dividend investors because it means there's increasingly more   money available for dividend hikes. Currently
column21: investors are   getting $0.39 per share in quarterly dividends
column22: which works out   to a 2.4% dividend yield
column23: at current share prices.Big changes could create big opportunityA huge amount of uncertainty exists in the health insurance   industry right now. Donald Trump's win last November means that a   repeal and replace of Obamacare is on deck
column24: and while it's not   clear yet what the replacement will be
column25: big insurers like   UnitedHealth Group
column26: the nation's largest insurer
column27: could be   rewarded.After losing hundreds of millions of dollars selling Obamacare   plans
column28: UnitedHealth Group became one of Obamacare's biggest   critics. The company decided to exit most of the Affordable Care   Act's exchanges early last year
column29: and in 2017
column30: it only offered   plans in a handful of states
column31: down from more than 30 states in   2016.Since UnitedHealth Group's already exited the majority of the   ACA states
column32: a repeal is likely to be far less disruptive to it   than it is to competitors. The company's vast experience in   managing health insurance plans
column33: however
column34: means it's still one of   the best-positioned companies to profit from any Obamacare   replacement.Despite losing money on Obamacare in 2016
column35: UnitedHealth Group   remains one of America's most financially healthy insurers.   Strength in its Medicaid
column36: Medicare
column37: and employer health insurance   businesses more than offset Obamacare headwinds last year
column38: and as   a result
column39: full-year operating profit jumped 20% to $13 billion   and adjusted earnings per share grew 25% to $8.05 in   2016.Assuming Congress replaces Obamacare with a more profitable   alternative
column40: the potential for UnitedHealth Group to grow its   bottom line in the coming years is significant. But even if an   Obamacare replacement is a dud
column41: UnitedHealth can still deliver   plenty of dividend-friendly bottom-line growth. Job growth is   boosting enrollment in its workplace insurance plans and aging   baby boomers offer tremendous growth for its Medicare Advantage   plans.A set-it and forget-it stockPerhaps
column42: no company is more deeply tied to global healthcare   markets than Johnson & Johnson. Its over-the-counter brands   are some of the planet's most widely recognized
column43: and its   pharmaceuticals and medical devices are among the most popular   choices of doctors worldwide.Consumer brands like Band-Aid keep cash flowing
column44: offsetting   some risk to investors
column45: while a prolific drug research and   development program fuels Johnson & Johnson's growth. For   example
column46: it's fastest-growing drugs are the multiple myeloma drug   Darzalex and the leukemia drug Imbruvica. Darzalex sales soared   to $572 million from $20 million in its first full year on the   market. Meanwhile
column47: Imbruvica's sales jumped 82% to $1.2 billion   in 2016 These two drugs are emblematic of Johnson & Johnson's   success at commercializing next-generation medicine.Granted
column48: the drug industry is a hypercompetitive and expiring   patents means more competition is coming
column49: but management has   decades of experience navigating patent risk
column50: and with some of   the deepest pockets in the industry
column51: I'm confident Johnson &   Johnson will innovate new drugs that help it sidestep its   competitors.Overall
column52: if you want to own fast-growing dividend stocks in   your income portfolio
column53: then there could be better options
column54: but if   your goal is to own a steady-Eddy performer with an enviable   track record of dividend increases
