column1: Virtual Reality Was a Flop in 2016. Will 2017 Be the Year It Takes Off?;2/20/2017;"Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();Consumer-level virtual reality (VR) received its first big   push in 2016 with major headset launches fromFacebook(NASDAQ: FB)
column2: HTC(NASDAQOTH: HTCCY)
column3: andSony(NYSE: SNE)
column4: but uptake for the technology fell short of many   analysts' expectations
column5: and there are a range of challenges that   threaten to limit future adoption. Sales for Facebook's   Oculus Rift and HTC's Vive headsets dried up after their   respective launches
column6: and SuperData cut its 2016 sales estimate   for Sony's PlayStation VR from 2.6 million units to 745
column7: 000 units   -- potentially worrying signs for the future of head-mounted   displays.VR still has compelling prospects
column8: but it's also clear that   the technology will have to overcome certain roadblocks before   it's ready for prime time. In order to better understand the   potential growth trajectory for virtual reality in 2017 and   beyond
column9: let's take a look at some of the factors that are shaping   the progression of the technology.More affordable
column10: but not cheap enoughThe fact thatSamsung's Gear VR -- which uses compatible cellphones for its display   and retails at $99 -- is the top-selling headset suggests that   price will continue to be a key hurdle for higher-end virtual   reality adoption. The Oculus Rift still sells for $599
column11: while the   Vive is priced at $799
column12: and the PlayStation VR retails at $399.   In addition to a growing list of compatible phones for Gear VR   and Alphabet's Google Daydream platform
column13: more headsets will hit   the market in 2017 and fill in the gaps between high- and low-end   experiences. Increased competition should put pressure on   Facebook
column14: HTC
column15: and Sony to lower the prices for their devices or   improve value propositions through bundling and other   promotions.Lenovois expected to release a headset this year that delivers higher   resolution than the Rift or the Vive
column16: a lighter weight
column17: and   augmented reality (AR) capabilities -- all at a sub-$400 price.   Lenovo's device will be part ofMicrosoft's(NASDAQ: MSFT) Windows Holographic virtual reality ecosystem
column18: and make use of a dual-camera internal tracking system (as   opposed to the external systems used by the Vive
column19: Oculus Rift
column20: and PS VR) that could be instrumental in the emergence of more   affordable headsets. Windows Holographic headsets will reportedly   start in the $300 price range and are being designed to be   compatible with mid-range computers -- moves that should make   virtual reality more accessible and build Microsoft's position in   the space. Companies including Asus
column21: Acer
column22: HP
column23: and Dell are also developing entries for the Windows   Holographic virtual reality platform
column24: though it's not clear   which
column25: if any
column26: will launch this year.Even with new entrants
column27: the cost of high-end VR will likely   continue to be prohibitive to mass-market adoption
column28: but reports   that Facebook is closing 200 out of 500 Oculus Rift demo stations   atBest Buylocations due to low engagement suggests other obstacles to VR   going mainstream this year.VR isn't going to break out yetWhile new competition means the cost of entry for mid-level   and high-end virtual devices is likely to fall this year
column29: a   growing selection of headsets will contribute to the trend of   fragmentation that threatens to limit the progression of VR.   Early competition to establish leadership in the space and   technological differences between high-end and low-end   devices have created a situation where many software   offerings are not compatible across devices. Fragmenting even   exists within individual platforms
column30: with Oculus Rift developers   needing to account for segmentation created by the introduction   of the device's touch-based controllers.For now
column31: VR hardware lacks a ""killer app"" to justify the cost   of entry
column32: and the dynamics of the current market present barriers   to the arrival of breakthrough software. With small and fractured   installed bases for VR headsets
column33: developing big-budget virtual   reality experiences still doesn't make sense for most developers
column34: and that issue is likely to persist through 2017. Even Sony
column35: a   platform holder with wide range of video game development   studios
column36: seems to have few projects on the horizon to support its   headset. Without standout software experiences to hook users and   encourage engagement with the new display mediums
column37: the high cost   of entry will remain prohibitive to the mass market audience.Future potentialWhile early uptake for VR has been disappointing compared to   initial projections
column38: it's important to remember just how young   this technology is. The overly optimistic forecasts for VR   adoption in 2016 give cause for some skepticism when looking at   future targets
column39: but expectations for huge growth in the category   persist
column40: with a study fromCitigroupestimating that the combined market for VR and AR will reach   $2.16 trillion by 2035.Despite initial roadblocks
column41: the immersive potential offered by   VR and AR and improvements to hardware and software make it   likely that the technology will eventually achieve mass adoption.   Last year marked the beginning of the consumer VR push
column42: and
column43: while it doesn't look like 2017 will deliver the confluence of   factors needed to propel the medium into the mainstream
column44: the   long-term outlook remains very bright.The early adopter market is mostly buying VR for video games
column45: but the technology will eventually be bridged to online shopping   and other uses
column46: and the immersive qualities of AR and VR should   open up huge advertising opportunities that help build support   for the new mediums.10 stocks we like better than MicrosoftWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column47: it can pay to listen. After all
column48: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column49: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column50: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Microsoft wasn't one of     them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

column1: How the Leaders of Enterprise Management SaaS are Growing;2/19/2017;"The battle for space in the Enterprise Management Software or Business Management Software segment has gotten a bit intense of late
column2: with Salesforce (CRM)
column3: Oracle (ORCL)
column4: Microsoft (MSFT) and SAP (SAP) fighting to increase their market share.Salesforce is the only niche player in the segment
column5: with a heavy focus on the Customer Relationship Management segment. The company came from behind to beat leaders of the segment
column6: Oracle and SAP
column7: and have more than $6 billion in annual revenues to show for their efforts. The CRM market is estimated to reach $36.5 billion in size in 2017
column8: with Salesforce in pole position.makeArticleAd();Oracle has recently upped its focus on this segment
column9: as the company wants to race against Salesforce to be the first SaaS/PaaS provider to reach ten billion dollars in annual SaaS sales. Oracle is more of a horizontal player in the segment
column10: with hands in CRM
column11: ERP
column12: HCM and SCM. The company recently bought Netsuite for $9.3 billion because it gave them a solid footing in the cloud ERP market.During the second quarter of 2017 Oracle had $878 million in revenue from its SaaS and PaaS units
column13: a growth of 81% compared the to the prior period. To hit ten billion dollars in revenue their quarterly revenues have to go over $2.5 billion. Even if the company were to continue its current growth rate
column14: it will easily take them two more years to get there. It's possible
column15: but Oracle has to remain aggressive if its wants to beat Salesforce to $10 billion
column16: because Salesforce revenue grew 25% during the recent third quarter results to reach $2.14 billion
column17: with subscription and support revenue touching $1.983 billion.But whoever gets there first is only going to get the bragging rights
column18: and nothing more. The fact remains that Salesforce is still a very strong player in its niche and will stay that way for a long time. Oracle is astutely going after multiple areas in the enterprise management software segment because a head to head collision is only going to slow things down for them.Microsoft is also slowly beefing up its capabilities in the enterprise management segment through Dynamics. It is the smallest player of the three right now
column19: but Microsoft has nothing to lose by moving into a segment they see as a natural extension of their office collaboration suite of products. Thanks to Office 365 and its growing portfolio of offerings
column20: it makes sense to dig deeper and wider into the enterprise market with asset management tools.Moreover
column21: with LinkedIn
column22: they're sitting at arm's length from millions of businesses that are potential clients
column23: so it's natural for the software maker to drive their strategy in that direction. In fact
column24: that was very likely their intention behind acquiring the professional network in the first place.The enterprise management software market is dominated by large vendors
column25: with some niche players in the mix. Due to the size and growth pace of the segment
column26: all of them will be able to show revenue growth in a sustainable manner.Disclosure:I have no positions in the stock mentioned above and no intention to initiate a position in the next 72 hours.Premium MembersThis article first appeared onGuruFocus."

column1: More Bullish
column2: Schwab Investors Are On The Prowl For Stocks;2/17/2017;"Investors know what they like
column3: and they liked the November   election results and December's interest-rate increase by the   Federal Reserve.Those events prompted a jump in investors who have retail   accounts withCharles Schwab(SCHW) to declare themselves bullish. In a fourth-quarter survey of   those investors
column4: Schwab found 42% of them said they now feel   bullish. That was a big jump up from the 34% who felt that way in   Q4 a year earlier.""As a result of the election
column5: clients saw an increased   prospect for a reduction in personal and corporate tax rates
column6: an   increased likelihood of spending on infrastructure
column7: and an   increased likelihood of a reduction in regulatory burdens for   some industries
column8: said Myhanh Hoskin
column9: a Schwab financial   consultant
column10: who is based in Seal Beach
column11: Calif. ""The rate increase   was a sign of growing strength in the economy.""makeArticleAd();Amid that widespread perception that the stock market had   become increasingly worth investing in
column12: Schwab investors did as   much buying as selling in the quarter.The top five U.S. holdings among all Schwab stock mutual funds   wereApple(AAPL)
column13: Microsoft(MSFT)
column14: Exxon Mobil(XOM)
column15: Johnson & Johnson(JNJ) andJPMorgan Chase(JPM) as of Feb. 16
column16: according to Morningstar Inc.Apple is up 17% year to date
column17: while Microsoft is up 4%
column18: Exxon   is down 10%
column19: Johnson & Johnson is up 3%
column20: and JPMorgan is up   5%.In Schwab's survey of its clients
column21: the general balance between   buying and selling bodes well for the market in additional ways.   ""It shows there isn't a sense of euphoria
column22: Hoskin said. ""It   shows caution by many investors. And that suggests that we're not   seeing a market top. That is a good thing. When you have too many   people doing the same thing
column23: that tends to be a contrarian   indicator.""On the other hand
column24: only 13% of investors said their top   concern about the market is that it appears overdue for a   correction
column25: suggesting a tone of overconfidence.In contrast
column26: a whopping 88% said they are confident about   reaching their financial goals.Allocations And OutlookInvestors had 41.3% of their money in stocks
column27: 21.1% in cash
column28: 18.8% in mutual funds
column29: 11.9% in exchange traded funds
column30: and 6.9%   in fixed income.And 21% of those investors said they planned to move more   money into stocks during the current first quarter.Stocks were the most popular planned destination for   additional allocations.ETFs were the second most popular target asset
column31: with 17% of   investors saying that's where they planned to put more money.Mutual funds were the third most popular
column32: with 15% of   investors saying they would move money into them in Q1.Investors were more inclined to get help in making investment   decisions. The number of clients seeking planning advice rose 10%   from a year earlier.RELATED:How This Mutual Fund Is Lighting Up Retirement     AccountsAre Fidelity's Recent Stock Buys And Sells     Retirement Account Hot Sauce?"

column1: VMware
column2: Inc. (VMW) Keeps the Momentum Going;2/17/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsVMware
column4: Inc.(NYSE:VMW) may not be one of the first companies that comes to mind when you're thinking about cloud services stocks. But
column5: it should be.makeArticleAd();Source:FlickrBelieve it or not
column6: VMW is one of the top enterprise cloud services and virtualization companies out there. And
column7: its growth up to now
column8: while impressive
column9: is just the beginning. In the past 12 months
column10: VMW stock has almost doubled.That sounds compelling
column11: but the underlying story is what makes VMW's rise something you should understand
column12: especially if you're looking for exposure in this massively disruptive market.Simply put
column13: cloud computing means that your computer doesn't need to have individual software packages for each specific job you want it to do. In the old days
column14: you ran a word processing program
column15: a spreadsheet program
column16: a design program
column17: etc. And
column18: every machine had to have its individual software suite.The rise of networked computers meant that all of this software could be stored on a network ""library"" and each user could access what they needed.7 Tech Stocks That Could Implode at Any MinuteThe next iteration of these networks were housed in the ""cloud
column19: which simply implies a virtual space built into servers. One of the primary advantages is the ability to access your information from the cloud
column20: regardless of where you are or what computer you're using.Cloud computing has been around for a long time
column21: and companies such asAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOGL)
column22: Microsoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT)
column23: Oracle Corporation(NYSE:ORCL) andAmazon.com
column24: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) have been using the cloud for many years.Now
column25: companies of all sizes are migrating to the cloud
column26: and within the cloud universe there both public clouds (where many people have access) and private clouds (where only select people have access). VMW provides the ability to develop each of these systems
column27: and also facilitates unique access between public and private clouds.Why Don't We Hear Much About VMware?VMWare is actually owned byDell Technologies Inc(NYSE:DVMT) subsidiary
column28: EMC Corporation(NYSE:EMC). Last April
column29: Dell bought EMC to become the largest privately-held tech company in the world. So
column30: VMWare is a cloud-based
column31: publicly-traded branch of this major tech player now.Part of the reason you don't hear about VMWare as much as its competitors is because the company's relationship to its owners is a bit convoluted
column32: and analysts aren't very confident in figuring out how to value VMW stock. Their loss is your gain.3 Stocks to Buy for Under $10 With 25%-Plus UpsideQ4 and full-year numbers were posted in late January
column33: and they show how strong VMW stock remains. Earnings beat analyst expectations and revenue continued to grow at a solid clip. A new strategic partnership with AMZN's cloud-computing juggernaut
column34: Amazon Web Services (AWS)
column35: adds some serious firepower to the VMW arsenal. It also helps the company remain competitive in a very dynamic field.When you have a tech parent like EMC and a tech partner like AWS
column36: you are doing very well. These brands are major players in the enterprise sector and will open even more doors for VMW in the future. VMWare stock is on a significant growth trajectory that should last years
column37: not months.Louis Navellieris a renowned growth investor. He is the editor of five investing newsletters:Blue Chip Growth
column38: Emerging Growth
column39: Ultimate Growth
column40: Family TrustandPlatinum Growth. His most popular service
column41: Blue Chip Growth
column42: has a track record of beating the market 3:1 over the last 14 years. He uses a combination of quantitative and fundamental analysis to identify market-beating stocks. Mr. Navellier has made his proven formula accessible to investors via his free
column43: online stock rating tool
column44: PortfolioGrader.com. Louis Navellier may hold some of the aforementioned securities in one or more of his newsletters.More From InvestorPlace7 Stocks to Sell or Short Before the Bears StrikeWhy Amazon.com
column45: Inc. (AMZN) Stock Could Fly to $1

column1: Apple Inc. (AAPL) May Have Different View On Trump’s iPhone Manufacturing Plans;2/17/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsApple Inc.(AAPL) does not mind making Trump furious.makeArticleAd();The U.S. President has been targeting Apple's low-energy and economically-sensible overseasmanufacturingsince the beginning. Even though the iPhone maker has so far stayed away from this debate
column3: recent comments from CFO Luca Maestri suggest that the U.S. firm has no plans of closing up shop in China any time soon
column4: according toBGR.In response to a question about overseas manufacturing at a Goldman Sachs conference
column5: Maestri said
column6: ""One of the points that we are making in Washington is the fact that we have been a very large contributor to the US economy during the last decade. We made billions ofinvestmentsin the United States. In the last 10 years
column7: we created about 2 million jobs in this country - in the developer community in our retail stores in our call centers and through the supplier chain.""Maestri then talked about Apple's U.S.-located call centers
column8: adding that speculating on Apple's manufacturing plans is really difficult
column9: especially when Trump hasn't outlined any specific policies.He did note that imposition of a border tax on imported products would lead to an additional burden on the end consumer.This could also mean that Apple is making yet another attempt to take iPhone manufacturing off the table for discussions with Trump. It seems that the iPhone maker does not mind taking back ancillary services
column10: such as support centers
column11: back to the US
column12: but it doesn't want to move the entire iPhone supply chain
column13: notes BGR.Microsoft Corporation (MSFT) Stock Could Win Big With 'Windows Cloud'Apple's iPhone manufacturing has been in the news for quite some time now.Reportedly
column14: Apple asked its subsidiaries to examine the feasibility of iPhone manufacturing soon after Trump's electoral victory. This ledBreitbartto run an (untrue) story:Silicon Valley Bows to Trump: Apple to Build iPhones in America.Apple Back on Top in Smartphone WarsMeanwhile
column15: for the first time in the last eight quarters
column16: Apple has taken the lead overSamsung Electronics(SSNLF) to become the world's top smartphone vendor. According to Gartner
column17: during the crucial holiday season
column18: the U.S. firm shipped the most smartphones
column19: but it only enjoys a razor thin lead over the Korean firm.As per Gartner's estimate
column20: the U.S. firm shipped about 77.04 millionsmartphonesin the fourth-quarter
column21: just ahead of Samsungs's 76.78 million. Based on this
column22: Apple's share in the global smartphone market is 17.9%
column23: while that of Samsung is 17.8%. This is the smallest difference recorded by Gartner
column24: according toCNBC.The postApple Inc. May Have Different View On Trump's iPhone Manufacturing Plansappeared first onValueWalk.Many academics claim investing is a ""random walk."" We believe this to be only partially true. It is our core belief that value investing can outperform the market
column25: hence the name ""ValueWalk."" (AAPL) May Have Different View On Trump's iPhone Manufacturing Plansappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Jeff Ubben Nabs NetScout in 4th Quarter;2/17/2017;"ValueAct Capital founderJeff Ubben(Trades
column2: Portfolio) gained one new holding in the final quarter of 2016
column3: NetScout Systems Inc.(NTCT).Ubben founded ValueAct in 2000 and serves as the CEO and chief investment officer. He manages a concentrated portfolio composed of companies he believes are fundamentally undervalued or out of favor. He generally establishes a significant ownership stake in order to work with management on maximizing returns to shareholders. His current portfolio consists of 14 stocks and is valued at $12.17 million.Ubben purchased 1
column5: 000 shares of NetScout for an average price of $30.68 per share
column6: expanding the portfolio 0.43%.makeArticleAd();NetScout is involved in application and network performance management. The Westford
column7: Massachusetts-based company serves enterprise communities
column8: government agencies and telecommunication service providers. It has a market cap of $3.5 billion; its shares were trading around $37.65 on Friday with a price-earnings (P/E) ratio of 418.3
column9: a forward P/E ratio of 17.4
column10: a price-book (P/B) ratio of 1.5 and a price-sales (P/S) ratio of 3.The Peter Lynch chart below shows the stock is trading above its fair value.GuruFocus ranked the company's financial strength 6 of 10. The Piotroski F-Score of 7 and Altman Z-Score of 2.2 suggest the company is in good business condition with minor financial stress. Since the return on invested capital underperforms the weighted average cost of capital

column12: the interest coverage ratio of 2.04 falls below Benjamin Graham's standard of five
column13: implying it may soon be burdened by debt.GuruFocus ranked NetScout's profitability and growth 8 of 10. It has an operating margin of 1.6% and a net margin of 0.6%. The return on equity (ROE) and return on assets (ROA) underperform 64% and 61% of other companies in the global software-application industry. In contrast
column14: the return on capital (ROC) outperforms 53% of competitors.NetScout does not pay a dividend.Among the gurus invested in NetScout

column17: Portfolio)

column20: Portfolio) also hold the stock.Technology stocks have a 23.1% weight in Ubben's portfolio. Other technology stocks he holds areSeagate Technology PLC(STX) andMicrosoft Corp.(MSFT). Microsoft is his largest holding with a weight of 19.7%.Disclosure:I do not own any stocks mentioned in the article.Start afree 7-day trial of Premium Membershipto GuruFocus.Premium MembersThis article first appeared onGuruFocus."

column1: Apple to Begin Assembling iPhone SE in India from April;2/17/2017;"makeZacksArticleAd();Reportedly
column2: Apple Inc.AAPLin collaboration with its manufacturer
column3: Wistron Inc. will begin to assemble iPhone SE in India starting this April. The plant will be located in the state of Karnataka in south India.Though there is no official word on the matter from Apple or Wistron
column4: it has been reported that initially the Cupertino giant wants to assemble 0.3-0.4 million units of iPhone SE. Apple hasn't even waited for the numerous tax concessions that it sought from the India government including the 15-year customs duty holiday.Analysts observe that it was prudent on part of Apple to begin assembling its most economic iPhone offering
column5: SE
column6: which was launched to cater to cost sensitive markets like India. Plus
column7: it also will support future iOS upgrades unlike iPhone 5S
column8: which will soon be discontinued in most of the markets including India.Apple Inc. PriceApple Inc. Price|Apple Inc. QuoteWhy is Apple Keen on India?Since the last year
column9: Apple has been increasing its focus on India to claim a greater share of the vast smartphone market
column10: of which it reportedly holds only 2% as of now. Apple faces slowing iPhone demand in most of the regions
column11: either because of competition or regulatory hurdles (China) or market saturation (the U.S). Therefore
column12: it makes sense for the company to solidify its position in India
column13: which is projected to become the second largest smartphone market in the world. In fiscal 2016
column14: Apple sales in India grew approximately 50% over the prior fiscal.Furthermore
column15: a younger (and skilled) population and increasing investment in broadband network by the government also make India an attractive growth opportunity for Apple over the long run. In fact
column16: the government under PM Narendra Modi is eager to bring foreign capital and boost manufacturing facilities in India.The recently outlined FDI policy also bodes well for the company as it eliminates the requirement to locally source products for at least a three-year period. This will enable Apple to open its solely-owned retails stores in India. Thereafter
column17: the company will have to comply with the rule. The company has also partnered with telecom company Reliance
column18: which is providing its Jio (a unique all-IP network) service for free with the new iPhones.Last year
column19: Tim Cook was on a charm offensive in India. Besides meeting Modi
column20: he also announced the opening of an iOS App Design and Development Accelerator in Bengaluru and a map development office in another southern Indian city
column21: Hyderabad in collaboration with regional firm RMSI.ChallengesThe market is highly cost sensitive. Reportedly
column22: majority of the smartphones sold are priced around INR 10K (roughly $145). iPhone 7 on the other hand costs almost five times more. Even iPhone SE is priced at INR 30K. The lion's share of Apple's revenues in the country comes from devices
column23: which are a couple of generations old. Newer models have relatively low demand given the hefty price tag.  A few days back
column24: it was reported that the Apple team in India is trying to increase revenues to $3 billion by 2017-18 and by local assembling operations
column25: the company can start to operate its own retail outlets and avail a 10% tax benefit. This should lower prices.Plus
column26: Apple's rival Samsung along with a few Chinese smartphone makers dominates this market. Samsung has long been in the market and with reportedly 23% share
column27: it is a leading player in the country. Apple is quite late to the party.Also
column28: Apple's lack of focus on regional customers' demand is a concern. India is categorized by handsets that work on dual SIMs. Apparently
column29: Apple is not keen on making dual SIM handsets. This could be a very big impediment to growth in the country.Also
column30: analysts observe that Apple is ""relocating"" manufacturing to India from China
column31: given rising labor costs. However another analyst argues that though labor is cheap compared with China
column32: productivity is relatively better in China. Simple assembling may not drastically bring down prices. However
column33: the creation of a local supply chain as in China will be a big positive.Despite the pros and cons
column34: Apple is expected to continue its India drive. It will be taking up a lot more initiatives this year. However
column35: whether those initiatives yield desirable results remains a watch and see story.Apple
column36: of course
column37: is not the only tech player eyeing India for growth. Given the potential of this market
column38: Silicon Valley's interest is well understood. From Microsoft Corp.MSFTto AlphabetGOOGLto Facebook Inc.FBall remain laser focused on the market.Zacks Rank & Price MovementAt present
column39: Apple has a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold). You can seethe complete list of today's Zacks #1 Rank (Strong Buy) stocks here.Over the past one year

column1: Better Buy: Microsoft Corporation vs. Oracle Corporation;2/17/2017;"Co-founder and Chief Technology Officer Larry Ellison   describesOracle(NYSE: ORCL) as a cloud leader to be reckoned with
column2: and he may be   right -- eventually. But today it'sMicrosoft(NASDAQ: MSFT) at the top of the cloud heap. But Oracle's late   start -- thanks to Ellison's early dismissal of cloud computing   as nothing more than ""the latest fashion"" -- could work in   investors' favor because it translates to tremendous upside from   here.Meanwhile
column3: Microsoft's decision to name Satya Nadella as CEO   three years ago has proven to be an absolute game changer.   Microsoft's stock was meandering under former chief Steve   Ballmer
column4: but no longer. Nadella has changed Microsoft's business   focus as well as its culture -- and it's working.So which stock is the better buy? Let's take a look.makeArticleAd();Image source: Oracle.The case for OracleOracle's fiscal second quarter (ended Nov. 30) was one to   remember as it relates to cloud results. For the first time
column5: Oracle's combined cloud Platform-as-a-Service (PaaS)
column6: Software-as-a-Service (SaaS)
column7: and infrastructure revenues topped   the $1 billion mark. PaaS and SaaS revenue climbed 81% last   quarter  to $878 million.Cloud Infrastructure-as-a-Service (IaaS) couldn't match the   growth rate of Oracle's skyrocketing SaaS and PaaS results
column8: but   its revenue still climbed 6% to $175 million
column9: bringing total   cloud sales to $1.05 billion
column10: equal to 12% of Oracle's $9 billion   in total revenue last quarter. For some perspective
column11: a year ago   Oracle reported $649 million in cloud revenue
column12: which equaled just   7% of its $8.99 billion in total sales.Oracle has quickly become a software vendor of note outside   the cloud
column13: too. Its legacy hardware and related support sales of   $1 billion notched a 10% decline from a year ago
column14: which can be   attributed to Oracle's shift to up-and-coming opportunities along   with the inevitable slowing of ""old-school"" enterprise hardware   markets.Though software and license sales declined 4% last quarter
column15: when combined with cloud revenue -- an Oracle earnings report   staple nowadays -- the $7.2 billion was a 2% year-over-year   improvement. Better still
column16: and something worth watching for when   Oracle reports estimated third-quarter earnings on March 13
column17: is   that combined cloud and software revenue now accounts for 80% of   all sales
column18: up from 78% a year ago.Image source: Microsoft.The case for MicrosoftSimilar to Oracle
column19: Microsoft's cloud results are centered on   SaaS. According toGartner
column20: overall SaaS cloud revenue jumped $36 billion to $144 billion   in 2016. SaaS is forecast to grow at an annual rate of 37%   through 2020
column21: and Microsoft is leading the charge. The only cloud   segment expected to grow faster than SaaS are business process   sales
column22: at 43% per year
column23: which is another key to Microsoft's   stellar results.Last quarter
column24: Microsoft's cloud annual revenue run rate was   more than $14 billion
column25: led by commercial Office 365 sales
column26: its   Azure platform
column27: and Dynamics CRM. Azure
column28: which is Microsoft's   PaaS for delivering cloud solutions
column29: soared 93%. Despite its   rapid cloud growth
column30: Microsoft is controlling costs.Total revenue increased just 1.2% last quarter to $24 billion
column31: but net income grew nearly 4% to $5.2 billion. With about 200   million fewer shares outstanding and the company managing   expenses
column32: Microsoft's $0.66-per-share earnings was a 6.5%   increase
column33: and that included a negative $0.01 hit from the   LinkedIn acquisition.So
column34: which is the better buy?In addition to being further along in its cloud transition   than Oracle
column35: Microsoft has multiple revenue drivers including the   LinkedIn assets and the data that comes with it. And Microsoft is   leading the race to dominate augmented reality (AR)
column36: a market   expected to generate $83 billion by 2021 compared to virtual   reality's (VR) $25 billion.Oracle is on the right path
column37: and its 1.5% dividend yield is   respectable. However
column38: considering Microsoft's cloud and AR   leadership positions
column39: a dividend yield of 2.5%
column40: data analytics   driven by artificial intelligence (AI)
column41: Bing search
column42: and OS   leadership positions
column43: it all adds up to Microsoft as the better   buy.10 stocks we like better than OracleWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock       tip
column44: it can pay to listen. After all
column45: the newsletter they       have run for over a decade
column46: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column47: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Oracle wasn't one of       them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even       better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

column1: Meet The 'Fastest-Growing' $1 Billion Enterprise Software Firm;2/17/2017;"Technology investors looking for high revenue growth often   find their answer in software-as-a-service companies.ServiceNow(NOW) is one of the fastest-growing companies that fits that   bill. ServiceNow's 2016 sales exploded 38% to $1.4 billion
column2: and it has laid claim to being the ""fastest-growing enterprise   software company with more than $1 billion in revenue.""[ibdchart symbol=""NOW"" type=""daily"" size=""threequarter""   position=""leftchart"" ]It has set big goals
column3: too. The Santa Clara
column4: Calif.-based company plans to nearly triple its revenue   to $4 billion by 2020.makeArticleAd();""There's not another company that produces growth at our scale   like we do
column5: Frank Slootman
column6: ServiceNow's chief executive
column7: said   in an interview. ""It's a trifecta - scale
column8: growth and free   cash flow.""ServiceNow faces fierce competition
column9: though
column10: most notably fromSalesforce.com(CRM)
column11: currently the market leader in the industry known as SaaS.   Salesforce.com's 2016 sales boomed 24% to $6.7 billion
column12: and the   San Francisco-based company is on track to hit $10 billion in   revenue for the current fiscal year. It's aiming to hit $20   billion after that.Salesforce.com has the higher profile
column13: being oft-mentioned in   industry merger activity
column14: whether it involvesMicrosoft(MSFT)
column15: LinkedIn
column16: Twitter(TWTR) or another company. It specializes in software that helps   businesses organize and handle sales operations.But ServiceNow stock has shot up 25% in 2017
column17: while   Salesforce.com is up 18% after lagging last year.How It WorksSaaS companies sell online subscriptions to software
column18: rather   than one-time licenses. SaaS providers have high customer renewal   rates and book recurring revenue over the long term. Most sell   into the so-called ""enterprise market"" - large companies
column19: government agencies and other big customers.ServiceNow has prospered by taking away the customers of BMC   Software
column20: Hewlett Packard Enterprise(HPE)
column21: CA Technologies(CA) and other ""on-premise"" software providers that shifted slowly   to cloud-based SaaS business models.Founded in 2004
column22: ServiceNow developed software for information   technology service management
column23: basically IT help-desk tools for   tracking internal company issues. As Salesforce.com has expanded   into marketing
column24: customer service and e-commerce
column25: ServiceNow has   made a similar push into customer-service tools
column26: heightening the   rivalry between the two.Salesforce.com has been an acquisition machine
column27: spending more   than $4.6 billion in 2016 alone to buy companies.In ServiceNow's case
column28: though
column29: it can hit its $4 billion target   by growing ""organically
column30: meaning without big acquisitions
column31: says   Alex Zukin
column32: a Piper Jaffray analyst.""There may be opportunities for them to enhance the breadth of   their offerings with (small) tuck-in acquisitions
column33: Zukin   added.New MarketsServiceNow expects to reach its $4 billion revenue goal by   expanding into new markets - human resources
column34: customer service   management and security
column35: to name a few - and by landing bigger   contracts while targeting the top 2
column36: 000 global companies.ServiceNow has bought small companies like Neebula Systems
column37: iTapp and most recently DxContinuum to acquire ""talent and   technology
column38: said Slootman
column39: who has been ServiceNow's CEO since   2011. He earlier headed Data Domain
column40: which was sold to data   storage networking giant EMC in 2009.""Technology is not as useful without the talent
column41: Slootman   said. ""We have the ability to sell
column42: so I don't need to acquire   revenue or customers. We can do that ourselves. We try to acquire   small companies with promising technology before they go vertical   and their revenue explodes
column43: because then it's way more expensive   (to acquire them).""ServiceNow still garners most revenue from service management
column44: but the 2014 Neebula acquisition provided key technology for   mapping a customers' IT infrastructure in case outages or other   problems occur. That's a different market
column45: called IT operations   management. ServiceNow's 2016 purchase of ITApp provided cloud   management tools.ServiceNow's operations management tools account for about 9%   of subscription revenue
column46: with that expected to grow to at least   15% by 2020.Common GroundSlootman says the same software tools that automate   information-technology workflows and record keeping can be   applied for finance
column47: legal
column48: procurement and other corporate   departments. Like Salesforce.com
column49: ServiceNow is building a   library of business apps that customers can download via the   internet.The name of the game for many SaaS companies is building a   cloud ""platform"" so they can sell multiple software tools to   different industries.IBD'S TAKE:After a series offlat basesover the last 10 months
column50: ServiceNow broke out last month and is     staking out higher ground above the 90 level. ServiceNow is theeighth-ranked companyin IBD's Computer Software-Enterprise Group. Tops on the list     isPaycom Software(PAYC)
column51: which has aComposite Rating of 95out of a possible 99.""In software everyone claims to be a platform play
column52: but in   reality there are only a few that can make that claim
column53: and   ServiceNow is one of them
column54: said Matthew Hedberg
column55: a RBC Capital   analyst in a report.Much of ServiceNow's revenue growth has come from   ""cross-selling."" Its sales staff aims to sell more products to   existing service management customers. IBM has emerged as a   key partner of ServiceNow
column56: reselling its service management and   other tools. Accenture has been a marketing partner in the   government market.Alex Zukin
column57: an analyst at Piper Jaffray
column58: says IBM looms as a   ""logical acquirer (of ServiceNow) over the longer term.""""ServiceNow's platform would be a logical extension of IBM's   cloud infrastructure
column59: Zukin said.Possible Buyout?In mid-2016
column60: ServiceNow was among companies listed in a score   card of possible Salesforce.com acquisitions that leaked from a   board of directors meeting.Pegasystems(PEGA) andTableau Software(DATA) also were on Salesforce's wish list
column61: but ServiceNow's   market cap is much bigger at more than $15 billion.ServiceNow generates hefty free cash flow
column62: a feat that's not   common among SaaS companies
column63: and a plus for any potential   acquirers. Free cash flow rose 40% to $322 million in   2016.The company reported unadjusted earnings of 71 cents in 2016   but it's still not profitable on an adjusted basis
column64: which   includes stock-based compensation. Shares of ServiceNow   ended trading Friday up 1% to 92.74.ServiceNow has forecast 2017 revenue growth of 32% to $1.835   billion
column65: at the midpoint of its guidance. Billing growth has   stabilized after slowing in 2015
column66: when the company reorganized   sales. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters are modeling 54%   earnings growth to $1.08 a share in 2017.A roadmap to ServiceNow's $4 billion revenue goal was revealed   in May 2016. A month earlier
column67: it settled patent infringement   cases with BMC and HPE. Analysts expect ServiceNow to   continue taking share in the service management market from   BMC and others
column68: though privately held Cherwell Software is a   strong rival.As ServiceNow expands into new markets
column69: analysts say it could   run into more competition from the likes ofAtlassian(TEAM)
column70: Zendesk(ZEN) andSplunk(SPLK).Zukin says that in many cases ServiceNow's management software   can work alongside other tools. He says human resources
column71: whereWorkday(WDAY) is a leading provider
column72: is one example.Growing RivalryThe Salesforce rivalry
column73: though
column74: seems to be growing.""Historically
column75: ServiceNow's messaging has been that ServiceNow   and Salesforce.com can coexist in accounts. The new message seems   to be that customers are increasingly taking a 'CRM model' or   'service management' platform approach
column76: Brian Schwartz
column77: an   Oppenheimer analyst
column78: wrote in a recent report to clients. ""In   other words
column79: we believe the two platforms will increasingly be   seen as future alternatives rather than running in parallel.""ServiceNow aims to leverage its database technology to provide   more problem-solving tools in handling customer-service issues.   Both Salesforce.com and ServiceNow are adding artificial   intelligence to software. By embedding data analytics and   ""machine learning"" into software
column80: they aim to make it easier for   customers to automate tasks.ServiceNow acquired AI startup DxContinuum in January.   Slootman says he plans to utilize DxContinuum's  throughout   ServiceNow's cloud platform. The tools will help customers build   predictive models that make it easier to categorize incoming   requests from company employees.Aside from HR
column81: customer service and security
column82: Slootman says   SeriveNow could target other areas.""The good thing about this model is we can try things
column83: we can   be opportunistic
column84: Slootman said. ""If something works
column85: we'll do   more. But we can also back out if it doesn't. There are no   life-and-death bets. We can be very agile in how we move in or   out of adjacent markets.""RELATED:Will Microsoft Stymie Salesforce.com's Stock     Turnaround?"

column1: Why Connected Cars Are a Big Deal for Microsoft Corporation's Cloud Business;2/16/2017;"Microsoft(NASDAQ: MSFT) is making a big move in the automotive space   without making any cars of its own. The Redmond
column2: Wash. company   has decided that it won't be joining the race to develop its own   cars
column3: like many of its peers. Instead
column4: Microsoft wants to become   the racetrack itself.Microsoft's automotive moveAt CES 2017
column5: Microsoft announced the launch of the Connected   Vehicle Platform based on Azure in a bid to become the   cornerstone of the connected and automated car revolution. This   platform will focus on five key things the cars of tomorrow need   -- advanced navigation
column6: predictive maintenance
column7: better in-car   productivity
column8: customer inputs
column9: and finally
column10: enabling autonomous   driving.Image source: Microsoft.makeArticleAd();According to a blog post by Microsoft Executive VP of   Business Development Peggy Johnson:Microsoft's cloud will do the heavy lifting by ingesting     huge volumes of sensor and usage data from connected vehicles
column11: and then helping automakers apply that data in powerful     ways.Microsoft
column12: therefore
column13: is taking the smart approach of becoming   the enabler of connected and automated cars. Such an approach   avoids the need for delivering any sort of packaged product to   automakers. The connected vehicle platform will use artificial   intelligence (AI) based on data provided by vehicles and drivers   in real time.In fact
column14: the company has been shoring up its AI capabilities   in order to develop its automotive platform. Last month
column15: it   announced the acquisition of Canadian AI company Maluuba for an   undisclosed amount. Maluuba uses deep learning and neural   networks to create independent machines that can ""think
column16: reason
column17: and communicate like humans."" Microsoft can use these traits to   enhance the data processing and decision-making capabilities of   its own technology.Additionally
column18: Microsoft will power the in-car productivity of   cars by equipping automakers with its key products
column19: such as   Office 365
column20: Cortana
column21: and Skype for Business. This focus on   offering a cloud platform with advanced computing and   productivity to automotive clients should help it win a lot of   business in this space.The opportunity in automotive data processing and     storageComputer software provider Tuxera believes a new car in 2017   will generate 20 GB of data daily if it is driven for just two   hours. This amount of data will come from just 16 sensors and two   cameras
column22: and these cars are far from being fully autonomous. By   comparison
column23: future cars with enhanced self-driving capabilities   are expected to have at least 20 computers on board to process   the data captured by cameras.In fact
column24: an autonomous vehicle is expected to generate 10 GB   of data each second
column25: which will increase as more sensors are   added. This presents the need for a centralized   infrastructure to share the processing workload. This way
column26: the   vehicle can collect data and prioritize actions that have to be   executed in real time and upload the rest to a data center for   further processing and analysis.Microsoft wants to become this data center with its connected   vehicle platform. The company has even equipped the Azure cloud   platform withNVIDIA's Quadro professional graphics card. As a result
column27: Azure can now   offer supercomputing-class performance to its customers for   high-performance applications
column28: indicating that it is prepared to   process the huge amount of data connected cars will generate.What connected cars mean for Microsoft's     businessMicrosoft is on the right track as it has already won   contracts with key automakers. TheRenault-Nissanalliance is one of the first adopters of the connected vehicle   platform as it plans to put 10 autonomous cars on the roads by   2020 using Microsoft's cloud.Investors should also note that car makers aren't the only   ones utilizing the Azure connected cloud platform. Reinsurance   provider Swiss Re
column29: for example
column30: is exploring the use of the Azure   cloud to collect and analyze telematics data to create specific   insurance packages for customers based on driving   behavior. Similarly
column31: geographical information system   provider Esri has also signed up to use the Azure cloud to   provide analytics and data to the driver of a car.A growing
column32: diversified client base can boost the company's   cloud business in the long run
column33: which is already growing at a   faster-than-expected pace. When Microsoft released its second   quarter results
column34: its cloud revenue grew 10% year over year to   $6.9 billion
column35: outperforming analyst expectations.The company's cloud growth was driven by a 93% jump in revenue   from Azure as Microsoft saw the platform's usage by clients   double on a year-over-year basis. An increase in the adoption of   Microsoft's connected vehicle services over time will lead to   wins for the Azure platform as data needs inevitably grow.10 stocks we like better than MicrosoftWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column36: it can pay to listen. After all
column37: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column38: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column39: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now...and Microsoft wasn't one of     them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6
column40: 2017.Teresa Kersten is an employee of LinkedIn and is a member     of The Motley Fool's Board of Directors. LinkedIn is owned by     Microsoft.Harsh Chauhanhas no position in any stocks mentioned. The Motley Fool owns     shares of and recommends Nvidia. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: Fidelity Investments' Revenue And Profit Rose In 2016;2/16/2017;"Known for managing millions of retirement accounts
column2: college   savings plans and regular taxable-investment accounts
column3: Fidelity   Investments on Thursday said 2016 revenue rose 3.4% to $15.9   billion
column4: a record for the privately held company.The combination of revenue growth and slightly lower expenses   produced a record profit of $3.5 billion. That was an increase of   19.5% over 2015's $3 billion in operating income.""All businesses contributed to our strong results
column5: a Fidelity   spokesman said.makeAd('4'
column7: 'mktsnews'
column8: 'vanguard'
column10: '');The 2016 profit increase reversed a profit decline in   2015
column11: when profit fell $325 million
column13: from 2014's $3.282   billion.""Fidelity is profitable
column14: strong
column15: innovative and driven to   growth
column16: said Jim Lowell
column17: editor-in-chief of Fidelity   Investor
column18: an independent newsletter. ""That's not true for many   financial services companies.""The 2015 profit erosion was caused by spending on staffing and   technology to compete with tough rivals.Operating expenses fell slightly to $12.35 billion in 2016   from $12.4 billion the year before.""The slowdown in expenses is because Fidelity is starting to   see the benefit in Abigail's (Johnson) leadership
column19: Lowell said.   One way she has cut spending is by centralizing functions
column20: eliminating redundancies in information technology and   compliance. ""There's more efficiency
column21: Lowell said.Across all of its stock mutual funds
column22: technology was   Fidelity's largest sector as of Jan. 31 with a 20.3%
column23: according   to Morningstar Inc.Fidelity's top U.S. holdings wereApple(AAPL)
column24: Facebook(FB)

column1: Would You Ditch Your Home Phone for Amazon.com
column2: Inc. (AMZN)?;2/16/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column3: Stock Advice & Trading TipsRoughly half of American homes no longer have an old-school telephone
column4: relying instead on cell phones and smartphones. IfAmazon.com
column5: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN) andAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOGL) have their way
column6: home phones could become even more of a rarity.makeArticleAd();Source: AmazonA report inTheWall Street Journalsuggests the companies are working on adding voice-calling capabilities to the Amazon Echo and Google Home smart speakers.The Plan to Make Amazon Echo Your New TelephoneTheWall Street Journalis reporting that Google and Amazon are looking at an all-new use for their smart speakers:replacing the home telephone.The idea makes sense. Telephones increasingly seem like outdated technology. Between smartphones and PC-based calling services likeMicrosoft Corporation's(NASDAQ:MSFT) Skype
column7: the days of the dedicated home phone seem numbered. In 2015
column8: a survey by the Center for Disease Control and Prevention (which
column9: apparently
column10: cares about these things) found thatnearly half of American homes had given up their dedicated landline.But
column11: that still leaves a lot of telephones in operation.Apparently
column12: it's occurred to both Amazon and Google that smart speakers such as the Amazon Echo and Google Home may be the right device in the right place at the right time. Smart speakers get the name because they leverage an AI-powered personal digital assistant.Why Amazon.com
column13: Inc. (AMZN) Stock Could Fly to $1
column14: 000 in 2017Amazon's Echo is home to Alexa
column15: withover 5
column16: 000 skills. These devices have the smarts to take on telephone functionality. They could incorporate Skype
column17: for example. And
column18: Google has a slew of its own telephony applications it could leverage
column19: including Google Voice and Duo.The Amazon Echo and Google Home are equipped with excellent microphones
column20: they have speakers
column21: they are always connected (to the internet) and they respond instantly to voice commands
column22: even from across a room.So
column23: as long as privacy isn't an issue (since using one would be like using a speakerphone)
column24: a smart speaker could replace a telephoneandsave consumers money by eliminating the monthly cost of a landline. While this would be a potentially useful trick for existing smart speaker owners
column25: it's the kind of practical capability that could drive sales among those consumers who wouldn't otherwise consider a high-tech device like the Amazon Echo.The Challenges of Turning a Smart Speaker Into a TelephoneWhile the technology and built-in smarts may be there
column26: in reality turning that Amazon Echo on your kitchen counter into your home phone may not be quite that simple.TheWall Street Journalarticle lays out some of the challenges. For example
column27: there are potential privacy issues
column28: not only in speaking out loud to the Echo (it lacks an AUX input
column29: so you couldn't physically connect a handset)
column30: but the fact that now your telephone would always be listening to you and recording key data like phone numbers and call durations.Amazon and Google would also have to implement a feature to prevent voice commands from being triggered during a phone conversation.It's also been pointed out that switching from a cell phone or landline to an internet-based telephone service has implications for emergency services. For example
column31: theFCC lists a series of limitations to 911 servicewhen home owners rely on internet-based (or VoIP) services.Calls may not be routed directly to an emergency center
column32: locational information may not be available to emergency responders and
column33: in a power outage
column34: internet telephones go offline without battery backups.7 Tech Stocks That Could Implode at Any MinuteDespite the challenges
column35: The Wall Street Journalsays its sources are convinced Amazon and Google will move forward
column36: calling the move to telephone capability ""the logical next step for the artificial intelligence-powered speakers."" And
column37: that move could happen later this year.The question is
column38: knowing that there are some privacy concerns and potential safety issues in doing so
column39: would you ditch your landline and use an Amazon Echo as your home's new telephone?As of this writing

column1: Apple Inc. (AAPL) Careens Closer to Major AR Announcement;2/16/2017;"InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) CEO Tim Cook has been talking an awful lot lately about augmented reality - or AR. The latest episode was last week
column3: when hecompared the technology to the iPhonein terms of its potential to be big.makeArticleAd();Source: NanticAfter months of repeatedly playing up AR in public
column4: it's beginning to feel as if Cook is setting the expectations of the press and public about the technology.That begs the question: Is Apple Inc. planning a major augmented reality announcement?AR vs. VR: What's the Difference?Augmented reality is related to virtual reality - or VR - but the two are also very different.Virtual reality uses technology to completely immerse people in a virtual world. This requires powerful computing hardware and special headgear. VR has spent several years as the next big thing
column5: culminating withFacebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB) buying VR pioneer Oculus for $2 billion in 2014.Virtual reality hasn't quite caught on in a big way - the expensive and awkward equipment is a big hurdle to overcome - but gamers have begun embracing it.7 Stocks Warren Buffett Is Buying or SellingSo far
column6: Apple has shown no interest in virtual reality and Tim Cook has actually made a point in several interviews of downplaying VR. In the latest
column7: when Cook spoke toThe Independent
column8: he laments the fact that virtual reality""closes the world out.""""Most people don't want to lock themselves out from the world for a long period of time and today you can't do that because you get sick from it.""The antisocial aspects of virtual reality
column9: the equipment requirements and side effects such as motion sickness have been common themes in Cook's argument against virtual reality.However
column10: he is very excited by augmented reality and its ability to go mainstream. Instead of locking a person into a virtual world
column11: AR overlays the existing world with additional information. One of the most popular examples of AR in action is the gamePokemon Go
column12: released last summer. That game was themost downloaded app of 2016on Apple Inc.'s App Store.Is Apple Inc. Planning a Major AR Announcement?Tim Cook's views on augmented reality seem to have been getting more positive in the past few months
column13: reaching the point where he's actively hyping the technology.In October
column14: he said:""I do think that a significant portion of the population of developed countries
column15: and eventually all countries
column16: will have AR experiences every day
column17: almost like eating three meals a day. It will become that much a part of you.""And last week
column18: he toldThe Independent:""I regard it as a big idea like the smartphone. The smartphone is for everyone
column19: we don't have to think the iPhone is about a certain demographic
column20: or country or vertical market: it's for everyone. I think AR is that big
column21: it's huge.""What's holding AR back is the technology.Hardware doesn't need to be as powerful as the silicon needed to drive virtual reality gear. And rather than a fully enclosed headpiece or goggles - that themselves are so complex they can cost $600 on top of the PC needed to drive them - augmented reality can be delivered through specialized eyeglasses or on a smartphone's display. The problem is current efforts haven't been quite good enough.Alphabet Inc's(NASDAQ:GOOG
column22: NASDAQ:GOOGL) failed Google Glass is the best-known example of the AR overlay glasses model
column23: whilePokemon Goshows the relatively primitive AR experience that current smartphones can deliver.What if Tim Cook has been playing up augmented reality (and dissing VR) because Apple Inc. is preparing to make a major push into AR? It could be the company that takes augmented reality mainstream by nailing the hardware
column24: while everyone else is distracted by trying to get consumers to buy into VR.There has been speculation that Apple is working with German optics firmCarl Zeiss AGonApple-branded AR glasses. The iPhone 8 could also incorporate next generation hardware - from cameras to CPU and GPU - that are optimized to make AR a killer feature.Microsoft Corporation (MSFT) Stock Could Win Big With 'Windows Cloud'We'll have to wait until the company is ready to show its hand to know exactly what is up. But based on Tim Cook's continued promotion of the technology
column25: it seems likely that Apple Inc. is priming us for AR-related announcement.And if Cook is even close to being right about augmented reality having the potential to be as big as the iPhone
column26: the upside for Apple stock could be huge.As of this writing
column27: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace7 Stocks to Sell or Short Before the Bears Strike3 Tire Stocks That Are Burning Rubber in ChinaThe postApple Inc. (AAPL) Careens Closer to Major AR Announcementappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Tech Stock Roundup: INTC Analyst Day
column2: AAPL Smartphone Lead;2/15/2017;"Intel Analyst DayIntel's analyst day was mostly about the growing importance of the data center business as a driver of both revenue growth and margin pressure. Within data center
column3: the enterprise and government segment is expected to be the weakest due to delays related to the transition from on-premises to public cloud-based deployment
column4: which is why it will grow a mere 2%.But this will be strongly supplemented with 15%+ growth in cloud service provider (helped by TAM expansion and higher prices) and 10%+ growth in communications service provider revenues. The much larger CPU portion will post a 6% CAGR dropping from 87% of revenue in 2017 to 75% in 2021. Non CPU parts of the data center business will record a 30% CAGR during the same time period.Intel put out some rather convincing charts showing the artificial intelligence opportunity and Intel's position within it along with its significance for total server revenue. Accordingly
column6: AI was just 7% of revenue
column7: of which 60% was classic machine learning with the remainder being deep learning.In 2010
column8: when NVIDIANVDAentered the market
column9: Intel HPC accounted for 93% of the market with NVIDIA making up the rest. NVIDIA grew strongly for the next two years but Xeon Phi has started taking back share again. As a result
column11: Intel's combined technologies gained back some market to end at 84%.Because of the huge opportunity
column12: Intel will be devoting more R&D dollars to strengthen this business and its new chips starting from the last iteration of 10nm will be first available to its data center customers. Increasing costs will therefore have a negative impact on this business over the next few years.In 2017
column13: management expects revenue growth in the low single digit range
column14: a gross margin of around 63% and EPS of around $2.80. DCG will be up high single digits
column15: CCG will be down mid single-digits
column16: NSG up 20%+
column17: IoTG up 10%+ and PSG up mid-single-digits.Intel expects to spend $12 billion (+/- $500 million) on capex this year
column18: of which $2.5 billion will be on memory. But capacity additions will account for most of the rest.Management also pointed to future opportunities: memory ($100 billion TAM)
column19: autonomous vehicles in 2025 ($10 billion TAM) and 5G connected devices (more than $50 billion TAM).Intel's U.S. Factory Endears It to TrumpIntel CEO Brian Krzanich met with Trump and promised to invest an additional $7 billion in an Arizona factory it originally started building back in 2011. The plant will employ 3K high-tech high-wage employees and it is estimated that indirect jobs relating to it will take employment up by about 10K.Intel has struggled to take the x86 architecture below 10nm
column20: which could be partially responsible for construction being put on hold. Intel is one of the few technology companies that stuck with its U.S. fabs as a matter of policy even when many of its peers moved offshore. Intel owns leading edge IP that it wouldn't want to outsource to places where IP laws are suspect.The CEO made no bones about the fact that conducive tax and regulatory measures had prompted the company's decision to complete the investment now
column21: so he may have eked out some concessions from Trump.Apple Sells More Smartphones Than SamsungAccording to IDC data published Feb 1
column22: Apple shipped slightly more smartphones in the holiday quarter than Samsung
column23: despite the fact that iPhone shipments were down for the first time in 2016. This is the first time in five years that the company gained the top spot.Apple's success was attributed to the iPhone 7 and Samsung's Galaxy Note 7 fiasco. Samsung said the exploding phones cost it $3 billion in sales. Overall smartphones grew just 2.3% in 2016 compared to 10.4% the previous year. Apple's 4.7% growth rate was better than the industry. Samsung shipments declined 5.2%.IDC expects the market to rebound this year
column24: in part because of expectations of a landmark phone from Apple and renewed demand in the Middle East and Latin America
column25: which didn't have a good 2016. Separately
column26: Canaccord Genuity has said that while Apple accounted for just 18% of the smartphone market last quarter
column27: it took 92% of the profits.Google Selling Its Satellite CompanyGoogle has agreed to sell its high-resolution satellite imaging business
column28: Terra Bella
column29: to imaging startup Planet Labs for somewhere between $300 and $500 million. Planet Labs has a number of medium resolution satellites that will complement the ones it has acquired
column30: according to Planet.Google is not quitting the mapping business and a long-term agreement to license the technology back from Planet is reportedly a part of the deal. This may not be a hugely profitable deal for Google given that it originally acquired Terra Bella for $500 million in 2014 when the company was called Skybox. But it may be a part of the realignment of its business units and goals under CFO Ruth Porat.CompanyLast WeekLast  6 MonthsAAPL+2.36%+22.12%FB+2.45%+7.12%GOOGL+1.79%+3.68%MSFT+0.50%+10.23%INTC-3.23%+0.86%CSCO+0.61%+1.61%AMZN+2.12%+7.94%Other stories you might have missed-CorporateApple Submits on Aussie Bank Boycott: Apple has submitted a statement to the Australian Competition & Consumer Commission (ACCC) charging the top four banks (Commonwealth Bank of Australia
column31: National Australia Bank Ltd.
column32: Westpac Banking Corp. and Bendigo & Adelaide Bank Ltd) in Australia of delaying the expansion of Apple Pay
column33: which could prove detrimental to smaller card issuers while reducing options for consumers.The banks
column34: which are in the process of developing their own mobile technology
column35: are seeking to bargain collectively with Apple to have their apps included in Apple Pay. Apple would rather have card issuers add their cards to its wallet and have the banks pay for inclusion. Apple said it won't give the banks a ""free ride"" while the banks responded saying Apple's assertion was ""incorrect and unsupported."" In its draft ruling
column36: the ACCC denied the banks' request. The final ruling is expected in March.Apple Hires Away Amazon Executive: Timothy D. Twerdahl
column37: who formerly headed Amazon's Fire TV unit as its general manager and director
column38: has now joined Apple as its VP in charge of marketing Apple TV. Pete Distad who previously played that role will now help Apple negotiate content deals. Twerdahl has vast experience in streaming: before his four-year stint at Amazon he was VP of consumer devices at Roku and before that
column39: he was an executive at Netflix. The executive changes seem to indicate that Apple is finally going to make some bold moves in this business
column40: which hasn't really done that well versus competitors.Facebook VR Demo Stations Shutting Down: Facebook (FB) is closing down around 200 of its 500 VR demo stations at Best Buy stores. It appears that the Oculus wasn't as much of a success as anticipated because few people came in for a demo at all and store attendants said that frequent software issues with the headsets made them unsellable. But the headsets aren't going out of circulation. The stores will continue to sell them and Facebook has promised that there will be pop up and other stores that will continue with the demos. The program started with 50 stores that were later expanded to 500 in August last year.Facebook Hires MTV Executive: Facebook is very serious about content
column41: video content in particular. On the earnings call
column42: Zuckerberg mentioned how video was the next big thing just like mobile. So it has done everything possible to help share videos of every description and host Facebook Live streams. But in order to increase differentiation and the price of ads running adjacent to these videos
column43: Facebook needs a little bit more. And now it's apparent that that is original content. The company has snapped up Mina Lefevre
column44: who was in charge of scripted programming at MTV to head up its content development efforts. She will report to Ricky Van Veen
column45: co-founder of CollegeHumor.Legal/RegulatoryMicrosoft Battles with Govt Spying: The court hasn't allowed the government's request to throw out a MicrosoftMSFTlawsuit
column46: in which it contended that the Electronic Communications Privacy Act violates the first amendment. The act allows the government to issue gag orders when asking for data housed on third-party servers like those owned by Microsoft.The Justice Department had asked the government to dismiss the lawsuit saying that it needed to keep investigations confidential so as not to alarm possible wrong-doers and that they did eventually get to know when charges were filed. Microsoft succeeded in convincing the judge that this affected its ability to do business. But the court held that Microsoft couldn't assert constitutional rights for someone else
column47: so it couldn't talk on behalf of its customers.Google Wants Warrants for Govt Snooping: Google's head of information security Richard Salgado visited senators to speed up the passage of a bill that has previously been endorsed by the House of Representatives. The bill seeks to do away with one clause of the current law that allows the government to obtain access emails that are more than 180 days old without a warrant. Google would like the law to be applicable for all emails irrespective of age. The bill was in the hands of Senator Jeff Sessions prior to the elections
column48: when he was elevated to the position of Attorney General by President Trump.New Technology/ProductsCisco Announces First SIG: CiscoCSCOhas created a new Secure Internet Gateway (SIG) in the cloud that will allow on-field or mobile enterprise users to connect securely to the Internet even when they aren't connected through VPN. Cisco's solution is called Umbrella. Umbrella can identify which SaaS apps are being used and enforce policies to block risky or inappropriate apps; analyze over 100 billion internet requests every day
column49: correlating with over 11 billion historical events to identify patterns
column50: detect anomalies
column51: and create models to automatically uncover attacker infrastructure being staged for the next threat; and other security checks through machine learning
column52: Cisco Talos threat intelligence
column53: and Cisco Advanced Malware Protection (AMP).Microsoft Extends Support to Cloud Customers: Boston Consulting Group says that while IP lawsuits have increased 22% over the last five years
column54: patent trolls - companies that don't have a business but acquire patents to benefit from litigation - increased patent acquisitions by 35%. It is perhaps these trends that prompted Microsoft to expand its patent protection coverage to all users of its Azure infrastructure. Microsoft will give customers one of its own patents to help them deal with the litigation. Microsoft also expanded its indemnification program under which it provides funds or legal counsel to help customers defend themselves.M&A and CollaborationsNES and Google Have a Deal: Nashville Electric Service has withdrawn its lawsuit against the Metro Council and telecom companies filed last October
column55: after Google promised to indemnify it against liabilities that may arise out of Metro's One Touch Make Ready policy. The current law requires that when a new provider's line is added to a utility pole
column56: each existing provider is required to move its line
column57: resulting in needless delay and disruption on the sidewalk.The new policy allows one person to move the poles
column58: thus making the process more efficient. Existing providers like AT&T and Comcast object to the law on the grounds that Metro is not authorized to make the law
column59: which is a matter for the Federal Communications Commission (FCC). The deal is significant because NES owns 80% of the utility poles in Nashville and Google is likely to succeed because the action promotes competition in the market and can force incumbents to match Google Fiber's high-speed services.Some NumbersMicrosoft Azure Price Cuts: Microsoft has taken the lead in announcing price cuts for its Azure Virtual Machines. The company said that compute-optimized F Series instances would cost its customers up to 24% less
column60: while A1 Basic instances would drop by up to 61%. Azure HotBlock Blob Storage and Cool Block Blob Storage costs are also down. Suntrust analyst Kunal Madhukar expects Amazon to follow soon
column61: as price cuts are ""business as usual"" for cloud infrastructure service providers.Amazon Payments: Amazon's payments service called Pay With Amazon
column62: which allows people to check out quickly using the details saved on Amazon says that the service now has 33 million users
column63: 32% of which access it with mobile devices. Pay With Amazon had 23 million users last April. Amazon's alliances with companies like PrestaShop
column64: Shopify and Future Shop have brought more users over the past few months.Zacks' Top 10 Stocks for 2017In addition to the stocks discussed above
