column1: Why General Electric Company (GE) Stock Is Strictly for Yield;2/10/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAfter holding shares ofGeneral Electric Company(NYSE:GE) for several years
column3: I sold my position and wrote about it
column4: on Jan 11.
column5: at $31.41 per share. GE stock opened Feb 10. at $29.65.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockAround here we call that a win.General Electric is like a baseball team that is always predicted to win the pennant
column6: but somehow never gets out of the second division. Under Jeff Immelt
column7: it has turned itself inside-out to become much like what it was a century ago
column8: a company that builds big engines to capture fuel and burn it.The move was capped bya deal taking a majority interestinBaker Hughes Incorporated(NYSE:BHI)
column9: the oilfield services firm.You will still findGE stock bullshere and bless their heart. General Electric is a great old American company with thousands of employees
column10: and retirees
column11: depending upon it.But I'm done
column12: and unlessyou're really into yield
column13: you should be done
column14: too. Here is why.Leaving GE StockImmelt has been running the company for over 15 years now and GE stock is still trading below where it was when he started. It's also 25% below its 2007 peak.7 Marvelous Mid-Cap Stocks to Buy for the Best of All WorldsAfter years of pounding the table for the stock
column15: Jim Cramer finally threw in the towel this month
column16: saying after an interview with Immelt that if General Electric fails to hit its 2017 targets it will become a ""must not own.""The 2017 goals are modest
column17: organic growth of 3% to 5%. The result would be a nice little yield stock
column18: but one that has no excitement.For all of General Electric's talk about becoming a software company withPredix
column19: its industrial Internet of Things platform
column20: technology remains a very small piece of the business. Even if Predix were to hit its goal of $15 billion in sales for 2020
column21: that would still be barely 10% of the current company.Buying ServiceMax
column22: in November
column23: for $915 million
column24: and consolidating the field service management arena
column25: doesn't change that underlying reality. Linking software and services to sales of big ticket engines doesn't change the fact that the money still comes from the engines.That market is declining
column26: and GE is a big reason why. When you make machines more energy efficient
column27: when you make capital last longer
column28: you eventually slow the replacement cycle. Things aren't broken
column29: why fix them?General Electric isbig in wind power
column30: too
column31: but that doesn't change the fact that the vast majority of the company's energy operations are focused on fossil fuels
column32: especially after the Baker Hughes deal. Immelt has been proclaiming the future while buying the past.The GE Dividend OpportunityThere is an opportunity here
column33: but it is limited to investors seeking income
column34: retirees and those with the patience to watch paint dry.Should Bill Gates Sell His Microsoft Corporation (MSFT) Stock?Under Immelt
column35: General Electric has proven to be a reliable payer of dividends. Over the last five years
column36: for instance
column37: those dividends have increased by nearly 50%
column38: from 17 cents per share to 24 cents. Most years
column39: GE's earnings should clear those dividends rather easily - in 2016
column40: it paid out 93 cents per share to investors while earning $1.This means that the GE dividend is currently yielding 3.24%
column41: against a 10-year bond rate of 2.4% and a 30-year bond rate of 3.02%. If you are seeking retirement income
column42: you get a better deal with General Electric shares
column43: especially if your income is modest (dividends are taxable income) than with U.S. government paper. And GE stock might go up. As referenced earlier
column44: Richard Saintvilus
column45: an InvestorPlace contributor I trust
column46: thinks it may rise 20% this year.If he's right you have a bargain
column47: even before Immelt retires and someone else gets the chance to turn General Electric inside-out again.Dana Blankenhornis a financial and technology journalist. He is the author of the sci-fi novellaInto the Cloud
column48: available at the Amazon Kindle store. Write him atdanablankenhorn@gmail.comor follow him on Twitter at@danablankenhorn. As of this writing

column1: Apple Inc. a 50% Dividend Grower Hiding in Plain Sight (AAPL);2/10/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsThere are two ways to get big dividends: you can buy stocks that boast highcurrentyields
column3: or you can buy stocks that consistently grow their payouts.makeArticleAd();A well-balanced portfolio will include both types of companies
column4: withdividend-growth stocksbeing the cornerstone of a longer-term income strategy.Still
column5: investors sometimes get frustrated with dividend growers because to get their outsized payout growth
column6: you often have to settle for a low current yield. And why buy a risky asset that yields 1% when you can get a long-term Treasury that pays 2%?There are two answers to this question. The first is that Treasuries aren't risk-free. If you buy a 10-year note and interest rates go up
column7: the value of your Treasury will go down. If you need to sell early for some reason
column8: you'll lose money.Secondly
column9: dividend-growth stocks will increase their income over time-something Treasuries will never do. In fact
column10: if you choose thebest dividend growth stocks
column11: you'll see your income skyrocket in a few short years.And the best dividend growth stock is one of the world's most recognizable and popular brands:Apple Inc.(AAPL).If you read about investing in Apple
column12: you almost always see a focus on iPhone sales
column13: the value of future products and so on. Bears note slowing iPhone sales growth (or negative sales growth)
column14: devices that didn't quite catch on and rising competition. Bulls counter that Apple has a valuable and unique market position and innovative products that captivate consumers.Both arguments are really missing the point.The main reason to buy Apple is more boring but more important: net income
column15: free cash flow (FCF) and dividends.Let's start with FCF
column16: which is now $9.65 per share
column17: meaning Apple's dividend-payout ratio is a measly 24%. But the really amazing thing is how the company's cash flow has exploded and continues to rise:FCF Boots UpYes
column18: there's been a bit of a dip in the last year
column19: but you can also see that FCF has already bottomed out and is now back on the rise.7 Tech Stocks With Explosive Growth PotentialThe next thing to consider is Apple's operating margin
column20: which is currently 27%. This is important because it means the company is so profitable that it can continue to pay out dividends at the current payout rate. That operating margin has fallen slightly in recent years
column21: partly as a result of changes in the smartphone market
column22: but it's still historically high:Apple Remains a Profit MonsterNote that we've seen Apple's profit margin remain over 25% since 2009. This is great news for investors
column23: but it also means Apple has become a very different company than it was in the 1990s and 2000s. It's no longer a burgeoning tech firm but an enterprise that reliably and consistently produces cash it can distribute to shareholders. In other words
column24: it's a blue chip stock
column25: not a speculative bet.Again
column26: great news for investors-especially those looking for income. Ironically
column27: many dividend-growth investors forget about Apple
column28: or they may allocate a very small part of their portfolios to the company out of fear that it's risky. That's a mistake.In the last five years since Apple started paying dividends
column29: its payout has soared 50.6%:Strong Dividend GrowthIf we compare that to some of the most popular and supposedly ""safer"" dividend payers
column30: we see that Apple's dividend growth is a big outperformer:Apple Trounces the RestAs you can see
column31: General Electric Company(GE)
column32: AT&T Inc.(T)
column33: Johnson & Johnson(JNJ)
column34: Chevron Corporation(CVX)
column35: Consolidated Edison
column36: Inc.(ED)andExxon Mobil Corporation(XOM)are all growing their dividends at a slower pace than Apple.The tech giant also has a lower P/E ratio than all of these names (just 15.6
column37: which is 39% lower than the rest of the S&P 500).It's time to think different about Apple; this is a relatively safe dividend stock that is destined to be a Dividend Aristocrat. While headlines about iPhone sales may cause some volatility in the short term
column38: the company's strong cash generation will reward you with big payouts in the long run.Buy Apple Now … Then Add These 6 High YieldersThere's no doubt Apple is a best-in-class dividend-growth stock. But you also need high yields to go with that dividend growth-especially if you're in or near retirement.Should Bill Gates Sell His Microsoft Corporation (MSFT) Stock?That's where the 6 reliable income generators in our new""No-Withdrawal"" retirement portfoliocome in. They throw offrock-solid yields of 6%
column40: 9% and up.And with an average yield of 8.0%
column41: this portfolio willeasily hand you a $40
column42: 000 income stream on a $500
column43: 000 nest egg.Each of those payouts is backed byrock-solid balance sheetsandsurging cash flows.Like Apple
column44: these income powerhouses are all cheap now
column45: but I don't expect that to last.These no-drama plays are perfect for 2017
column46: with the market starting to look twitchy after the go-go ""Trump bump."" Don't miss out.Click here and I'll share our 6 top picks for high income and double-digit upside.More From InvestorPlace7 Cheap Stocks to Buy That Could Double in 2017The 10 Best Stocks to Buy for 2017: The Experts' PicksThe postApple Inc. a 50% Dividend Grower Hiding in Plain Sight (AAPL)appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: CyberArk (CYBR) Beats Q4 Earnings and Revenue Estimates;2/10/2017;"Keeping its earnings streak alive for the tenth consecutive quarter
column2: CyberArk Software Ltd.CYBRreported better-than-expected fourth-quarter 2016 results. The company reported adjusted earnings per share (excluding amortization of intangible assets and other one-time items but including stock-based compensation) on a proportionate tax basis of 30 cents per share
column3: which came way ahead of the Zacks Consensus Estimate of 24 cents per share. Adjusted earnings however were flat year over year.Quarter DetailsCyberArk's revenues grew 25% year over year to $64.4 million and surpassed the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $63 million. The company's revenues increased on a year-over-year basis
column4: primarily due to better-than-expected demand for its privileged account security platform.Revenues were also boosted by a 23% increase in License revenues
column5: which came in at $40.8 million and accounted for 63% of total revenue. Also
column6: a 28% year-over-year increase in Maintenance and Professional Services revenues (37% of total revenues) positively impacted the quarterly results.Geographically
column7: on a year-over-year basis
column8: revenues from the Americas increased 12% and contributed 58% of total revenue. EMEA increased 53% and accounted for 36% of total revenue. Asia-Pacific and Japan increased 30% year over year
column9: representing 6% of total revenue.CyberArk's adjusted gross margin (excluding amortization of intangible assets and other one-time items but including stock-based compensation) contracted 60 basis points (bps) on a year-over-year basis to 86.9%
column10: primarily due to higher cost of sales.The company's adjusted operating margin (excluding amortization of intangible assets and other one-time items but including stock-based compensation) shrunk 80 bps from the year-ago quarter to 22.3%
column11: primarily due to lower gross margin and higher adjusted operating expenses as a percentage of revenues. Adjusted operating expenses increased 25.7% year over year to $41.6 million.The company's adjusted net income (excluding amortization of intangible assets and other one-time items buts including stock-based compensation) came in at $11 million
column12: which improved from $10.8 million reported in the year-ago quarter. On a GAAP basis
column13: net income came in at $10.2 million compared with $9.9 million reported in the year-ago period.CyberArk exited the quarter with cash
column14: cash equivalents
column15: short-term deposits and marketable securities of approximately $238.3 million
column16: flat with the previous quarter. Receivables were $20.4 million at the end of the quarter.CyberArk's balance sheet does not have any long-term debt. The company reported cash flow from operations of $59.2 million for 2016.GuidanceThe company provided guidance for the first quarter and full year 2017.For the first quarter

column18: representing 22% to 24% year-over-year growth. The mid-point of the guided range is below the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $57.95 million. Non-GAAP operating income is expected to be in a range of $9.9 million to $10.7 million. The company expects non-GAAP earnings for the first quarter in a range of 21 cents to 23 cents. The Zacks Consensus Estimate is pegged at 13 cents.For the year
column19: the company expects revenues in a range of $267 million to $270 million (mid-point $268.5 million)

Non-GAAP operating income is expected to be in a range of $56 million to $58 million. The company expects non-GAAP earnings for 2017 in a range of $1.20 per share to $1.24 per share. The Zacks Consensus Estimate is pegged at 88 cents.Our TakeCyberArk is an Israeli company that specializes in protecting accounts from cyber-attacks. The company offers several products that protect passwords

column22: and secure cloud-based assets.The company ended 2016 on a strong note as evident from the better-than-expected results for the fourth quarter. While CyberArk's revenues marked a year-over-year improvement

column1: The Death Of The Commercial Database: Oracle's Dilemma;2/10/2017;"BySamadhi Partners:(click to enlarge)Contributing authors:John Freeman
column2: Fred McClimans
column3: Zach Mitchell.____We see the $29.6b commercial database market contracting 20-30% by 2021
column4: and do not believe Oracle (ORCL) can transition its revenue streams (from legacy commercial database to cloud-based subscription offerings) fast enough to offset the decline of this market
column5: which represents a major legacy core of its revenue.makeArticleAd();(click to enlarge)The commercial database market - 80% of which is an oligopoly of Oracle
column6: IBM (IBM)
column7: and Microsoft (MSFT) - has remained one of the most stable and sticky in all of tech for over two decades. However
column8: we think the velocity and magnitude of its decline is likely to surprise many investors.(click to enlarge)The deflationary pressures that have already hit the database market are just getting started
column9: including:Migration to SaaS
column10: where most offerings use free open-source   databases;faster growth in use cases such as social media
column11: IoT
column12: and   unstructured/semi-structured data that are ill-suited to the SQL   standard upon which the database oligopoly is based;the increasing stability and functionality of a variety of   free open-source options
column13: most of which are ""Not Only SQL""   (NoSQL) and are therefore much better suited to the   aforementioned use cases; andthe disproportionately large benefits that NoSQL databases   continue to realize as a result of Moore's Law-driven   improvements in processors
column14: memory
column15: solid-state storage
column16: and   network throughput (these improvements increase NoSQL's ability   to handle both NoSQL and SQL use cases on-the-fly and   progressively marginalize SQL-only databases just as SQL-only   databases marginalized mainframe-based databases during the late   '80s and '90s).Revenue from database software represented ~36% of Oracle's total FY16 revenue and ~55% of its operating profit.(click to enlarge)Note: Database Software and On-Premise Applications include   both licenses and maintenance revenue.The company's decline in projected database revenue is distinct from and in addition to the decline in its on-premises application revenue
column17: which accounted for ~25% of total FY16 revenue and ~39% of operating profit.(click to enlarge)Microsoft and IBM will be hurt only marginally
column18: as database software generates just ~5% of revenue for each.Without aggressive action to significantly increase non-database revenue
column19: we do not believe Oracle can offset the oncoming decline in commercial database revenue fast enough to maintain its present valuation.Specifically
column20: we believe Oracle needs an even more radical and rapid organizational and cultural shift toward ""cloud-first"" that incentivizes both its sales force and its customers to move aggressively into the cloud. The company also needs to consolidate its various home-grown and acquired cloud/SaaS offerings toward a single platform in order to generate operational leverage down the road. Both of these initiatives will be painful in several ways
column21: especially financially
column22: for a few years to come. To partially offset the pain
column23: Oracle should divest its remaining hardware and other non-core businesses.(click to enlarge)Source: Morningstar______ThemeExplanationFor those that are interested in a more technical dive
column24: below is a deeper
column25: historical explanation of the five interrelated trends that are gaining momentum
column26: and that will
column27: in combination
column28: cause the commercial-database market to contract 20% to 30% by 2021:1. The Continued Enterprise Migration to SaaS/Cloud.Except for a few of the first SaaS offerings that were built on top of an Oracle database
column29: namely Salesforce.com (CRM)
column30: NetSuite (N)
column31: and Oracle itself
column32: it is difficult to find a SaaS provider that uses any commercial database. For companies founded after 2005
column33: that number is virtually zero.The vast majority of SaaS providers today either use an open-source database
column34: or
column35: as is the case with SaaS HCM vendor Workday (WDAY)
column36: develop their own. Every user of an on-premises enterprise application
column37: including one of the five core client-server application categories: ERP (Enterprise Resource Planning)
column38: CRM (Customer Relationship Management)
column39: HCM (Human Capital Management)
column40: SCM (Supply Chain Management)
column41: and BI (Business Intelligence) applications
column42: which moves to SaaS therefore eliminates a commercial database seat
column43: and with it
column44: the maintenance/support and future upgrade revenue it would have generated. Even an enterprise seat that moves to Salesforce.com will generate far less revenue for Oracle than that seat did when it was deployed on-premises.Hence
column45: we believe the enterprise migration to SaaS/cloud is highly deflationary for commercial-database revenue. Further
column46: we are still early in the migration from client-server to SaaS/cloud. Depending on which research one believes
column47: this migration is only 10% to 25% complete and is only just beginning to impact more mission-critical applications - such as ERP - that are more likely to be running on higher-end SQL databases (including those from Oracle and IBM
column48: and to a lesser extent
column49: Microsoft).2. Commercial SQL Databases are Not Well-Suited to Handle the Most Compelling Emerging Use Cases.After SQL was standardized in 1987
column50: it went unchallenged for over 20 years in defining how data was organized
column51: searched
column52: and sorted. However
column53: in the mid-2000s
column54: colossal tech companies began running into the limitations of SQL databases in handling both the sheer volume and varying structure (or lack thereof) of the data that they wanted to preserve
column55: navigate
column56: analyze
column57: and serve up on-demand to their users/customers.Amazon (AMZN)
column58: Google (GOOG) (GOOGL)
column59: LinkedIn (LNKD)
column60: and Facebook (FB) each solved its own scaling problems by developing and implementing its own database software that broke with the constraints of the SQL standard.What's more
column61: each company released open-source versions of its databases shortly after. Dozens of new open-source databases were consequently produced in 2008 and 2009
column62: leading to what Guy Harrison - the author of Next Generation Databases - termed ""a sort of Cambrian explosion."" As a result of their departure from SQL
column63: these databases all fell under the term ""NoSQL"" - even though most were as different from each other as they were from SQL.Given the exponential growth in the volume and variety of data - driven by richer social media content
column64: more social media users
column65: and an explosion of autonomously captured IoT data - and given the increasing desire for analysis on captured data
column66: we believe the number of use cases suited to NoSQL will soon far exceed those suited to SQL.The rise of these new use cases will drive greater adoption by large enterprises of open-source NoSQL solutions at the expense of commercial SQL databases.3. NoSQL Databases and Schema-on-Read Processes Are on the Right Side of Moore's Law;SQL and Schema-on-Write Are on the Wrong Side. In general
column67: NoSQL databases are substantially more processor
column68: memory
column69: and storage intensive than SQL databases
column70: even after considering the fact that they relax many of the constraints that SQL places on how data is organized. Though NoSQL database architectures existed well before 2005 - at least
column71: in theory - there was simply not enough processing power
column72: memory capacity
column73: and storage space for them to be put to practical use outside of academia.During the comparatively processor/memory/bandwidth-starved 1980s and 1990s
column74: adherence to the more-rigid SQL standard was effectively compulsory to ensure the performance and reliability that enterprises needed in order to migrate their applications
column75: especially those more mission-critical applications
column76: from mainframes and minis to the more-distributed and network-dependent client-server architecture.The price paid for SQL's acceptable performance and reliability was driven by:The overall inflexibility of the data structure
column77: called a   schema;the onerous requirement to define that structure prior to the   deployment of the database and its associated applications;the difficulty in changing that structure over time in order   to capture different kinds of data
column78: and to better reflect changes   in the structure of the data and in the organization of the   enterprise; andthe requirement for a schema-on-write process
column79: which fits   data into the schema as it is inputted
column80: as opposed to   schema-on-read
column81: which is simply dumping data into a big   ""container"" and organizing it later into a schema.Over time
column82: however
column83: Moore's Law-driven improvements in processing power
column84: memory capacity and speed
column85: storage capacity and speed
column86: and network throughput have made the rigidity of the SQL standard and the requirement for schema-on-write processes increasingly less necessary and will continue to do so. Hence
column87: with every Moore's Law cycle
column88: SQL and its resource-efficient schema-on-write process loses its competitive advantage
column89: while NoSQL
column90: with its relatively resource-inefficient but much more flexible schema-on-write process
column91: becomes increasingly free from the constraints that prevented it from being adopted in the first place.4. In-Mem Possibilities and the Elimination of HDD Compromises. When SQL was standardized
column92: hard disk drives (HDDs) were the only cost-effective storage medium that could be accessed in real time. Therefore
column93: much of the fundamental code written into SQL database software is designed to accommodate the shortcomings of HDDs
column94: such as the slow speed with which they can read and transmit requested data into memory and their relatively higher failure rates - at least
column95: compared to the major solid state components of a system such as the CPU
column96: memory
column97: and network throughput. Now that SSDs are rapidly becoming a cost-effective replacement for HDDs
column98: much of the design and certainly much of the code of legacy SQL database software that made such compromises in order to accommodate comparatively much slower HDDs is now rendered unnecessary.In contrast
column99: many NoSQL databases are written so as to take maximum advantage of SSD storage and will likely be updated to take advantage of even faster-emerging non-volatile memory technologies such as Intel (INTC)/Micron's (MU) 3D xPoint
column100: which is just now becoming commercially available. We believe that
column101: given the strong requirement to maintain compliance with the SQL standard and maintain their own backward compatibility
column102: SQL database vendors will not be able to optimize their code for SSDs nearly as fast as many of the open source projects will be able to
column103: putting them further at a competitive disadvantage - a classic example of Clayton Christensen's ""The innovator's dilemma"".5. Increasing Availability of ""SQL Methadone"" Solutions for Weaning Enterprises Off Expensive Commercial Databases. We are seeing an increasing number of software tools and services designed to help enterprises migrate from commercial SQL databases. Even the most mission-critical applications running on an Oracle or IBM database can be increasingly surrounded
column104: ""quarantined""
column105: and dismantled over time
column106: much like what happened to many of the legacy mainframe applications during the shift to the client-server architecture in the 1990s.While SQL databases from the likes of Oracle
column107: IBM
column108: and MSFT will survive in some enterprises for many more years - again
column109: much like mainframes - they will be increasingly marginalized and cost-reduced as much as possible. We see many of these tools maturing already within the Hadoop ecosystem
column110: which already has multiple ways to integrate with SQL databases and/or put SQL interfaces and querying ability on NoSQL databases. In our opinion
column111: this is a very similar development to the early-1990s emergence of multiple ways to integrate mainframe applications with PCs and client-server applications.______To subscribe to the Samadhi Brief newsletter
column112: please visit SamadhiPartners.com. An overview of our research process and explanation of the Samadhi Index can be foundhere.See alsoMystery REIT Shopper: Taubman Centerson seekingalpha.com"

column1: Genpact Limited (G) Stock Has Room to Grow;2/10/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsGenpact Limited(NYSE:G) stands for ""generating business impact"" and began as a business unit withinGeneral Electric Company(NYSE:GE) two decades ago. Unfortunately
column3: over the last year or so
column4: Genpact hasn't generated much shareholder impact
column5: despite that catchy slogan. G stock is up around 3.5% just over a month into the new year
column6: but is nearly that same amount in the red if we zoom out to the past 12 months.makeArticleAd();Still
column7: I believe Genpact is about to start a more substantial recovery. Itsearningscall this morning - including an earnings beat and a slight miss on revenue - could be the beginning of a run that could tally up double-digit gains for 2017.More specifically
column8: Genpact is a business-to-business company which hangs its hat on efficiency. The company offers digital solutions related to payments
column9: processing services
column10: risk and compliance
column11: customer and channel management
column12: and business insights and optimization. And it boasts 75
column13: 000 employees in 25 countries.For the fourth quarter
column14: G stock posted earnings growth of 21%
column15: while its full-year earnings growth was around 16%. That's solid considering Genpact is facing difficult currency exchange.Genpact Stock a Good DealBut despite those headwinds
column16: Genpact still offers great deal for shareholders
column17: as stock has a trailing price-to-earnings ratio of 21
column18: which is well below the industry average of 35
column19: and a forward P/E of just 16. This latest earnings beat wasn't a surprise either
column20: as Genpact has posted an earnings beat in each of the last four quarters as well.7 Marvelous Mid-Cap Stocks to Buy for the Best of All WorldsThe previous quarter represented the smallest beat thanks in part to lower technology spending in the investment banking and healthcare markets. But it wasn't too bad: non-GAAP earnings still grew 9% year over year to36 cents- 3 cents better than Wall Street hoped.Plus
column21: a recent acquisition by Genpact could fuel more growth down the line. The company just reached an agreement to acquire an Australian arm ofFiserv Inc(NASDAQ:FISV)
column22: which serves three of the four major retail banks in Australia
column23: handling approximately 70% of all checks processed in the Australian market
column24: according to the press release.Looking forward a bit further
column25: Genpact's earnings are expected to maintain a double-digit average over the next five years
column26: smoothing out right around 12%. That's almost double the average of the last five years
column27: when Genpact stock still managed average gains of almost 7%.Add it up
column28: and I like the moves Genpact is making and I like the estimates on tap. Efficiency is never going to go out of style across industries. Even if discretionary spending on B2B tech has been soft in spots of late
column29: I like the prospects for the near-term and believe Genpact stock has some immediate value to realize.I expect investors to realize that now that the latest earnings report has come out
column30: and recommend a buy before Genpact gets its post-earnings pop.Hilary Kramer is the editor ofGameChangers

column1: Should Bill Gates Sell His Microsoft Corporation (MSFT) Stock?;2/10/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsIn late December
column3: I made apredictionthatMicrosoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT) stock would hit $80 in 2017. In reality
column4: it was less a prediction than my agreement with Piper Jaffray analyst Alex Zukin's 12-month price target for MSFT stock of $80.makeArticleAd();Source:Via MicrosoftMore than one month into the year and the Microsoft stock price has a long way to go to reach this lofty goal.It's fair to say that if MSFT stock is going to hit $80
column5: Microsoft's burgeoning cloud business - an annualized revenue run rate of $14.0 billion as of Q2 2017 - needs to deliver more growth over the next three quarters (April
column6: July and October earnings announcements) to justify to investors a forward2018price-to-earnings ratio of 24.5.As I said in my earlier article
column7: I think MSFT can deliver on this front.But it got me thinking about Microsoft co-founder Bill Gates
column8: the world's richest person at $85 billion and the owner of approximately 179 million shares of MSFT stock
column9: a number that's been dwindling by approximately80 millionper year over the past decade or so; the proceeds going to fund the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation.If this pace continues Bill Gates will have reduced his Microsoft stake to zero by sometime in 2019.Should Bill Gates Sell His MSFT Stock?No
column10: I'm not talking about whether he should continue to fund his foundation - of course
column11: he should -I'm merely wondering if there wasn't a better stock to sell to fund the foundation's good works.10 Super-Safe Dividend Growth Stocks to Buy TodayA quicklookat the financial statements for the foundation's 2015 and 2014 fiscal years shows that $11.3 billion was spent over the course of two years to fund its programs around the world
column12: an average of $5.65 billion per year
column13: about the same amount that Gates would currently generate from the sale of 80 million shares of Microsoft stock.So
column14: from a financial planning standpoint
column15: the 80 million figure makes a whole lot of sense.The holdings of the trust that oversees the investments and cash donated by the Gates's along with Warren Buffett for use by the foundation had a value of $18.5 billion as of September 30
column16: 2016; more than half (57.8%) of the portfolio invested inBerkshire Hathaway Inc.(NYSE:BRK.A
column17: NYSE:BRK.B) Class B stock.Since August 24
column18: 2006 through July 2015
column19: Buffett has donated 200.6 million shares of Class B Berkshire Hathaway shares to the foundation; this past year
column20: Buffett donated roughly15 millionshares. The remaining 285 million shares he agreed to donate back in June 2006 will be doled out at a rate of 5% per year until all 500 million shares are in the hands of the foundation sometime around 2036.So
column21: the choice comes down to whether it makes sense to sell the shares of Microsoft for cash to fund the foundation's work and continue to hold the Berkshire Hathaway shares as an investment or the other way around.The Gates have chosen the former rather than the latter.Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN) Stock Is More Valuable Than You ThinkOn the surface
column22: that would seem to be a mistake given MSFT stock has outperformed Berkshire Hathaway Class B stock by 269 basis points on annuallized basis over the last five years through Feb. 6.So
column23: with that in mind
column24: does it make sense for Bill Gates to sell his MSFT stock?I don't think he should as some of its best growth lies in the immediate future. But
column25: I also don't think the trust should sell Berkshire Hathaway stock because it provides such good diversification and protection of capital.Both of these stocks are worth owning for the long haul.If it were up to me
column26: I'd probably look at cashing in some of the trust's other holdings first
column27: but thankfully for all those around the world deserving of the good education and healthcare the foundation looks to fund
column28: it's not up to me.As of this writing
column29: Will Ashworth did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceThe Top 10 Dow Dividend Stocks for February7 Tech Stocks That Are Bucking the DowntrendThe postShould Bill Gates Sell His Microsoft Corporation (MSFT) Stock?appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Why I’m Raising My Price Target On Microsoft Corporation Stock (MSFT);2/10/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsIf you thinkMicrosoft Corporation(MSFT) shares are expensive now
column3: they are about to get even more so.makeArticleAd();Back in December
column4: I issueda 12-month piece target of $72 per share. But following the company's breathtaking fiscal second-quarter earnings results
column5: I am now confident is too cheap.As such I'm raising my price target by $8 per share to $80 per share.Why the price increase? For starters
column6: Microsoft stock is currently priced at a forward P/E of just 21 based on fiscal 2017 estimates of $2.97 per share. And while that P/E is two points above the average stock in the S&P 500 index
column7: Microsoft's recent moves suggests it deserves a much higher multiple.With growth opportunities emerging in the realm of the cloud
column8: Internet-of-Things
column9: smart home and a host of other areas thanks to its recent acquisitions
column10: Microsoft stock still looks like a bargain. I'll get back to this in a moment. But let's first assess its recent earnings.The main question heading into 2017 was to what extent Microsoft could sustain the strong cloud momentum it used in 2016 to surpassAmazon.com
column11: Inc.(AMZN).Microsoft answered that question with authority. In three months that ended December
column12: the company earned $5.2 billion
column13: or 66 cents per share
column14: rising from $5.02 billion a year earlier. On an adjusted basis
column15: when taking out one-time gains and costs
column16: earnings came to 84 cents per share
column17: which beat the consensus estimate of 79 cents per share. Second-quarter revenue came in at $24.1 billion
column18: while adjusted revenue was $26.1 billion
column19: also topping Wall Street estimates.The company's aggressive move towards the cloud was the main driver of the strong top- and bottom-line beat. Not only does this lessen Microsoft's reliance on declining PC sales
column20: but cloud businesses also generate higher margins. Revenue from the Office 365 business grew almost 50% year-over-year
column21: while gross margins in its commercial cloud business
column22: which includes Azure and Office 365 products sold to businesses
column23: reached 48% during the quarter - up two percentage points year-over-year.7 Tech Stocks With Explosive Growth Potential""Our customers are seeing greater value and opportunity as we partner with them through their digital transformation
column24: said CEO Satya Nadella in a statement. ""Accelerating advancements in AI across our platforms and services will provide further opportunity to drive growth in the Microsoft Cloud.""Azure revenue surged 93% year-over-year (up 95% in constant currency) during the quarter. Though Microsoft provided no specific dollar amount to help break down the cloud revenue
column25: Bernstein analysts Mark Mordler estimates Azure now generates some 20% of commercial cloud revenue
column26: which Microsoft said was generating an ""annualized run rate"" just north of $14 billion
column27: according to Barron's. This means Azure now generates quarterly revenue at around $3 billion.Between now and 2020
column28: worldwide spending on public cloud services is expected to soar to more than $195 billion. This is double the revenue the industry is expected to generate by the end of 2016
column29: according to a research firm IDC.""Cloud software will significantly outpace traditional software product delivery over the next five years
column30: growing nearly three times faster than the software market as a whole and becoming the significant growth driver to all functional software markets
column31: said Benjamin McGrath
column32: senior research analyst
column33: SaaS and Business Models. ""By 2020
column34: about half of all new business software purchases will be of service-enabled software
column35: and cloud software will constitute more than a quarter of all software sold.""IDC is not alone in this prediction. Pacific Crest analyst Brent Bracelin forecasts public cloud spending
column36: currently around $58 billion annually
column37: will triple to $205 billion in the next three years. During that span
column38: Bracelin sees spending on SaaS services to surge 20% annually
column39: reaching $129 billion by 2020.As Microsoft's cloud business takes up greater portions of its total revenue
column40: Microsoft stands to secure larger pieces of the cloud pie. And Microsoft
column41: which during the second quarter completed its blockbuster $26.2 billion acquisition of LinkedIn
column42: now has even more ways to attract businesses to Azure. To that end
column43: Microsoft stock should command a higher P/E of 4 to 6 points above its current valuation.When applying a P/E of just 25 to fiscal 2018 estimates of $3.26 per share
column44: this puts the stock's fair value at around $80. That valuation is still more than half that of Amazon
column45: which relies on its AWS cloud platform for the bulk of its profits. And with almost $121 billion in cash on its balance sheet make more deals for growth in key areas
column46: Microsoft
column47: which also pays a 2.45% annual dividend yield
column48: is a stock to own and forget about.Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN) Stock Is More Valuable Than You ThinkRisks To Consider:Much of my optimism is based on the assumption that Microsoft can continue to increase cloud market share and successfully integrate LinkedIn.Action To Take:Microsoft should be kept on the watchlist of investors who are looking for a company with upside potential that pays a reliable dividend.Editor's Note:All Wall Street firms closely-guard theirblack box trading systemsto gain an edge over their competition. And over you and me. column51: StreetAuthority doesn't simply regurgitate the latest stock market news. Instead

Visit us atStreetAuthority.com.More From InvestorPlaceThe 5 Best Stocks to Buy for Big Emerging Markets Profits7 Stocks to Buy That Could Double by 2018The postWhy I'm Raising My Price Target On Microsoft Corporation Stock (MSFT)appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Don't Overlook These 6 Incredible Amazon.com Numbers;2/9/2017;"Shares ofAmazon.com(NASDAQ: AMZN) fell more than 3% on Feb. 3 after the tech giant   posted mixed fourth quarter earnings and  soft guidance for   the first quarter. Revenue rose 22% annually to $43.7 billion
column2: but that  missed expectations by $980 million. The company   was hit hard by currency headwinds
column3: which reduced its top line by   about $558 million. Amazon's closely watched AWS (Amazon Web   Services) revenue rose 47% annually to $3.54 billion
column4: but that   also missed expectations of $3.6 billion and represented a   slowdown from 55% growth in the third quarter.For the first quarter
column5: Amazon expects 14.1% to 22.7%   year-over-year sales growth
column6: which missed analyst forecasts for   23.4% growth. But on a currency neutral basis
column7: which excludes an   expected currency impact of $730 million
column8: Amazon expects its   revenue to rise 17% to 25%.Image source: Amazon.makeArticleAd();Some negative reports about Amazon focused on those headline   numbers
column9: but they glossed over many of the positive growth   figures. Let's take a look at six incredible numbers from that   report that investors shouldn't overlook.1. $749 million in net incomeDuring the fourth quarter
column10: Amazon's net income rose 55%   annually to $749 million
column11: or $1.54 per share -- which beat   expectations by $0.19. For the full year
column12: its net income surged   over 300% to $2.4 billion.That incredible growth was mostly attributed to the rapid   growth of AWS' high-margin business
column13: which gives Amazon much more   freedom to expand its e-commerce ecosystem with low-margin   hardware like its Echo speakers
column14: loss-leading services like   Amazon Video and Prime Now
column15: and logistics solutions like new   fulfillment centers and drones.2. AWS' operating margin of 26%AWS finished last quarter with an operating margin of 26%
column16: compared to 24% in the year-ago quarter. That margin expansion   indicates that AWS' massive scale is offsetting tough price   competition across the cloud platform market
column17: which caused Amazon   and its rivals to reduce their prices throughout the year.3. AWS' annual run rate of $14 billionAmazon announced that AWS had achieved an annual run rate of   $14 billion
column18: indicating that it maintains a commanding lead overMicrosoft's(NASDAQ: MSFT) Azure in the cloud platform race.Microsoft claimed that its ""commercial cloud"" had achieved an   annual run rate of over $14 billion last quarter
column19: but most of   that total came from SaaS platforms like Office 365 and Dynamics   CRM. Azure -- which competes directly against AWS in the   IaaS/PaaS ""cloud platform"" markets -- accounts for a much smaller   percentage.Microsoft doesn't disclose how much revenue Azure generates
column20: but  combining earlier industry estimates and its reported   growth rate  over the past few quarters indicates that its   annual run rate could be around $3 billion.4. Over 1
column21: 000 new AWS featuresAmazon already serves massive customers like NASA
column22: the CDC
column23: andNetflix(NASDAQ: NFLX) with AWS
column24: but it's continuously widening the   platform's competitive moat against rival platforms like Azure   with new features. Amazon added over  1
column25: 000 new features and   services to AWS in fiscal 2016
column26: compared to about 700 in   2015.It also opened eleven new AWS Availability Zones across five   geographic regions in 2016
column27: bringing AWS' total coverage to 42   Availability Zones across 16 regions globally. That massive data   center expansion will help AWS reach more companies and   developers
column28: all while supporting the expansion of its e-commerce   and digital ecosystem into new markets.5. Prime Video in over 200 countriesA big part of that digital ecosystem expansion is Prime Video
column29: the company's streaming answer to Netflix. Amazon has made the   platform a ""free"" perk for Prime subscribers and a stand-alone   subscription service that costs slightly less than Netflix.Like Netflix
column30: Amazon is investing heavily in original content
column31: and popular shows likeTransparentandMan in the High Castlehelped it become the third largest video streaming platform in   the U.S. after YouTube and  Netflix last year
column32: according to   research firm Sandvine. Amazon is also following Netflix's lead   and investing heavily in localized original content in key   markets like Japan and India
column33: which could help  expand its   Prime user base worldwide.6. 4
column34: 000 new skills for AlexaAmazon also taught its voice recognition platform Alexa 4
column35: 000   new skills since last October. It noted that ""tens of thousands   of developers"" are building new skills for the platform -- which   powers the Echo
column36: Kindle
column37: and Fire TV devices -- and that it was   working with ""a lot of major companies"" to integrate their   products with that ecosystem.The expansion of the Alexa ecosystem is important
column38: because it   can give Amazon control of users' connected homes via Dash   buttons
column39: DRS-enabled appliances
column40: and other connected devices. In   addition to boosting its e-commerce revenue with ""frictionless""   orders
column41: that platform can process data through AWS and widen its   moat in the smart home race againstAlphabet's Google
column42: which is trying to establish its own home-based   ecosystem around its Home smart speaker.The key takeawayAmazon's fourth quarter report was lumpy
column43: but investors   shouldn't overlook these positive numbers. Analysts still expect   Amazon's revenue and  earnings to respectively rise 22% and   53% next year -- so its overall growth won't peak anytime soon.   Therefore
column44: I believe that investors should take advantage of   Amazon's temporary swoon and pick up a few more shares for the   long term.10 stocks we like better than MicrosoftWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column45: it can pay to listen. After all
column46: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column47: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column48: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Microsoft wasn't one of     them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4

column1: Voice Control Platforms a Key Technology Trend in 2017;2/9/2017;"Technology companies have spent years on computational linguistics to solve the basic problem of making machines more efficient in an era where they would have to deal with bigger data loads and more complex queries. One of the products of this research is voice driven artificial intelligence that can connect and drive everyday devices to understand human speech and react accordingly.The most basic form of voice technology is a person directing a machine to do routine tasks such as play a track
column2: read the mail
column3: send automated response to mails and such things that Apple'sAAPLSiri
column4: Alphabet'sGOOGLGoogle Now or Microsoft'sMSFTCortana took care of. Home automation is a more recent trend and wouldn't it be cool if most of the smart devices/appliances used in the home can also take voice commands? And sync with each other to decide the desirable activity and then get it done?Amazon AheadWhile Microsoft has many years of research behind it
column5: it is AmazonAMZNthat has really taken voice controlled platforms mainstream. The company launched its first Echo device a couple of years ago and sold more than seven million devices last year. While many of them were the cheaper Dot
column6: it still puts Alexa
column7: Amazon's voice assistant into that many new homes.At this year's CES
column8: Amazon had a coup as companies ranging from FordF
column9: Huawei and LG to a large number of startups unveiled phones
column10: cars
column11: home appliances and other gadgets with Alexa integration making Amazon's voice assistant that much more useful.And Amazon has doubled down to develop Alexa's ""skills
column12: which are discrete voice-based applications that allow the system to carry out specific tasks (like ordering pizza for example). At launch
column13: Alexa had just 20 skills
column14: which has reportedly jumped to 5
column15: 200 today with the company adding about 100 skills per day.In fact
column16: Bezos has said
column17: ""We've been working behind the scenes for the last four years
column18: we have more than 1
column19: 000 people working on Alexa and the Echo ecosystem … It's just the tip of the iceberg.""Just last week
column20: it launched a new website to help brands and developers create more skills for Alexa. It also has a home consultation service called ""simplify your life"" where Amazon reps teach you to automate your home using Echo and Alexa. But all this works simply because everything is connected with AWS
column21: which transmits data between different devices.Amazon.com
column22: Inc. Price and ConsensusAmazon.com
column23: Inc. Price and Consensus|Amazon.com
column24: Inc. QuoteGoogle Has Jumped InAmazon is clearly the leader in voice controlled platforms today
column25: but competition is in hot pursuit. Google Home was launched late last year and the search leader will do all it can to grow market share.To prove the point Google too had some important announcements for the Google Assistant
column26: which drives Google Home. But some of the most important deals were for integrations into Hyundai's navigation system
column27: Chrysler's 300 model
column28: NVIDIA'sNVDAShield TV as well as others such as Belkin smart switches
column29: Switchmate smart lights
column30: Coway Airmega air purifiers
column31: etc. Google still has miles to go before it catches up with Amazon
column32: but it's made a strong start.Google has the most to lose if it can't make it big here because a lot of voice search will probably happen through these assistants going forward. But it also has an advantage
column33: i.e.
column34: all the information it has curated over the years
column35: your preferences and your habits that it can draw from to serve you. In short
column36: it knows you better.Alphabet Inc. Price and ConsensusAlphabet Inc. Price and Consensus|Alphabet Inc. QuoteApple Also in the FrayApple doesn't have a separate Home device
column37: but a useful app of the same name that can connect all the smart devices in your home and get them to communicate with each other. So it's also dependent on the number of gadget makers supporting the app and this number has been swelling in the recent past.While Apple's partners aren't making the news as much as the other two
column38: there are a host of switch
column39: light
column40: camera
column41: sensor
column42: security system and other such device makers that have been announcing their support for Apple's platform the last couple of CESs (Apple makes it a point to stay away from the show).Apple Inc. Price and ConsensusApple Inc. Price and Consensus|Apple Inc. QuoteSamsung Taking NoticeSamsung paid a cool $8 billion to acquire auto infotainment
column43: acoustics
column44: display and other systems supplier Harman. That is a big sum to pay
column45: although justified considering that Harman does offer a number of products that would be complementary with the displays and chips that are an important part of the increasingly electronic and soon-to-be self-driving cars. IHS iSuppli expects the market to grow from $42 billion in 2016 to $61 billion next year.But there's more: just last year
column46: Harman announced a number of collaborations indicating its growing importance in the world of voice activated controls. In September
column47: it agreed to incorporate Baidu speech recognition and synthesis technology in smart speakers so people can use voice commands to turn on audio experiences and access on-demand services.Earlier
column48: the two collaborated to create CarLife offering advanced Internet capabilities
column49: entertainment features and location-based services on HARMAN's in-vehicle infotainment head units for the Chinese market. At the World of Watson conference last October
column50: Harman collaborated with IBM to bring voice activated intelligent assistance based on IoT and cognitive computing to hotels
column51: offices and hospitals across the world.Along Comes SoundHoundKeyvan Mohajer of SoundHound says
column52: ""We are at the inflection point of our long-term vision that every product or service needs to have a smart voice-enabled interface
column53: and consumers have increasingly high expectations for this requirement
column54: beyond simple commands or skills
column55: said Mohajer.He may be right because of the $115 million raised in its 10-year long life
column56: $75 million was contributed just last week from a group of companies including NVIDIA
column57: Samsung's Catalyst Fund
column58: Nomura Holdings
column59: Sompo Japan Nipponkoa Insurance
column60: Recruit Holdings' RSI Fund
column61: Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers
column62: SharesPost 100 Fund and MKaNN. Global Catalyst Partners
column63: Walden Venture Capital and Translink Capital Partners participated for a second time.The reason the investment is significant at this juncture is SoundHound's voice interface technology called Houndify that will now be empowered to reach more users. Houndify was incorporated into more than 500 products within the first 12 months of launch.Its popularity in the past and why companies like Samsung and NVIDIA are interested in it right now is simple. The technology is not designed to take over the device or transfer data to SoundHound unlike platforms like Alexa and Google Home. So its proliferation will let device makers employ the technology and also retain user data. Houndify already has 20K developers working on the platform and this number could expand rapidly with the cash infusion. Houndify already hasSumming UpInteraction with machines is set to become more interesting than ever before as they gradually understand our needs to get things done the way we want it even before we tell them to or perhaps right after. Since this is a nascent market
column64: there may not be any clear winners. Right now it does look as if there's enough growth opportunity for all the above players and more.Zacks' Top 10 Stocks for 2017In addition to the stocks discussed above

column1: BlackBerry Ltd (BBRY) Stock Worth $8 a Share;2/9/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsSaying it is better late than never is cliché
column3: so whenBlackBerry Ltd(NASDAQ:BBRY) announced it would license BBM
column4: the news was met with yawns. The stock moved a bit over 4% on the week. Still
column5: BBRY's march away from hardware devices and towards software sales will pay off. And with potential earnings growth of 31.6% next year (perFinviz)
column6: BBRY may make a run back to $8 a share.makeArticleAd();Source:WEi WEi via FlickrNokia Corp (ADR)(NYSE:NOK)

Only its top level of security may set the SDK apart from the others.The SDK cuts development time and promises to speed up bringing a messaging product to market. Building on the platform is also cheap: BlackBerry is using a subscription-licensing model.BlackBerry Hardware Not Forgotten: $1 RevenueUnsurprisingly

column1: 3 Covered Calls to Cash in on Blue-Chip Stocks;2/9/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsOptions are still considered rather exotic securities by the average investor
column3: and in some ways
column4: that's a good thing. They can be exotic and there is a higher degree of risk associated with them
column5: depending on what one's investment goals are. I made big mistakes using options early in my investing life because I didn't really have a clear purpose for using them.makeArticleAd();Source:401(K)2012 via FlickrHowever
column6: there is one basic strategy that may be of interest to the average income investor
column7: and it's a strategy involving covered calls. This is one of a few strategies I'll be using in my forthcoming stock advisory newsletter
column8: The Liberty Portfolio.With covered calls
column9: you either own a stock or purchase it
column10: and then sell the right
column11: but not the obligation
column12: for another person to buy that stock from you at a given price on a given day. It generates income for you when you sell the call.7 High-Risk
column13: High-Reward Stocks to Buy NowI sometimes like to use blue-chip stocks when selling covered calls. That's because they tend to have modest premiums
column14: and if you don't have the stock called away
column15: you are still owning a quality company. If it does get called away
column16: you can always buy it back.Covered Calls: Microsoft (MSFT)Source:Mike Mozart via Flickr (Modified)Microsoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT) is a prime candidate for selling covered calls against blue-chip stocks. Believe it or not
column17: MSFT is right near its all-time high and it has tons of cash.I actually think it's overpriced here at 30 times earnings with only 10% earnings growth
column18: so if you own it and it gets called away
column19: you may want to consider waiting for a price drop before buying back in.MSFT closed Wednesday at $63.34. The 24 March $63.50 covered calls are selling for $1.10. That's a very modest return of 1.74% for a holding period of 44 days
column20: or about 13% annualized. It's a bit less than I'd like to get
column21: but reasonable.Covered Calls: Exxon Mobil (XOM)Source:Mike Mozart via Flickr (Modified)Oil prices seem to have stabilized butExxon Mobil Corporation(NYSE:XOM) has fallen out of favor with investors. After doing exceptionally well compared to most blue chips in the oil patch
column22: XOM stock has floundered a bit.I think it's due to concerns over big expenses coming up
column23: but I think this is unfounded. As I've written
column24: I believe the Rex Tillerson confirmation will eventually lead to the big Rosneft deal starting to produce.There's probably also some concern about valuation. On an EV-to-Ebitda ratio
column25: which I think is the best way to evaluate the big producers
column26: it's expensive compared to almost all of its peers. Thus
column27: I think a near-to-medium term decline seems likely
column28: so having XOM called away is not a bad thing.12 Stocks That Will Live and Die by Donald Trump's PenXOM closed Wednesday at $81.50. The 24 March $81.50 covered calls are selling for $1.78. That's 2.2% returned in 44 days
column29: or about 18% annualized.Covered Calls: AT&T (T)Source: ShutterstockAT&T Inc.(NYSE:T) can sometimes be one of the blue-chip stocks to sell covered calls against. For starters
column30: despite its mountain of debt
column31: it produces amazing amounts of free cash flow.It usually pays out about half to cover its 4.77% dividend. It recently hit a multi-year high
column32: added DirecTV to its portfolio
column33: and is now trying to merge withTime Warner Inc(NYSE:TWX).The merger makes great sense
column34: but given President Trump's hawkishness toward media these days
column35: some people think he might try to pressure agencies to block it. I don't think that'll happen
column36: but it may put near-term pressure on the stock.T closed Wednesday at $41.21. The 24 March $41.50 covered calls are selling for 65
column37: cents which is a return of 1.6%. However
column38: if called away
column39: you pick up another 29 cents in capital gains
column41: for a total of 2.3%.Lawrence Meyers is the CEO of PDL Capital
column42: and manager of the forthcomingLiberty Portfolio stock newsletter. As of this writing
column43: has no position in any stock mentioned. He has 22 years' experience in the stock market
column44: and has written more than 1
column45: 600 articles on investing. Lawrence Meyers can be reached atTheLibertyPortfolio@gmail.com.The post3 Covered Calls to Cash in on Blue-Chip Stocksappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Snap Just Became One of Google's Most Important Cloud Customers;2/9/2017;"One of the many interesting details revealed inSnap's S-1 filing with the SEC is that it agreed to a $2 billion   contract with Google Cloud in January. The agreement with theAlphabet(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) subsidiary spans five years with   relatively equal payments scheduled for every year.Snap has used Google Cloud since its creation
column2: but had been   spending considerably less than the $400 million per year it's   slated to spend through 2021. For the first few years of its   existence
column3: it spent less than $30 million per year on Google   Cloud. Last year
column4: however
column5: it started seeing its hosting costs   increase considerably
column6: up $192 million for the year.Image Source: GettymakeArticleAd();Google's cloud service competes against the largerAmazon(NASDAQ: AMZN) Web Services andMicrosoft(NASDAQ: MSFT) Azure. A $2 billion infusion could help it catch   up to the competition.What does $2 billion mean to Google Cloud?Alphabet isn't exactly forthright with its cloud revenue. It   lumps Google Cloud in with Google's other revenue line item
column7: which also includes Google Play and hardware sales. In 2016
column8: the   three categories produced $10.1 billion in revenue. Google Play   likely accounts for the bulk of revenue.The cloud unit had an estimated run rate of just $1 billion as   of the end of 2015
column9: according to RBC Capital. Snap's new contract   likely makes it Google's biggest cloud customer.While Google has made several advancements in its cloud   services over the past year
column10: so have its competitors. Microsoft   boasted that its Azure revenue increased 93% last quarter
column11: but   Morgan Stanley analyst Keith Weiss estimates the unit brought in   just $1.6 billion. Bernstein's Mark Mordler estimates Azure's run   rate at $3 billion as of last quarter.Meanwhile
column12: Amazon just reported AWS sales topped $12 billion   in 2016. Sales surpassed $3.5 billion in the fourth quarter   alone
column13: although that fell short of analysts expectations.Google still needs to diversifyThe growth of Snapchat has been a major boon to Google's cloud   services
column14: but it's still actively seeking to pull customers away   from its competitors and take market share. The hiring of   cloud-computing veteran Diane Greene to lead the division has   helped the company attract numerous high-profile customers
column15: but   there's still more work to do.On Alphabet's fourth-quarter earnings call
column16: Google CEO Sundar   Pichai said
column17: ""We have truly differentiated offerings in four key   areas: data analytics and machine learning
column18: security and privacy
column19: tools for application development
column20: and the ability to create   connected business platforms."" Snap can take advantage of at   least three of those four factors
column21: so it's clear why it was   willing to lock down a long-term contract.At the same time
column22: the contract is not exclusive. If Snap wants   to enter China
column23: for example
column24: where Google doesn't operate
column25: it   could tap one of Google's competitors. Or it could build its   own servers.Snap recently hired Jerry Hunter from AWS
column26: who ran global data   centers for the cloud-computing giant. In Snap's S-1 filing
column27: management notes
column28: ""In the future
column29: we may invest in building our   own infrastructure to better serve our customers.""If Snap continues to grow at the pace it has been for the last   few years
column30: it may make economic sense for it to switch to its own   cloud infrastructure
column31: which would be a huge blow for Google.What this means for SnapSnap is now on the hook for $400 million per year in cloud   costs. There is some wiggle room: The contract says it can   postpone up to 15% of expenses for a year
column32: so it only has to   spend $340 million this first year. Still
column33: that's a huge amount   for a company that generated just $404.5 million in revenue last   year.It also means that switching service providers will be   difficult
column34: considering it would either have to eat the contract   as a loss
column35: or leave at least some of its operations on Google   Cloud in order not to waste the money. That makes the economics   of building out its own infrastructure within the next five years   even costlier.On the flip side
column36: analysts expect Snap's revenue to continue   growing at a rapid pace
column37: approaching $1 billion this year fueled   by continued user growth and product expansion that will surely   put additional demands on Google's servers. It has plenty of   capital to cover the expense
column38: and if last year's growth is any   indication of what to expect
column39: it will need to spend at least $340   million on cloud infrastructure this year. The deal with Google   ensures that it gets the lowest rates possible
column40: so it can to make   the most of its spend.Overall
column41: it's not a bad deal for Snap
column42: but it does tie the   company to Google for a long time.10 stocks we like better than Alphabet (A     shares)When investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column43: it can pay to listen. After all
column44: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column45: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column46: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Alphabet (A shares)     wasn't one of them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks     are even better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6

column49: is a member of The     Motley Fool's board of directors. Teresa Kersten is an employee     of LinkedIn and is a member of The Motley Fool's Board of     Directors. LinkedIn is owned by Microsoft.Adam Levyowns shares of Amazon. The Motley Fool owns shares of and     recommends Alphabet (A shares)

column1: Here's Why Adobe Systems Incorporated Stock Will Continue To Soar;2/9/2017;"If anyone deserved a promotion
column2: it'sAdobe(NASDAQ: ADBE) CEO and president Shantanu Narayen. Coming off   another stellar quarter and fiscal year
column3: Narayen has Adobe   soaring
column4: and he's earned his recently announced position of board   chairman to go alongside his roles as CEO and president. One of   the reasons Narayen warrants his chairman role is Adobe's   constant pushing of the innovation envelope.Adobe has long held the distinction in the design community of   being a leading packaged-software provider. But thanks to a few   targeted acquisitions and internal development efforts
column5: Adobe is   now a cloud leader as well. A recent concept video speaks   directly to Adobe's willingness to explore new opportunities
column6: despite what some pundits think.Adobe Cloud. Image source: Adobe.makeArticleAd();Reading between the linesShortly after Adobe shared a voice-editing feature it's   exploring
column7: it released a ""concept video"" demonstrating a similar   functionality for images. The demo of a voice-activated digital   assistant shows a user changing the size
column8: framing
column9: and saving of   an image. The demo finishes with a voice command that instantly   loads the edited pic onto the user's social-media page.A number of industry pundits chimed in with their   disappointment in the feature
column10: complaining about how ""simplistic""   it is. They missed the point entirely. There's a reason Adobe   called it a concept video: The technology hasn't even progressed   to the beta-testing stage. The demo was simply a way to introduce   another of the innovations Adobe is undertaking to stay ahead of   the curve.Some creative types also bemoaned the notion of having to   learn another method -- in this case a voice-activated personal   assistant -- for editing their projects. But there's a reason   some of the biggest players in the tech industry
column11: including Adobe   strategic partnerMicrosoft(NASDAQ: MSFT)
column12: are testing voice-activated assistants   incorporating artificial intelligence
column13: like the Windows king's   Cortana.According to one estimate
column14: the use of virtual assistants will   grow by nearly 35% annually over the next seven years
column15: becoming a   more than $11 billion market. As voice-activated tools like   Adobe's early-phase editing tool expand their capabilities
column16: just   as with Cortana
column17: using the technology will become second   nature.The bigger pictureSetting the criticisms aside
column18: Adobe's editing demo speaks   directly to its commitment to innovation. In addition to working   together on incorporating virtual reality (VR) and augmented   reality (AR) into Adobe's design solutions -- a natural fit for   creative folks -- the two companies recently partnered in the   cloud
column19: using Microsoft's Azure platform to incorporate artificial   intelligence (AI) and advanced analytics into Adobe's Marketing   Cloud solutions.Just as with its editing-assistant demo
column20: the strategic   alignment with Microsoft is an indication that Adobe has no   intention of resting on its laurels
column21: which should be music to the   ears of investors -- particularly those concerned with Adobe's   incredible performance of late.Coming off a quarter and fiscal year in which Adobe reported   record revenue of $1.61 billion and $5.85 billion respectively
column22: its shareholders have enjoyed a 44% jump in stock price the past   12 months. Some may question Adobe's relative value
column23: given its   trading at a whopping 49 times earnings. Don't.Due in part to continuously exploring cutting-edge new   features and technologies
column24: Adobe stock is trading at a mere 24   times forward earnings
column25: less than half its current valuation.   Another feather in Adobe's cap is that its transition to an   annual recurring revenue (ARR) model is hitting on all cylinders.   Adobe exited last quarter with trailing ARR of $4.01 billion.In addition to building a strong
column26: relatively stable revenue   foundation
column27: ARR also gives Adobe the flexibility to focus its   spending on developing new advanced functionalities. Much of the   12.7% increase in operating expenses last year
column28: which was more   than offset by Adobe's 22% increase in revenue
column29: was spent on   research and development.Adobe's decision to act
column30: rather than react
column31: to the   ever-changing possibilities offered by new technologies is a big   reason it will continue to outperform its peers...despite what   near-sighted pundits may think.10 stocks we like better than Adobe SystemsWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column32: it can pay to listen. After all
column33: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column34: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column35: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Adobe Systems wasn't one     of them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of February 6
column36: 2017Teresa Kersten is an employee of LinkedIn and is a member     of The Motley Fool's Board of Directors. LinkedIn is owned by     Microsoft.Tim Bruggerhas no position in any stocks mentioned. The Motley Fool     recommends Adobe Systems. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: Burned by FireEye Inc (FEYE) Stock? Try These Rebound Trades;2/9/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsThere was much hype surroundingFireEye Inc(NASDAQ:FEYE) back in 2015. The company had just come off revenue growth of 163% the year prior
column3: and FireEye was the first cybersecurity firm to be certified under the Safety Act. But the company fell prey to a major faux pas in the technology world - it didn't innovate fast enough
column4: and FEYE stock is now paying the price.makeArticleAd();Source:Fortune Brainstorm TECH via FlickrIn 2014
column5: the cloud business model was breaking onto the scene
column6: and it was creating enough of a stir that even major players likeCisco Systems
column7: Inc.(NASDAQ:CSCO) andMicrosoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT) were making significant moves into the new market. It was a lesson FireEye learned too late
column8: as evidenced by the company's recent quarterly earnings report.Despite a major push and a plethora of incentives to boost sales
column9: FireEye's revenue of $184.7 million missed Wall Street's estimates of $191 million. But the topline figure wasn't the only concern
column10: as FireEye guided to a 3% decline in first-quarter revenue
column11: compared to the Street's expected 5% growth.Among the myriad of problems facing the company
column12: including slower corporate enterprise spending and increased competition in the cybersecurity market
column13: FireEye's late restructuring into a cloud-subscription model is almost unforgivable - especially when blue-chip security firms were already headed that direction.But there is a bright side for FEYE stock investors
column14: at least over the short term. Barring any other major surprises or management short-sightedness (CFO Mike Berry and board chairman David DeWalt are both stepping down
column15: which could help)
column16: the worst appears to be already factored into FEYE's price. As such
column17: literally any positive news for the company could kick off a short-term bounce.7 High-Risk
column18: High-Reward Stocks to Buy NowAs usual
column19: potential drivers for such a bounce would come from FEYE's sentiment backdrop. For instance
column20: Thomson/First Call reports that 21 of the 31 analysts following FEYE stock rate the shares a ""hold"" or worse. The fact that there aren't more ""sell"" ratings after last week's quarterly report tells me that Wall Street is ready to reward FireEye for moving in the right direction. In other words
column21: upgrades are a distinct possibility following any positive progress.Elsewhere
column22: short sellers are already taking profits on FEYE. As of the most recent reporting period
column23: the number of FEYE shares sold short dropped by 3% to 20.3 million. Still
column24: roughly 13.3% of FireEye's float remains sold short
column25: and could spark a round of profit taking or a covering rally if the stock can find its feet and move higher.Click to EnlargeJudging by FEYE's options configuration
column26: short sellers may be preparing for just such an outcome. Currently
column27: the March put/call open interest ratio for FEYE stock rests at 0.44
column28: with calls more than doubling puts among options set to expire on March 17.FEYE is trading well below all major put and call accumulations in the series
column29: with the $13 strike home to peak put OI and $14 representing the next significant call OI strike
column30: leaving little in the way of potential options headwinds in the short term.March implieds
column31: meanwhile
column32: are pricing in a potential move of about 12.6% for volatile FEYE stock. This places the upper bound at $12.39
column33: while the lower bound rests at $9.61.2 Trades for FEYE StockCall Spread:Bearish sentiment on an underperforming stock is to be expected
column34: but FEYE stock is trading at oversold levels following a post-earnings beating. With said beating now out of the way
column35: FEYE should trend higher
column36: with any positive news providing additional lift.Those traders looking to take a risk on an FEYE comeback over the short-term might want to consider a March $12/$13 bull call spread. At last check
column37: this spread was offered at 19 cents
column38: or $19 per pair of contracts. Breakeven lies at $12.19
column39: while a maximum profit of 81 cents
column40: or $81 per pair of contracts
column41: is possible if FEYE stock closes at or above $13 when March options expire.The Smart Money: Sears Holdings Corp (SHLD) Is Already InsolventPut Sell:Those looking for a more bullish-to-neutral position may want to look at a FEYE March $10 put sell position. At last check
column42: this put was bid at 25 cents
column43: or $25 per contract. Remember that you keep the initial premium received as long as FEYE stock closes above $10 when March options expire. However
column44: if FEYE trades below $10 ahead of expiration
column45: you could be assigned 100 shares of stock for every put sold at a cost of $10 per share.As of this writing
column46: Joseph Hargett did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace3 Stocks to Buy for Their Coming ReboundThe 2 Best
column47: and 2 Worst
column48: Dow Dividend Stocks TodayThe postBurned by FireEye Inc (FEYE) Stock? Try These Rebound Tradesappeared first onInvestorPlace."
