column1: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd (BABA) Stock Has a Secret Weapon;2/2/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAlibaba Group Holding Ltd(NYSE:BABA) is often compared toAmazon.com
column3: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN)
column4: which isn't always accurate. Most notably
column5: Alibaba doesn't hold inventory like its larger U.S. peer
column6: and it doesn't have AMZN's massive distribution capabilities. But
column7: there is one notable similarity that doesn't seem priced into BABA stock at the moment:makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockA large
column8: fast-growing cloud computing offering.Amazon's cloud business
column9: called Amazon Web Services (AWS)
column10: has been a major factor in the rise of AMZN stock from less than $200 to more than $800 over the past five years.Alibaba Cloud is still much smaller
column11: but its growth profile looks much like that of AWS back in 2011-12. That explosive growth - and the ability to be a legitimate competitor to Amazon.com andMicrosoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT) - has the potential to drive significant additional upside in BABA stock.The Impact of Alibaba Cloud on BABA StockSo far
column12: the cloud business hasn't done much for Alibaba's revenue
column13: or BABA stock
column14: for that matter. BABA still trades around $100
column15: basically the same levels at which it went public in late 2014.Through the first nine months of fiscal 2016
column16: cloud has generated just 3.3% of total revenue. Over the past four quarters
column17: Alibaba's cloud sales total just $765 million - likely less than 6% of what AWS will create in calendar 2016. And at the moment
column18: Alibaba's cloud business actually is a drag on BABA earnings. The business has lost $92 million in EBITA (not EBITDA; BABA uses EBITA for segment income) over the past four quarters.3 BRICS Buys That Play Banking
column19: Buying and ... Beef?But the gap to Amazon and the losses in the business have more to do with Alibaba's relatively late start than with a lack of demand. Cloud revenue growth has been impressive
column20: increasing 130% through the first nine months of fiscal 2016
column21: and 115% in the December quarter
column22: despite a pricing cut.That follows a 138% increase in cloud sales in fiscal 2016. Most impressively
column23: the number of customers nearly doubled year-over-year in Q3
column24: and BABA added 114
column25: 000 new customers in the December quarter alone.As for profitability
column26: Alibaba isn't worried
column27: yet
column28: with management saying on the Q3 conference call it was spending to gain market share. Profitability will come
column29: but for now
column30: Alibaba is looking to cement its dominance of the lucrative Chinese market.Losses now are OK - AWS lost money until recently - because those new customers will provide high-margin recurring revenue going forward
column31: possibly for decades.The Impact of Alibaba Cloud on BABA Stock Going ForwardThe good news for BABA stock is that it looks like the cloud business is nearing an inflection point. Losses are narrowing
column32: but still represent a drag on overall earnings for BABA. Over the past 12 months
column33: cloud has actually had a negative impact on EPS of about $0.03. That will change shortly
column34: as Alibaba has said that the business will hit a profit around 1 million users
column35: a milestone almost certain to be hit in 2017.The question is what happens after that. If Alibaba's growth looks anything like Amazon's going forward
column36: it should be very positive for BABA stock.AMZN didn't break out cloud revenue until 2015; it appears that the business generated about $1 billion in sales in 2011 and $2 billion in 2012. That then grew to almost $4 billion in 2013
column37: $5.6 billion in 2014
column38: and $7.9 billion in 2015. 2016 growth to date suggests a figure over $12 billion in 2016. AWS is now estimated by analysts to be worth (on its own) about $150-$160 billion.Can Alibaba grow its cloud business to the same extent? Goldman Sachs analysts argued it could
column39: projecting a valuefor Alibaba Cloud of $42 billion by 2019
column40: based on $5 billion in sales. That growth alone would add almost 20% to the value of BABA stock over the next few years and it's not as outlandish as it seems.The Future Looks Bright for BABA StockGrowth rates have been over 100%
column41: yet cloud computing is still relatively unknown in China. On the Q3 conference call
column42: Alibaba CEO Daniel Zhang estimated that
column43: even assuming pricing discounts to lure customers using hard drives
column44: the addressable market for cloud in China would be $30 billion. And in November
column45: Alibaba added new data centers in four locations worldwide: Sydney
column46: Tokyo
column47: Dubai and Germany.The concern might be whether a Chinese company will be able to compete internationally with Amazon and Microsoft. U.S. companies might prefer domestic providers
column48: and elsewhere there could be worries about security.But
column49: the reverse of that argument is that Alibaba should have a huge advantage in marketing to Chinese consumers
column50: as those customers might be similarly unwilling to use American companies for their cloud services. Even with BABA now worth approximately $250 billion
column51: the $30 billion Chinese market is more than enough to provide a material catalyst.3 Stocks to Buy for Better Deals Than the Great RecessionAWS profit margins already arenearing 25%despite its own spending in that business. Assuming Alibaba can get half of the Chinese market at 30% margins
column52: the cloud segment could contribute as much as $1.50 per share in EPS annually
column53: enough to add $30 billion-$40 billion in market value. Any international success would simply add to that value.Until now
column54: the business hasn't been a focus of BABA stock investors
column55: but that seems likely to change. When the company hits the 1 million mark and turns cloud profitable in 2017
column56: coverage of the business should likely increase. And
column57: further awareness of that driver seems equally likely to drive upside for BABA stock. Investors should consider getting long in Alibaba stock before the rest of the market figures that out.As of this writing
column58: Vince Martin did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceThe 5 Best Stocks to Buy for Big Emerging Markets ProfitsThe Top 10 Dow Dividend Stocks for FebruarySears Holdings Corp (SHLD): A Great American Tragedy Nears Its EndThe postAlibaba Group Holding Ltd (BABA) Stock Has a Secret Weaponappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: 3 Big Stock Charts for Thursday: Microsoft Corporation (MSFT)
column2: Amazon.com
column3: Inc. (AMZN) and Cincinnati Financial Corporation (CINF);2/2/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column4: Stock Advice & Trading TipsWe're still seeing a lot of weakness in the market as the earnings season is failing to add the spark that most investors were hoping for. While the aggregate bullish effect of the season hasn't been felt
column5: there have been some stocks that are seeing opportunities to extend themselves higher likeMicrosoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT) andAmazon.com
column6: Inc.(NASDAQ:AMZN). On the other hand
column7: Cincinnati Financial Corporation(NASDAQ:CINF) has found itself in a must-win situation ahead of next week's earnings results as the company's stock is barely hanging on to its long-term bullish trend.makeArticleAd();Amazon.com
column8: Inc. (AMZN)Amazon heads into the earnings confessional this afternoon as the stock sits near its highs around $850 technically teasing those looking at taking a position ahead of the numbers.The charts indicate that AMZN shares have become less overbought over the last week as the stock took a move towards its 20-day moving average. This move is very familiar to those of us that watch Amazon as it is a carbon copy of the pre-earnings activity last quarter.Today's AMZN chart is somewhat different and more supportive of the bulls as the stock is now shifting into an intermediate-term bull trend with the 50-day trendline crossing back over the 100-day. Our historical testing shows that Amazon stock is 63% more likely to outperform the at-any-time returns for the two months following this crossover.Volume on AMZN has dropped a little over the last week as we've seen traders back away ahead of the earnings. Call options on the stock have dropped in premium
column9: suggesting that the options traders aren't expecting Amazon stock to knock the cover off of the ball this afternoon.7 High-Yield Stocks Ripe For A Short SqueezeThis adds up to breakout potential for the stock on an in-line report. The potential fly in the ointment would be the fact that MSFT is growing their Azure line of business. Watch for this to take a little away from the magic that has been AWS
column10: Amazon's real driving force. Outside of that
column11: the charts suggest a breakout on the way for AMZN.Cincinnati Financial Corporation (CINF)Last month
column12: Cincinnati Financial shares took a hit on the exposure to the tragedy in Gatlinburg. Since then
column13: CINF shares have spent their time consolidating and trying to place a tradable bottom
column14: but there's a hanging issue.As of this week
column15: all but the 200-day moving average have transitioned into a short- to intermediate-term bearish pattern. This means that Cincinnati Financial stock is likely to start feeling more pressure from the sellers again as overhead pressure builds.CINF chart watchers remember the significance of the $70-level last October. The shares took a decline to this level after an earnings report that failed to impress. Now
column16: Cincinnati Financial prepares to report its quarterly results next Wednesday as the stock sits on this same critical chart support level. This makes the earnings announcement a ""must win"" for CINF.The 20-month moving average sits at $66.50
column17: which is the line in the sand that long-term investors should be watching. A move to or below this level is going to spark additional selling as this stock has been one of the better performers in its peer group.Microsoft Corporation (MSFT)Again we get to cover Microsoft this week as the stock appears to be giving those patient traders an opportunity.Why Amazon.com
column18: Inc. (AMZN) Stock Should Expect Fireworks SoonMSFT shares rallied after a positive earnings announcement and took the shares to new all-time highs. After ringing that bell
column19: the profiteers stepped in to lock in gains resulting in a near 5% drop in the Microsoft stock price.Technically
column20: MSFT stock is now setting up for a nice short-term buying opportunity as it has worked off a technically overbought indication at the same time that it is nearing the 50-day moving average at $62.40.Since breaking above the 50-day in October
column21: Microsoft stock has found significant buying interest on each test of the widely watched trendline. The last test
column22: in December
column23: resulted in an 8% rally over an 11-trading day period.Those looking to hold off and be patient can look for MSFT stock to head to the $60.50
column24: which is the next site of trendline support at the 100-day. For now
column25: our money is on a more shallow pullback to the 50-day holding as the more likely technical scenario to play out on Microsoft.As of this writing
column26: Johnson Research Group did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceThe Top 10 Dow Dividend Stocks for February7 Awful Stocks You Need To Ditch Right AwayThe post3 Big Stock Charts for Thursday: Microsoft Corporation (MSFT)

column1: The International Business Machines Corp. (IBM) Stock Dip Beckons to Profit-Seekers;2/2/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsTraders seeking strength are flocking to theNasdaqin droves. The tech-laden index continues to be the best looking of the bunch
column3: and its dominance has only increased during earnings season. Solid performance fromApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) toMicrosoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT) following their respective earnings releases has helped keep the good times rolling. But do you know which heavy hitter may be sporting the best opportunity right now?International Business Machines Corp.(NYSE:IBM).makeArticleAd();Source:Open Grid Scheduler Via FlickrLet's take a deep dive into the chart of IBM stock to see what kind of trade we can drum up.Like the lion's share of the equities market
column4: IBM jumped into an uptrend following last year's election and it hasn't looked back since. The tech titan entered the new year with a solid high base pattern that created a breakout opportunity for technical traders.And they didn't have to wait long. Big Blue's earnings beat from Jan. 19 served as the excuse for buyers to come rushing in.The action in IBM stock since then has been textbook. After breaching the $170 resistance level
column5: the stock gained a quick ten bucks before the bulls' fury finally faded.5 Safe Dividend Stocks to Buy for RetirementSince then
column6: mild profit-taking has created an attractive four-day pullback. Traders loath to chase now have their opportunity to scoop up shares at a discount.Source: OptionsAnalytixRecent volume patterns have also been favoring buyers. The post-earnings breakout was accompanied by a handful of accumulation days suggesting institutions were entering the fray with aggression. And while the stock has retreated in recent days
column7: the volume has been muted suggesting a lack of any real conviction by sellers here.Throw it all together
column8: and this IBM stock dip looks like a buy.IBM Stock Calendars
column9: Anyone?With earnings fading in the distance
column10: IBM options have become cheap again. And that means long option trades carry much less risk. Let's build a calendar spread to capitalize on further upside in the stock over the coming month.First
column11: buy to open the Apr $170 call for around $7.60. Then
column12: sell to open the Mar $180 call for around $1.25. This creates a diagonal call spread for a net debit of $6.35. The max loss is limited to the initial debit and will be forfeited if IBM sits below $170 at Apr expiration.Why Sony Corp (ADR) (SNE) Stock Should Ditch the Entertainment BizTo minimize the loss
column13: I suggest exiting if the stock breaks the $165 support level.The max profit is around $400 and will be captured if IBM sits right at $180 at March expiration. Since the April option will only have one month remaining at March expiration
column14: I suggesting exiting at that point.At the time of this writing
column15: Tyler Craig had no positions in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace5 Stocks to Buy to Defy a Weak FebruaryThe 5 Best Stocks to Buy for Big Emerging Markets ProfitsThe postThe International Business Machines Corp. (IBM) Stock Dip Beckons to Profit-Seekersappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: 3 Naked Puts on High-ROI Stocks;2/2/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsThis week I'm going to do something a little different as I discuss naked puts. First
column3: let's remind ourselves what we're up to with naked puts
column4: which will be an important piece of my forthcoming stock advisory newsletter
column5: The Liberty Portfolio.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockWith naked puts
column6: you are selling the right for someone to ""put
column7: or sell
column8: the chosen stock to you at a certain price if the stock falls below that price on or before a given date of expiration.It's unlikely that the stock will get sold to you prior to that date even if shares fall below the strike price. It is possible
column9: but it only tends to happen if the stock is well below the strike.5 Stocks to Buy to Defy a Weak FebruaryNaked puts generate income from the contract
column10: and I only sell them on stocks I want to own
column11: so I don't mind if they get put to me. I'll be calculating returns a bit differently this week.Naked Puts: Dollar Tree (DLTR)Source:Mike Mozart via FlickrDollar Tree
column12: Inc.(NASDAQ:DLTR) is a massive dollar retail store
column13: and has performed exceptionally well over the long term. It's had a recent selloff that I think presents a great opportunity to sell naked puts. DLTR closed Wednesday at $76.39.By selling the 17 March $75 naked puts
column14: assuming you get $3.10 per contract
column15: you get a ""raw real return"" of 4.06%
column16: which is calculated by dividing $3.10 by $76.39. Because the contract runs 44 days
column17: that comes out to 33.7% annualized.Another way to calculate it is to assume DLTR stock is put to you
column18: but that the stock is purchased using margin. Most brokers have a 35% margin requirement for an effective short positions - an amount set aside to partially cover the cost of a potential purchase. So 35% of the total purchase price if DLTR were put to you is $2
column19: 625. Thus
column20: what I would call the ""gross ROI"" would be $310 divided by $2
column22: or 11.81%.Naked Puts: Starbucks (SBUX)Source:Javier González Via FlickrGross ROI is just another way to compare option trades. Let's look at another example with it and raw real return forStarbucks Corporation(NASDAQ:SBUX).SBUX stock has fallen the past few days on earnings results that annoyed some people
column23: but it's a long-term story and it means being able to get the stock at a cheaper price with naked puts.SBUX closed Wednesday at $53.90. The 10 March $54 naked puts are selling for about $1.10. So the raw real return here is 2.04%
column24: which comes out to 20.1% on an annualized basis.3 ""Left for Dead"" Stocks Making a ComebackTaking our 35% margin requirement on a $5
column25: 400 purchase
column26: we come out to $1
column27: 890. Dividing $110 into $1
column28: 890 gives us a gross ROI of 5.82%.Naked Puts: Microsoft (MSFT)Source:Mike Mozart via Flickr (Modified)Finally
column29: look atMicrosoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT)
column30: which closed at $63.58 on Wednesday. The 10 March $63.50 naked puts are selling for $1.35. On a raw real return basis that comes out to 2.12%
column31: or 20.9% on an annualized basis. A 35% margin requirement on a $6
column32: 350 purchase is $2
column33: 222. So our gross ROI is 6.07%.Now
column34: compare all three. Note that the more volatile stock
column35: DLTR
column36: offers a higher premium but also sells at a higher price. Even though DLTR stock is only $13 more expensive than MSFT stock
column37: or about 20%
column38: and the contract is only one week longer
column39: the premium sells for 130% more
column40: thus creating a higher gross ROI.SBUX stock is about 20% cheaper than MSFT stock
column41: yet both its raw real return and gross ROI are about the same. The purpose of this exercise is just to show a different way to calculate a return should a stock get put to you
column42: and you elect to actually purchase it instead of just buying back the naked position.Lawrence Meyers is the CEO of PDL Capital
column43: and manager of the forthcomingLiberty Portfolio stock newsletter. As of this writing
column44: has no position in any stock mentioned. He has 22 years' experience in the stock market
column45: and has written more than 1
column46: 600 articles on investing. Lawrence Meyers can be reached atTheLibertyPortfolio@gmail.com.The post3 Naked Puts on High-ROI Stocksappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: 4 Tech ETFs Set to Soar on Facebook's Stellar Q4 Results;2/2/2017;"The fourth-quarter reporting cycle saw a spate of solid earnings reports from tech giants like International Business MachinesIBM
column2: NetflixNFLX
column3: MicrosoftMSFT
column4: and AppleAAPL. Social media giant Facebook (FB) continued the bullishness after the closing bell yesterday (read:IBM Tops
column5: Guides Higher: ETFs in Focus).makeArticleAd();FacebookFBreported stellar fourth-quarter 2016 results beating our top and bottom line estimates on the strength in mobile advertising business and growing momentum for video advertising.Q4 Results in DetailAdjusted earnings per share (accounting for stock-based compensation) came in at $1.24
column6: crushing the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $1.11 growing over twofold from the year-ago quarter. Revenues soared 51% year over year to $8.81 billion and edged past our estimate of $8.47 billion. Growing advertising revenue is the major reason for the robust performance.Advertising revenues grew 53% year over year to $8.63 billion. Notably
column7: mobile advertising revenues accounted for 84% of total advertising revenue
column8: up from 80% in the year-ago quarter. The company's dominance in mobile advertising revenues is expected to increase in the coming months as it is looking to add advertising in its messaging services What's App and Facebook Messenger.Additionally
column9: Facebook is expected to garner about $33.76 billion in global ad revenue this year
column10: the company world's No. 2 digital ad publisher behind AlphabetGOOGLaccording to eMarketer. Further
column11: the company will continue to reap the benefits of a big push into video both on Facebook itself and on Instagram (read:Tech ETFs to Watch Post Microsoft & Alphabet Results).Daily active users grew 18% year over year to 1.23 billion in the fourth quarter with 1.15 billion coming from mobile. Meanwhile
column12: monthly active users grew 17% year over year to 1.86 billion
column13: of whom mobile active users accounted for 1.74 billion
column14: up 21%. eMarketer expects the number of US users will increase 2.7% in 2017
column15: while user growth worldwide will grew 7.9%.Given outstanding results
column16: shares of FB spiked as much as 3.6% to an-all time high of $137.99 in aftermarket hours
column17: eroding all the negative sentiments of the revenue slowdown
column18: which the company warned in the third quarter. It further indicates good tidings for the near term. Currently
column19: Facebook has a favorable Zacks Rank #3 (Hold) with a VGM Style Score of C.ETFs in FocusGiven this

column1: Microsoft Sells "Thousands" of HoloLens -- What Now?;2/2/2017;"Microsoft's(NASDAQ: MSFT) HoloLens -- a ""mixed reality"" headset which   projects virtual and augmented reality ""holograms"" on real   objects -- captured the attention of many gadget enthusiasts last   year
column2: but the development kit's$3
column3: 000 price tagkept it mostly in the hands of serious developers.However
column4: Microsoft recently announced that  it had sold   ""thousands"" of HoloLens units since last March -- indicating that   developer base was growing. Let's take a look at what lies in   store for the HoloLens this year
column5: and when a cheaper   consumer-facing model might finally arrive.Image source: Microsoft.makeArticleAd();The Windows 10 Creators UpdateUnder CEO Satya Nadella
column6: Microsoft has gradually built a ""One   Windows"" ecosystem in which various devices are connected by a   single operating system
column7: app store
column8: and cloud platform. HoloLens   will play a crucial role in tethering ""mixed reality"" users to   that ecosystem via Windows 10.The first major step toward that integration will be the    Windows 10 Creators Update this spring. That update will   add 3D image capture and editing tools
column9: which will enable artists   and developers to create 3D objects which can be viewed in   HoloLens. That learning curve sounds steep
column10: but Microsoft claims   that the tools will be so simple that they can be used by   12-year-olds. Doing so could help Microsoft attract more   developers to make Windows 10 and HoloLens a truly ""holographic""   combination.The virtual reality training wheelsLast October
column11: Microsoft announced that it would  launchVR headsetsthat could track a user's head rotation and position without   using external sensors likeFacebook's(NASDAQ: FB) Oculus Rift andHTC's Vive. Like the Rift and Vive
column12: Microsoft's VR headsets will be   tethered to PCs.But Microsoft's headsets will start at just $300 --   significantly undercutting the Rift and Vive's respective price   tags of $600 and $800. Microsoft also claims that the headsets   will work on mid-range PCs
column13: which could pull PC gamers away from   the Rift and Vive. Microsoft won't manufacture these headsets on   its own. Instead
column14: it will rely on hardware partners likeHP
column15: Lenovo
column16: Dell
column17: Asus
column18: andAcerto launch the devices.These headsets will notably use similar voice and gesture   commands as the HoloLens. This means that they could serve as   cheaper ""training wheels"" for the HoloLens -- so the controls   feel more familiar when the commercial version finally   arrives.More retail and enterprise partnershipsMicrosoft has been boosting the HoloLens' public exposure with   several retail partnerships.Volvouses the HoloLens to let consumers ""virtually"" customize their   dream cars in augmented reality -- regardless of a dealer's   in-store inventory. That virtual customization helps dealers   minimize inventory space to reduce real estate expenses.The HoloLens being used at a Volvo dealership. Image source:     Microsoft.Home improvement retailerLowe'slets customers use the  HoloLens to view changes to   their homes in virtual reality. Microsoft will likely sign   similar retail partnerships this year
column19: since they help both   retailers and customers understand the practical uses of   HoloLens' mixed reality features.Microsoft has also signed enterprise deals with several   companies to test the HoloLens' effectiveness in the workplace.   Its integration withAutodesk360 helps designers create hologram versions of their   designs
column20: and its partnership withTrimblestreamlines communications for construction workers and   provides them with 3D visualizations of their projects.Japan Airlinesalso used the headset to train mechanics and flight crew members   last  year. That list will likely grow this year if the   Creators Update whets companies' appetite for holographic   applications.But don't expect a consumer release in 2017Microsoft is laying down the foundations for the HoloLens
column21: but   consumers shouldn't expect a cheaper version of the device to   arrive this year. Alex Kipman
column22: who oversees the development of   the HoloLens
column23: recently toldCNETthat he doesn't expect hardware prices to significantly decline   anytime soon. Kipman admitted that ""roadmaps"" for getting the   price under $1
column24: 000 exist
column25: but he declined to share any additional   details.It's very common for a device to have a long waiting time   between developer kit releases and the commercial launch. Oculus
column26: for example
column27: released the first dev kit of the Rift in March   2013. The commercial version didn't arrive until three years   later. Therefore
column28: we could still need to wait averylong time before a cheaper HoloLens arrives.10 stocks we like better than MicrosoftWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column29: it can pay to listen. After all
column30: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column31: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column32: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Microsoft wasn't one of     them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4

column1: Symantec (SYMC) Tops on Q3 Earnings
column2: Down on Tepid View;2/2/2017;"Symantec CorporationSYMCreported third-quarter fiscal 2017 results. The company's adjusted earnings (excluding deferred revenues fair value
column3: amortization
column4: restructuring and other one-time items but including stock-based compensation) of 22 cents per share came a penny ahead of the Zacks Consensus Estimate. On a year-over-year basis
column5: it remained flat.Furthermore
column6: on a non-GAAP basis
column7: Symantec's earnings came in at 32 cents per share
column8: which not only came ahead of its own guidance range of 27 cents to 29 cents but also marked a year-over-year increase of 23%. The year-over-year improvement in non-GAAP earnings was mainly driven by increased sales.Despite a strong bottom-line performance
column9: shares of Symantec fell approximately 4% in yesterday's after-hour trade as the company's top-line results and fourth quarter revenue outlook fell short of analysts' expectations.Nonetheless
column10: the stock has outperformed the Zacks categorizedComputer-Softwareindustry in the year-to-date period. Symantec shares gained 11% in the said period while the industry's gain was just 5.6%.Quarter in DetailSymantec's revenues of $1.041 billion increased 14.5% year over year mainly driven by strong performance at the company's Enterprise Security segment. However
column11: it fell short of the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $1.085 billion.Nonetheless
column12: adjusted for deferred revenues fair value
column13: revenues were $1.088 billion compared with $909 million in the year-ago quarter. Moreover
column14: the company's non-GAAP revenues were above the mid-point of its own guidance $1.070 billion to $1.090 billion (mid-point: $1.080 billion).Segment-wise
column15: the Consumer Security division witnessed a 4% year-over-year decline in revenues
column16: while revenues at Enterprise Security increased 30% on a year-over-year basis. Moreover
column17: adjusted for deferred revenues fair value
column18: Enterprise Security revenues surged 40%.Symantec's adjusted gross profit of $917 million was up 19.7%
column19: primarily attributable to a higher revenue base and lower cost of goods sold. Consequently
column20: as a percentage of revenues
column21: gross margin improved 380 basis points (bps) on a year-over-year basis to 86.9%.Furthermore
column22: adjusted operating income increased 8.3% year over year to $234 million
column23: as the benefits from increased revenues and lower cost of goods sold were partially offset by a 24.2% jump in adjusted operating expenses. Consequently
column24: adjusted operating margin contracted 130 bps year over year to 22.5%.On a non-GAAP basis
column25: operating income grew 30.3% year over year to $331 million while margin improved 250 bps to 30.4%. Moreover
column26: non-GAAP operating margin was higher than the company's guidance range of 27% to 28%.The better-than-expected margin was mainly driven by strong top-line growth and realization of cost savings ahead of time. As per Symantec
column27: it remains on track to realize over $200 million of cost savings in fiscal 2017 through its cost restructuring initiatives and synergies from the newly acquired business
column28: Blue Coat.Adjusted net income for the quarter came in at $136.6 million compared with $151.6 million in the year-ago quarter. However
column29: on per share basis
column30: adjusted earnings per share were flat year over year at 22 cents as a lower numerator was offset by a lower denominator.Balance Sheet & Cash FlowSymantec exited the quarter with cash
column31: cash equivalents and short-term investments of $5.575 billion
column32: compared with $5.619 billion last quarter. Long-term debt was $6.358 billion
column33: down from $6.576 billion in the previous quarter.During the first three quarters of 2016
column34: Symantec used operating cash flow of $573 million. Moreover
column35: it paid $173 million as dividend during the period.GuidanceSymantec did not provide any update on the fiscal 2017 guidance. It should be noted that during the second-quarter earnings release
column36: the company had reiterated its non-GAAP revenue guidance but raised its non-GAAP operating margin and earnings per share outlook for fiscal 2017. For fiscal 2017
column37: Symantec still expects revenues in a range of $4.040 billion to $4.120 billion (mid-point $4.08 billion). Non-GAAP operating margin is now anticipated in a range of 27% to 29% (previously 26%-28%). Non-GAAP earnings per share are now expected to be $1.12 to $1.18 (previously $1.08 to $1.14).However
column38: it provided guidance for the fourth quarter. For the fourth quarter of fiscal 2017
column39: Symantec expects GAAP and non-GAAP revenues in a range of $1.039 billion - $1.059 billion (mid-point $1.049 billion) and $1.070 billion - $1.090 billion (mid-point $1.080 billion)
column40: respectively. The Zacks Consensus Estimate is pegged at $1.11 billion.GAAP and non-GAAP operating margin is projected in a range of 1%-3% and 27%-29%
column41: respectively. Management expects to report a breakeven to loss of 2 cents on a GAAP basis for the fourth quarter. However
column42: on a non-GAAP basis
column43: it expects earnings between 27 cents and 29 cents.LifeLock AcquisitionDuring the third quarter of fiscal 2017
column44: Symantec entered into a definitive agreement to acquire Arizona-based LifeLock Inc.LOCKfor $2.3 billion. The company anticipates completing the acquisition on Feb 9.In connection with this
column45: the company yesterday announced raising $1 billion in aggregate principal amount by issuing senior unsecured notes due 2025.In our opinion
column46: the acquisition will be a strategic fit for Symantec
column47: which is trying hard to expand its business in the high growth area of next-generation cybersecurity. The acquisition will help Symantec enhance its capabilities in identity protection
column48: which is currently a huge concern for almost every sector
column49: be it financials
column50: retail or technology.Symantec expects the LifeLock acquisition to contribute about $100 million in revenues and around $9 million of non-GAAP earnings before interest and taxes in the fourth quarter. However
column51: the benefits will not impact its net income as these will be offset by incremental interest expenses from the debt used to fund the transaction.Our TakeSymantec reported modest third-quarter results wherein its bottom line surpassed the Zacks Consensus Estimate but the top line missed the same. However
column52: the company exceeded its own guidance on all metrics.Symantec Corporation Price
column53: Consensus and EPS     SurpriseSymantec Corporation Price
column54: Consensus and EPS   Surprise|Symantec Corporation QuoteAccording to Symantec CFO
column55: Nick Noviello
column56: ""Our third quarter results exceeded our constant currency revenue
column57: operating margin
column58: and EPS guidance. In just two quarters since combining Symantec and Blue Coat we are tracking ahead of schedule on product integrations
column59: cost savings and synergies. We are pleased to be increasing our fiscal year 2017 financial outlook.""Investment in growth areas such as Enterprise Backup
column60: Storage Management and Security businesses are expected to boost Symantec's long-term prospects. Moreover
column61: restructuring initiatives and synergies from acquisitions are expected to support its bottom line.Nonetheless
column62: we are disappointed by the company's fourth quarter revenue guidance
column63: which fell short of our estimate. Furthermore
column64: the company's announcement of issuing another $1 billion of senior notes to fund the acquisition of LifeLock will increase its interest expenses
column65: thereby negatively impacting its bottom-line going forward.Moreover
column66: smaller companies like Kaspersky are consistently launching comparable products. These
column67: along with competition from the likes of MicrosoftMSFT
column68: remain headwinds. The uncertainty over PC sales adds to its woes.Currently
column69: Symantec carries a Zacks Rank #4 (Sell).A better-ranked stock in the computer software space is Check Point SoftwareCHKP

column1: The Clock Ticks Down to the Yahoo! Inc. (YHOO) Acquisition;2/2/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsI'm increasingly confident thatYahoo! Inc.'s(NASDAQ:YHOO) acquisition byVerizon Communications Inc.(NYSE:VZ) is going to close only a little behind schedule.makeArticleAd();Source:Christian Barmala Via FlickrYes
column3: the online superpower is facing an SEC investigation into why management waited years to let the world know their billion-user database had been hacked. But those managers and the compliance systems the regulators want to test are unlikely to stick around once VZ stock takes its prize.Troubles for YHOO Stock?The SEC investigation doesn't seem like it will become the kind of juicy probe into fraud that can bring a company to its knees. All the regulators really want to know is whether the timing of the hack announcement left outside investors at a disadvantage.Based on price action since we all found out that YHOO security was compromised several years ago
column4: I'd say the gun just isn't smoking. Management confessed that the database had been accessed back in September
column5: when the stock was trading at a comfortable $44.15. Today
column6: shares are priced around $45
column7: so any investor harm here is minimal at best.The Top 10 Dow Dividend Stocks for FebruaryWhat we're left with is a deal timeline that is pushed back only a few months. Given the complexity of YHOO stock's media architecture
column8: a merger like this takes time to do right
column9: so I'm actually pleased to see a few delays.And they're almost certain to be just delays and not any kind of hard stop. This deal made sense before the investigation
column10: and it still makes sense now.YHOO's business may have flattened out
column11: but Verizon isn't interested in building a business organically from the ground up. They're already running a $200 billion juggernaut that has stopped growing on its own. Bolting YHOO onto that chassis could help earn VZ stock 4%-5% of top-line growth in the first year after the deal closes. That's enough to keep shareholders happy in the near term.From there
column12: it's a matter of strategic execution.VZ stock has ambitious media plans
column13: and I think the ongoing presence of theHuffington Postproves that the company is dedicated to building an empire of online content. Granted
column14: YHOO itself hasn't been growing that fast lately - revenue stalled last quarter - but that's what happens when managers brace for a transition - plans get mothballed
column15: ideas get filed away
column16: and the innovation cycle pauses.Microsoft Corporation (MSFT) Stock: Buy This Old Dog for Its New TricksWhether it gets back to work down the road is up to the new managers. In the meantime
column17: it's likely that the processes which facilitated the security breach at Yahoo will go away as the acquisition unfolds.Verizon has its own account security
column18: and moments like this are a traditional opportunity to let IT managers on both sides take the best overall solution for the larger enterprise and let the weaker systems go.Hilary Kramer is the editor ofGameChangers

column1: 3 Tech Stocks Paying Better Dividends Than Apple;2/2/2017;"Technology stocks
column2: once the domain of high-flying growth investors
column3: are becoming an increasingly generous source of dividends for income investors. The information technology sector led the market by total dividends paid both for the third quarter of 2016 and for the 12 months that ended September 30
column4: according to a FactSet analysis of the 419 dividend payers in Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. Apple (symbolAAPL) was tops in the IT sector
column5: paying $12.2 billion in dividends over the 12-month stretch.But just because Apple handed out the most money to its shareholders doesn't mean it's the best source of income in the sector. In fact
column6: Apple's stock currently yields just 1.8%
column7: even less than the S&P 500's 2.1%. So we set out to find mature tech stocks with solid business outlooks that offer superior yields to Apple. Our search turned up three blue-chip names. How blue? Like Apple
column8: all three of our picks are components of the Dow Jones Industrial Average. Take a look.makeArticleAd();Cisco SystemsCisco Systems
column9: which makes the routers
column10: switches and modems that form the backbone of the internet
column11: is poised for better-than-expected sales growth
column12: analysts say. A recent survey of its customers by UBS Securities revealed that spending on Cisco products remains a top budgetary priority. The tech company gets good marks for being easy to work with
column13: and two-thirds of respondents said it has the best overall security offering. The growth of cloud-based computing (storing data and applications on remote servers) and the Internet of Things (the expanding digital interconnectivity of everyday items
column14: from cars to refrigerators) are long-term tailwinds for the company and the stock. UBS has a ""buy"" rating on Cisco shares.Analysts
column15: on average
column16: expect Cisco's earnings to rise by just a penny this fiscal year ending July 30
column18: according to a survey by Thomson Reuters. Sales are forecast to slip 1.9% in fiscal 2017. The more bullish case for Cisco stems from projections for the following fiscal year (ending in July 2018)
column19: when profits are projected to climb 5% to $2.49 a share
column20: and revenue is expected to gain 2.4%.Cisco's dividend
column21: which dates back to 2011
column22: has increased annually. The company disbursed $5 billion in common dividends for the 12 months ended Oct. 31. That was supported by $12 billion in free cash flow
column23: or cash left over after spending the money required to operate and expand the business.SEE ALSO:10 Stocks Every Retiree Should OwnIntelConsumers are increasingly forgoing desktop computers for mobile devices. As a result
column24: PC sales have become a slowly melting iceberg. Market research firm Gartner found that PC sales fell for eight consecutive quarters as of the third quarter of 2016. That has forced Intel
column25: the world's largest maker of the central processing units that serve as a PC's brain
column26: to find new ways to generate revenue growth.The expansion of cloud-based services has been a boon to Intel
column27: thanks to its market-share dominance in server chips. True
column28: Intel faces changes in customer demands and competition from rival Advanced Micro Devices (AMD)
column29: but analysts at Stifel say it's responding well. ""Intel has been acquiring technologies and recruiting outside managerial talent to prepare for the changing market
column30: Stifel analyst Kevin Cassidy
column31: who rates Intel shares a ""buy
column32: said in a recent note to clients.Analysts expect 2017 earnings to rise to $2.79 from $2.72 a share in 2016
column33: according to Thomson Reuters. Revenue is forecast to increase 1% to $60.1 billion. Intel paid its first cash dividend in 1992
column34: and the company resumed annual dividend hikes two years ago. Intel's payout ratio
column35: or dividends as a percentage of earnings
column36: is a conservative 37% and below even the S&P 500's average ratio of 40%.SEE ALSO:3 Reasons to Own Apple Stock in RetirementMicrosoftMicrosoft is another tech company that's benefiting from the rise in cloud computing. An increasing number of customers now pay a recurring subscription fee to use its software rather than purchasing it outright. It's proving to be a hot area of growth. ""The closely watched commercial cloud business -- which includes Office 365
column37: Azure and Dynamics 365 -- continued to grow at a torrid rate
column38: reaching over $14.0 billion in annualized revenue in the second quarter [which ended December 31
column40: William Blair & Co. analyst Jason Ader said in a recent note to clients.Importantly
column41: the analyst expects Microsoft to become more profitable over time because of its ""disproportionate growth in its commercial cloud business
column42: which is being boosted by rapid customer adoption of Office 365 and Azure."" Azure is Microsoft's cloud-computing platform
column43: and Office 365 is the subscription version of its popular Office applications. Cloud-based services can have higher profit margins than traditional licensed software.Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters project earnings to rise to $2.97 a share for the current fiscal year ending June 30
column44: from $2.79 in fiscal 2016. Revenue for fiscal 2017 is expected to increase 4.9% year over year
column45: to $96.5 billion. For its second quarter
column46: which ended December 31
column47: Microsoft generated $1.3 billion in free cash flow after disbursing $3 billion worth of dividends. The company has paid a dividend to its shareholders since 2003. By contrast
column48: Apple resumed paying a regular quarterly dividend only in 2012
column49: following a 17-year layoff.SEE ALSO:10 Best Dividend-Paying Stocks for 2017"

column1: Will Microsoft's $1 Billion Cybersecurity Play Hurt Smaller Players?;2/1/2017;"Microsoft(NASDAQ: MSFT) recently announced that  it will invest over   $1 billion per year on cybersecurity research and development.   That amount
column2: which is equivalent to roughly 8% of its R&D   spend over the past 12 months
column3: doesn't include any acquisitions   that Microsoft might make. Let's see why Microsoft is beefing up   its cybersecurity efforts
column4: and what that could mean for smaller   players across the fragmented industry.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();What cybersecurity means to MicrosoftMicrosoft's Windows is the most widely used PC operating   system in the world
column5: Office is the  most popular   productivity suite
column6: and Azure is the second largest cloud   platform in the world afterAmazon's(NASDAQ: AMZN) AWS. Much of this massive ecosystem has   traditionally been protected by third party companies.   Microsoft's own products -- like Windows Firewall
column7: Windows   Defender
column8: and Microsoft Security Essentials -- were  often   considered inferior to third-party ones.However
column9: Microsoft's ecosystem has become more cohesive under   CEO Satya Nadella's ""One Windows"" strategy
column10: which aims to install   the same OS and app store across multiple platforms. Since users   would ideally download apps from the Windows Store and deliver   their data to Cortana and Bing via Azure
column11: it would be logical to   add first-party
column12: self-updating security solutions across the   entire ecosystem. Microsoft claims that the number of weekly   cyber attacks has risen from 20
column13: 000 to as many as 700
column14: 000 over   the past two to three years.To counter those threats while expanding its ecosystem
column15: Microsoft acquired three Israeli cybersecurity firms over the   past two years -- enterprise security start-up Aorato
column16: cloud   security firm Adallom
column17: and data protection firmSecure Islands. Those acquisitions and its planned R&D investments could   help Azure challenge AWS
column18: which already integrates an    arsenal of security features into its cloud infrastructure   platform. Azure's revenue surged 93% annually last quarter
column19: but   Microsoft hasn't revealed its exact sales figures yet.How this could hurt smaller playersAs Microsoft's cybersecurity ecosystem grows
column20: it could overlap   with the services of many smaller stand-alone third-party   players. For example
column21: Microsoft recently  launched Windows   Defender ATP (Advanced Threat Protection) for Windows 10. That   endpoint service matches events with Microsoft's cloud-based   Security Graph
column22: which gathers data across over a billion Windows   devices worldwide. It also works with Microsoft's email   protection services from Office 365 and Microsoft Advanced Threat   Analytics.This platform directly competes against ""perimeter"" players   like threat prevention firmFireEye(NASDAQ: FEYE) and next-gen firewall vendorPalo Alto Networks(NYSE: PANW) . During last year's RSA Conference
column23: Microsoft   principal research lead Tanmay Ganacharya toldDark Readingthat Windows Defender ATP can ""help capture network traffic out   of a given endpoint""
column24: so that it could ""detect the same attacks""   as FireEye and other threat detection services.Consider what $1 billion means to these smaller cybersecurity   companies. Palo Alto and FireEye are expected to respectively   generate $1.8 billion and $720 million in revenues this year --   so there's no way that they could match Microsoft's R&D   investments. Windows
column25: Office 365
column26: Azure
column27: Dynamics
column28: and other   platforms all give Microsoft the ability to bundle and scale up   its cybersecurity services very quickly. It can also offer lower   prices and offset those losses across other parts of its   ecosystem.But ""best in breed"" cybersecurity firms could still     surviveMicrosoft's growing interest in the cybersecurity market could   render some smaller players obsolete
column29: but ""best in breed"" players   like FireEye and Palo Alto have survived similar assaults from   bundled players before.Cisco(NASDAQ: CSCO)
column30: for example
column31: has aggressively bundled threat   prevention and next-gen firewalls into its networking hardware   and software. Yet FireEye still serves 5
column32: 000 customers across 67   countries
column33: which includes nearly half of the Forbes Global 2000.   Palo Alto serves over 35
column34: 500 customers in more than  140   countries
column35: including 80 of the Fortune 100 and half of the Global   2000.Those numbers indicate that companies will likely value a   company's track record and reputation over the convenience of   cheaper bundles. They also indicate that it could be smarter for   Microsoft to either acquire or partner with smaller stand-alone   players instead of trying to render them obsolete.The key takeawayBeefing up its cybersecurity business will help Microsoft   counter Amazon and tighten up its ""One Windows"" ecosystem. While   some of the new features seem destined to crush third-party   security players
column36: investors should remember that companies will   likely stick with ""best in breed"" players instead of the cheapest   bundle
column37: and a mass switch to a new security platform can be   costly and time consuming.Therefore
column38: investors in cybersecurity companies should be   mindful of Microsoft's ambitions
column39: but they should remember that   many ""best in breed"" companies have weathered similar attacks   from companies like Cisco before.10 stocks we like better than MicrosoftWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column40: it can pay to listen. After all
column41: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column42: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column43: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Microsoft wasn't one of     them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4
column44: 2017Teresa Kersten is an employee of LinkedIn and is a member     of The Motley Fool's Board of Directors. LinkedIn is owned by     Microsoft.Leo Sunowns shares of Amazon.com and Cisco Systems. The Motley Fool     owns shares of and recommends Amazon.com and FireEye. The     Motley Fool recommends Cisco Systems and Palo Alto Networks.     The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: Microsoft Corporation (MSFT) Stock: Buy This Old Dog for Its New Tricks;2/1/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsCompanies likeMicrosoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT) are rare for a reason. You can call it the Polaroid effect: Scientist and inventor Edwin H. Land's idea for a light polarizing lens sparked multiple innovations
column3: includinginstant photography.makeArticleAd();Source:Johannes Marliem Via FlickrTogether with businessman George Wheelwright
column4: Land formed Polaroid in 1937. Land and Wheelwright completely dominated the instant photography sector
column5: until that sector was no longer relevant. Once considered an economic bellwether
column6: Polaroiddeclared bankruptcyin 2001.True
column7: the company is back on the wheel again
column8: but not before taking down its original investors. Worst of all
column9: they're an afterthought. Polaroid is seemingly stuck in a reality that hasseen its zenith30 years ago. It's a fate that anyone vested in MSFT stock will obviously want to avoid. Still
column10: it is a legitimate fear
column11: especially among technology companies. In this day and age
column12: if you're not ahead
column13: you're almost intractably behind.MSFT Stock Is Getting the Job DoneBased on its most recent second-quarterearnings report
column14: Microsoft stock is in good hands. On a year-over-year basis
column15: earnings grew 3.6%
column16: matching consensus estimates for 79 cents per share. Top-line sales increased by a 2.2% margin over the year-ago level
column17: which slightly exceeded forecasts. While InvestorPlace writer Tom Taulli is correct in pointing out that these aren't earth-shattering figures for MSFT stock
column18: they're more than good enough.I've made the argument before that Microsoft stock issteady
column19: not sexy- and that's not a bad thing. Sure
column20: everybody lovesFerrari N.V.(NYSE:RACE) and its incredible machines. Rarely do people rave when they have to spend an inordinate amount of time in the shop. I'm not suggesting that MSFT stock is the market equivalent of a minivan; what I am saying is that it's not going to pull too many unwanted surprises.Take a look at the broader picture of its earnings performances. In the past fourteen quarters inclusive of the latest Q2
column21: MSFT shares have only failed to meet earnings consensus twice. Of those misses
column22: the negative surprise averaged 6% below forecast. While that's a notable ding
column23: the total average earnings surprise for Microsoft stock in the aforementioned time frame is well over 8%.No matter how you look at it
column24: that's a respectable trend. It's especially true given that MSFT is an old dog with fierce rivals chomping at the bit.Microsoft Is Still in the Innovation GameCEO Satya Nadella has made it no secret that he wants MSFT stock to be more than just a play on software and computers. To that end
column25: the company has been investing heavily in cloud applications. It's a market that is projected to jump from last year's$204 billionto$318 billionin two years' time.Unfortunately
column26: it's a market that has stiff opposition for Microsoft stock. Public enemy number one isAmazon.com
column27: Inc. (NASDAQ:AMZN)
column28: which commands air superiority in the cloud.SAP SE (ADR)(NYSE:SAP)
column29: International Business Machines Corp.(NYSE:IBM) andOracle Corporation(NYSE:ORCL) are big league players that are eager to make their presence known. Certainly
column30: they're not going to make the ride easy for those vested in MSFT shares.This
column31: however
column32: is one of those areas where being an old dog has its advantages. Primarily
column33: MSFT stock carries the leverage of a ubiquitous
column34: utilitarian brand. While SAP and Oracle have powerful cloud applications
column35: chances are
column36: unless you're a business analyst for a Fortune 500 company
column37: you're not going to be too familiar with their platforms. Even Amazon has a little bit of a vulnerability in this area
column38: considering that it's mostly used as an e-commerce function.For Microsoft stock
column39: it's all about selling the trust factor. Everybody - from the high school student writing a research paper to experts from all industries -knows MSFT's platform. Many of us have literally grown up with the company. Already
column40: there's an entire generation of workers that have known nothing but Microsoft Windows' graphical user interface.MSFT Is Backed by Smart MovesThis familiarity definitely carries substance to it. Back in January of 2014 - after the ""One Microsoft"" brand message was launched - the tech giant became themost trustedcompany according to a brand survey conducted by Forrester Research. Beating outApple Inc. (NASDAQ:AAPL)
column41: this ledForresteranalyst Tracy Stokes to conclude that Microsoft ""has a utilitarian essentiality
column42: not the kind of emotional essentiality that Apple relies on.""Although the remarks were made three years ago
column43: they're still spot on today. For example
column44: Microsoft's acquisition of LinkedIn gives it an incredible professional network: LinkedIn has467 million usersand 128 million in the U.S. - roughly 40% of our total national population. Better yet for MSFT stock
column45: that 40% represents the company's target audience - tech savvy
column46: money-making individuals.Here's Why General Electric Company (GE) Stock Will Definitely Gain 20%-PlusTo be sure
column47: Microsoft has a lot of challenges. Obviously
column48: the personal computer segment isn't doing anyone any favors. At the same time
column49: investors in MSFT shares don't have to worry about thePolaroideffect. Management is making smart moves that are paying dividends - literally and figuratively.As of this writing
column50: Josh Enomoto did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceThe 5 Best Stocks to Buy for Big Emerging Markets Profits3 Stocks to Buy for Better Deals Than the Great RecessionThe postMicrosoft Corporation (MSFT) Stock: Buy This Old Dog for Its New Tricksappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: What Apple's (AAPL) Earnings Say About The Future;2/1/2017;"When you regularly give your opinion on something as unpredictable as financial markets
column2: gloating when you get something right is rarely a good idea. That is especially true when those opinions arearchivedfor all to see; it's too easy for a reader to check out that archive and find examples of when the market and hindsight combine to make even logical arguments seem foolish. I am fully aware of that
column3: but when it comes to yesterday’searnings release from Apple(AAPL)
column4: I will still say""told you!""What really matters about the Apple release to investors is certainly not that I got it right
column5: nor is it even that the tech giant returned to growth in revenue for the first time in a year
column6: nor that the already great margins at Apple increased. Those last two are important
column7: but necessarily backward looking
column8: as all hard data in an earnings release are by definition.What matters most is what the report tells us about the future and there the message was somewhat mixed.makeArticleAd();The official guidance for Q1 2017 contained in the release fell just short of Wall Street’s expectations
column9: which would normally be enough of a negative to more than offset the good historical results. In this case
column10: though
column11: a look at where Apple succeeded in Q4 2016 suggests that that guidance may just be another example of Apple’s past tendency to err on the side of under-promising and over-delivering when it comes to guidance. That is why
column12: even though growth stalled last year
column13: AAPL has beaten EPS expectations in three of the last four quarters.First and foremost
column14: iPhone sales hit another record. That is particularly significant as not that long ago many were predicting that Google parent Alphabet (GOOG:GOOGL)’s move into the phone business would do Apple some serious harm. It looks now as if those saying that were about as accurate as those that maintained that the Windows phone from Microsoft (MSFT) or the Amazon (AMZN) Fire phone would be the next big thing.The fact is that the iPhone has an iconic status that looks almost impossible to challenge. Even phones that are objectively better in some ways
column15: such as memory capacity
column16: camera resolution
column17: or speaker quality for example
column18: cannot take market share. As Apple advances the iPhone with each release
column19: beating them on those and other fronts becomes harder
column20: but remains
column21: according to the evidence so far
column22: a pointless exercise. As long as that dynamic remains
column23: holding Apple stock and adding to holdings at times of weakness still makes sense for investors.The weakness in this release was mainly in one area; iPad sales declined for the twelfth successive quarter. That
column24: however
column25: was offset to some extent by strong sales of Macs and Apple Watches. For the latter we are reliant on the word of Tim Cook as Apple doesn’t release a breakdown of watch sales
column26: but
column27: as I pointed out in the article referenced above
column28: anybody who tried to buy a Series Two watch as a Christmas gift is probably aware that sales were at least more than Apple expected. None were available in any of the five states where I tried and most stores have just now received inventory.That shortage of watches
column29: combined with Cook’s admission that they seriously underestimated demand for the iPhone 7 Plus
column30: means that the record sales reported yesterday were achieved with a background of supply constraints. Given that and the fact that there was considerable growth in areas such as services and enterprise operations that still have lots of room for Apple to expand
column31: the message underlying yesterday’s earnings is that
column32: despite conventional wisdom
column33: growth can still be achieved."

column2: View Disappoints;2/1/2017;"Advanced Micro DevicesAMDreported loss of 4 cents per share in fourth-quarter 2016
column3: which matched the Zacks Consensus Estimate.Revenues increased 15.4% year over year to $1.11 billion primarily driven by higher GPU sales. However

column6: revenues were well above the Zacks Consensus Estimate of $1.07 billion.AMD's shares rose 1.2% in after-hour trading. We note that shares have outperformed the ZacksElectronics Semiconductorsindustry over the last one year. While the industry gave a positive return of 67.2%
column7: AMD gained a whopping 384.6%.The company benefited from strong demand for its graphics products. However
column8: AMD's first-quarter 2017 will be impacted by seasonal weakness.RevenuesAdvanced Micro has two reportable segments -Computing and Graphics(focused on the traditional PC market) andEnterprise
column9: Embedded and Semi-Custom(focusing on adjacent high-growth opportunities). The details of these segments are discussed below:Computing and Graphics includes desktop and notebook processors and chipsets
column10: discrete GPUs and professional graphics. This segment accounted for 54.2% of revenues and was up 27.1% sequentially and 27.7% year over year to $600 million.Notably
column11: this segment's revenues grew on an annualized basis for the first time since 2011 as AMD's increased efforts to strengthen this particular segment paid off.Also
column12: the segment posted the highest revenue in the last two years. Client revenues were the highest in the last seven quarters. Graphics processor revenues were also the highest in the last 11 quarters.During the reported quarter
column13: strong adoption of the company's seventh generation notebook accelerated processing units (APUs) drove growth for the company. While desktop processor sales improved on a sequential basis
column14: it declined on a year-over-year basis.The company also won a number of high-end design deals with global original equipment manufacturers over its Ryzen desktop processor that is expected to be launched in early Mar 2017.AMD's Polaris line of GPUs witnessed increased adoption in the fourth quarter. column1: Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Has a New Hero: Services!;2/1/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) reported its fiscal first-quarter earnings on Tuesday after the bell
column3: and it kicked the year off the right way. Apple set an all-time quarterly revenue record - snapping its streak of declines - and broke its previous iPhone sales record. AAPL stock is up strongly Wednesday morning as a result.makeAd('4'
column5: 'mktsnews'
column6: 'vanguard'
column8: '');Source: AppleBut the star of yesterday's show wasn't the iPhone. It was the Services division
column9: which includes the App Store
column10: Apple Pay
column11: iTunes
column12: AppleCare and Apple Music. Services didn't just set another record - it also posted the strongest year-over-year growth of any AAPL division.Services Is on Fire
column13: Led by the App StoreApple reported that the quarterly revenue for its Services division topped $7.17 billion for Q1
column14: an increase of 18% compared to the previous year. If that sounds like a lot of money for what is largely made up of mobile payment transaction fees and digital content
column15: it is. In comparison
column16: Netflix
column17: Inc.(NASDAQ:NFLX) experienced its largest-ever subscriber growth in the final quarter of 2016
column18: leading it to post revenue of $2.48 billion.During the AAPL earnings conference call
column19: CEO Tim Cook noted that he expects the Services division to bethe size of a Fortune 100 company by the end of the year. Other key information about the Services division from that earnings call includes:App Store revenue for December alone was a record-setting $3 billionThere are now 2.2 million apps in the App Store
column20: and AAPL paid out over $20 billion to developers in 2016The number of Apple Pay users has tripled over the past year
column21: with transaction volume up over 500% year-over-yearAppleCare and storage services (iCloud) both set all-time recordsApple's music business grew for the third straight quarterWhy Services Revenue is ImportantYou might not know it based on Apple's record-setting iPhone sales this quarter
column22: but selling hardware is tough.The Top 10 Dow Dividend Stocks for FebruaryOnce a consumer has an iPhone in his or her hands
column23: it becomes very difficult to convince them to spend a minimum $649 to ditch that smartphone for a new one. In one sense
column24: a huge installed user base - which AAPL has
column25: withmore than 1 billion iOS devices in active use- works against the company. When the iPhone first began to take off
column26: AAPL was selling to people who'd never owned one before. Now
column27: that pool of easy sales is dwindling. And Apple is left in the tougher position of convincing its installed user base to upgrade.Thus the hand-wringing about slowing iPhone sales.Apple's Services division largely benefits from that huge installed user base
column28: though. True
column29: AAPL only gets one shot at selling these customers AppleCare. But once they own an iPhone
column30: iPad
column31: iPod
column32: Mac
column33: Apple Watch or AppleTV
column34: they begin to explore Apple's other services. They are increasingly adopting Apple Pay. They are in a prime position to buy movies on their Apple TV. They are perfect candidates to subscribe to Apple Music. There are plenty of hooks for storing data on iCloud. And of course
column35: there is the App Store and the lure of its millions of apps.Apple's Services revenue doesn't come in big chunks like selling an iPhone. It's $9.99 a month here
column36: 99 cents for an app there
column37: a few cents for a transaction. But it adds up
column38: especially when over a billion customers are generating it.More importantly
column39: that revenue doesn't drop off the same way hardware revenue does when people stop buying new iPhones.Some services - like iCloud and Apple Music - are subscription-based. AAPL keeps automatically billing the customer's card every month regardless of whether their iPhone is brand new or five years old. Apple Pay revenues are increasing as more countries and businesses accept it and iPhone owners grow more accustomed to using it.Bottom Line for AAPLPeople never stop buying apps. They may slow down after the initial rush of a new device
column40: but developers keep bring enticing new games and other apps to the App Store. That means the 1 billion users continue to download.Trade of the Day: Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock No Longer a Home RunJust look at the 40 million-plusSuper Mario Rundownloads from the App Storein only four days.How many iPhones will AAPL sell two years from now? No one knows for sure
column41: but odds are it won't be many more than it does now. On the other hand
column42: Apple is confident its highflying App Store
column43: Apple Pay and other services will see Services division revenue double in that time.The iPhone may have driven Apple stock growth over the past decade. But Services revenue is increasingly important as AAPL stock searches for that elusive next hardware hit.As of this writing
column44: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace10 Stocks to Buy That Already Make America GreatCan Facebook Inc (FB) Stock Jump Over These Hurdles?The Only 3 Vanguard Funds You Need to Build a PortfolioThe postApple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Has a New Hero: Services!appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Can Facebook Inc (FB) Stock Jump Over These Hurdles?;2/1/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsAhead of earnings forFacebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB)
column3: which will come out at the end of trading on Wednesday
column4: investors are certainly upbeat. And why not? FB stock has been a pretty good bet.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockBut could things be different this time around? Maybe the enthusiasm for Facebook stock is too carried away?Well
column5: it is important to note that the valuation is still reasonable. The forward price-to-earnings ratio on FB stock is at about 25X. This compares to roughly 20X for bothAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOG
column6: NASDAQ:GOOGL) andMicrosoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT). And these companies are not growing at anywhere near the pace of Facebook.What's more
column7: it seems like Facebook earnings should do fine in Q4. Revenues are expected to jump by 46% to $8.5 billion and adjusted EPS are forecasted to come to $1.31
column8: up from 79 cents during the same period a year ago. Keep in mind that - for the past five quarters - the company has beat the Street on both the top and bottom lines.FB Stock Still Faces Several RisksBut the real potential issue for Facebook stock is any disappointing commentary on the future growth trends. Interestingly enough
column9: on the Q3 earnings call
column10: the company's CFO had this ominous thing tosay: ""We continue to expect that revenue growth rates will decline in Q4 as we lap a strong fourth quarter in 2015. We also continue to expect that our total payments and other fees revenue in Q4 will be lower than it was in the fourth quarter of last year.""10 Stocks to Buy That Already Make America GreatNo doubt
column11: this should not be a surprise. As FB gets much larger
column12: it will increasingly get more difficult to churn out strong revenue numbers. It's the curse of the so-called ""law of large numbers.""Let's face it
column13: Facebook already has a massive user base. In the most recent quarter
column14: the number of monthly active users hit 1.79 billion
column15: up 16% on a year-over-year basis. There were also a stunning 1.2 billion daily users.But going forward
column16: what will the sources of new users be? It's hard to tell. But initiatives from FB show concerns. After all
column17: the company has been working hard to provide internet access to developing nations.And don't forget about China. According to a report from theWall Street Journal
column18: it appears that Facebook has made little progress. Instead
column19: rivals likeWeibo Corp(ADR)(NASDAQ:WB) andTencent(OTCMKTS:TCEHY) have been capitalizing on the opportunity.At the same time
column20: other problems could affect FB stock. For example
column21: during the last few months
column22: there have been various embarrassing stories about how the company has inflated certain metrics. Might this cause some pushback from advertisers?The Snapchat IPO: The Next Facebook Inc (FB) ... Or Twitter Inc (TWTR)?Then there is the ""fake news"" controversy. Granted
column23: the company has taken actions to improve the publishing of news
column24: such as with a focus on credible sources. But this could result in lower clicks and views
column25: which would slow down the revenue momentum for Facebook stock.Something else that could dampen some of the enthusiasm for FB stock: the upcoming Snapchat IPO
column26: which should hit the markets within the next couple of months. Of course
column27: there will be tremendous buzz and excitement. There will also be the inevitable comparisons to FB. In other words
column28: investors may look at Snapchat as an alternative to Facebook stock when seeking the next growth play.Overall
column29: Wednesday's earnings announcement will definitely be important. And if there are signs of deceleration on the top-line
column30: FB stock could be vulnerable
column31: especially since it has already pulled off a nice run for the year.Tom Taulli runs the InvestorPlace blogIPO Playbookand is a registered investment adviser representative (you canvisit his siteto learn more about his financial planning services).He is also the author of various books on investing like All About Commodities
column32: All About Short Selling and High-Profit IPO Strategies.Follow him on Twitter at@ttaulli. As of this writing
column33: he did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace10 High-Yield Dividend Stocks That Are SOMEHOW Still Bargains7 High-Yield Stocks Ripe For A Short SqueezeThe postCan Facebook Inc (FB) Stock Jump Over These Hurdles?appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: 3 Trends Shaping the Internet of Things in 2017;2/1/2017;"Image source: Getty Images.As the number of connected devices and sensors continues to   grow at a rapid rate

column3: and analysis of this data is creating efficiency   improvements in everything from traffic flow and healthcare to   security and manufacturing. This growing network of devices and   sensors is known as the Internet of Things (IoT)
column4: and many tech   watchers are heralding the connectivity and data boom as the   impetus for the next industrial revolution
column5: as well as sweeping   improvements to public and private life.makeArticleAd();ssIoT is already having an impact
column6: but it's also still in the   early phases of its evolution
column7: and 2017 is on track to be a   formative year for its progression. Click through the   presentation below to learn about three trends that are shaping   the future of the Internet of Things and what they could mean for   companies includingCisco Systems(NASDAQ: CSCO)
