column1: Is Microsoft Corporation (MSFT) Resurrecting the Cursed Windows RT?;1/31/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsDon't look now
column3: butMicrosoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT) looks to be taking another run atAlphabet Inc's(NASDAQ:GOOGL
column4: NASDAQ:GOOG) Chrome operating system. References have begun popping up in builds of the Windows 10 Creators Update (which is due to arrive in April) to Windows 10 Cloud.makeArticleAd();Source: MicrosoftSpeculation is growing that Windows 10 Cloud is in fact a new simplified version of Microsoft's operating system
column5: designed to run on devices powered by inexpensive ARM chips fromARM Holdings plc (ADR)(NASDAQ:ARMH).In other words
column6: it appears that Microsoft is preparing to take on the threat of Chromebooks - the cheap
column7: popular laptops running Google's Chrome OS. And it seems to be doing so by resurrecting the idea of Windows RT.Windows 10 CloudWindows 10 Creators Build is the next major revision of the Microsoft Windows PC operating system. It's due to begin rolling out to users around April 17.The 5 Best Stocks to Buy for Big Emerging Markets ProfitsBut developers have been testing pre-release builds of Microsoft's software and recently some of them began to notice something strange: The code references different variations of the operating system. For example
column8: Windows 10 Pro for Workstation and Windows 10 for Enterprise are spiked out. Nothing unusual there. But then
column9: references to Windows 10 Cloud began to appear. And that started raising eyebrows - what is Windows 10 Cloud?ZDNet'sMary Jo Foley put the pieces together yesterday. Quoting unnamed sources
column10: she says that the mysterious Windows 10 Cloud is a new
column11: simplified version of Microsoft Windows that will run only Unified Windows Platform (UWP) apps. In other words
column12: it's a""simpler
column13: safer
column14: cheaper"" version of Windows 10.You might also think of it as another crack at Windows RT …Windows RT? But Why?Everyone remembers the mess that wasWindows RT. The attempt to shoehorn a version of Windows onto a consumer tablet running ARM chips -the ill-fated Surface RT - very nearly dealt MSFT's tablet aspirations a fatal blow.However
column15: despite the failure of Windows RT
column16: Microsoft has never given up on the idea of Windows on ARM chips. By doing so
column17: it can get Windows onto mobile devices that can't use the more powerful and expensive chips fromIntel Corporation(NASDAQ:INTC). The company has already been showing offWindows 10 running in emulation on high-end ARM chips. As part of that effort
column18: it could also be working on a ""lite"" version that can deliver much of the Windows 10 experience on less expensive
column19: lower powered ARM hardware.So why
column20: why
column21: whywould Microsoft risk falling flat on its face again with what essentially amounts to another crack at Windows RT? There are two reasons.The first is that dream of ""Windows everywhere."" Having the full Windows 10 experience on high-powered ARM chips is great
column22: but only flagship smartphones and tablets can afford to use those chips. Windows 10 Cloud would get Microsoft Windows (and Bing) onto a whole lot more mobile hardware.The second is Google's Chrome OS and Chromebooks. These cheap laptops have been under Microsoft's skin for years. They've become extremely popular in the education sector thanks to low cost
column23: ease of use and built-in security. And Chromebooks have just kept selling
column24: to the point where last year they passed evenApple Inc.'s(NASDAQ:AAPL)MacBooks in sales.Microsoft has tried fighting back by helping manufacturers put out cheap Windows 10 laptops
column25: but that hasn't stemmed the Chromebook flood. Windows 10 makes for a sluggish experience on inexpensive Intel hardware
column26: it's far more complex than Chrome OS to use and lacks the drop-dead easy security of Chromebooks.Cash Out of Facebook Inc (FB) Stock Before EarningsWindows 10 Cloud running on laptops with ARM processors would compete head-to-head with Chromebooks running Chrome OS: simpler
column27: safer and cheaper than Windows 10.Microsoft refused to comment on theZDNetpost
column28: but the pieces pointing to Windows 10 as a Chrome OS-fighting
column29: second crack at Windows RT make sense. Naturally
column30: MSFT is going to avoid all references to Windows RT - that's poison - and the Windows 10 Cloud name could end up being a code name.It could also be an attempt to steal some of the Chrome OS ""cloud"" thunder. Expect to get the final answer on Windows 10 Cloud from Microsoft prior to that April 17 Windows 10 Creators Build release.As of this writing
column31: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace3 ""Golden"" Ammo Stocks to Buy for Big 2017 Returns3 Stocks to Buy for Better Deals Than the Great RecessionThe postIs Microsoft Corporation (MSFT) Resurrecting the Cursed Windows RT?appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: 4 Reasons I'm Buying Baidu Inc. (ADR) Stock;1/31/2017;"Chinese search giantBaidu(NASDAQ: BIDU) is often dismissed as a slow-growth tech stock   that has run out of room to grow. Its heavy investments in   expanding its ecosystem into adjacent markets have weighed down   its bottom line growth
column2: making the stock seem like dead money.   Despite those challenges
column3: however
column4: I recently started a new   position in Baidu for four main reasons.Baidu Image Search. Image source: Author's screenshot.makeArticleAd();1. It's still the 800-pound gorillaBaidu controls roughly 80% of the internet search market in   China. That dominant position enables it to expand its ecosystem   in the same way asAlphabet's(NASDAQ: GOOG) (NASDAQ: GOOGL) Google. Its sprawling ecosystem   now includes Baidu Maps
column5: video streaming site iQiyi
column6: its Duer   voice assistant
column7: the Baidu Wallet payment platform
column8: numerous   portal sites
column9: and various O2O (online-to-offline) services in its   ""monolithic"" mobile app.While the profitability of these services varies greatly
column10: they   all help Baidu gather data from its users for targeted ads. Last   quarter
column11: Baidu's revenue per online marketing customer rose 10.6%   annually. This indicates that Baidu still remains a top   advertising pick in China
column12: even as other popular apps -- likeTencent's WeChat -- tether more users to their ecosystems. Moreover
column13: China still has an internet penetration rate of just 52%
column14: which   means that there may be plenty of room for all these companies to   expand without stepping on each other's toes.2. Its slowdown is temporaryBaidu fell out of favor with growth investors as its top and   bottom line growth seemingly dried up. Last quarter
column15: its revenue   fell  0.7% annually
column16: its core online marketing revenue slid   6.7%
column17: and its non-GAAP net income rose just 6.3%. Analysts expect   its  revenue to rise 6% this year
column18: but for its earnings to   decline 9%.However
column19: that slowdown was mainly caused by three temporary   headwinds. First
column20: Chinese regulators forced Baidu to remove   misleading pharmaceutical ads following the death of a student   who bought unapproved cancer drugs advertised on the site.   Second
column21: Baidu sold its stake in online travel agencyQunarto its rivalCtrip(NASDAQ: CTRP)
column22: essentially swapping its stake in Qunar for one   in Ctrip but temporarily throttling revenue growth.Lastly
column23: Baidu's heavy investments in R&D are squeezing its   margins
column24: but launching new services could boost its long-term   growth and widen its moat against rivals like Tencent. That's why   analysts believe that Baidu's revenue and earnings will   respectively rebound 21% and 33% in fiscal 2017.3. Growth potential in next-gen marketsLike Google
column25: Baidu is investing heavily in artificial   intelligence
column26: driverless cars
column27: and other ""next-gen"" technologies.   Machine learning and AI have become increasingly important to   search and advertising companies
column28: since they help gather more   data from users to create targeted ads that users are more likely   to click on. Baidu has been hiring a lot of top talent in that   field -- its chief scientist
column29: Andrew Ng
column30: previously led the   Google Brain AI project
column31: and its  new augmented reality   chief Qi Lu was aMicrosoftexec specializing in AI.To showcase its AI efforts
column32: Baidu pitted its AI robot against   Google's AlphaGo AI in a battle of facial and voice recognition   in early January. It partnered withNVIDIAand HERE Maps to develop mapping systems for autonomous vehicles
column33: and plans to launch a driverless shuttle bus in China in 2018. It   also partnered with  smart remote maker Peel to establish a   foothold in the growing smart home market. These projects   won't generate meaningful revenue for years
column34: but they could   greatly expand Baidu's O2O ecosystem over the long term.4. The stock is still cheapBaidu currently trades at just 13 times earnings
column35: which is   much lower than Google's P/E of 31 and the industry average of 50   for internet information providers. But due to its projected   decline in earnings this year
column36: the stock has a forward P/E of 30.   While that forward multiple doesn't seem cheap
column37: we should   remember that Baidu's earnings are expected to rebound in   2017.The key takeawayBaidu will likely remain weighed down by near-term challenges   over the next few quarters
column38: but it's still well-positioned to   profit from the long-term growth of the Chinese internet market.   Baidu may struggle to pull social users away from Tencent and   shoppers away fromAlibaba
column39: but its dominance of the search-based ad market won't end   anytime soon.10 stocks we like better than Alphabet (A     shares)When investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column40: it can pay to listen. After all
column41: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column42: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column43: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Alphabet (A shares)     wasn't one of them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks     are even better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4

LinkedIn is owned by Microsoft.Leo Sunowns shares of Baidu. The Motley Fool owns shares of and     recommends Alphabet (A shares)

column1: Alphabet Employees Protest Against Trump's Immigration Ban;1/31/2017;"Protests against Donald Trump's anti-immigration policy are gaining steam and the technology sector appears to be leading the way.  More than 2000Alphabet Inc.'sGOOGLGoogle employees staged protests against Trump's immigration ban by walking out of eight offices worldwide including the company's headquarters in Mountain View on Monday. Photos and videos of the walkouts have been tweeted using hashtag #GooglersUnite.Google co-founder Sergey Brin and CEO Sundar Pichai have extended their full support to the opposition.Concurrent with the protest
column2: Google created a $4 million fund to support immigrant rights groups like the Immigrant Legal Resource Center
column3: the American Civil Liberties Union
column4: the U.N. Refugee Agency and the International Rescue Committee.The protest was particularly against Trump's executive order to ban nationals of seven Muslim majority countries - Iraq
column5: Iran
column6: Somalia
column7: Libya
column8: Syria
column9: Sudan and Yemen - from coming to the U.S. Pichai denounced the order and stated that the ban affects about 187 Google employees.We note that not quite long ago
column10: Trump had called up technology leaders and urged them to create and retain jobs within the U.S. to which most of them had given their nods. However as the immigration ban order rolled out
column11: the sector is sending clear indications that it will not create jobs at the cost of preventing entry to external talent.Alphabet Inc. Free Cash Flow (TTM)Alphabet Inc. Free Cash Flow (TTM)|Alphabet Inc. QuoteProtests Across the Technology IndustryTrump's immigration restrictions have faced the flak of tech leaders in the form of tweets
column12: memos and statements. Chief executive officers of MicrosoftMSFT
column13: AppleAAPL
column14: NetflixNFLX
column15: Uber
column16: Airbnb and Tesla Motors have all indicated that they are against the decision.The technology sector recruits a big chunk outside talent and the survival of the sector could be at stake if immigration reduces or stops completely.The sector fears that Trump may overhaul the H1-B program that allows Silicon Valley to bring foreign engineers and technical experts to the U.S. for three to six years.Zacks Rank and Stock Price MovementAt present
column17: Alphabet is a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold) company. You can seethe complete list of today's Zacks #1 Rank (Strong Buy)   stocks here.Over the last one year

column1: The Zacks Analyst Blog Highlights: Microsoft
column2: Ford and United Technologies;1/31/2017;"For Immediate ReleaseChicago
column3: IL - January 31
column4: 2017 - Zacks.com announces the list of stocks featured in the Analyst Blog. Every day the Zacks Equity Research analysts discuss the latest news and events impacting stocks and the financial markets. Stocks recently featured in the blog includeMicrosoft(NASDAQ:MSFT-Free Report)
column5: Ford(NYSE:F-Free Report) andUnited Technologies(NYSE:UTX-Free Report).Today
column6: Zacks is promoting its ''Buy'' stock recommendations.Get #1Stock of the Day pick for free.Here are highlights from Monday's Analyst Blog:Q4 Earnings Scorecard and Analyst Reports for Ford
column7: Microsoft
column8: UTXThe Zacks Research Daily features the best output of our research team every day. In today's write-up
column9: we are featuring analyst reports on 16 major stocks
column10: including reports on Microsoft (NASDAQ:MSFT-Free Report)
column11: Ford (NYSE:F-Free Report) and United Technologies (NYSE:UTX-Free Report). These stock research reports have been hand-picked from the 70 or so reports published by our analyst team today. You can see all of today's research reportshere >>In addition to these stock research reports
column12: we are also giving you a real-time scorecard of the ongoing Q4 earnings season. We take pride in closely monitoring each and every earnings report and presenting our analysis of emerging trends in the weekly Earnings Trends and Earnings Preview reports. Our latest Earnings Preview report is:Earnings Growth Returns
column13: Will it Continue?Q4 Earnings Scorecard: We are one-third into the Q4 earnings season
column14: with results from 171 S&P 500 members
column15: or 34.1% of the index's total membership
column16: already out. More than 400 companies are on the docket to report quarterly results this week
column17: including 106 S&P 500 members. By the end of next week
column18: we will have seen Q4 results from 55% of S&P 500 members.Total earnings for the 171 index members that have reported results already are up +6% on +3.1% higher revenues
column19: with 64.3% beating EPS estimates and 54.4% beating revenue estimates. This is better earnings and revenue growth performance than we have seen from this group of 171 S&P 500 members in other recent periods
column20: even after adjusting for the strong growth from the Finance sector. The proportion of companies beating EPS and revenue estimates
column21: however
column22: is tracking moderately below other recent periods.Looking at Q4 as a whole
column23: combining the actual results from the 171 index members with estimates from the still-to-come 329 companies
column24: total earnings are expected to be up +5.3% from the same period last year on +4% higher revenues. This is the best earnings and revenue growth pace in the last 8 quarters. Importantly
column25: estimates for the current period (2017 Q1) are holding up fairly well; they are coming down
column26: but not at the pace as would typically expected. All of this should help add to confidence in market expectations for the current and following quarters when growth is expected to notably ramp up.Buy ratedMicrosoftshares lagged the Zacks Tech sector through the fall
column27: but have led the way over the last three months (up +9.8% versus +6%) on greater appreciation for the company's reorganization and repositioning which got reconfirmed by the company's impressive quarterly results last week. The Zacks analyst points to the company's continuing enterprise strength
column28: benefits from the Office 365 subscription model
column29: strong growth prospects of Azure and promising new products. The recent acquisition of artificial intelligence startup Maluuba is a big positive for the company given the growing demand for artificial intelligence techniques throughout the world. Further
column30: the anticipated completion of the LinkedIn acquisition will boost Microsoft's presence in the social media market. All in all
column31: the company has emerged as a leader in the cloud space that promises momentum on a number of fronts. (You canread the full research report on Microsoft here     >>)United Technologiesshares have gained +7.3% over the last three months
column32: higher than the +6.3% increase for the Zacks Conglomerates sector. The company's fourth-quarter 2016 results were mixed
column33: with revenues beating expectations and earnings coming in-line. But the Zacks analyst likes the business mix and diversification which allows the company to deliver consistent earnings and dividend growth. The company is focused on revamping its aerospace unit to overhaul the organizational structure and accelerate inorganic growth through potential acquisition opportunities. On the flip side
column34: the company remains exposed to a weak global macroeconomic backdrop and uncertainty about the Trump administration's trade policy. Other issues include exposure to market price volatility and availability risks related to raw materials. (You canread the full research report on United Technologies     here >>)Fordshares have underperformed the domestic auto manufacturing industry as well as GM over the last three months. Ford's adjusted earnings for the fourth quarter declined year-over-year and also came in under expectations. Losses in South America
column35: Brexit-related concerns
column36: frequent product recalls and rising structural expenses are some of the issues faced by the company. However
column37: the positives for Ford include product launches
column38: global expansion plans
column39: efficient capital deployment
column40: success of the One Ford plan
column41: focus on autonomous vehicle development and a solid long-term outlook. (You canread the full research report on Ford here     >>)Today's Long-Term Buys & SellsToday you can gain access to the best long-term trades unearthed by Zacks Research. These moves have double and triple-digit profit potential and are rarely available to the public. Starting now
column42: you can look inside our stocks under $10

column44: plus more. Want a peek at this private information?Click here >>Today

column1: Apple Inc. Gets Extra Help From the Dual Camera iPhone 7 Plus (AAPL);1/30/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsWhenApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) first introduced its new
column3: big and bigger smartphones - the iPhone 6 and iPhone 6 Plus - the company opted to offer a few minor features for buyers of the largest model. The 6 Plus had longer battery life
column4: and an image stabilized camera. That basic strategy continued with the 6s Plus in 2015. But last year with the iPhone 7 Plus
column5: AAPL included a more significant carrot in the signature Dual Camera feature.makeArticleAd();Source: AppleThe move of making a key feature exclusive to its larger phones appears to have paid off with a big increase in iPhone 7 Plus sales compared to regular iPhone 7 sales.Having more of the costlier iPhone 7 Plus models in the mix means AAPL can generate more revenue
column6: even if overall unit sales are soft.Differentiating Between Big and BiggerHistorically
column7: the larger-sized iPhone hasn't sold nearly as well as the ""standard"" 4.7-inch model.When AAPL first introduced the two model strategy in 2014
column8: the iPhone 6 Plus had an immediate bump in demand from Apple fans who were hungry for a phablet. It was also very popular in Asian markets
column9: where phablets
column10: which can take the place of both smartphone and tablet
column11: are often preferred. However
column12: overall the bigger and more expensive iPhone 6 Plus only accounted foraround 20% of overall iPhone salesglobally.10 Stocks to Buy That Already Make America GreatIn 2015
column13: AAPL added a little more appeal to the bigger iPhone
column14: adding increased RAM to the optically image stabilized camera for the iPhone 6 Plus. However
column15: that saw just a small uptick in sales of the bigger model.Last year
column16: Apple rolled the dice: It decided to release a dual camera smartphone
column17: a premium upgrade that it heavily promoted as a must-have feature. With this advanced camera system
column18: users could take DSLR-like portraits and optically zoom in on subjects. AAPL made this key feature an iPhone 7 Plus exclusive
column19: at the same time boosting the price of its larger iPhone. Previously
column20: it had charged $649 and $749 respectively for the two sizes. In 2016
column21: the company still started the iPhone 7 at $649
column22: but to get the dual camera smartphone feature required shelling out at least $769 for the iPhone 7 Plus.iPhone 7 Sales See Big Increase in iPhone 7 Plus AdoptionTheWall Street Journalis reporting that Apple's iPhone 7 Plus strategy appears to have paid off. Citing numbers from Cowen & Co. UBS
column23: Cowen and Creative Strategies Inc.
column24: theWSJsays that in AAPL's first quarter (ending in December)
column25: theiPhone 7 Plus is estimated to have accounted for 40% of total iPhone 7 sales
column26: globally.Breaking the numbers down regionally
column27: it's estimated that 52% of Chinese iPhone buyers opted for the more expensive iPhone 7 Plus
column28: while in the U.S. it accounted for 47% of total iPhone 7 sales.Why Increased iPhone 7 Plus to iPhone 7 Sales MatterThe difference between the two iPhone models is material to AAPL's bottom line.Apple Inc. New iPads Might Be Late to the Party (AAPL)It's likely that the iPhone 7 Plus costs Apple more to manufacture than previous Plus versions - it does have more RAM
column29: a larger battery and that dual camera system - but at least some of the additional cost is offset by the boost from $749 to $769.The profit margin for Apple on the iPhone 7 and 7 Plus probably remains roughly the same. However
column30: with a base price that's $120 higher
column31: having more Plus models in the mix means that even if overall iPhone 7 sales are soft
column32: the average selling price of a new iPhone goes up. As a result
column33: iPhone revenue could get a boost
column34: despite sales that may not meet expectations.And
column35: as theWSJarticle points out
column36: there's another positive point for AAPL in the iPhone 7 Plus numbers. The fact that pricing the iPhone 7 Plus so high still resulted in big gains for the premium smartphone bodes well for later this year when the company will release the10th anniversary iPhone 8. The iPhone 7 sales numbers indicate that AAPL has additional room to price the iPhone 8 as an ultra-premium
column37: special edition model if it chooses.As of this writing
column38: Brad Moon did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlace3 Things Apple Inc. (AAPL) MUST Do to Soar in 2017Microsoft Corporation (MSFT) Steps on Amazon and Google's TurfThe postApple Inc. Gets Extra Help From the Dual Camera iPhone 7 Plus (AAPL)appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column3: January 30 2017The Zacks Research Daily features the best output of our research team every day. In today's write-up

We take pride in closely monitoring each and every earnings report and presenting our analysis of emerging trends in the weekly Earnings Trends and Earnings Preview reports. column8: Will it Continue?Q4 Earnings Scorecard: We are one-third into the Q4 earnings season
column9: with results from 171 S&P 500 members
column10: or 34.1% of the index's total membership

column14: with 64.3% beating EPS estimates and 54.4% beating revenue estimates. This is better earnings and revenue growth performance than we have seen from this group of 171 S&P 500 members in other recent periods
column15: even after adjusting for the strong growth from the Finance sector. The proportion of companies beating EPS and revenue estimates
column16: however
column17: is tracking moderately below other recent periods.Looking at Q4 as a whole

column19: total earnings are expected to be up +5.3% from the same period last year on +4% higher revenues. This is the best earnings and revenue growth pace in the last 8 quarters. Importantly

But the Zacks analyst likes the business mix and diversification which allows the company to deliver consistent earnings and dividend growth. The company is focused on revamping its aerospace unit to overhaul the organizational structure and accelerate inorganic growth through potential acquisition opportunities. On the flip side

Other issues include exposure to market price volatility and availability risks related to raw materials. column33: global expansion plans

column1: Sign Up for Free Profits From Facebook Inc (FB) Stock;1/30/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsI recently wrote uptwo bullish trades to profit fromFacebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB). Luckily
column3: I caught an uptrend and the profits came quickly so I booked them. This week I want to reset to try and repeat performance - but this time I have an earnings report to worry about.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockTraders are fickle around earnings. The short-term reaction to an earnings report is more gambling than investing
column4: regardless of the quality of the report. Often enough great company stocks come under selling pressure even on solid reports.FB stock is a mega cap and usually they takes cues from other mega cap earnings reactions. We recently saw a split decision betweenMicrosoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT) andAlphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOG
column5: NASDAQ:GOOGL).Eventually these companies are winners; they are beasts with little chance of debacles. But for the short term
column6: investors have to contend with the knee-jerk reactions.Having said that
column7: there are ways I can trade earnings reports without much out-of-pocket risk. Last week I sold puts in MSFT to buy its calls. The trade was an easy win.10 Stocks to Buy That Already Make America GreatThis week
column8: I will set up a trade to benefit from a positive reaction to FB's earnings. Experts think that Wall Street will not be impressed by what FB stock management has to report and that the risk is to the downside. I want to bet on the opposite but without much immediate risk.FB Stock TradesClick to EnlargeThe Trade:Buy Facebook Mar $135 calls. This is a bullish trade for which I pay $3 per contract to open. To profit
column9: I need FB stock to rally past my strike before mid March. I could change this trade to a debit call spread to lower the entry cost. So I would instead buy the $135/$140 debit call spread and only spend $1.40 per contract. The trade-off is that with the spread
column10: I cap my maximum profit to $3.60 per contract.I usually like to lower my entry cost especially when volatility is high so I need to cautiously sell options.The Bank:Sell the Facebook Dec $100 put. This is a bullish trade for which I collect $3.80 per contract. This trade has an 85% theoretical chance of success and a 18% price buffer from current price.I only sell naked puts if I am willing and able to own the stock at the strike sold. IF FB stock falls below $100 per share this year I would be put the stock. Anything lower than $96 per share would be losses for me.The Twist:Selling naked puts is not suited for every risk profile. So I can change the bank trade to being a credit put spread instead. Selling a spread makes the trade's maximum risk finite. For example
column11: I can sell the FB Dec $100/$95 credit put spread. I collect $1.06 per contract to open. If successful
column12: this trade yields 22% on money risked.Why Under Armour Inc (UA) Stock Could Be ScrewedThis is one of those occasions where I could do either or both. Some traders don't like selling risk into an earning report. I don't mind doing it with quality stocks like FB. I also usually do it far out in time and away from current levels.I am not required to hold option trades through expiration. I can close them at any time for partial gains or losses.Nicolas Chahine is the managing director ofSellSpreads.com. As of this writing
column13: he did not hold a position in any of the aforementioned securities. You can follow him on Twitter at@racernicand stocktwits at@racernic.More From InvestorPlace7 Stocks to Buy That Could Double by 201810 High-Yield Dividend Stocks That Are SOMEHOW Still BargainsThe postSign Up for Free Profits From Facebook Inc (FB) Stockappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: One Put
column2: One Call Option To Know About for Microsoft;1/30/2017;"Consistently
column3: one of the more popular stocks people enter into theirstock options watchlistat Stock Options Channel is Microsoft Corporation (Symbol: MSFT). So this week we highlight one interesting put contract
column4: and one interesting call contract
column5: from the July expiration for MSFT. The put contract our YieldBoost algorithm identified as particularly interesting
column6: is at the $57.50 strike
column7: which has a bid at the time of this writing of $1.23. Collecting that bid as the premium represents a 2.1% return against the $57.50 commitment
column8: or a 4.5% annualized rate of return (at Stock Options Channel we call this theYieldBoost).Selling a put does not give an investor access to MSFT's upside potential the way owning shares would
column9: because the put seller only ends up owning shares in the scenario where the contract is exercised. So unless Microsoft Corporation sees its shares fall 11.7% and the contract is exercised (resulting in a cost basis of $56.27 per share before broker commissions
column10: subtracting the $1.23 from $57.50)
column11: the only upside to the put seller is from collecting that premium for the 4.5% annualized rate of return.makeArticleAd();Interestingly
column12: that annualized 4.5% figure actually exceeds the 2.4% annualized dividend paid by Microsoft Corporation by 2.1%
column13: based on the current share price of $65.13. And yet
column14: if an investor was to buy the stock at the going market price in order to collect the dividend
column15: there is greater downside because the stock would have to lose 11.69% to reach the $57.50 strike price.Always important when discussing dividends is the fact that
column16: in general
column17: dividend amounts are not always predictable and tend to follow the ups and downs of profitability at each company. In the case of Microsoft Corporation
column18: looking at the dividend history chart for MSFT below can help in judging whether the most recent dividend is likely to continue
column19: and in turn whether it is a reasonable expectation to expect a 2.4% annualized dividend yield.Turning to the other side of the option chain
column20: we highlight one call contract of particular interest for the July expiration
column21: for shareholders of Microsoft Corporation (Symbol: MSFT) looking to boost their income beyond the stock's 2.4% annualized dividend yield. Selling the covered call at the $70 strike and collecting the premium based on the $1.33 bid
column22: annualizes to an additional 4.3% rate of return against the current stock price (this is what we at Stock Options Channel refer to as theYieldBoost)
column23: for a total of 6.7% annualized rate in the scenario where the stock is not called away. Any upside above $70 would be lost if the stock rises there and is called away
column24: but MSFT shares would have to climb 7.5% from current levels for that to occur
column25: meaning that in the scenario where the stock is called
column26: the shareholder has earned a 9.6% return from this trading level
column27: in addition to any dividends collected before the stock was called.The chart below shows the trailing twelve month trading history for Microsoft Corporation
column28: highlighting in green where the $57.50 strike is located relative to that history
column29: and highlighting the $70 strike in red:The chart above
column30: and the stock's historical volatility
column31: can be a helpful guide in combination with fundamental analysis to judge whether selling the July put or call options highlighted in this article deliver a rate of return that represents good reward for the risks. We calculate the trailing twelve month volatility for Microsoft Corporation (considering the last 251 trading dayMSFT historical stock pricesusing closing values
column32: as well as today's price of $65.13) to be 20%.In mid-afternoon trading on Monday
column33: the put volume among S&P 500 components was 1.08M contracts
column34: with call volume at 1.29M
column35: for a put:call ratio of 0.83 so far for the day
column36: which is unusually high compared to the long-term median put:call ratio of .65. In other words
column37: there are lots more put buyers out there inoptions tradingso far today than would normally be seen
column38: as compared to call buyers.Find out which 15 call and put options traders are talking about today.Top YieldBoost MSFT Calls »"

column17: but instead of ''shares'' investors are actually buying and selling ''units''. These ''units'' can be traded back and forth just like stocks
column18: but can also be created or destroyed to accommodate investor demand. Each week we monitor the week-over-week change in shares outstanding data

column2: Apple
column3: Amazon
column4: Alphabet and Intel;1/30/2017;"For Immediate ReleaseChicago
column5: IL - January 30
column6: 2017 - Zacks.com announces the list of stocks featured in the Analyst Blog. Every day the Zacks Equity Research analysts discuss the latest news and events impacting stocks and the financial markets. Stocks recently featured in the blog includeMicrosoft(NASDAQ:MSFT-Free Report)
column7: Apple(NASDAQ:AAPL-Free Report)
column8: Amazon(NASDAQ:AMZN-Free Report)
column9: Alphabet(NASDAQ:GOOGL-Free Report) andIntel(NASDAQ:INTC-Free Report).Today
column10: Zacks is promoting its ''Buy'' stock recommendations.Get #1Stock of the Day pick for free.Here are highlights from Friday's Analyst Blog:The Cloud Drives Technology Stocks This QuarterAnalysts and experts have talked at length about the importance of cloud computing and how it would transform the technology sector. But the sense of waiting that underpinned such discussions is now giving way to a sense of arrival.Several factors are making cloud computing a reality today
column11: the most important of which are an awareness of the resultant cost reductions
column12: awareness of the economic value of processing ever-increasing volumes of data
column13: and recognition of the advantages of sharing resources and having anytime anywhere access to data and information.Of course
column14: along with all these advantages comes concerns related to privacy and security
column15: which have been further exacerbated by government snooping
column16: gag orders and orders to turn over data in private individual devices or in servers on foreign soil that have in turn made individuals and corporations wary about adopting the cloud.But technology companies are fighting it out. Microsoft (NASDAQ:MSFT-Free Report) for one has strongly resisted government demands as have Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL-Free Report) and Amazon (NASDAQ:AMZN-Free Report). Alphabet's (NASDAQ:GOOGL-Free Report) Google has also been vocal in its opposition. It makes perfect sense when you consider that these are some of the biggest cloud computing stocks that also offer computing and other devices. So they have vested interests at both ends of the networks.Other players with similar interests are chip makers like Intel (NASDAQ:INTC-Free Report); networking companies like Cisco and Juniper; and software/service companies like IBM and Oracle.Here's a brief glimpse of three cloud companies that just reported December quarter results:IntelIntel's results this quarter were driven by both the PC and data center businesses. The PC strength was seasonal and unlikely to be sustained.Although non-volatile memory had the strongest growth rate of 24.8% and will grow even stronger this year
column17: it currently contributes a lower share of revenue
column18: which equates to fewer incremental dollars. Also
column19: the business is poised to benefit from Intel's strength in the server market.Data center revenue growth of 8% year over year was helped by platform volume growth of 3% and platform price increase of 4%. Intel has new products in the pipeline and will also be integrating some technology it acquired through Altera
column20: so this year may be less disappointing than the last when enterprise softness skewed expectations.MicrosoftMicrosoft has become a cloud-focused company
column21: impressing analysts and investors alike. The company is making the most of legacy workloads that use its software and its all-new Windows OS
column22: while leveraging Office productivity software and enterprise relationships to post record growth in cloud revenue.The company reported solid cloud results
column23: with Azure revenue growing 93% (95% in constant currency) and compute usage doubling year over year. Its cloud productivity business also saw strong growth: Office 365 commercial revenue grew 47% (49% in constant currency) with seat growth of 37% and monthly active iOS and Android devices more than doubling to 65 million
column24: Office 365 consumer revenue grew 22% (21% in constant currency) with seat growth of 20.9%.Dynamics 365 paid seats also more than doubled. Nadella promised commercial cloud annualized revenue runrate of $20.0 billion in 2018 and last quarter's $14.0 billion means that Microsoft is definitely on track to beat or exceed the target.AlphabetAlphabet doesn't break out its cloud revenue separately although independent market research data indicates that it is well behind market leader Amazon and even runners up Microsoft. In fact after the December quarter results some analysts have started saying that Microsoft has also started pulling away from the pack in its chase of Amazon.Alphabet's growth should not be discounted however because while cloud and hardware are lumped together right now
column25: its common knowledge that most of its new hardware has been unavailable for a lot of the time. So the 62% growth in this segment seems to be less on account of hardware sales and more of an indication of strength it is seeing in the cloud.CFO Ruth Porat has said that cloud
column26: hardware and YouTube subscriptions will be ""major revenue drivers for Google in the next several years."" This will of course require capital investment
column27: something the company can afford given the way the search business continues to rake in cash. Capex was around $3.08 billion last quarter
column28: that's nearly up by a billion dollars and will mostly be spent on data centers to support its cloud business.Now See Our Private Investment IdeasWhile the above ideas are being shared with the public

column1: Facebook Inc (FB) Stock: New All-Time Highs or New Problems?;1/30/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsFacebook Inc(NASDAQ:FB) enters this week's fourth-quarter earnings report in a peculiar position: Despite the fact that FB stock is trading near all-time highs
column3: Facebook absolutely has something to prove.makeArticleAd();Source: ShutterstockThat's because FB has spent the past three months recovering from a rough Q3 report that sent the stock to one of its biggest dips since coming public in 2012. While the company reported a strong earnings beat
column4: Facebook CFO warned about a slowdown in revenue growth for Q4
column5: and said ad load might ""come down meaningfully"" in the second half of this year.The news sparked a selloff from which Facebook wouldn't really recover until the start of 2017. But recover it has - FB stock is up roughly 15% in the past month to trade near all-time highs around $113.So
column6: what's in store for Facebook this time around?If you believe Jefferies analyst Brian Fitzgerald
column7: FB could be sitting on the powder keg that sends Facebook through the price ceiling.Fitzgerald believes Instagram and mobile ad revenues will drive the business forward
column8: and expects Q4 revenues to grow 46% year-over-year to $8.54 billion - slightly ahead of Wall Street's broader estimates for $8.5 billion. He also projects GAAP profits of $1.05
column9: which are a penny higher than the consensus mark.""We remain particularly optimistic around Instagram
column10: bottom-funnel ad units like DPAs
column11: and Live video
column12: says Fitzgerald
column13: whose $175 price target represents 33% upside from here. ""While expense growth is a potential concern
column14: FB has a history of under-promising and overdelivering in this area.""10 Stocks to Buy That Already Make America GreatIndeed
column15: mobile is king for Facebook
column16: which crossed the 1 billion mark for ""mobile only"" active users in Q3. In fact
column17: 84% of the company's $6.82 billion in ad revenues came from mobile - up from 78% in the year-ago period. At about $5.7 billion
column18: mobile ad sales came in more than 30% higher thantotalFacebook ad sales in Q3 2015.Still
column19: if Facebook matches Wall Street's projections for 45.6% sales growth
column20: that would be down both sequentially from Q3's 59% revenue expansion
column21: and last Q4's 52% increase in sales. Which means investors will be looking for other areas of growth.They could get it in Facebook Live
column22: the company's somewhat controversial live streaming service that has unwittingly exposed users to real-time torture and suicide videos. Still
column23: CEO believes images and video are the future of Facebook - and the expansion and advertising of Live's services reflect that plenty.Facebook will need to show Wall Street something exciting
column24: though
column25: or FB could be in for its second straight quarterly tumble.Facebook shares reached all-time highs just above $133 in late October. They then dropped but rebounded to the $132 area
column26: but were rejected following the Q3 earnings report. FB then was sent packing to the $114 level
column27: which it fought several times before rebounding into the current rally.Now
column28: Facebook stock finds itself challenging the $132-$133 area once more
column29: but this time with an overbought Relative Strength Index (RSI) reading in the low 70s.And from a fundamental perspective
column30: Facebook's forward price-to-earnings ratio of 25 isn't nearly on par with the likes of pricey Big Tech stocks such asNetflix
column31: Inc.(NASDAQ:NFLX)
column32: but it's still a little lofty.At the very least

column1: 17 Years Later
column2: Microsoft Corp. Is Worth $500 Billion Again!;1/29/2017;"Microsoft(NASDAQ: MSFT) is putting some pep back in its step these days.   On Friday
column3: Reuters pointed out that the software giant's market   cap has risen above $500 billion for the first time since March   2000.I'm all for celebrating neat milestones
column4: including this   17-year benchmark. And it's no secret that Microsoft really isdoinga lotof thingsrightthese days. Large-cap stocks don't post market-crushing 55%   returns in two years for no reason.That being said
column5: I would like to argue that the Microsoft you   see today is miles removed from the $500 billion beast you knew   17 years ago.makeArticleAd();Horace Chow
column6: Microsoft's general manager of Hong Kong     operations
column7: illustrating ""transformation"" on stage. Image     source: Microsoft.Inflated dollar valuesFirst
column8: let me point out that $500 billion ain't what it used   to be. The inexorable march of inflation hollows out the value of   your dollar over time
column9: and 17 years of that action can do a lot   of damage. To wit:The buying power of $500 billion in 2016 dollars works out     to just $363 billion of inflation-adjusted 2000 currency.Conversely
column10: $500 billion then is the equivalent of roughly     $697 billion in today's dollars.From this perspective
column11: Microsoft would need a market cap     boost of 37% from today's total in order to make up for the     inflation effect.Okay
column12: nobody sets up milestones and goalposts at $697 billion.   We want nice
column13: round numbers. But if you don't consider   inflation-based erosion over the long run
column14: you're doing a   disservice to your investments.It's real.Another yardstickMarket cap is the easy way out. You simply multiply current   share prices by the number of shares outstanding. Handy for   discussion and popular at every cocktail party
column15: market cap is one   of those metrics you can lean on for quick comparisons.But it's also an overly simplistic measurement in many ways.   Let's say you actually wanted to buy all of Microsoft. You (or   the cabal of multi-billionaires and cash-rich companies you're   working with) would then have to take over all of Microsoft's   debts
column16: because lenders and bondholders won't just drop their   claims when the takeover happens. On the upside
column17: you also get to   keep all of Microsoft's cash equivalents
column18: which is kind of like   buying a nice wallet and finding a hundred-dollar bill   inside.Now we're looking at theenterprise valueinstead. The market cap is just a starting point
column19: followed by   adding the company's debt balances and subtracting its cash   reserves. This (plus an appropriate buyout premium) would be the   true price tag in a takeover.As it turns out
column20: Microsoft comes with more cash equivalents   than debt. Today
column21: this metric stops at $459 billion -- a few   bucks short of the magic $500 billion waterline. Here's how   Redmond's enterprise value has developed over the last 17 years   compared to the simpler market cap:MSFT Market Capdata byYCharts.But wait
column22: there's more!Honestly
column23: there's always more to say about a business as   complex as Microsoft. I'm not here to write a book today
column24: so   let's keep this short and sweet.Before I go
column25: let me just point out that Microsoft has done a   lot of growing up since the dot-com boom and bust. Trailing sales   have nearly quadrupled
column26: while free cash flows doubled:MSFT Revenue (TTM)data byYCharts.The company's dividend policy is just 13 years old
column27: but now   provides a decent 2.4% yield. And Microsoft's balance sheet was   free of long-term debt 17 years ago
column28: but that changed in 2009.   The current statement of financial accounts has very little in   common with the lean
column29: low-capital version it wielded in 2000.   Cash and debt balances have skyrocketed in recent years
column30: and   Microsoft has started amassing a generous chunk of plant
column31: property
column32: and equipment assets (PP&E in the chart below).If I didn't know better
column33: this almost looks like the   balance-sheet antics of an industrial manufacturing   conglomerate:MSFT Net PP&E (Quarterly)data byYCharts.Meet the new boss
column34: not the same as the old bossAny way you slice it
column35: the rejuvenated version ofMicrosoft sharesfew characteristics with the older owner of a $500 billion market   cap. The world has changed
column36: the software industry never stops   changing
column37: and Microsoft is forever busy adjusting to new   realities.So if your opinions and investment thesis regarding Microsoft   haven't changed in 17 years
column38: I'm sorry to say that the company   didnotjust hop in a time machine to skip the last 17 years. You'll have   somereadingto do if you want to keep up.10 stocks we like better than MicrosoftWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column39: it can pay to listen. After all
column40: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade

column42: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Microsoft wasn't one of     them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4

column1: Microsoft Goes From Window(s) Cleaning to Cloud-Gazing;1/29/2017;"After nearly two years
column2: Microsoft(MSFT) finally reported quarterly revenue growth during the second quarter of 2017. In many ways
column3: Microsoft's performance during the second quarter is a peek into what the future holds for the company. Revenue from the Productivity and Business Process segment and the Intelligent Cloud segment was up10%during the quarter
column4: while More Personal Computing declined by 5% due to lower phone revenues.Microsoft raced past analyst estimates
column5: posting adjusted EPS of83cents on the back of $26.07 billion in revenues
column6: while the market was expecting 79 cents in earnings and $25.3 billion in revenues.The above-average results were made possible by stellar performance from Microsoft's cloud business
column7: whose annualized commercial cloud revenue run rate has now exceeded $14 billion. Microsoft takes the revenue earned from cloud products (Office 365
column8: Microsoft Azure
column9: Dynamics 365) in the final month of the quarter
column10: and multiplies it by 12 to get to its annual cloud run rate. During the first quarter
column11: Microsoft said that its cloud run rate exceeded $13 billion
column12: and in the second quarter it has gone past $14 billion. This means Microsoft's cloud properties brought nearly $1.08 billion in September 2017 and $1.16 billion December 2017.makeArticleAd();Microsoft's cloud-based businesses are still growing sequentially
column13: which is great news for the company as it transitions from being Windows-dependent to being cloud-reliant. Office 365 commercial revenue grew 47% during the quarter
column14: while Office consumer products and cloud services revenue increased by 22%.Office and related products
column15: especially the cloud-delivered lineup
column16: has been growing in a very strong way for the company. Microsoft has steadily built its lead in this segment
column17: and if the above-47% growth of the last six quarters continues
column18: it will be very difficult for the competition to catch up.Microsoft Azure has been clocking triple-digit growth rates for the past several quarters
column19: and in the second quarter it came very close
column20: posting 93% growth over the prior period. Microsoft noted that Azure compute usage has more than doubled during the quarter.Productivity and Business Processes and Intelligent Cloud
column21: the two forward-looking business streams that are based on cloud delivery
column22: made $14.283 billion during the second quarter
column23: nearly $2.5 billion more than the More Personal Computing segment that hosts Windows OEM
column24: Phone and Gaming revenues. Though Windows OEM revenue increased by 5% during the quarter
column25: Windows revenue are on shaky grounds due to the steady decline of PC sales around the world. As smartphones and tablets keep replacing PCs
column26: the Windows operating system
column27: which has a negligible presence in the mobile world
column28: does not have a great future
column29: at least in the short to medium-term.But second quarter results have already proved that Microsoft has successfully transitioned into a new era
column30: where cloud
column31: not Windows
column32: dominates the revenue landscape. The company is now poised on the threshold of where CEO Satya Nadella wants it to ultimately go
column33: and the next several quarters will make that transition even more pronounced.Disclosure:I have no positions in the stocks mentioned above and no intention to initiate a position in the next 72 hours.Start a free seven-day trial of Premium Membership to GuruFocus.Premium MembersThis article first appeared onGuruFocus."

column1: Why Microsoft Corporation Will Put $1 Billion Into Cyber-Security (MSFT);1/28/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News

The company has reportedly invested into three Israel-based firms. One of those investments was made just this week

column12: withTarget Corporation(NYSE:TGT) losing its 200-week moving average for the first time since 2011
column13: as Trump seemed to warm to the idea of a border tax that would increase the cost of goods sold.Intel Corporation(NASDAQ:INTC) gained 1.1% after reporting a fourth-quarter earnings per share beat 4% ahead of estimates thanks to results from its cloud computing group.Microsoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT) gained 2.4% after reporting a top-and-bottom line beat as analysts remain excited about the company's cloud business.Alphabet Inc(NASDAQ:GOOG
column14: NASDAQ:GOOGL) fell 1.4% after missing on earnings.10 Stocks to Buy That Already Make America GreatOn the downside
column15: JetBlue Airways Corporation(NASDAQ:JBLU) fell 6.9% after suffering a downgrade from analysts at Argus citing valuation concerns after a rally over the last three months. Rising fuel costs and other expenses were noted as a concern.Colgate-Palmolive Company(NYSE:CL) fell 5.2% after reporting a 4% revenue miss on slower-than-expected organic sales growth. AndStarbucks(NASDAQ:SBUX) fell 4% after reporting a revenue miss with traffic down 2% in the United States.On the economic front
column16: GDP growth slowed to a 1.9% rate in the fourth quarter
column17: down from the 3.5% rate seen in Q3 and the 2.2% growth that was expected by analysts. Personal consumption increased at a 2.5% rate
column18: down from 3% in the previous quarter.Looking ahead
column19: investors have a lot to think about next week including a Federal Reserve policy announcement on Feb. 1. Fed Board Chair Janet Yellen and her cohorts have been sounding a hawkish note lately
column20: leaning against the fiscal stimulus plans of the Trump White House as consumer price inflation rose above their 2% target last month (on fuel and housing costs).As a reminder
column21: the Fed has penciled in three quarter-point hikes for 2017 vs. just two quarter-point hikes since the tightening campaign started in December 2015.After that
column22: we've got the non-farm payroll report on Friday
column23: Feb. 3. The unemployment rate has compressed in recent months
column24: standing at 4.7% in January
column25: as the job market tightens. Non-farm payrolls came in at 156
column26: 000 in January
column27: continuing a steady if somewhat tepid pace.3 ""Golden"" Ammo Stocks to Buy for Big 2017 ReturnsTechnically
column28: investors should remain cautious as stocks continue to look dramatically overbought here and vulnerable to a profitmaking move to the downside. Sentiment is off the charts here
column29: with theCBOE Volatility Index(INDEXCBOE:VIX) posting its second-lowest close in 11 years. Breadth continues to narrow.Anthony Mirhaydari is founder of theEdgeandEdge Proinvestment advisory newsletters. column1: Earnings Growth Returns
column2: Will it Continue?;1/27/2017;"makeZacksArticleAd();Corporate earnings have started growing again
column3: with growth in the ongoing Q4 earnings season on track to reach its highest level in 8 quarters. Growth is still modest - the Q4 earnings growth is currently on track to reach +5.2% and the final growth tally for the quarter will at best be a couple of percentage points higher. But this is still a notable improvement over what we were experiencing in the recent past.Please recall that earnings growth turned positive only in 2016 Q3
column4: having declined in each of the preceding 5 quarters
column5: as the chart below of year-over-year earnings growth for the S&P 500 index shows.Positive surprises
column6: particularly on the earnings front
column7: are tracking below other historical periods at this stage. We will see if this trend continues this week as we enter the heart of the earnings season
column8: with more 400 companies coming out with quarterly results
column9: including 106 S&P 500 members.Q4 Scorecard(as of January 27
column10: 2017)We have crossed the one-third mark in the Q4 reporting cycle
column11: with results from 170 S&P 500 members
column12: or 33.9% of the index's total membership
column13: already out. Total earnings for these 170 index members are up +6.0% on +3.1% higher revenues
column14: with 64.1% beating EPS estimates and 54.7% coming ahead of top-line expectations.The table below provides the current Q4 scorecardThe charts below provide a comparison of the results thus far with what we have seen from this same group of 170 S&P 500 members in other recent periods.As you can see
column15: the Q4 growth pace is notably tracking above what we had seen from the same group of 170 index members in other recent periods. But positive surprises (right-hand chart above) are tracking on the low side at this stage
column16: particularly on the earnings front. The 64.1% proportion of Q4 companies beating EPS estimates compares to 81.2% in the preceding quarter
column17: 76.3% as the 4-quarter average and 72.2% as the 12-quarter average. Positive revenue surprises are tracking below what we had seen from the same group of companies in Q3
column18: but are roughly in-line with historical periods.The chart below compares the proportion of companies reporting Q4 results that are beatingbothEPS and revenue estimates with what this same group of companies had reported in other recent periods.Standout SectorsSectors with strong growth and better than expected results include the Finance
column19: Technology
column20: Construction
column21: Industrial Products
column22: Basic Materials and Consumer Discretionary sectors. Positive surprises for all of these sectors are tracking above the index level.Finance: With results from 57.7% of the sector's market cap in the S&P 500 index already out
column23: total earnings for the sector are up +11.3% from the same period last year on +3.1% higher revenues
column24: with +66.7% beating EPS estimates and +46.2% beating top-line estimates.This is a better growth performance than we have seen from the sector in other recent periods
column25: as the comparison charts below show. Please note that positive surprises are as hard to come by in the Finance sector as they are elsewhere.Strong Finance sector growth is a big driver of the aggregate growth performance for the S&P 500 index as a whole. Excluding the Finance sector
column26: the Q4 growth pace still compares favorably with other recent periods
column27: but a lot less so
column28: as the right-hand chart below shows.Technology: For the Technology sector
column29: we now have Q4 results from 59.6% of the sector's total market cap. Total earnings for these companies are up +7.2% from the same period last year on +4.9% higher revenues
column30: with 69% beating EPS estimates and 82.8% beating revenue estimates.We will see what this week'sApple(AAPL) andFacebook(FB) reports bring
column31: but the sector's Q4 earnings and revenue growth is about in-line with what we saw from this same group of Tech companies in the preceding quarter (2016 Q3)
column32: though it is notably tracking above the 4-quarter and 12-quarter averages. With respect to positive surprises
column33: Tech companies appear to be beating EPS estimates at a lower proportion than has historically been the case
column34: though the proportion of positive earnings surprises remains above the index level. Revenue surprises
column35: on the other hand
column36: are tracking notably above historical periods.Key Reports for the Week of January 30thTuesday - 1/31/2017: Monday has a relatively light reporting docket
column37: but Tuesday is very busy with more than 90 companies reporting results
column38: including 33 S&P 500 members (of which 22 are in the morning). The focus will be onApple(AAPL)
column39: which reports after the market's close.Exxon(XOM)
column40: Pfizer(PFE)
column41: Eli Lilly(LLY) andUnder Armour(UAA) will be the key reports in the morning.Apple is expected to report $3.22 in earnings on $76.2 billion in revenues
column42: which compare to $3.28 on $75.9 billion in revenues in the year-earlier period. The stock is up +9.7% since November 8th vs. +7% for the S&P 500 index and +6.1% for the Zacks Technology sector. December quarter estimates have been stable in recent days
column43: though they have come down for the March quarter.Wednesday - 2/01/2017:Facebook(FB) is the most high profile of the 27 index members reporting results today (it will report after the market's close). The focus will be on the social media giant's ad revenues and daily active users
column44: but the current Zacks Consensus EPS estimate is $1.13 on $8.4 billion in revenues. This compares to EPS of $0.59 on $5.8 billion in revenues in the year-earlier period. Estimates have modestly inched up in recent days. The stock has performed in-line with the Zacks Tech sector since November 8th
column45: up +6.3% vs. +6.1%.Thursday - 2/02/2017: On a busy reporting day with 35 index members coming out with Q4 results (23 in the morning & 12 after the market's close)
column46: the notable reports are fromCME Group(CME) andInternational Paper(IP) in the morning andAmazon(AMZN) in the evening.Amazon is expected to report $1.41 in earnings (up +41.5% year over year) on $44.8 billion in revenues (up +25.4% in revenues). Estimates have come down ahead of the earnings report
column47: but Amazon has never really been an EPS story; it is all top-line growth
column48: particularly gains in its cloud business
column49: Amazon Web Services. Amazon
column50: along withMicrosoft(MSFT)
column51: which came out with impressive cloud numbers of its own
column52: has staked a well-regarded claim to leadership in the fast-growing cloud business. The stock has been a strong performer over the past year
column53: up +31.4% vs. +12.4% gain for the Zacks Retail sector.Friday - 2/03/2017:AutoNation(AN) andHershey(HSY) are the notable reports today
column54: both in the morning.Q4 Expectations As a WholeFor Q4 as a whole
column55: combining the actual results from the 170 S&P 500 members that have reported with estimates for the still-to-come 330 companies
column56: total earnings are expected to be up +5.2% from the same period last year on +4.0% higher revenues. This would follow the +3.8% growth in Q3 earnings on +2.3% higher revenues
column57: the first instance of positive earnings growth for the index after five quarters of back-to-back declines. Comparisons for the Energy sector

column1: Q4 Earnings Results Pouring In: Can Facebook Continue Its Insane Growth?;1/27/2017;"On today's episode of the Zacks Friday Finish Line podcast
column2: Content Writer Ryan McQueeney and Editor Maddy Johnson take on this week's biggest story: the wave of fourth-quarter earnings results and the upcoming earnings announcement from Facebook.The first earnings report that the hosts highlighted this week came from StarbucksSBUX. The coffee giant's stock slumped after the company reported worse-than-expected revenues. While Starbucks was still able to post solid growth metrics in the quarter
column3: its results fell short of analyst expectations and investors reacted accordingly.Find out more here:Starbucks Slides on Mixed Q1 Earnings
column4: Mobile Order     & Pay Up 3%Next up on the docket was Intel Corporation'sINTCfourth-quarter earnings report. The chip maker was able to post an impressive double beat on the back of soaring revenues in its Data Centers division
column5: underscoring the success of its adaption to changing industry trends.Read more:Intel Beats Q4 Earnings and Revenue Estimates Behind     Solid Data Centers GrowthThe hosts then moved on to recap some of the week's big tech reports. MicrosoftMSFTreported second-quarter fiscal 2017 earnings on Thursday
column6: and the company was able to surpass our earnings and revenue estimates thanks to more impressive growth in its Intelligent Cloud business.On the other hand
column7: Alphabet Inc.'sGOOGLreport was mixed. The company missed earnings estimates but was able to surpass our consensus revenue estimate. While there were no specific details about Google's new hardware
column8: the ""other"" category that would include things like the Pixel phone soared more than 60%
column9: so there were some encouraging signs.Find out more on both reports here:Microsoft Posts Q2 Earnings Beat
column10: Intelligent Cloud     Revenue Up 8%&Alphabet Inc. Stock Slumps on Q4 Earnings MissFinally
column11: Maddy and Ryan spent some time previewing Facebook'sFBupcoming earnings announcement. Investors are cautious about Facebook's revenue growth rates slowing down a bit
column12: but the company is still poised to report another great quarter. The hosts also chatted about some of Facebook's new features
column13: including Facebook Live.Check out the full preview:Facebook Q4 Earnings Preview: Will Live Pay Off     Big?As always
column14: thanks for checking out this week's episode of the Zacks Friday Finish Line
column15: and make sure to check back next week for even more news from the investment and financial world!Which Stocks are Zacks Experts Talking About?Stocks in today's headlines may be tempting buys

column1: Microsoft's Surface Lineup Is Now a $4.3 Billion Business;1/27/2017;"Surface lineup. Image source: Microsoft.WhenMicrosoft(NASDAQ: MSFT) first launched itsSurface lineup in 2012
column2: I had my doubts as to whether or not the company could   successfully jump into hardware. The company has had its fair   share of missteps for the Surface
column3: but it's safe to say at this   point that Microsoft has exceeded most early expectations for its   first-party devices. Microsoft has adapted quickly to flops like   Surface RT
column4: which resulted in a $900 million writedown back in   2013
column5: and pushed forward with expanding the portfolio
column6: most   recently with Surface Studio.makeArticleAd();Surface revenue during the fourth quarter came in at $1.3   billion
column7: representing a sequential increase of over 40% for the   busy holiday shopping season. That's enough to bring full-year   2016 Surface revenue to an impressive $4.3 billion.Data source: Microsoft. Chart by author. Calendar years     shown.It also probably helps that CEO Satya Nadella is a stronger   leader than his predecessor
column8: even though the Surface strategy was   conceived under Steve Ballmer. The push with Surface hardware   created a rift between Ballmer and Bill Gates
column9: and may have also   contributed to Ballmer's ouster.Out with the old
column10: in with the newDuring the earnings call
column11: Nadella noted that Surface has   enjoyed three consecutive quarters of 25%-plus growth. Sales mix   is transitioning toward the newer products like Surface Pro 4 and   Surface Book
column12: and Surface 3 sales are expected to continue   winding down.The customer reception for Surface Studio in particular has   been strong
column13: which is especially impressive for two reasons:   Surface Studio was not widely available during the fourth   quarter
column14: and it's extremely expensive
column15: starting at $3
column16: 000.   Inventories for the new all-in-one should start improving this   quarter as production ramps up.Taking a bite out of AppleMore broadly
column17: Surface is but part of a bigger push among the   Windows PC crowd to take a bite out ofApple's(NASDAQ: AAPL) turf: the premium PC market. Surface is doing   well
column18: but it was never expected to comprise a large chunk of the   Windows ecosystem; that's what original equipment manufacturers   (OEMs) are for.CFO Amy Hood said that Microsoft's ""OEM non-pro performance   should grow ahead of the market
column19: due to strength in the premium   device category."" In other words
column20: high-end consumer-oriented PCs   made by Microsoft's partners are gaining traction in the market
column21: at a time when Apple lost PC market share for thefirst three quartersof 2016 (Apple reports fourth-quarter results next week). OEM   non-pro revenue grew 5% last quarter
column22: outpacing the broader PC   market.Surface is profitable
column23: tooIt's also worth pointing out that Surface is now profitable on   a gross margin basis (up 6% last quarter in dollar terms)
column24: so   those revenue gains are starting to enjoy some operating   leverage.Unfortunately
column25: currency headwinds are adversely impacting   profitability
column26: as Surface gross margin was up 17% on a constant   currency basis in dollar terms. There's a big discrepancy between   the currency impacts on revenue (2 percentage points) compared to   gross margin (11 percentage points)
column27: which is due to the fact   that Surface devices are manufactured in Asia and the Surface   cost structure is more vulnerable to currency fluctuations.Still
column28: you have to give Nadella credit for being able to take   a struggling segment conceived under Ballmer and turn it into a   profitable $4.3 billion business within just a couple of   years.10 stocks we like better than MicrosoftWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column29: it can pay to listen. After all
column30: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column31: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column32: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Microsoft wasn't one of     them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4
column33: 2017Teresa Kersten is an employee of LinkedIn and is a member     of The Motley Fool's Board of Directors. LinkedIn is owned by     Microsoft.Evan Niu
column34: CFAowns shares of Apple. The Motley Fool owns shares of and     recommends Apple. The Motley Fool has the following options:     long January 2018 $90 calls on Apple and short January 2018 $95     calls on Apple. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: Xbox Live Games With Gold for February 2017;1/27/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsMicrosoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT) has unveiled its selection of Xbox live games with Gold for next month.makeArticleAd();Source: MicrosoftTheFebruary selectionincludes two Xbox 360 titles that subscribers of the company's exclusive Gold service can download for free
column3: as well as two Xbox One offerings.Here's what next month has in store in the form of Xbox live games with Gold:Monkey Island 2: SE- The first title on tab for Xbox 360 owners is Monkey Island 2: SE

column1: Cisco Snatches IPO Baby from the Arms of Wall Street;1/27/2017;"makeZacksArticleAd();On January 24
column2: Cisco (CSCO)revealed they were buying a private company called AppDynamics for $3.7 billion. The funny thing is that the little guy already had a stock symbol picked out
column3: APPD
column4: for its scheduled IPO this week. Talk about a buzzer-beater.But Cisco is also viewed as paying a hefty premium for a software firm specializing in a niche called application performance management (APM). Why would they do that?According to Pacific Crest Securities
column5: ""AppDynamics is a natural fit for Cisco's portfolio
column6: in our view
column7: given its ability to monitor legacy applications and infrastructure and its growing presence in next-generation application deployments.""AppDynamics' software stack now allows Cisco's product portfolio to extend its insight across the network
column8: security and application layers. The acquisition broadens Cisco's software portfolio as Cisco attempts to diversify its revenue base with more subscription and recurring revenue.""Tech Titans Clash With War Chests of CashThis was precisely a theme that I discussed on the Zacks Ultimate webinar January 12: tech titans like Amazon (AMZN)
column9: Microsoft (MSFT)
column10: IBM
column11: Facebook (FB) and Alphabet (GOOGL) ""battling for innovation"" with war chests of cash to scoop up ""off-the-shelf"" technology before the other guy.And MarketWatch reported in a story on January 25 that there is a trend of the smaller companies gladly accepting these buyouts to avoid the market volatility of the public markets. ThinkTwilio (TWLO)there. Here were a couple of interesting lines from the story by Caitlin Huston...""Just last week
column12: SimpliVity
column13: a software company
column14: took a big valuation cut after it agreed to be bought by Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) for $650 million in cash
column15: compared with a $1 billion private valuation.""Cisco and HPE show that large legacy tech companies are willing to swoop in to acquire startups
column16: but the wide range of potential outcomes could lead to startups trying to stay private another year
column17: said Max Wolff
column18: market strategist at 55 Capital Partners. The top-tier of unicorn companies
column19: such as SnapChat and Airbnb are not as affected
column20: he added.Stifel: Potential Takeout Candidates After APPD DealCourtesy of TheFly.com...Cisco's acquisition of AppDynamics is a sign that the wave of Software deal activity in 2016 has carried over into the new year
column21: Stifel analyst Brad Reback tells investors in a research note. He believes the deal bodes well for the small- and mid-cap names across his firm's coverage list
column22: including potential consolidation candidates such as Barracuda (CUDA)
column23: ChannelAdvisor (ECOM)
column24: FireEye (FEYE)
column25: HubSpot (HUBS)
column26: Paycom (PAYC)
column27: Paylocity (PCTY)
column28: Proofpoint (PFPT)
column29: SecureWorks (SCWX)
column30: Splunk (SPLK)
column31: Tableau (DATA)
column32: Ultimate Software (ULTI)
column33: Veeva (VEEV) and Zendesk (ZEN). He notes that AppDynamics most directly competes against other application performance management vendors such as New Relic (NEWR) and privately-held Dynatrace.Death By AmazonThis was my theme for the Zacks Ultimate webinar earlier this month. You can watch all or part of it below in the player
column34: and there's no sales pitch. This was premium content for our ZU members that we wanted to share with a wider audience because we thought it was so good.While I've been furiously researching the ""Amazon Effect"" onmobile commerce
column35: entrepreneurship
column36: and public companies like Macy's for the past 2 years
column37: I can't take credit for the ""Death By Amazon"" tag.That comes from Bespoke Investment Group who actually created an index to follow the public company impact of Amazon's disruptive model as it has grown at exponential scale. I show their chart in the webinar.And my latest research project is focused on Facebook advertising which grew 55% to $26.5 billion last year and will add another $10 billion this year.Facebook Ads are truly an economic phenomenon because they are actually expanding the pie that Google Adwords created with PPC (pay per click).In other words
column38: just like the ""Gig Economy"" creates jobs the government doesn't know about
column39: the ""GAF (Google-Amazon-Facebook) Economy"" is creating thousands of small businesses that you maybe didn't know about.Exploring the GAF EconomyCheck out the webinar below where I also had a great discussion with my colleague Eric Dutram
column40: Zacks ETF Strategist
column41: as his topic -- the Internet of Things -- fit in perfectly with mine.And I highlight 4 areas of disruption after I studied the investment approach of VC Chris Sacca of lowercase capital who hit grand slams with Twitter
