column1: Interesting January 2018 Stock Options for MSFT;1/23/2017;"Consistently
column2: one of the more popular stocks people enter into theirstock options watchlistat Stock Options Channel is Microsoft Corporation (Symbol: MSFT). So this week we highlight one interesting put contract
column3: and one interesting call contract
column4: from the January 2018 expiration for MSFT. The put contract our YieldBoost algorithm identified as particularly interesting
column5: is at the $50 strike
column6: which has a bid at the time of this writing of $1.85. Collecting that bid as the premium represents a 3.7% return against the $50 commitment
column7: or a 3.7% annualized rate of return (at Stock Options Channel we call this theYieldBoost).Selling a put does not give an investor access to MSFT's upside potential the way owning shares would
column8: because the put seller only ends up owning shares in the scenario where the contract is exercised. So unless Microsoft Corporation sees its shares fall 20.3% and the contract is exercised (resulting in a cost basis of $48.15 per share before broker commissions
column9: subtracting the $1.85 from $50)
column10: the only upside to the put seller is from collecting that premium for the 3.7% annualized rate of return.makeArticleAd();Worth considering
column11: is that the annualized 3.7% figure actually exceeds the 2.5% annualized dividend paid by Microsoft Corporation by 1.2%
column12: based on the current share price of $62.73. And yet
column13: if an investor was to buy the stock at the going market price in order to collect the dividend
column14: there is greater downside because the stock would have to lose 20.33% to reach the $50 strike price.Always important when discussing dividends is the fact that
column15: in general
column16: dividend amounts are not always predictable and tend to follow the ups and downs of profitability at each company. In the case of Microsoft Corporation
column17: looking at the dividend history chart for MSFT below can help in judging whether the most recent dividend is likely to continue
column18: and in turn whether it is a reasonable expectation to expect a 2.5% annualized dividend yield.Turning to the other side of the option chain
column19: we highlight one call contract of particular interest for the January 2018 expiration
column20: for shareholders of Microsoft Corporation (Symbol: MSFT) looking to boost their income beyond the stock's 2.5% annualized dividend yield. Selling the covered call at the $72.50 strike and collecting the premium based on the $1.60 bid
column21: annualizes to an additional 2.6% rate of return against the current stock price (this is what we at Stock Options Channel refer to as theYieldBoost)
column22: for a total of 5.1% annualized rate in the scenario where the stock is not called away. Any upside above $72.50 would be lost if the stock rises there and is called away
column23: but MSFT shares would have to advance 15.5% from current levels for that to occur
column24: meaning that in the scenario where the stock is called
column25: the shareholder has earned a 18.1% return from this trading level
column26: in addition to any dividends collected before the stock was called.The chart below shows the trailing twelve month trading history for Microsoft Corporation
column27: highlighting in green where the $50 strike is located relative to that history
column28: and highlighting the $72.50 strike in red:The chart above
column29: and the stock's historical volatility
column30: can be a helpful guide in combination with fundamental analysis to judge whether selling the January 2018 put or call options highlighted in this article deliver a rate of return that represents good reward for the risks. We calculate the trailing twelve month volatility for Microsoft Corporation (considering the last 251 trading dayMSFT historical stock pricesusing closing values
column31: as well as today's price of $62.73) to be 21%.In mid-afternoon trading on Monday
column32: the put volume among S&P 500 components was 1.12M contracts
column33: with call volume at 1.12M
column34: for a put:call ratio of 0.72 so far for the day
column35: which is above normal compared to the long-term median put:call ratio of .65. In other words
column36: if we look at the number of call buyers and then use the long-term median to project the number of put buyers we'd expect to see
column37: we're actually seeing more put buyers than expected out there inoptions tradingso far today.Find out which 15 call and put options traders are talking about today.Top YieldBoost MSFT Calls »"

column1: Samsung (SSNLF): TWO Different Battery Failures on Galaxy Note 7;1/23/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace   - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsSamsung Electronic(OTCMKTS:SSNLF) held a press conference this weekend that was buried by coverage of the U.S. presidential inauguration and the Women's March on Washington. The company announced the final results of its Galaxy Note 7 investigation
column3: and according to Samsung
column4: there was not one buttwoseparate Galaxy Note 7 battery flaws to blame.Source:Sylwia Bartyzel Via UnsplashThe second was introduced in the replacement battery after the initial issue was discovered.makeArticleAd();Samsung's Galaxy Note 7 Testing MarathonIt was pretty obvious once Galaxy Note 7s started bursting into flames that the battery was involved. But when the problems continued with replacement smartphones using a new battery from a different supplier
column5: suddenly the root cause got murkier.At thepress conference
column6: Samsung explained just how deeply it investigated the Galaxy Note 7.10 Blue-Chip Stocks That Could Be Holding You     BackEverything from the new USB-C port
column7: to wireless charging and even software overload was closely studied and eliminated as a factor. So was Samsung's manufacturing process. The company built four test facilities (one at each site where it assembled the doomed smartphone) and put 700 engineers to work testing 200
column8: 000 Galaxy Note 7s plus 30
column9: 000 Galaxy Note 7 battery packs on their own. External testers from three different firms were also added to the teams.Exploding Galaxy Note 7 Battery Cause: Almost UnbelievableThe result?It turns out that SSNLF got hit by an almost unbelievable coincidence.In its rush to take advantage of the expected low-keyApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) iPhone 7 launch
column10: it used a battery sourced from an unnamed supplier
column11: that had a hidden design flaw. The battery lacked sufficient space to expand and contract - as batteries do - when charging and discharging. As a result
column12: the battery's electrodes could touch
column13: then short circuit. This issue was not caught by the battery manufacturer.Samsung pointed out that for its own quality assurance team to have noticed the problem
column14: they would have had to X-Ray the batteries.Batteries from a second supplier (also un-named) used in some Galaxy Note 7s were fine. They became the go-to replacement batteries once the first wave of trouble began. However
column15: Samsung then pushed that second supplier to dramatically increase its Galaxy Note 7 battery production volume.The demand to quickly churn out 10 million batteries overwhelmed that company's production capability and manufacturing defects crept in. A faulty internal weld could cause these replacement batteries to also short circuit and again
column16: the defect was not visible.Samsung's Safety Pledge and the Galaxy S8Samsung took full responsibility for the Galaxy Note 7 battery fiasco
column17: admitting that it had pushed suppliers and the limits of the manufacturing process.Going forward
column18: the company is implementing an8-point battery safety checkthat includes accelerated usage testing
column19: durability tests
column20: X-Ray examination and physically disassembling the batteries.In recognition that lithium-ion batteries can be extremely volatile
column21: Samsung has also committed to leaving more space around the battery packs in its smartphones going forward. While this runs contrary to the ""thinner at all cost"" mentality that Samsung and Apple have been pursuing
column22: additional buffer space will protect the battery from impacts.In aninterview with Recode
column23: Samsung's mobile division head said: ""I wish [that] this serves as an opportunity to improve safety of lithium-ion not only for Samsung but for the entire industry.""Samsung also made it clear that the Galaxy S8 - due for release this spring - will be covered by the enhanced battery safety procedures.Bank of America Corp's (BAC) Irrational     Exuberance Will EndThat Galaxy S8 launch will be the critical test of whether SSNLF truly recovers from the Galaxy Note 7 battery fiasco. The chapter is estimated to havecost the company $10 billion
column24: Samsung stock took a hit (although strong performance by its chips division more than made up for that) and its brand was damaged.If consumers accept Samsung's findings
column25: apology and pledge to prevent this from happening in the future
column26: the Galaxy S8 could see a sales rebound. If the Galaxy Note 7 battery episode still surrounds the company
column27: Apple's iPhone 8 stands a chance of clawing back share from Android when it launches in the fall and the Samsung's place on top of the Android pyramid could ultimately be in doubt.As of this writing
column28: Brad Moon did not hold a position in   any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceApple Inc. New iPads Might Be Late to the Party     (AAPL)3 Things Apple Inc. (AAPL) MUST Do to Soar in     2017Microsoft Corporation (MSFT) Steps on Amazon     and Google's TurfThe postSamsung (SSNLF): TWO Different Battery Failures on Galaxy Note 7appeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Qualcomm (QCOM) Faces $1B Patent Royalty Suit from Apple;1/23/2017;"Qualcomm Inc.QCOM
column2: the largest mobile chipset manufacturer using baseband technology globally
column3: has recently been pressed with a $1 billion lawsuit related to licensing royalty payments by tech giant Apple Inc.AAPL. In the lawsuit filed in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of California
column4: Apple has accused Qualcomm of overcharging for chips and refusing to pay some $1 billion in promised rebates.Notably
column5: just a couple of days before filing of Apple's lawsuit
column6: Qualcomm had faced an anti-trust lawsuit from the U.S. Federal Trade Commission (FTC). The regulator filed a lawsuit with the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California claiming that the company has used anticompetitive measures to maintain a monopoly in baseband chipset market.The FTC said Qualcomm had established an exclusivity agreement with iPhone and iPAD maker Apple from 2011 to 2016. Through this deal the San Diego-based chipmaker provided billions of dollars in license rebates to Apple subject to the condition that Apple would not use chipset of Qualcomm's rival companies. The company recognized that any competitor that won Apple's business would become stronger
column7: and used exclusivity of the deal to prevent the latter from working with and improving the effectiveness of its competitors.However
column8: Qualcomm argued that the FTC's complaint is based on ""flawed legal theory
column9: a lack of economic support and significant misconceptions about the mobile technology industry"". While the chipset maker observes major flaws in the accusations
column10: it is likely get a full hearing. In the last five trading days
column11: the stock price of Qualcomm has declined 5.34% on Nasdaq.The FTC alleged that Qualcomm has barred competitors from getting a foothold in the baseband chipset market by using unfair means to secure business
column12: thereby harming consumer choice. Notably
column13: Intel Corp.INTCand Media Tek are closest competitors of Qualcomm in this field. In addition to iOS
column14: Qualcomm chipsets are vastly used for Alphabet Inc.'sGOOGLGoogle developed Android software and Microsoft Corp.MSFTdeveloped Windows operating system.Qualcomm generates approximately 29% of its total revenue from the licensing business however
column15: this business accounts for almost 77% of the company's net profit. Moreover
column16: the company has a history of facing allegations related to licensing disputes. The US regulator is latest in the line of accusers alleging Qualcomm of abusing its dominant position and imposing unfair licensing terms.In 2015
column17: the Chinese regulatory authority
column18: National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC) fined Qualcomm nearly $975 million for abusing China's anti-competitive terms. In Dec 2016
column19: the company was fined nearly $886 million in South Korea for restrictive licensing practices. Moreover
column20: since 2011
column21: Qualcomm has been under investigation for competition violations in the European Union region.In its filing
column22: Apple has accused Qualcomm of pressurizing the company in providing false statement to South Korea's antitrust regulator
column23: the Korea Fair Trade Commission regarding the above mentioned anti-trust case in that country. Apple and Samsung Electronics are the two major customers of Qualcomm's chipsets for modems that connect phones to wireless networks. The two companies together accounted for over 40% of Qualcomm's $23.5 billion in revenue in fiscal 2016 (ended in Sep 2016). Thus
column24: a royalty lawsuit from Apple may harm Qualcomm in big way.Price Performance of QualcommIn the last one year
column25: the stock price of Qualcomm has gained a substantial 32.16% compared with 5.97% loss witnessed by the Zacks categorizedWireless Equipmentindustry. Qualcomm
column26: the undisputed leader in the global wireless baseband chipset market is widening its presence in adjacent opportunities
column27: including automotive
column28: networking
column29: and mobile computing strategies which bode well for long-term growth. Qualcomm's Snapdragon processor is best known for its versatility in IoT applications.However
column30: aggressive competition in the mobile phone chipset market
column31: stringent regulatory norms and anti-competitive charges are some of the major headwinds faced by the company. We believe that these are the reasons behind the company's currently carrying a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold). column1: 3 Stocks That Are Up 20% in January;1/22/2017;"The S&P 500 has risen less than 1% since the beginning of   the year
column2: but plenty of stocks posted double-digit gains during   that time. Let's take a closer look at three stocks that have   rallied about 20% in January --Shopify(NYSE: SHOP)
column3: Box(NYSE: BOX)
column4: andWorkday(NYSE: WDAY) -- and see if they can continue rising through the   rest of the year.Image source: Getty Images.makeArticleAd();ShopifyShopify provides a cloud-based e-commerce platform for small   to medium-sized businesses. Its software enables companies to   design
column5: set up
column6: and run their own online stores
column7: and lets them   accept credit cards
column8: view incoming orders
column9: and review completed   transactions.Shopify's 18% rally in January is a continuation of its 150%   rally over the past 12 months. That rally can be attributed to   its impressive top-line growth -- its revenue surged 89%   annually
column10: to $99.6 million last  quarter
column11: following four   straight quarters of 90%+ growth.Shopify served over 325
column12: 000 merchants at the end of last   quarter
column13: which was a big jump from its customer base of ""over   200
column14: 000"" merchants in the prior-year quarter
column15: and its gross   merchandise volume doubled to $3.8 million. It also announced   deeper integration withAmazon's sales channel earlier this month
column16: making it easier for its   customers to sell products on  the e-commerce giant's   marketplace.Analysts expect Shopify's revenue to rise 86% for the   full year
column17: but it still isn't profitable yet on a GAAP or   non-GAAP basis. Its GAAP loss widened last quarter
column18: mainly due to   higher stock-based compensation expenses
column19: but its non-GAAP loss   slightly narrowed. Shopify is a pretty pricey stock at 13 times   sales
column20: but its growth trajectory might support that   valuation.BoxBox provides online file sharing and personal cloud content   for businesses. The company faces tough challenges in the   cloud-storage market from Dropbox and bigger tech giants
column21: but its   customer base already includes massive companies likeGeneral ElectricandSymantec.Like Shopify
column22: Box has great top-line growth and weak   bottom-line growth. Its revenue rose 31% annually
column23: to $102.8   million last quarter
column24: as billings rose 26%. Deferred revenue
column25: a   key indicator of future demand
column26: jumped 36%
column27: to $192.6 million.   Box's quarterly revenues have now risen by more than 30% annually   for the past five quarters
column28: and analysts anticipate 31% sales   growth this year. Box is unprofitable by both GAAP and non-GAAP   metrics
column29: but its losses are narrowing by both measures.Image source: Getty Images.Box has rallied 23% in January
column30: but still trades at six times   sales
column31: which is only slightly higher than the industry average of   four for  application-software companies. But looking ahead
column32: Box and Dropbox both face very tough competition in the   cloud-storage market.Companies likeMicrosoft(NASDAQ: MSFT) are offering plenty of free and cheap storage to   enterprise customers to tether them to their cloud ecosystems.   Despite that competition
column33: Microsoft has integrated Box into   Office 365
column34: sparking rumors of an eventual takeover. With an   enterprise value of just over $2 billion
column35: Box could certainly be   a lucrative target in a consolidation of the cloud-storage   market.WorkdayWorkday provides enterprise cloud applications that help   companies staff
column36: pay
column37: and organize their workforces. They also   utilize analytics and machine learning to help companies make   financial and workforce-related decisions.Demand for these services has been robust -- Workday's sales   rose 34% annually last quarter and have risen 30% to 40% over the   past four quarters. Analysts expect its revenue to rise 35% this   year
column38: although the company warned in early January that a few of   its bigger deals had been delayed by global uncertainties   regarding Brexit
column39: the U.S. presidential election
column40: and other G8   country elections.But like Shopify and Box
column41: Workday has weak profitability.   That's because the cost of securing new customers coupled with   price competition and the low margins of the cloud SaaS (software   as a service) market make it tough to squeeze out a profit
column42: even   with double-digit sales growth. Workday squeezed out a narrow   non-GAAP profit last quarter

column45: Recruiting

column48: according to   Drexel Hamilton analyst Brian White -- but Wal-Mart didn't   disclose how many of its 2 million+ employees would actually use   the system. Nonetheless

column1: Why Himax Technologies Is Not a Top Stock to Buy Now;1/22/2017;"Image source: Getty Images.Himax Technologies(NASDAQ: HIMX) may seem poised to benefit from the potential   growth of augmented reality (AR)
column2: but there's one major hurdle   the company will have to overcome before that happens: AR devices   are too expensive for the mass market right now.makeArticleAd();This challenge can be overcome -- after all
column3: we're still at   the beginning stages of AR's growth. But as a component maker
column4: Himax relies on mass adoption to be able to scale its AR   component production. With device prices so high
column5: and adoption   rates so low
column6: Himax may not be a top stock to buy right now.AR is still too expensive for consumersNorthland Capital Markets' Tom Sepenzis wrote in a recent   investor note (republishedonBarron's):Augmented reality remains the largest potential for HIMX     with its LCOS and WLO products
column7: but the market has hit another     stumbling block as prices remain prohibitive for consumers. We     believe that this will limit the number of new AR devices for     the next 12-24 months....He's referring to Himax's liquid crystals on   silicon (LCOS) and wafer-level optics (WLO) products   that the company is ramping up this year
column8: with plans tobring new production online late this yearor in early 2018. Himax says that it works with 30 augmented   reality device makers right now
column9: and believes that it's at ""the   beginning of a very long-term growth story"" for AR.The problem is that some AR devices
column10: suchMicrosoft's HoloLens (which Himax is a supplier for)
column11: cost $3
column12: 000. To be   fair
column13: the current version of HoloLens is for developers. But at   $3
column15: AR devices are still a very long way from becoming a   Saturday afternoon purchase for most consumers.A Bloomberg article fromlast yearsaid it could take four to five years for AR and virtual reality   (VR) headsets and other technologies to reach mainstream   adoption
column16: and that price will be one of the main factors in   determining when they take off.A bit too earlyIt's hard to get passed the idea that Himax's AR potential may   still be a little too far off. Sure
column17: the company is bringing new   production lines online to prepare for possible AR component   growth
column18: but AR's viability is not a sure thing.It can be a great thing for investors to find a company that's   betting on a new market that's poised for growth
column19: but there   appears to be too many unknowns for Himax. First
column20: investors will   be waiting until the end of this year
column21: or the beginning of 2018
column22: to see the company's LCOS and WLO production ramp up. If AR was a   sure-thing
column23: then sitting patiently for that to come to fruition   would be easier to stomach. As it stands
column24: AR is still in its   nascent stages.Second
column25: component makers like Himax can easily getting burned   in situations like this
column26: where the need to score big design wins   from tech makers can take precedence over earning solid margins   and strong revenues. Himax CEO Jordan Wu indicated on the   November earnings call that its AR component sales were falling   because just one ""major customer"" was pulling back on demand:We therefore expect our LCOS and WLO sales to decline in the     fourth quarter
column27: as well as over the next few quarters in 2017.     We are not particularly worried about the short-term headwind     as the said major customer is more committed than ever in the     long-term development of the AR product concept
column28: which is     viewed as a new computing platform and that Himax remains a     critical partner to the customer in these AR efforts.Himax might be on the right path
column29: but the company's reliance   one just one key customer for AR sales -- and current AR device   prices being too high -- make me perfectly comfortable staying   away from the stock right now.10 stocks we like better than Himax     TechnologiesWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column1: 3 Things to Watch in the Stock Market This Week;1/22/2017;"Stocks ticked lower last week
column2: but remain up slightly through   the first few weeks of 2017. TheDow Jones Industrial Average(DJINDICES: ^DJI)  and theS&P 500(SNPINDEX: ^GSPC)  each remain near all-time highs as   investors brace for an avalanche of quarterly earnings reports   over the coming weeks.^SPXdata byYCharts.makeArticleAd();Hundreds of companies are set to post results for the final   quarter of 2016 this week. A few of the most anticipated reports   includeStarbucks(NASDAQ: SBUX)
column3: McDonald's(NYSE: MCD) andMicrosoft(NASDAQ: MSFT) .McDonald's sales growthFast-food giant McDonald's starts the week off for investors   with fourth-quarter results due out on Monday morning. After a   disappointing two-year stretch
column4: the restaurant chain is on a   winning streak of five straight quarters of comparable-store   sales growth
column5: including a 6% spike early in 2016.The company's latest report wasn't as impressive
column6: but global   comps still accelerated to a 3.5% pace from the prior quarter's   3.1% uptick due to continued help from its all-day breakfast   shift and a popular McPick 2 value platform. Growth might be   harder to come by this quarter given the overall weak selling   environment in the fast-food industry.Shareholders will likely hear updated thinking from management   on industry trends and how they plan to keep improving the guest   experience through menu additions and store remodels. On the   financial side
column7: McDonald's will complete most of its   refranchising plan in 2017
column8: which should raise significant funds   for reinvesting in the business and returning cash to   shareholders through dividends and stock buybacks.Starbucks' customer trafficStarbucks kicks off its 2017 fiscal year with results due outafter the market closeson Thursday. The coffee titan has seen its traffic gains slow   recently
column9: with transactions rising 2% in the past year following   a 3% bump in the prior period. Beverage innovations and increased   food sales helped average customer spending jump higher. However
column10: the traffic decline muted overall gains.Image source: Starbucks.The coffee chain will need steady transaction growth to hit   its long-term expansion plans. Executives believe they can boost   earnings by between 15% and 20% each year through 2021 as   Starbucks adds 12
column11: 000 stores to its base and increases sales at   existing locations by about 5% annually. ""I have never been more   energized or optimistic about the opportunities ahead
column12: CEO   Howard Shultz said in early December as he discussed handing over   his leadership role to Chief Operating Officer Kevin Johnson.Investors will be looking for evidence this week that these   ambitious targets are achievable through initiatives like mobile   ordering
column13: global expansion
column14: and a deeper push into the retailing   world .Microsoft's cloud revenueMicrosoft is coming off astrong 2016that saw the stock finally surpass the all-time high it posted   during the dot-com bubble era in late 1999. Investors sent shares   higher
column15: thanks to the success of its cloud business
column16: which has   been helped along by a doubling of Azure revenue. In Mr. Softy's   most-recent quarter
column17: growth in that segment helped offset a   decline in the company's personal computing (PC) division
column18: which   was driven by continued weakness in the PC market.Image source: Microsoft.Consensus estimates call for a 2% sales decline and flat   earnings when Microsoft posts results on Thursday. CEO Satya   Nadella is likely to focus his management comments on high-growth   cloud services
column19: including an Azure offering that the company aims   to grow into a $20 billion business by fiscal 2018.""The cloud is winning significant customer support
column20: Nadella   said following Microsoft's blockbuster July quarterly report. The   key question for the company going forward is whether those   growth engines will ramp up quickly enough to offset declines in   legacy business like PC software and video gaming.Find out why Starbucksis one of the 10 best stocks to buy nowMotley Fool co-founders Tom and David Gardner have spent     more than a decade beating the market. column1: Has Toymaker Mattel Beaten Netgear With This New High-Tech Device?;1/21/2017;"When it comes to high-tech gadgetry
column2: you'd think networking   hardware specialistNetgear(NASDAQ: NTGR) would have a commanding lead over toymakerMattel(NASDAQ: MAT)
column3: but while both companies are branching out in new   directions
column4: where they're intersecting may actually have Barbie's   parent in the lead.Even baby monitors have gone high-tech from their humble   walkie-talkie beginnings. Image source: Joris via Wikimedia   Commons.makeArticleAd();Baby monitors have come a long way from the walkie-talkie-type   devices that let you listen in on the coos and cries of your   infant. Today they're part of the Internet of Things in a   connected home that let you wirelessly watch your child on your   computer
column5: laptop
column6: or smartphone whether you're at home
column7: outside
column8: or away. Yet for all their tech wizardry
column9: they're really little   more than remote viewers
column10: which is why the surprising new   developments from Mattel and Netgear are so innovative. They lift   the baby monitor out of being just a static device that watches   and listens and turn it into something that is interactive.Security outside the home
column11: and in the nurseryNetgear's Arlo Baby is a natural progression from its Arlo and   Arlo Q home security cameras that it acquired back in 2012
column12: which   were marketed at the time under the VueZone brand. After   significantly upgrading the hardware and networking capabilities
column13: they were rebranded as Arlo and won industry plaudits. So it's   really not such a stretch for Netgear to go from helping you   watch your house and possessions to keeping an eye on your   baby.Image source: Arlo.Shaped like a rabbit -- a small
column14: Cyclops-like rabbit -- the   Arlo Baby offers parents two-way talk and listen capabilities
column15: night vision
column16: and 1080p video. That's not much more than what   you'll find on existing baby monitors on the market like the   Summer Infant Baby Link camera or TrendNet's WiFi Baby Cam
column17: and   even its preloaded lullabies and ability to play your own music   can be found on devices like the iBaby Monitor M6S. Its   sensors monitor temperature
column18: humidity
column19: and air quality levels in   the nursery as well as provide alerts when the baby moves
column20: similar to features found on thePhilipsIn.Sight monitor.Where Netgear's device improves on existing monitors is   combining them all into one product and then adding a few   upgrades such as the ability to distinguish between a baby's cry   and other sounds an infant might make
column21: and note it in its audio   alerts. It also records movement and sound and stores the clips   in the cloud
column22: allowing you to download them for free for seven   days
column23: and allows for expansion with five additional cameras being   added for free
column24: and up to 15 cameras total.Technology doesn't come cheap
column25: though
column26: as an Arlo Baby will   set you back around $250
column27: or $300 if you add a dedicated 7-inch   LCD viewer to it. Other accessories
column28: including cat and Dalmatian   designs
column29: are also available.This is definitely not a toyMore remarkable
column30: however
column31: may be what Mattel has achieved with   its Aristotle by Nabi baby monitor. Essentially performing all of   the same tasks as Netgear's Arlo
column32: the toymaker's device is no   toy.Mattel entered the market in a roundabout way
column33: acquiring last   year for $21.5 million the bankrupt company Fuhu
column34: which made the   popular Nabi children's tablet. It unveiled the Aristotle at this   year's Consumer Electronics Show
column35: and though it will cost $299   when it becomes available this summer
column36: it offers what appears to   be superior functionality over the Arlo and other devices on the   market.Image source: Microsoft.Beyond the capabilities found elsewhere
column37: the system is billed   as the first artificially intelligent smart assistant for kids.   Essentially anAmazonEcho or Google Home
column38: the Aristotle device usesMicrosoft(NASDAQ: MSFT) programming andQualcomm(NASDAQ: QCOM) processors to recognize your child's voice   patterns
column39: and as the child grows
column40: it becomes more interactive. It   can read stories
column41: help a child learn the alphabet
column42: and using   Microsoft's Bing search engine
column43: it can help a child search for   answers to homework assignments.Furthermore
column44: Mattel has partnered with retailers likeTargetand Babies 'R' Us to take advantage of its ability to take note   of nap and diaper change times
column45: and to speed up orders of baby   supplies that may be running low
column46: like diapers or formula. It   sees the device also becoming connected with other toys for a   greater immersive play experience as well as partnering with   other companies for additional capabilities.Considering the opportunity for this ""baby monitor"" to develop   into something much more than simply a static device to watch
column47: listen
column48: and monitor
column49: as well as to last beyond a child's infancy
column50: it would seem Mattel has jumped well ahead of Netgear and other   companies trying to compete for a share of the playroom.10 stocks we like better than MattelWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip

column52: the newsletter they have run for   over a decade

column54: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Mattel wasn't one of them! column1: Let's Make Earnings Season Important Again;1/21/2017;"Now that we officially have a new President and the market has broken its losing streak
column2: it's time to direct our focus back to earnings season. So far
column3: Donald Trump has been completely overshadowing the reports
column4: but that should change next week when the season really kicks into gear.makeArticleAd();As Steve said in today'sRTA:""keep an even keel in your reaction to each individual report. Don't get too upset if it goes against us…don't get too elated if we seem to have a non-stop string of winners. This state of mind will help us navigate the often turbulent waters of earnings season to get to desired shores of higher profits"".It was a challenging week for the market but it ended on a high note as the Dow broke its five session losing streak with an advance of 0.48% to 19
column5: 827.3. The S&P was up 0.34% to 2271.3 and the NASDAQ increased 0.28% to 5555.33. The market reacted much better on the first day of Trump's presidency then Obama's
column6: but we must remember that the now former president came to power during the Great Recession. President Trump has been bequeathed a growing economy and low unemployment
column7: so it will be interesting to see what he can do with that.The portfolios saw a couple big winners on Friday.Options Traderdecided to remove one of its spreads ahead of its quarterly report
column8: which brought the portfolio a triple-digit return.Surprise Traderhad its second consecutive double-digit winner from the same stock
column9: and also bought today. Learn more about these moves below
column10: along with some excerpts from other portfolios.Triple-Digit Winner for Options Trader→ TheOptions Trader's bull call spread in State Street (STT) is fully in-the-money
column11: but the stock has dropped in the past few days. With earnings scheduled for next week
column12: Kevin thought this would be a good time to remove the spread and take a nice return of 104%. Therefore
column13: he sold to the close the Feb. 70.00 Call AND bought to close the Feb. 75.00 Call.→ TheSurprise Tradermade a big double-digit profit yesterday as shares of CSX (CSX) soared. But the stock pulled back on Friday a bit more dramatically than Eric was expecting. So the editor sold the second half of the position to secure a double-digit return of 13.8%.Today's Portfolio Highlights:• Microsoft (MSFT) has been pretty impressive at earnings season of late with two straight quarters of double-digit beats. Eric is hoping for more of the same when this tech giant reports again after the bell on Thursday. The company has amassed an average surprise of 10% over the past four quarters and has a positive Earnings ESP heading into next week
column14: so it appears set for another solid performance. The stock is also a Zacks Rank #2 (Buy) with a Zacks VGM Score of ""A"". For all these reasons
column15: MSFT was added toSurprise Traderon Friday with a 12.5% allocation.• ""The inauguration is over and the market chopped around again
column16: much too many traders dismay. Trump was sworn in and gave a populist speech that caused modest selling. However
column17: markets came right back with the S&P finishing up 0.34% and the Nasdaq closing 0.28% higher.""I talk to a highly skilled trader on instant messenger all day and it was interesting getting his perspective this week. In his words ""This is the strongest weakest marker ever"". I agree
column18: there seems to be so much energy building up to shoot higher
column19: but it just can't seem to go. Something is holding it back
column20: whether it's a manipulation
column21: foreign selling
column22: democrats selling or whatever you want to dream up.""When the selling is done
column23: you really have to wonder if there will be anything left to hold the market back
column24: or if we just explode up like a rubber band being stretched too far. We will find out shortly
column25: said Jeremy inZacks Counterstrike.• ""The Trump economy officially kicked off today as Donald J Trump was sworn in as the 45th President of the United States of America. The volatility that traders had murmured about through the course of the week simply did not show up. Stocks ended on a strong note and the bulls were back in charge. Earnings season ended its first big week without any huge disappointments and now we're set up for a pretty good January so far.""It looks like smooth sailing on the horizon for the market in the early part of earnings season here. Next week there is a huge emphasis on tech with a lot of big names reporting. Should make for some volatility on the NASDAQ and could be fuel to push the S&P 500 on through to new highs
column26: said Dave inMomentum Trader.Have a Great Weekend

column1: Nokia's New Phone Sells Out in a Minute -- But What Does That Mean?;1/20/2017;"Nokia's(NYSE: NOK) new Android phone
column2: the  Nokia 6
column3: reportedly   sold out within the first minute on its launch day in China. The   device was offered briefly in an online flash sale
column4: although   Nokia didn't disclose how many units were actually offered.   However
column5: over a million people reportedly registered for the   flash sale.The Nokia 6. Image source: Nokia.makeArticleAd();The Nokia 6 is a mid-range device which sports a Snapdragon   430 chipset
column6: 4GB of RAM
column7: a 16-megapixel rear camera
column8: 8-megapixel   front camera
column9: a 3
column10: 000 mAh battery
column11: and a 5.5"" screen. The device
column12: which is only available in China for now
column13: costs  around $245   and runs Android 7.0 out of the box.Those specs don't sound too impressive
column14: but the device marks   Nokia's long-awaited return to the smartphone market. But before   investors start thinking that this is the start of Nokia's   comeback
column15: they should understand that Nokia's smartphone business   changed considerably after it sold its handset unit toMicrosoft(NASDAQ: MSFT) back in 2014.The evolution of Nokia's smartphone businessAfter Nokia sold its handset unit to Microsoft
column16: it signed a   non-compete agreement with Microsoft which barred it from selling   new mobile devices until the  end of 2016. During the   following two years
column17: Microsoft dropped the Nokia branding from   its Lumia devices
column18: and tried using them to grow Windows Phone's   market share against iOS and Android. That effort flopped
column19: and   Windows Phone now  controls less than 1% of the smartphone   market. Admitting defeat
column20: Microsoft took a $7.6 billion writedown   on the unit
column21: laid off most of the handset unit
column22: and reduced the   number of annual Lumia launches.During that time
column23: Nokia formed a new business unit called   Nokia Technologies
column24: which housed its patent portfolio and   developed experimental new products like the Ozo VR camera. Nokia   then realized that it could license out its design
column25: patents
column26: and   branding to other companies that wanted to create Nokia-branded   devices. This strategy enabled Nokia to keep its brand relevant   and collect low-risk royalties without shouldering any production   costs.Nokia's N1 tablet. Image source: Nokia.Since Nokia was prohibited from launching new phones
column27: it   licensed out its brand toFoxconnto create the N1 Android tablet for China in early 2015. Nokia   and Foxconn used a flash sale strategy for the N1
column28: proclaiming   that  the device sold out ""within minutes"" each time --   although the first batch only included 20
column29: 000 units. Nokia then   realized that it could apply the same strategy to the smartphone   market once the non-compete agreement expired.The birth of HMD GlobalFor that purpose
column30: private equity fund Smart Connect formed a   new company
column31: led by former Nokia executives
column32: calledHMDGloballast year. HMD obtained the exclusive global license (excluding   Japan) to create Nokia-branded phones and tablets over the next   decade
column33: and signed a contract to exclusively source the   production of the devices to Foxconn's subsidiary FIH Mobile. HMD   and FIH Mobile also co-purchased Nokia's feature phone business   from Microsoft last May.The creation of HMD Global meant that HMD and Foxconn would   produce brand new Nokia devices while paying Nokia Technologies a   steady stream of royalties. This means that robust sales of new   Nokia handsets would benefit HMD much more than Nokia
column34: but Nokia   would be insulated from any downside risks.But can Nokia smartphones become relevant     again?Nokia devices face a long uphill battle to becoming relevant   again in the highly saturated smartphone market. The Android   market in China is a particularly brutal one flooded with   low-margin players. EvenXiaomi
column35: the former Chinese market leader which lost its crown toHuaweiin late 2015
column36: admitted that it  didn't make any money from   its smartphone sales last November.Nokia's design and specs don't really stand out in the Chinese   market
column37: so HMD is likely counting on Nokia's brand strength and   the hype of flash sales to boost demand. While the initial   reports of the Nokia 6 ""selling out"" are encouraging
column38: the lack of   actual sales figures indicate that it's just an attempt to   generate hype like the claims of its N1 tablets ""selling out""   during its flash sales. Therefore
column39: investors should keep an eye   on the Nokia 6's reception in China
column40: but they shouldn't believe   that it signals a comeback for Nokia in the smartphone   market.10 stocks we like better than NokiaWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column41: it can pay to listen. After all
column42: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column43: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column44: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Nokia wasn't one of them!     That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even better     buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4
column45: 2017Teresa Kersten is an employee of LinkedIn and is a member     of The Motley Fool's Board of Directors. LinkedIn is owned by     Microsoft.Leo Sunhas no position in any stocks mentioned. The Motley Fool has no     position in any of the stocks mentioned. The Motley Fool has adisclosure policy."

column1: Q4 Earnings Growth the Highest in 8 Quarters;1/20/2017;"makeZacksArticleAd();The Q4 earnings season has gotten off to a good start
column2: with earnings and revenue growth tracking above other recent periods and on track to reach the highest level in 8 quarters. Positive surprises
column3: particularly on the earnings front
column4: are a bit on the low side relative to historical periods at this stage. We will see if this trend continues this week as we enter the heart of the earnings season
column5: with more than 300 companies coming out with quarterly results
column6: including 105 S&P 500 members.As of Friday
column7: January 20th
column8: we have seen Q4 results from 63 S&P 500 members that combined account for 19.2% of the index's total market capitalization. Total earnings for these 63 index members are up +4.7% on +2.7% higher revenues
column9: with 66.7% beating EPS estimates and 50.8% coming ahead of top-line expectations.The table below provides the current Q4 scorecardThe charts below provide a comparison of the results thus far with what we have seen from this same group of 63 S&P 500 members in other recent periods.As you can see
column10: the Q4 growth pace is notably tracking above what we had seen from the same group of 63 index members in other recent periods. But positive surprises (right-hand chart above) are tracking a bit on the low side at this stage
column11: particularly on the earnings side. The 66.7% proportion of Q4 companies beating EPS estimates compares to 81% in the preceding quarter
column12: 75% as the 4-quarter average and 71.3% as the 12-quarter average. Positive revenue surprises are tracking below what we had seen from the same group of companies in Q3
column13: but are roughly in-line with historical periods.The chart below compares the proportion of companies reporting Q4 results that are beatingbothEPS and revenue estimates with what this same group of companies had reported in other recent periods.Trump Bump for BanksThe sample of Q4 earnings reports is heavily weighted towards the Finance sector at this stage whose improved results are helping the aggregate growth picture as well. The growth picture looks a lot less impressive once looked at on an ex-Finance basis.Total earnings for the roughly half of the Finance sector's market cap in the S&P 500 index that have reported results are up +11.8% from the same period last year on +2.6% higher revenues
column14: with +68.2% beating EPS estimates and +45.5% beating top-line estimates.This is better growth performance than we have seen from the sector in other recent periods
column15: as the comparison charts below show. Please note that positive surprises are as hard to come by in the Finance sector as they are elsewhere.We didn't really see the full impact of higher interest rates on the banks' net interest margins in Q4 results. But higher interest rates
column16: increased confidence and the resultant enhanced appetite for risks did juice the trading revenues forJPMorgan(JPM)
column17: Bank of America(BAC)
column18: Goldman Sachs(GS) and evenMorgan Stanley(MS). This didn't come as a surprise to the market
column19: as estimates and stock prices had already run up quite a bit ahead of these earnings reports. It is reasonable to expect these bank stocks to remain in a holding pattern in the coming days till fundamentals changes in a meaningful way and/or progress on legislative expectations start showing up.Key Reports for the Week of January 23rdMonday - 1/23/2017:McDonalds(MCD) andHalliburton(HAL) are the notable for the four index members reporting results today. Estimates for Zacks Rank # 1 (Strong Buy) rated Halliburton have been going up lately
column20: reflecting the company's strong positioning in the North American oilfield region. The stock has literally been on a tear lately
column21: up +88.9% in the past year vs. +44.2% gain for the Zacks Energy sector and +41.9% gain for peerSchlumberger(SLB) whose Q4 results failed to impress on Friday.Tuesday - 1/24/2017: We have 21 S&P 500 members reporting results today
column22: of which 12 report before the market's open.Verizon(VZ)
column23: Johnson & Johnson(JNJ) and3M(MMM) are the notable reports
column24: all reporting in the morning. China'sAlibaba(BABA) is also on deck to report results today.Wednesday - 1/25/2017: Of the 31 index members reporting results today (16 in the morning)
column25: the notable reports are fromBoeing(BA) andAT&T(T). Boeing shares are up +11.8% since November 8th
column26: outperforming the Zacks Aerospace sector (up +8.9%) on hopes of ramped up defense spending from the Trump administration.Thursday - 1/26/2017: On a busy reporting day with 37 index members coming out with Q4 results (24 in the morning & 13 after the market's close)
column27: we haveAlphabet(GOOGL)
column28: Intel(INTC) andMicrosoft(MSFT) reporting results after the close. Other notable reports today includeCaterpillar(CAT) andFord(F) in the morning andStarbucks(SBUX) after the close.Estimates for Microsoft have gone up ahead of the earnings release and the stock has outperformed the broader Tech sector (up +21.5%) and Alphabet (up +13.4%) by gaining +23.4% over the past year. Starbucks has been a notable laggard over the past year
column29: with the stock modestly in negative territory over that time period
column30: though it has turned around a bit since early November.Friday - 1/27/2017:Chevron(CVX) andAmerican Airlines(AAL) are the notable reports today
column31: both in the morning.Q4 Expectations As a WholeFor Q4 as a whole
column32: total earnings for the S&P 500 companies are expected to be up +4.8% from the same period last year on +3.7% higher revenues. This would follow the +3.8% growth in Q3 earnings on +2.3% higher revenues
column33: the first instance of positive earnings growth for the index after five quarters of back-to-back declines. Comparisons for the Energy sector
column34: a big driver of the earnings recession
column35: turn positive in Q4
column36: with the sector's earnings growth turning positive for the first time after 8 quarters of declines.The chart below shows the Q3 earnings growth contrasted with declines in the preceding 5 quarters. As you can see in the chart below
column37: the growth pace is expected to ramp up in 2017.The table below shows the summary picture Q4 contrasted with what was actually achieved in the preceding quarter.Note: Sheraz Mian heads the Zacks Equity Research department and is a well-regarded expert of aggregate earnings. He is frequently quoted in the print and electronic media and publishes the weeklyEarnings Trendsand Earnings Preview reports. column1: Square Inc (SQ) Stock Needs to Make Some Money;1/20/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsSquare Inc.(NYSE:SQ) has never been a money-making proposition. Like many tech companies
column3: net income has not been their thing
column4: man.Growthhas been their thing. Revenues rose from $552 million in 2013 to $1.267 billion two years later
column5: and that record will likely be beaten when the company next reports on Jan. 31.makeArticleAd();Source:Chris Harrison via Flickr (Modified)Analysts are expecting$451 million in revenue for the quarter
column6: or $1.307 billion for the year. The whisper on losses
column7: 8 cents per share
column8: would bring total losses for the year to 46 cents. Square survives on hope and cash flow
column9: which was slightly positive in 2015 and the third quarter of 2016. Its growth is slowing noticeably.But what if
column10: just for fun
column11: Square did something wild
column12: crazy
column13: and in-line with what the rest of the payments industry does
column14: and made a little money for shareholders?The stock would take off. It would take off bigly.How Square Stock Might Make MoneySquare is not going to make a net profit as a processor. It's not going to bypass exchange fees. Instead it's going to become profitable as a platform
column15: with a host of financial products attractive to its small business base.The 7 Best High-Yield Investments for RetirementAs our James Brumley wrote this weekthese include Square Capital
column16: whose loans havedoubled over the last year. Square is also offeringpayroll services
column17: inventory management and analyticsto its small business customers.This hope has sent SQ stock up 56% in the last six months
column18: which sounds great until you take the chart out a few months
column19: and see that stock hit another peak in April
column21: which took it higher than the present price of $14.90. At that point
column22: speculation on brighter days had pushed it to $15.13.Who Wants SQ Stock?Partly for that reason
column23: our Tom Taulli has another reason to buy Square stock.As takeout bait.Square has a powerful brand (at least within its niche)
column24: it's big in mobile
column25: and there are a lot of big tech companies that aren't in payments yet but might like a play there
column26: likeMicrosoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT).That's interesting
column27: but if SQ stock were going to be taken out
column28: the buyer would not likely come from that quarter. Processing is something a tech company can do for itself
column29: if it's interested in that low-margin business. There are easier ways to make money.It's more likely the buyer would come from the payments mainstream - processors likeFirst Data Corp(NYSE:FDC)
column30: PayPal Holdings Inc(NASDAQ:PYPL) andVantiv Inc(NASDAQ:VNTV). These companies understand just how complex processing merchant payments are
column31: and what the capacity is worth. Wait a few years and maybe some banking organizations likeJP Morgan Chase & Co.(NYSE:JPM) orCapital One Financial Corp.(NYSE:COF) might come calling.A move by any of these players could set off a feeding frenzy in the industry
column32: one that would deliver shareholders a premium well over its current $5.3 billion price.That may be why a processor isn't making such a move. SQ stock is already bigger
column33: by market cap
column34: thanNCR Corporation(NYSE:NCR)
column35: which has been around since the 19th century.The ancillary businesses may also be unattractive. It's hard enough just processing payments.A winning premium would also make Square unaffordable for a merchant processor outfit like Vantiv
column36: worth $12.3 billion
column37: and make the merchants payment outfit vulnerable to takeover by one of the banks that distribute cards and serve the customer side of the transaction. MaybeIntuit Inc.(NASDAQ:INTU) orAmerican Express Company(NYSE:AXP) might be interested in upsetting the apple cart in that way
column38: but again you're talking about a less-profitable operation and
column39: in the case of Intuit (worth $30.1 billion)
column40: a deal that could soak up a lot of its market cap.A SpeculationThere are many companies that could make a move on SQ stock
column41: setting off a frenzy of merger activity in the payments space akin to what everyone keeps expecting will happen in media after Sumner Redstone dies and the sharks come forViacom
column42: Inc.(NASDAQ:VIAB).Is the Groupon Inc (GRPN) Comeback Done for Good?But waiting for such a frenzy
column43: betting on it with your money
column44: is speculation. Square today is still a money-losing proposition in an industry where losing money is uncommon
column45: and a company whose growth is slowing rapidly.Go for it if you wish
column46: but don't hock the silver. This is a mad money play.Dana Blankenhornis a financial and technology journalist. He is the author of the sci-fi novellaInto the Cloud
column47: available at the Amazon Kindle store. Write him atdanablankenhorn@gmail.comor follow him on Twitter at@danablankenhorn. As of this writing he owned shares in AMZN
column48: AAPL
column49: MSFT and GOOGL.More From InvestorPlace3 Grossly Overpriced Tech Stocks That Could Collapse7 Stocks to Sell Before They ImplodeThe postSquare Inc (SQ) Stock Needs to Make Some Moneyappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Donald Trump Inauguration: Stocks To Buy
column2: Sell For The Next Four Years;1/20/2017;"Donald Trump (Shutterstock photo)Donald Trump has been sworn in as the 45th president of the United States. The President-elect
column3: who pledged to “Make America great again
column4: ” promised plenty of things he would do regarding his first day in office. From repealing and replacing Obamacare to renegotiating NAFTA and beginning the construction of the wall on the Mexican border.We won’t know for certain which of Trump’s policies will take priority or how they will be enforced. But what we do know is that for Trump to make good on his promises to bring back jobs
column5: grow GDP and strengthen industry
column6: he needs businesses to lead
column7: innovate and hire workers. For that to happen
column8: businesses leaders need to know their government is on their side. To that end
column9: here are some names to own for the next four years (at least) as Trump’s policies take shape.makeArticleAd();Lower Corporate TaxesTrump’s promise to lower corporate taxes can have a boosting effect on the tech sector
column10: which has an estimated $1.4 trillion stashed in overseas tax havens. These include some America's largest corporations such as Apple (AAPL) and Microsoft (MSFT)
column11: which could face a huge tax hit if they bring that cash home. Not only has Trump promised to lower the business tax rate from 35% to 15%
column12: he pledged to eliminate the corporate alternative minimum tax.Beyond lowering the tax rate
column13: it would hardly shock anyone if Trump — given his pro-business stance — were to enact a tax holiday at some point during his presidency. Companies like Cisco (CSCO)
column14: Facebook (FB) and Alphabet (GOOGL) would thrive. They would no longer need to borrow cheap cash to fund their operations. Likewise
column15: a better capitalized Tesla (TSLA) can accelerate the building of its Gigafactory
column16: helping it achieve not only higher profit margins
column17: but also higher vehicle production. In the process
column18: Tesla would ignite the state of Nevada as an innovative hub
column19: while mass-producing producing emission-free vehicles at affordable prices.“Repeal and Replace”The Affordable Care Act
column20: a.k.a Obamacare was designed to — among other things — “insure the un-insurable.” Notably
column21: to provide insurance coverage to people with pre-existing conditions who were blocked under the then-existing rules. Depending on what side of the aisle you’re on
column22: Obamacare either did its job or was a “complete disaster
column23: ” according to Trump. Still
column24: whether Obamacare is entirely dismantled or parts of it is kept
column25: you don’t have to look too far beyond UnitedHealth (UNH) to find a stock can will thrive.UnitedHealth has worked aggressively to exit the Affordable Care exchanges
column26: which reduces its  exposure to any changes Trump might make. What’s more
column27: added from being the nation's largest health insurer
column28: UnitedHealth owns Optum
column29: which provides pharmacy benefit management services. Last week
column30: not only did the company beat top- and bottom-line estimates
column31: UnitedHealth raised its fiscal 2017 financial outlook
column32: suggesting it is ready for whatever Trump decides to do.Not every company will be as lucky. Conversely
column33: companies such HCA Holdings (HCA) and Universal Health Services (UHS) that prospered under Obamacare may suffer. As will government health care providers such as Centene Corporation (CNC) and Molina Healthcare
column34: Inc. (MOH).Scale Back Dodd-FrankCutting down strict regulations imposed on financial institutions has been another policy Trump has proposed. After all
column35: how can he achieve economic growth and strengthen small business if banks aren't lending money — something banks collectively struggled to do under Dodd-Frank. But as evidenced by the strong earnings results released so far from the likes of Bank of America (BAC)
column36: JPMorgan Chase (JPM)
column37: Citigroup (C) and Goldman Sachs (GS)
column38: financials are once again the sector to bank on.Written to strengthen consumer protection and create tougher rules on excessive risk-taking
column39: the 2010 Dodd-Frank Act has been cited by bank executives as a prohibiter of growth. ""There's many aspects of it that we've got to kill
column40: said Steven Mnuchin
column41: Trump's pick for Treasury secretary. Mnuchin former partner at Goldman Sachs
column42: called Dodd-Frank ""the number one priority on the regulatory side.”To that end
column43: I would be surprised if Trump doesn’t take to “repeal and replace” Dodd-Frank in his first 100 days in office. Combined with the prospect of higher interest rates
column44: lower taxes it’s tough to ignore the potential upside a bank like Morgan Stanley (MS) can provide. It’s not just the big banks that will prosper
column45: however. Keep an eye on super regionals like Comerica (CMA)
column46: US Bancorp (USB) and PNC Financial (PNC)
column47: which Trump has made great again."

column1: Apple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Can’t Please Everybody;1/20/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace   - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading TipsI have to admit straight off the bat that I'm not too fond of writing aboutApple Inc. (NASDAQ:AAPL). For starters
column3: everyone - and I do meaneveryone- has an opinion on Apple stock.Source: AppleEven those that may be uninterested in the markets
column4: or consumers who prefer products fromSamsung Electronic(OTCMKTS:SSNLF) orSony Corp (ADR)(NYSE:SNE)
column5: still seem to throw in their two cents. That's the power of the Apple brand.makeAd('4'
column7: 'mktsnews'
column8: 'vanguard'
column10: '');I'm not complaining. Although I have a financial interest in SNE stock
column11: and have owned Samsung smartphones in the past
column12: Apple products are better. Its ecosystem is seamlessly connected
column13: and its interface is intuitive. Best of all
column14: the company has an uncanny ability to provide solutions for which you have yet to realize is a problem. And no - finding a good-looking
column15: untucked dress shirt isnot a real problem!The central issue I have with Apple stock is that investors may be too emotionally vested. If there's any advice I can give
column16: it's that business is all about the numbers. Holding any other view could lead you down a dangerous path.Positive Factors Buoying Apple StockAdmittedly
column17: Apple stock doesn't make market agnosticism easy. The heart of the organization of course is the iPhone. Last Friday
column18: rumors circulated that the upcoming iPhone 8 will featurebetter water resistancethan its predecessor. The improvement could potentially allow the ""8"" to survive immersion greater than one meter deep. Whether the safety feature is actually useful or not
column19: it's agreat marketing tool. Samsung initiated their waterproof model with their Galaxy GS4 Active to critical acclaim.7 Stocks to Sell Before They ImplodeOf course
column20: there's much more to Apple's flagship product than making it accident proof. According toInvestorPlace writer Tom Taulli
column21: there are already ""indications that the device will be standout
column22: such as with OLED (organic light emitting diodes) screens
column23: which will be thinner and perhaps even allow for bending. Interestingly enough
column24: there may not even be a bezel
column25: which will not only make the device look sleeker - one of Apple's hallmarks - but allow more room on the screen.""We also must consider the Apple stock price in comparative value against the broader consumer technology industry. As Taulli notes
column26: ""AAPL stock still sports a reasonable valuation
column27: with the forward price-to-earnings ratio of 11.5X. Hey
column28: Microsoft Corporation(NASDAQ:MSFT) is at 19X andOracle Corporation(NYSE:ORCL) is trading at 14X.""To go along with this analysis
column29: you have to appreciate the creative synergy that drives Apple stock. Despite roadblocks like theSupreme Court decisionthat has serious implications for intellectual property rights
column30: AAPL
column31: and by extension
column32: AAPL stock keeps on chugging. I don't doubt for a second that they'll continue asserting themselves in the retail market. They're too much of avaluable entityfor any other course of action.Weaknesses in Apple's ArmorYet it's in the financial markets where Apple stock loses some sheen. AsInvestor's Business Dailywryly notes
column33: in the same year that AAPL ""opens an edifice to its greatness - a massive new headquarters that looks like a flying saucer - the company faces growing questions about its future and whether it can still surprise and delight customers with exciting new gadgets."" Furthermore
column34: expectations are ""sky-high that 2017's 10th anniversary iPhone will be something special that unleashes the full potential of the Apple revenue-generating ecosystem.""No one questions that AAPL stock is backed by a solid team carrying out founder Steve Jobs' grand vision. Nevertheless
column35: that's a lot of pressure riding on the company. It's a well-known fact that a majority of AAPL's sales and profits comes from the iPhone. In fact
column36: we are starting to see some kinks in the vaunted armor.Again
column37: Investor's Business Dailywrites that iPhone ""sales declined last year for the first time ever
column38: during the iPhone 6S cycle. They could fall again this year
column39: during the iPhone 7 cycle. In fiscal 2016
column40: iPhone unit sales declined 8%
column41: while iPhone revenue shrank 12%.""Furthermore
column42: there's an overreliance on its smartphone division that could come back to haunt them. A glaring example is the fact that Apple hasn't done much of anything with its premium line of Mac computers. Sure
column43: that industry is in decline
column44: but Apple has always been chic-cool. If it's abandoning Macs in favor of portable e-devices
column45: it's going to be in a dogfight with discount-price leaders.And if it can't protect its designs as the Supreme Court decision implies
column46: that just makes Apple's job all the more difficult. Hence
column47: it either needs to kill it with its new iPhones or it needs other products for diversification.Technical Challenges AheadClick to EnlargeThis is where we get into a real tough decision. My heart tells me that AAPL is going to be just fine - and there's good reason to believe that.But Apple stock really hasn't shown that much confidence. Yeah
column48: it's soared from last summer
column49: but that's what rallies from yearly lows are supposed to do. What happens next is the critical question.In 2015
column50: Apple stock took multiple bites at $130
column51: only to be rebuffed. It then faltered
column52: and only began to pick itself up just recently. Now
column53: it's heading toward another crack at the psychological price target. Is the fifth time the charm? I'm sure AAPL stock is good for another 8% or 9% - enough to get real close to $130.Abandon General Electric Company (GE) Stock     After Q4 EarningsBut to actually breach that level and build something substantive on top of it? That's where I have my doubts about Apple stock. What AAPL does
column54: no one does better. But after so many years following the release of the first smart devices
column55: the consumer is expecting much more. Apple will deliver
column56: but what it does may not be so exciting for Wall Street.As of this writing
column57: Josh Enomoto was long SNE stock.More From InvestorPlaceThe Most Dangerous Dividend Stocks for 20173 Vanguard Funds That Are Taking on WaterThe postApple Inc. (AAPL) Stock Can't Please Everybodyappeared first onInvestorPlace."

column1: Apple Inc. New iPads Might Be Late to the Party (AAPL);1/20/2017;"InvestorPlaceInvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column2: Stock Advice & Trading     TipsIt's a pretty safe bet at this point thatApple Inc.(NASDAQ:AAPL) is releasing new iPads in 2017. Rumors had been pointing to a   March special event for AAPL to take the wraps off its latest   tablets
column3: including the iPad Air 3 and two new iPad Pro   models.However
column4: a newly released report - based on information from   Apple's supply chain - suggests the launch may be pushed to the   second half of 2017.makeArticleAd();New iPads Delayed9to5Macreported on aDigitimesstory based on sources from within Apple's supply chain. These   sources claim that the new iPads are still in the planning stage
column5: and may not be released or even announceduntil the second half of 2017.Many Apple watchers expected a Marchspecial event announcing the new iPads(the 9.7-inch iPad Pro was unveiled at a March 2016 event)
column6: but that timeframe now seems in doubt. Summer product   announcements are practically unheard of. Everyone is in vacation   mode and not paying close attention to what tech companies are   doing. That makes a fall announcement and release the most likely   option if spring falls through.MacRumorselaborated on potential causes for the delay
column7: besides the generic   ""being stuck in the design phase"" description. The site points to   speculation that the new A10X processor
column8: which would power the   new iPad Pro models
column9: is running into manufacturing challenges.   Reports since December have said the chips aresuffering from lower than expected yield   rates.3 Things Apple Inc. (AAPL) MUST Do to Soar in       2017If so
column10: this wouldn't be the first time pushing the boundaries   of technology has tripped up Apple
column11: or other consumer tech   companies.Fitbit Inc(NYSE:FIT) andGoPro Inc(NASDAQ:GPRO) both faced retail shortages of new products prior to Christmasdue to production issues.What to Expect: New iPad Pro Models and iPad Air 3While nothing is certain when trying to anticipate AAPL's   moves
column12: the expectation of what the company will release in terms   of new iPads is beginning to firm up.The consensus among Apple watchers and analysts is leaning   toward a second generation
column13: 12.9-inch iPad Pro
column14: powered by the   A10X chip. This is AAPL's flagship tablet
column15: competing against the   likes ofMicrosoft Corporation's(NASDAQ:MSFT) Surface Pro 4. Apple will want to keep its momentum in the   professional/enterprise tablet space.An all-new iPad Pro model in the form of a 10.5-inch
column16: bezel-free device that's a more business-friendly size than the   current 9.7-inch iPad Pro likely will make its debut.As for the 9.7-inch form factor
column17: that's up in the air. It's   too small for many business users
column18: so there's a good chance Apple   will drop the ""Pro"" designation. Instead
column19: it would become the new   low-cost midsize tablet in the Apple lineup
column20: repackaged as the   iPad Air 3.Experts also expect a new version of the Apple Pencil stylus   to be in the mix.If theDigitimesreport is correct and AAPL is forced to push the release of new   iPads to the second half of the year
column21: the company could have a   very crowded calendar come fall.Apple Inc. (AAPL) Faces New Challenges for       the iPhone 8The 10th anniversary iPhone 8 is a given for September. There   are rumors that anApple Watch Series 3could accompany the new iPhone on stage. Analysts are calling for   a refreshed MacBook Pro with new Kaby Lake CPUs fromIntel Corporation(NASDAQ:INTC) to go into production in the third quarter. The Apple TV is   also overdue for a refresh
column22: and fall is typically when it gets   featured.That may make for a quiet spring for Apple.Updated iMacs and MacBooks might give it something to show   off. But going into the holiday shopping season
column23: AAPL would have   a killer lineup of new products
column24: including that all-important   iPhone 8
column25: plus long-awaited new iPads.As of this writing
column26: Brad Moon did not hold a position     in any of the aforementioned securities.More From InvestorPlaceMicrosoft Corporation (MSFT) Steps on Amazon       and Google's Turf7 Stocks to Sell Before They Implode10 Stocks to Buy for Donald Trump's Second       WindThe postApple Inc. New iPads Might Be Late to the Party   (AAPL)appeared first onInvestorPlace."

The infrastructure required for this most important   resource will be massive here in the U.S. as well as across the   globe in both developed and emerging markets.The ETF should benefit from Trump's infrastructure build here   in the U.S. We do not currently own this ETF but we have in   the past

column41: Treasury inflation protected   securities (TIPS) tend to perform better than regular bonds given   their yield plus inflation construct - the principal rises with   inflation
column42: as measured by the consumer price index
column43: while the   yield is fixed.This ETF also uses a short duration
column44: currently 2.4 years
column45: as   added protection against rising rates. It yields 0.89%.Henry Ma is president and chief investment officer     at Julex Capital Management
column46: an SEC-registered     quantitative investment management firm based in Boston. The     firm's tactical unconstrained investment solutions aim to limit     downside risks while maximizing upside potential; total client     assets as of September 2016: $358 million.As we enter 2017
column47: we may be witnessing major shifts of   economic policies
column48: which could have significant impacts on   financial markets. The new year is likely to see a continuing   rise of protectionism
column49: which is evidenced notably in the Brexit   referendum and the U.S. presidential election.This trend could undermine global growth
column50: but there will be   winners and losers. The export-dependent sectors have the most to   lose.After eight years of monetary stimulus
column51: policymakers among the   developed countries have realized that loose monetary policies   are no longer effective and fiscal policies are needed to spur   economic growth. In the U.S.
column52: President-elect Donald Trump has   pledged to reduce taxes and spend $1 trillion on   infrastructure.These potential fiscal expansion programs have   improved growth prospects
column53: fueling higher inflation   expectations
column54: pushing bond yields upward
column55: and causing losses for   bond holders. We will see more rotation from bonds to equities in   this reflationary environment. Within the equity markets
column56: the   yield-seeking trade has run its course as investors rotate from   high-yielding sectors to growth sectors. We expect these two   rotation trades to continue
column57: and recommend three ETFs that could   outperform in 2017.Financial Select Sector SPDR(XLF) provides the most liquid and low-cost cap-weighted     exposure to the financial sector of the S&P 500.The Fed is likely to raise interest rates to 1.25%-1.50% at   the end of 2017. This higher rate will certainly boost the profit   margin for financial stocks. The potential appeal or revision of   financial regulations such as Dodd-Frank by the Trump   administration will also help improve their profitability and   earnings growth.Technology Select Sector SPDR(XLK) provides the most liquid and low-cost cap-weighted     exposure to the technology sector of the S&P 500.As we expect the U.S. economy to grow above 3% in 2017
column58: the   tech sector will benefit from increasing demand and higher   revenue growth. The valuation is still attractive as the sector   is traded at a slightly lower forward PE ratio than the S&P   500 index.IShares Russell 2000(IWM) provides the most liquid and low-cost cap-weighted     exposure to the small-cap sector.Potentially protectionist trade policies and fiscal expansion   programs will generate more domestic demand for small companies'   products. The trailing PE ratio of IWM is 21.4
column59: which is close to   the PE ratio of the S&P 500 Index (20.4). Better growth   prospects will provide small-cap stocks with more upside   potential.(Editor's note: These ETFs are currently owned/were recently   owned by Julex Capital strategies and could be purchased at any   time within their client portfolios.)RELATED:High Yield Strategy Uses 10 ETFs To Deliver     All-Weather Income With Low Risks6 Best ETFs For When You're Both Bullish And     Cautious About The Markets"

column1: Why Microsoft Stock Gained 12% in 2016;1/19/2017;"Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella. Image source: Microsoft.What happenedShares of software giantMicrosoft(NASDAQ: MSFT) rose 12% in 2016
column2: according to data provided byS&P Global Market Intelligence. While Microsoft made plenty of news last year
column3: including the   blockbuster acquisition of LinkedIn
column4: the rapid growth of its   cloud business seems to be the main thing driving the stock   higher.So whatMicrosoft reported mostly positive results throughout 2016
column5: consistently beating analyst estimates for revenue thanks to the   growing cloud business. Nearly all of the stock's gains occurred   following the company's fiscal fourth-quarter report in July
column6: which easily beat analyst estimates for both revenue and   earnings.makeArticleAd();MSFTdata byYCharts.During the fourth quarter
column7: revenue from Azure
column8: Microsoft's   cloud computing platform
column9: surged 102% year over year
column10: with usage   more than doubling. Microsoft has yet to disclose exactly how   much revenue Azure produces
column11: but the company is recognized as a   strong No. 2 player in the cloud infrastructure market.Other cloud-based products grew quickly as well. Office 365   commercial revenue soared 54% year over year
column12: and Office 365   consumer increased its subscriber count to 23.1 million. Dynamics   CRM Online
column13: the subscription version of Microsoft's customer   relationship management product
column14: grew paid seats by a factor of   2.5 compared to the prior-year period.All of these cloud businesses continued to grow quickly during   the fiscal first quarter
column15: with Azure revenue surging 116%
column16: Office   365 commercial revenue jumping 51%
column17: and Office 365 consumer   adding another 900
column18: 000 subscribers. While total revenue and   earnings growth was sluggish
column19: Microsoft CFO Amy Hood emphasized   that the company was investing and positioning itself for   long-term growth.Now whatUnder CEO Satya Nadella
column20: Microsoft has made good progress   transitioning from a PC-centric company to one focused on the   cloud. Investors clearly liked what they saw in 2016
column21: pushing   shares of Microsoft to their highest level since the dot-com boom   more than 15 years ago.There's still plenty of work to do
column22: however. In June
column23: Microsoft chairman John Thompson questioned whether the company   was moving fast enough
column24: worried that the traditional software   business could disappear in the matter of just a few years.Investor confidence in Microsoft's strategy grew in 2016 along   with the stock price. But for the stock to continue on its upward   path in 2017 and beyond
column25: Microsoft will need to replace legacy   software revenue with cloud revenue fast enough to stave off a   significant sales decline. A failure to move quickly enough could   undo last year's gains.10 stocks we like better than MicrosoftWhen investing geniuses David and Tom Gardner have a stock tip
column26: it can pay to listen. After all
column27: the newsletter they have run     for over a decade
column28: Motley Fool Stock Advisor
column29: has tripled the market.*David and Tom just revealed what they believe are the10 best stocksfor investors to buy right now... and Microsoft wasn't one of     them! That's right -- they think these 10 stocks are even     better buys.Click hereto learn about these picks!*Stock Advisor returns as of January 4
